passage_content: וארא אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד'. דקדקו המפורשים מ"ט התחיל הכתוב בשם אלקים מדה"ד ובלשון דיבור קשה, וסיים ויאמר אליו אני ד' שם של רחמים ואמירה לשון רכה, ורש"י ז"ל פי' דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למה הרעותה וגו' ויאמר אליו אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו' וצ"ב דלפי"ז המה ב' דברות סמוכים זל"ז , וה"ז מקרא קצר ולא נתבאר כוונת הדיבור והקישור בין שניהם, ובמד"ר (פ' ו' סי' א') נתבאר יותר לפי שאמר למה הרעותה וגו' על דבר זה בקשה מדה"ד לפגוע במשה הה"ד וידבר אלקים אל משה, ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צער ישראל דבר כן חזר ונהג עמו במדת הרחמים, הה"ד ויאמר אליו אני ד' עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דהלא הבוי"ת מסתכל בסוף דבר בקדמותו, ומעיקרא ידע דבשביל צערן של ישראל דיבר כך, ומהו זה שאמרו חזר ונהג עמו במדת הרחמים, ולא שייך חזרה לפניו ית '.
translation: And God appeared to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." The commentators have noted that the verse begins with the name of God, which denotes strict judgment, and in a harsh manner of speech, and concludes with "I am the Lord," which is a name of mercy and a gentle expression. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that He spoke with him in judgment for having harshly questioned, "Why have You done evil to Your people?" and He said to him, "I am the Lord," faithful to reward good, etc. It is puzzling that according to this, these are two statements that are close to each other, and it is a brief verse that does not clarify the intent of the speech and the connection between them. In the Midrash (Parashat Va'eira, section 1), it is explained further, for it says, "Why have You done evil to Your people?" Regarding this, He requested strict judgment to strike at Moses, as it is written, "And God spoke to Moses." And since the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that because of the suffering of Israel, He spoke this way, He returned and acted with him in the attribute of mercy, as it is written, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord.'" Thus far the Midrash. It is puzzling, however, that the Holy One, blessed be He, looks at the end of a matter from its beginning, and initially knew that because of the suffering of Israel, He spoke this way. What does it mean that they said He returned and acted with him in the attribute of mercy, when it is not fitting to speak of a return before Him, blessed be He?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the transition from God's harshness, represented by the name "Elokim," to His mercy, indicated by the name "Hashem." The text highlights the tension between divine justice and compassion, particularly in response to Moses' complaints about the suffering of the Israelites. The Midrash explains that God, recognizing the pain of His people, chose to respond to Moses with mercy rather than strict judgment. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of God's willingness to engage with human suffering and the importance of divine compassion in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ב) דרשו במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' ב') ר"י ב"ר חנינא אמר אלקים על המצרים: אני ד' על ישראל, ופי' היפ"ת אלקים על המצרים שיבוא בדין עליהם. אני ד' על ישראל לרחם עליהם כנגד מה שהרעו להם לישראל, וצ"ב דמצריים מאן דכר שמי', ולפי פשוטו נאמר דיבור זה למשה, גם לפי"ז אין לו קישור לא לפרשה של מעלה למה הרעותה וגו' ולא לפרשה שלאחרי '.
translation: B) It is expounded in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 2) that Rabbi Yochanan ben Chaninah said: God said regarding the Egyptians: "I am the Lord" concerning Israel, and the interpretation is that God will come to judgment against the Egyptians. "I am the Lord" concerning Israel to have mercy on them, in contrast to the evil they did to Israel. And it is puzzling why Egypt is mentioned here, and simply put, this statement was said to Moses. Even according to this, it has no connection to the preceding section regarding why they afflicted them, nor to the section that follows.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the relationship between God and the Israelites in contrast to the Egyptians. It highlights that while God is depicted as a judge against the Egyptians for their oppression, He is also a compassionate protector of the Israelites. The text raises questions about the relevance of the Egyptians in this context and suggests that the message is directed to Moses, emphasizing the divine concern for Israel amidst their suffering. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine justice and mercy, illustrating God's dual role as both a judge and a savior.

passage_content: ג) איתא (רמז קע"ו) וידבר אלקים אל משה וגו' זש"ה (תהלים נ') שמעה עמי ואדברה ישראל ואעידה בך אלקים אלקיך אנכי, א"ר פנחס הכהן בר חמא אמר הקב"ה למשה בשביל שקראתי אותך אלקים שנא' ראה נתתיך אלקים לפרעה, אלקיך אני ולכך נאמר וידבר אלקים אל משה עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב .
translation: 3) It is stated (Remez 196) "And God spoke to Moses, etc." This is as it is written (Psalms 50) "Hear, O My people, and I will speak; O Israel, and I will testify against you: I am God, your God." Rabbi Pinchas the priest, son of Chama, said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Because I have called you God," as it is stated, "See, I have made you God to Pharaoh." "I am your God," and therefore it is said, "And God spoke to Moses." Thus far the Midrash, and it requires further explanation.
summary: The passage discusses the divine communication between God and Moses, emphasizing the unique relationship where God refers to Moses as "elohim" (god) to Pharaoh. This designation highlights Moses' elevated status and role as a mediator between God and the Israelites. The reference to God speaking to Moses underscores the importance of divine revelation and the responsibility that comes with such a calling. The text reflects key Hasidic themes of divine connection and the transformative power of spiritual leadership.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם מ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה בפ ' שמות לפרש דברי הילקו"ש בשלח (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה, חמה כתיב שנתמלא עליהם הים חמה להטביען וכו ', מיד אותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים, הה"ד וישבו המים ששבו מישראל על מצרים, ולכאורה תמוה וכי יעביד קוב"ה דינא בלא דינא ח"ו, דחימה של ישראל יהי' על מצרים, הלא די להם בשלהם וק"ל אמונה ואין עול, אבל יובן כפשוטו עפי"ד המדרש שטען שר של מצרים מה נשתנו אלו מאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו עובדי ע"ז, והשיב ית ' וכי לדעתם עבדוה, והלא לא עבדוה אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף הדעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון וכו ', וידוע מ"ש השלה"ק וירעו אותנו המצרים וגו' שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, ועפי"ז יבוא על נכון המדרש הנ"ל, דאותה חמה החזיר על המצריים, כי הם הגורמים וישראל אנוסים עכת"ד הק ', ולכאורה עדיין ראוי להבין למה הי' הצורך להשתמש בחימה של ישראל, וכי לא הי' מספיק בשלהם, ובל"ס ראויים היו המצרים למדת עונשם גם בשביל עוונותם שעבדו ע"ז ועוד הרבה רעות שעשו.
translation: And it will be explained in advance what is mentioned in K'z, the holy name of the blessed memory, in Parashat Shemot, to clarify the words of the Midrash in Beshalach (Remez 274) that "the waters were a wall for them," it is written that the sea was filled with heat to drown them, etc. Immediately, that heat which was filled against Israel was returned upon Egypt, as it is said, "And the waters returned and covered the Egyptians." And at first glance, it is puzzling: how could the Holy One, blessed be He, execute judgment without judgment, Heaven forbid, that the heat of Israel should be upon Egypt? Surely it is enough for them with their own, and it is clear that there is faith and no oppression. But it can be understood simply according to the explanation of the Midrash, which argued that the minister of Egypt asked, "What is the difference between these and those? These are idol worshippers, and those are idol worshippers." And He answered, "Did they serve according to their knowledge? They did not serve except out of servitude and out of madness. And you judge the negligent as if they were intentional and the coerced as if they were willing," etc. And it is known what the holy Shelah wrote, "And the Egyptians made us evil and sinful," and according to this, the aforementioned Midrash will come to its proper understanding, that the same heat returned upon the Egyptians, for they are the cause, and Israel are coerced, thus far the holy text. And at first glance, it is still necessary to understand why there was a need to use the heat of Israel, and was it not enough with their own? Nevertheless, the Egyptians were deserving of their measure of punishment also for their sins of idol worship and many other evils they committed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice as it relates to the Israelites and Egyptians during the Exodus. It highlights that the anger directed at the Egyptians was a reflection of the Israelites' suffering, suggesting that their oppression led to a divine response. The text emphasizes that the Egyptians were judged for their actions, which were driven by idolatry and madness, while the Israelites were seen as victims of circumstance. Ultimately, it raises questions about the necessity of using the Israelites' anger in the divine judgment against the Egyptians, indicating a complex interplay of justice and mercy in God's actions.

passage_content: ואפשר לתרץ עפימ"ש במתני' (סוטה דף כ' ע"א) יש זכות תולה ב' שנים. יש זכות תולה ג' שנים, ובגמ' שם רצו ללמדה מפסוק דכתיב גבי אדום (עמוס א') כה אמר ד' על שלשה פשעי אדום וגו', ומסיק דאין ראי' לדבר אלא זכר לדבר, דדלמא שאני עכו"ם דלא מפקיד דינא עלייהו עכ"ד הגמ ' ופרש"י אין ממהרין מן השמים לפקוד עונותם עליהם בעוה"ז, אבל מישראל ממהרין ליפרע בעוה"ז ומדקדקין אחריהם, ובזה יבואר דברי מדרש הנ"ל דאותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים אע"פ שגם הם עבדו ע"ז וראויים היו לעונש, אבל עכו"ם לא מפקד דינא עלייהו ואין ממהרין להפרע מהם מידת ענשם, ואפשר הטעם כדי שיקבלו מדת שכרם עבור הטוב המגיע להם, וכשנתמלא סאתם הקב"ה פורע מהם, אבל לפי שהי' שליטת הדין והחימה על ישראל, והמצריים היו הגורמים ומחטיאים אותם, ע"כ נמדד להם במדתם של ישראל שמדה"ד ממהרת להפרע מהם ומדקדקין אחריהם כפרש"י ז"ל.
translation: And it is possible to explain according to what is stated in the Mishnah (Sotah 20a) that there is a merit that suspends for two years. There is a merit that suspends for three years, and in the Gemara there, they wanted to learn it from the verse written regarding Edom (Amos 1): "Thus says the Lord: For three transgressions of Edom..." and it concludes that there is no proof for this matter, only a reminder of the matter, for perhaps it is different with idolaters who do not have judgment imposed upon them, thus says the Gemara. And Rashi explains that the heavens do not hasten to punish their sins upon them in this world, but with Israel, they hasten to exact punishment in this world and scrutinize them closely. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash that the wrath that was kindled against Israel was returned upon Egypt, even though they also served idols and were deserving of punishment. However, the idolaters do not have judgment imposed upon them, and the measure of their punishment is not hastened against them. And perhaps the reason is so that they may receive their reward for the good that is due to them, and when their measure is full, the Holy One, blessed be He, exacts from them. But since the dominion of judgment and wrath was upon Israel, and the Egyptians were the cause and led them astray, therefore they were measured by the measure of Israel, that the judgment hastens to exact from them and scrutinizes them closely, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains.
summary: The passage discusses the differing divine judgments between Israel and the nations, emphasizing that while Israel is held to a stricter standard and faces quicker retribution for their sins, the nations are given more time to receive their rewards for good deeds. This reflects a theological insight into the nature of divine justice, where God's judgment is more immediate for the Jewish people due to their covenantal relationship. The text also highlights the idea that the suffering of Israel can be attributed to external influences, such as the Egyptians, who are seen as responsible for leading them astray, thus affecting the timing of divine retribution. Ultimately, it underscores the concept of divine mercy and justice, where the nations are allowed to accumulate merit before facing judgment.

passage_content: ומעתה יתבארו ב' המדרשים הנ"ל, ושניהם על קוטב א' נאמרו, והוא דבקשה מדת הדין לפגוע במשה על שהקשה לומר למה הרעותה , והגם שבשביל צערן של ישראל דבר כן, אבל לפי מידת גדלו וצדקתו הי' בזה פגם קצת ע"ד וסביביו נשערה מאוד, אולם לפי שהמצריים היו הגורמים לצערן של ישראל, והם אשר סובבו למדה"ד שיחול, ע"כ בדין הוא שאותו החימה ומדה"ד פגעה בהם במצרים, וזה לעומת זה נהג הקב"ה עם ישראל במדת הרחמים וז"ש במדרש אלקים על מצרים, אני ה' על ישראל, ומעתה א"ש קישור דרשתם ז"ל עה"פ וידבר אלקים אל משה.
translation: And from now on, the two aforementioned teachings will be clarified, and both were said regarding one pole, which is that the attribute of judgment sought to strike Moses for having questioned why He had caused harm, and although it was due to the suffering of Israel that he spoke this way, nonetheless, according to his greatness and righteousness, there was a slight flaw in this, as it was very much around him. However, since the Egyptians were the cause of Israel's suffering, and they were the ones who brought about the attribute of judgment to take effect, it is therefore just that that wrath and the attribute of judgment struck them in Egypt. Thus, in contrast, the Holy One, Blessed be He, dealt with Israel with the attribute of mercy, as it is said in the Midrash, "God concerning Egypt, I am the Lord concerning Israel." And from now on, I understand the connection of their teaching regarding the verse "And God spoke to Moses."
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine justice and mercy in relation to Moses' questioning of God's actions towards the suffering of the Israelites. It highlights that while Moses' inquiry stemmed from concern for Israel's plight, it nonetheless reflected a slight imperfection in his righteousness. In contrast, the Egyptians, who caused Israel's suffering, were justly punished by divine judgment. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that God operates with mercy towards Israel, as indicated in the Midrash, illustrating the balance between justice and compassion in divine governance.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר קישור הכתוב וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד', שנתעורר מדה"ד על משה בשביל שאמר למה הרעותה ומקושר לפרשה שלמעלה הימנו אלא בשביל שהמצרים גרמו לזה ע"י שציערו את ישראל, ע"כ חזר המדה"ד על המצריים ומדת הרחמים על ישראל, ובזה יתבאר דברי הילקוט הנ"ל אמר הקב"ה למשה בשביל שקראתי אותך אלהים שנא' ראה נתתיך אלהים לפרעה, ר"ל להמשיך מדת הדין על פרעה ועל מצרים, ע"כ אלקיך אני שנא' וידבר אלקים אל משה, ונתעורר מדה"ד על משה כדי להחזירו על ראש מצרים, שהם היו הגורמים להחטיאם ומגיע להם מדינא כנ"ל.
translation: And similarly, the connection of the verse will be explained: "And God spoke to Moses and said to him, I am the Lord," that the attribute of judgment was aroused against Moses because he said, "Why have You harmed this people?" and it is connected to the section above it. Rather, it was because the Egyptians caused this by oppressing Israel. Therefore, the attribute of judgment returned upon the Egyptians and the attribute of mercy upon Israel. And with this, the words of the aforementioned Yalkut will be clarified: God said to Moses, "Because I called you God," as it is said, "See, I have made you a god to Pharaoh," meaning to extend the attribute of judgment upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt. Therefore, "I am your God," as it is said, "And God spoke to Moses," and the attribute of judgment was aroused against Moses in order to return it upon the head of Egypt, for they were the ones who caused them to sin, and they deserve it according to the law, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between divine justice and mercy in the context of God's communication with Moses. It highlights that Moses faced divine judgment for questioning God's actions, which was linked to the suffering inflicted on the Israelites by the Egyptians. The text emphasizes that the Egyptians' oppression triggered God's judgment against them, while simultaneously invoking mercy for the Israelites. Ultimately, it illustrates the balance between justice and compassion in God's dealings with humanity, particularly in the context of leadership and responsibility.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה', פי' רש"י ז"ל דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למה הרעותה לעם הזה, לכאורה יש להפליא דהרי משה רבינו הי' מובחר היצורים ולגודל מדריגת קדושתו אין חקר והי"ל אימה ופחד ורעדה מהקב"ה יותר מכל הברואים שבעולם, ואיך דיבר מרע"ה לפני הקב"ה דברים קשים כאלה, ואף לפני מלך ב"ו לא יאות לומר כן ומכ"ש לפני ממ"ה הקב"ה, גם צ"ב הקישור בשאלתו למה זה שלחתני למ"ש למה הרעותה לעם הזה.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." Rashi explains that He spoke to him a judgment for having the audacity to speak and say, "Why have You harmed this people?" It is indeed astonishing, for our teacher Moses was the choicest of creations, and due to the greatness of his holiness, there is no limit, and he should have had awe, fear, and trembling before the Holy One, Blessed be He, more than all the creatures in the world. How then did Moses Rabbeinu speak such harsh words before the Holy One, Blessed be He? Even before a king of flesh and blood, it would not be appropriate to say such things, and certainly not before the King of Kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He. It is also puzzling the connection in his question, "Why have You sent me?" to the statement, "Why have You harmed this people?"
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the profound relationship between God and Moses, highlighting the paradox of Moses questioning God about the suffering of the Israelites. Despite Moses' elevated spiritual status and his fear of God, he expresses a deep concern for the people, raising the theological issue of divine justice and the role of a leader. This interaction underscores the Hasidic concept of the struggle between faith and doubt, illustrating that even the holiest individuals grapple with the complexities of God's actions in the world.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם מה שפירשתי (פ' לך עמוד של"ד) במאמה"כ במה אדע כי אירשנה וגו' פירש"י לא שאל לו אות על בשורת הזרע אבל על ירושת הארץ שאל לו אות ואמר לו במה אדע כי אירשנה , והקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל למה שאל אות בירושת הארץ ובנתינת זרע לא שאל אות עיי"ש תירוצו, עוד פי' רשיז"ל ד"א במה אדע לא שאל לו אות, אלא אמר לפניו הודיעני באיזה זכות יתקיימו בה, א"ל הקב"ה בזכות הקרבנות , ולכאורה קשה להעמיס זאת בלשון הכתוב במה אדע כי אירשנה . שמשמעותו מורה על הידיעה בעצם ההבטחה אם תתקיים ולא על הזכות במה יזכו, ופירשתי עפ"י המבואר בדברי חכז"ל בכ"מ כי א"י ניתן על תנאי אם ישמרו ישראל את התורה, כדאיתא במכילתא פ' יתרו (הובא בילקוט מלכים רמז ק"ע) ג' דברים נתנו על תנאי ארץ ישראל בית המקדש ומלכות בית דוד עיי"ש, והכתוב עומד וצווח ויתן להם ארצות גוים וגו' בעבור ישמרו חקיו וגו', ובזה יובן שעל בשורת הזרע לא שאל לו אות, מפני שההבטחה היתה מוחלטת ובלי תנאי, משא"כ בשורת הארץ הי' על תנאי אם ישמרו את התורה, ועד"ז היתה שאלתו אם יזכו לירושת הארץ ובאיזה זכות יזכו אלי', והשיב לו הקב"ה בזכות הקרבנות עיין שם בדברינו ביאור הענין באריכות, ולכאורה עדיין ראוי להבין מדוע שאל על ידיעת הזכות, ויספיק שיתפלל אל הקב"ה שיזכו בנ"י להרבות מצות ומע"ט ואז בודאי יזכו לירושת הארץ.
translation: And I would like to explain in advance what I interpreted (in Parashat Lech Lecha, page 34) regarding the verse "By what shall I know that I will inherit it?" Rashi explains that he did not ask for a sign regarding the good news of the seed, but rather he asked for a sign regarding the inheritance of the land, and he said to Him, "By what shall I know that I will inherit it?" The Ramban, of blessed memory, asked why he asked for a sign regarding the inheritance of the land, but did not ask for a sign regarding the giving of the seed; see there for his answer. Furthermore, Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that "By what shall I know" does not mean he asked for a sign, but rather he said before Him, "Make known to me by what merit they will be sustained in it." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "By the merit of the sacrifices." And at first glance, it is difficult to reconcile this with the language of the verse "By what shall I know that I will inherit it," as its meaning indicates knowledge of the very essence of the promise if it will be fulfilled, and not about the merit by which they will be worthy. I explained according to what is clarified in the words of our Sages, of blessed memory, everywhere that the Land of Israel is given conditionally, if Israel observes the Torah, as it is stated in the Mechilta, Parashat Yitro (brought in Yalkut Melachim, hint 490), "Three things were given conditionally: the Land of Israel, the Holy Temple, and the monarchy of the House of David," see there. And the verse stands and cries, "And He gave them the lands of the nations... so that they would keep His statutes..." and thus it can be understood that he did not ask for a sign regarding the good news of the seed, because the promise was absolute and unconditional, whereas the good news of the land was conditional upon their observance of the Torah. Similarly, his question was whether they would merit the inheritance of the land and by what merit they would be worthy of it, and the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, "By the merit of the sacrifices." See there for our elaboration on the matter at length. And at first glance, it is still appropriate to understand why he asked about knowing the merit, and it would suffice for him to pray to the Holy One, blessed be He, that the children of Israel should increase in commandments and good deeds, and then they would certainly merit the inheritance of the land.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Abraham's inquiry about the inheritance of the land of Israel, contrasting it with the unconditional promise of offspring. The question of the land's inheritance is framed as conditional upon the Israelites' adherence to the Torah, as indicated by traditional sources. The response from God highlights the importance of sacrifices as a means to secure this inheritance, emphasizing the theological concept that the land is granted on the condition of fulfilling divine commandments. The passage ultimately reflects on the necessity of understanding the basis for receiving God's promises and the role of merit in spiritual and physical inheritance.

passage_content: אמנם ידוע כי האבות הקדושים כל פעולתם הי' בשביל דורות העתידים, ועשו פועל דמיוני להכין ישועה לדורות לישראל, וכמו שמצינו באאע"ה כשבא לשכם הי' מתפלל על בני יעקב כשיבואו להלחם בשכם כפי' רש"י עה"כ עד מקום שכם וגו' ועד"ז יתבאר שאלת אאע"ה במה אדע באיזה זכות יזכו ישראל וכו ', ותכלית ידיעה זו אליו כדי להכין כח השפעת זכות זה לבניו שיחזיקו בו, כי זה הי' כל עבודתו הק ', וכמ"ש כו ידעתיו למען אשר יצוה את בניו ואת ביתו אחריו ושמרו דרך ה' וגו' ולזה רצה אאע"ה לידע באיזה זכות יזכו לירושת הארץ כדי להכין להם כח השפעה זו.
translation: Indeed, it is known that the holy patriarchs performed all their actions for the sake of future generations, and they created a figurative impact to prepare salvation for the generations of Israel. As we find with our forefather Abraham when he came to Shechem, he prayed for the sons of Jacob when they would come to fight in Shechem, as Rashi explains on the verse, "until the place of Shechem," etc. Similarly, the question of our forefather Abraham, "How will I know by what merit Israel will be worthy," etc., is ultimately for him to prepare the power of the influence of this merit for his children to hold onto it, for this was all of his holy service, as it is written, "For I have known him, that he will command his children and his household after him, and they will keep the way of the Lord," etc. For this reason, our forefather Abraham wanted to know by what merit they would be worthy of inheriting the land, in order to prepare for them the power of this influence.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the patriarchs' actions were intended to benefit future generations of Israel, preparing a spiritual foundation for their redemption. It highlights Abraham's prayers and inquiries about the merits that would secure Israel's inheritance of the land, illustrating his commitment to ensuring that his descendants would have the necessary spiritual resources. This reflects a central Hasidic concept of the interconnectedness between the past and future, where the patriarchs actively shaped the spiritual legacy for their children. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of divine merit and the role of the patriarchs in facilitating Israel's relationship with God.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל הכוונה גם במה שאמר מרע"ה להקב"ה למה הרעתה לעם הזה, שאינו כמתרעם ח"ו על דרכיו ית ', כי אם שאלה נכונה שאל באמרו למה הרעתה לעם הזה, ר"ל מהו הסיבה שגרם לזה שהרעתה לעם הזה ועל מה הגיע עליהם ככה, כי יש צורך בידיעה זו כדי לתקן החטא והפגם שבסיבתה בא עליהם הצרה הזאת, גם להמליץ זכות ולעורר רחמים עליהם, וכעין שמצינו בגמ' (יבמות ע"ח ע"ב) כתיב ויהי רעב בימי דוד ג' שנים שנה ראשונה אמר להם שמא עוע"ז יש בכם וכו ', בדקו ולא מצאו וכו' אמר אין הדבר תלוי אלא בי, מיד ויבקש דוד את פני ה', מאי היא אמר ר"ל ששאל באורים ותומים וכו ', ויאמר ה' אל שאול ואל בית הדמים וכו' עכ"ד הגמ ', ועד"ז הי' שאלת מרע"ה באומרו למה הרעתה לעם הזה, ובעוה"ר בדור הזה אין לנו מי שישאל ויחקור סיבת צרותינו לידע בשל מי הרעה הזאת ומה הגיע אלינו ככה, ותרופה אחת לנו שכולנו יחד נישא לבבינו אל אל בשמים, ונשוב אליו באמת ובלב שלם ונתקן אשר פגמנו עד שישוב וירחמנו.
translation: And similarly, one could say that the intention is also in what Moshe Rabbeinu said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Why have You afflicted this people?" which is not as if he is complaining, Heaven forbid, about His ways, but rather he is asking a proper question by saying, "Why have You afflicted this people?" meaning what is the reason that caused this affliction upon them and why has this come upon them in such a manner. There is a need for this knowledge in order to rectify the sin and the flaw that brought this distress upon them, and also to advocate for them and awaken mercy upon them, similar to what we find in the Gemara (Yevamot 78b) where it is written, "And there was a famine in the days of David for three years. In the first year, he said to them, 'Perhaps there is idolatry among you...' They investigated and found nothing... He said, 'The matter depends only on me.' Immediately, David sought the face of the Lord." What does this mean? It means that he asked through the Urim and Tumim, etc. And the Lord said to Saul and to the house of bloodshed, etc. Thus concludes the Gemara. And similarly, this was Moshe Rabbeinu's question when he said, "Why have You afflicted this people?" And woe to us, in this generation, we have no one to ask and investigate the reason for our troubles to know upon whom this affliction has come and why it has reached us in this way. And there is one remedy for us: that we all together lift our hearts to the God in Heaven, and return to Him truly and with a complete heart, and rectify that which we have blemished until He returns and has mercy upon us.
summary: The passage discusses the inquiry of Moses to God regarding the suffering of the people, emphasizing that his question was not a complaint but a sincere search for understanding the reasons behind their afflictions. It highlights the importance of recognizing the root causes of suffering in order to rectify sins and invoke divine mercy. The text draws a parallel to King David's actions during a famine, illustrating the need for communal reflection and repentance. In the current generation, it calls for collective return to God with sincerity to heal the spiritual wounds and restore divine compassion.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר הקישור למה הרעתה לעם הזה ולמה זה שלחתני, עפי"מ שפי' האר"י הק ' עה"כ לכה ואשלחך וגו' על כי בזה השליחות ששלח השי"ת למרע"ה הי' בו טובה ורעה טובה לישראל ורעה למצרים, ומאתו ית ' לא תצא הרעה, להכי נגד הרעה שמגיע מהשליחות אמר לכה כלומר לך מדעתך, ונגד הטובה שמגיע ממנה אמר השי"ת ואשלחך אני משלח אותך עכת"ד הק ', וזה שטען מרע"ה קובל אני על ששלחתני, דהא ממה שאמרת לי ואשלחך, נשמע שע"כ יצמח טובה לישראל מהשליחות, כי אם הקב"ה המשלח הרי מאתו לא תצא הרעה, ועדיין לא נתגלה בחי' הטוב שבשליחות, אדרבה ומאז באתי אל פרעה לדבר בשמך הרע לעם הזה והצל לא הצלת את עמך. ואין זה כבוד שמים שיתייחד השליחות בשמך על בחי' הרעה, ולכן מרע"ה בגודל ענוותנותו תלה החסרון בעצמו, כי הוא אשר מעל ח"ו בשליחות וע"ז הי' קובל מרע"ה , דהרי ראה כי הוכבד העבודה על בנ"י והוא מא' משתי הסיבות, או שחטא העם גרם לזאת ושאל למה הרעותה לידע הסיבה ע"מ לתקנה, או שהחסרון ממנו על כי הוא הי' השליח לזה וכנ"ל, והשיב לו הקב"ה לסתור טענתו שאין החסרון ממנו ח"ו, אלא שכל זה הי' מן השמים, מפני שהי' צורך לאלו הדיבורים שיאמר משה רבינו למה הרעותה וגו' כדי שיעורר על ידם רחמים על ישראל, ואחר שאמר למה הרעותה א"ל הקב"ה עתה תראה וגו' כי כבר נשלם הרצון ונתעורר רחמים ע"י דיבורך.
translation: And according to our path, it will be clarified the connection of why You have afflicted this people and why You have sent me, as explained by the holy Ari on the verse "Come, and I will send you," that in this mission that the Holy One, blessed be He, sent to Moshe Rabbeinu, there was both good and bad: good for Israel and bad for Egypt. And from Him, blessed be He, evil will not come forth. Therefore, against the evil that comes from the mission, He said "Come," meaning go of your own accord, and against the good that comes from it, the Holy One, blessed be He, said "And I will send you," I am sending you, thus far the holy text. And this is what Moshe Rabbeinu claimed: I complain about Your sending me, for from what You said to me "And I will send you," it is understood that therefore good will arise for Israel from the mission, because if the Holy One, blessed be He, is the sender, then from Him evil will not come forth. Yet the good aspect of the mission has not yet been revealed; on the contrary, since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, the evil has been upon this people, and You have not saved Your people at all. And it is not fitting for the honor of Heaven that the mission should be associated with Your name in the aspect of evil. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu, in his great humility, attributed the shortcoming to himself, for he was the one who, Heaven forbid, failed in the mission, and for this he was complaining, for he saw that the work had become burdensome upon the children of Israel, and this was due to one of two reasons: either the sin of the people caused this, and he asked why You have afflicted them to know the reason in order to rectify it, or the shortcoming was from him, for he was the messenger for this, as mentioned above. And the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to him to refute his claim that the shortcoming was from him, Heaven forbid, but all this was from Heaven, because there was a need for these words that Moshe Rabbeinu would say, "Why have You afflicted?" in order to arouse mercy upon Israel. And after he said "Why have You afflicted?" the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Now you will see," for the will has already been fulfilled and mercy has been aroused through your words.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of Moses' mission, which brings both good for the Israelites and suffering for the Egyptians, as explained by the teachings of the Arizal. Moses expresses his concern about the suffering of the people, questioning why he was sent if the mission was meant to yield good. God responds that the hardships serve a divine purpose, as Moses' inquiries will ultimately invoke mercy for the Israelites. This interaction highlights the themes of humility, the necessity of suffering for spiritual growth, and the belief that divine plans often unfold through human struggles.

passage_content: ואפ"ל שזהו הכוונה במאמר הכתוב וידבר אלקים אל משה זה מדה"ד , שדבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למה הרעותה , דלמראית עין הי' נחשב זאת לחטא, אבל אליבא דאמת הוכנו דיבורים אלו מן השמים וזה ירמוז ויאמר אליו אני ה' דמ"ש משה למה הרעותה וגו' אני ה' אמרתי זאת, והשכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו של משה, והקב"ה סיבב כן שיהיו נאמרים דיבורים הללו מפי משה נביאו, כי הי' צורך לדיבורים הללו לעורר רחמים על ישראל, וכעין שמצינו בגמ' (יבמות קכ"א ע"ב) בבתו של ר' נחוניא חופר שיחין שנפלה לבור וכו' והודיעו לר"ח ב"ד וכו' א"ל לא נביא אנכי וכו' אלא דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו, ואר"א אעפ"כ מת בנו בצמא וכו' ע"כ, ולכאו ' מדוע לא הועיל זכותו גם לבנו שינצל בטענה זו דבר שהצדיק מתעסק בו יכשל בו זרעו, ובשיטה מקובצת (מס' ב"ק ) כתב ולרבינו נל"פ אמרתי כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה וכו' והסכים הקב"ה לדברי, שכן דרכו של הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים שבדור, וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר' חנינא עכ"ד, וכן פי' בעץ יוסף על עין יעקב עיי"ש, הרי דאף אם הסברא אמיתית, מ"מ אם הקטרוג גדול יש צורך שצדיק גדול יאמר זה והקב"ה מסכים לסברת הצדיקים, וכן הי' כאן צורך גדול לאלו הדיבורים שיאמר משה רבינו למה הרעותה לעם הזה כדי לעורר רחמים למעלה, ובעוה"ר מה נענה אנן בדורותינו אלה בגודל השפלות אין מי יטעון בעדינו לעורר רחמי שמיא עלינו ורק הבוכ"ע בעצמו למענו ית ' יעשה ולמען שם קדשו שלא יחולל בגוים.
translation: And even if this is the intention of the statement written, "And God spoke to Moses," this is the measure of judgment, that He spoke with him a judgment for having questioned and said, "Why have You done evil?" For to the eye it would seem that this was considered a sin, but in truth, these words were prepared from Heaven, and this will hint and say to him, "I am the Lord." When Moses said, "Why have You done evil?" etc., "I am the Lord," I said this. And the Shechinah speaks from the throat of Moses, and the Holy One, blessed be He, arranged it so that these words would be said from the mouth of Moses, His prophet, for there was a need for these words to awaken mercy upon Israel. And as we find in the Gemara (Yevamot 121b) regarding the daughter of Rabbi Nechunya who dug wells and fell into a pit, etc., and they informed Rabbi Chiya of the court, etc., he said, "I am not a prophet," etc., "but a matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in." And Rabbi Elazar said, "Nevertheless, his son died of thirst," etc. Therefore, it seems, why did his merit not help his son to be saved with this claim, "A matter that the righteous is engaged in, his offspring will fail in"? And in the Shita Mekubetzet (Baba Kamma) it is written, "And to our Rabbi, it seems I said," meaning I presented this matter before the Holy One, blessed be He, etc., and the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed with my words, for it is the way of the Holy One, blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous of the generation. And when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chanina had already died. Thus, it is explained in the Etz Yosef on Ein Yaakov, see there. Hence, even if the reasoning is true, nevertheless, if the accusation is great, there is a need for a great righteous person to say this, and the Holy One, blessed be He, agrees with the reasoning of the righteous. And so, there was a great need for these words that Moses our teacher would say, "Why have You done evil to this people?" in order to awaken mercy above. And in our bitter times, what can we answer in our generations, in the great lowliness, there is no one to argue on our behalf to awaken Heavenly mercy upon us, and only the Blessed One Himself, for His own sake, will act and for the sake of His holy name, that it should not be desecrated among the nations.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses questioning God about the suffering of the Israelites, emphasizing that these words were divinely orchestrated to elicit mercy for the people. It highlights the concept that even a righteous person's struggles can lead to a need for divine intervention, as seen in the example of Rabbi Hanina. The text suggests that in times of great distress, it is essential for a great tzaddik (righteous person) to voice concerns to God, as this can influence divine compassion. Ultimately, it reflects on the current state of spiritual decline and the need for divine mercy in contemporary times.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד במאמה"כ ויאמר אליו אני ה', דמ"ש משה למה הרעותה וגו' זה אומר גם הקב"ה כביכול לטעון נגד מדת הדין, כי מלך במשפט יעמיד ארץ ומלכותא דרקיע כעין מלכותא דארעא, וכשיש ח"ו התעוררות דין למעלה אז יגער ה' בך השטן והקב"ה טוען נגדו, אלא שיש צורך באתערותא דלתתא , לזה צורך בדיבורים של צדיק אמת לעורר רחמים למעלה. והנה אז הי' מרע"ה מצער עצמו בצרתן של ישראל וטען בשבילם למה הרעותה לעם הזה ועי"כ הי' מעורר רחמים עליהם, אמנם מה יעשו ישראל באותן הדורות שלא יהי' משה רבינו בעולם ומי יטעון בשבילם, כי מאז ראה מרע"ה שהגאולה אינו נצחי, ומה"ט הי' מסרב בשליחותו כי רצונו הי' להמתין עד שיהי' גאולה נצחי, ולזה נחמו הקב"ה ויאמר אליו אני ד', דמה שאמרת למה הרעותה וגו' אני ה' אמרתי זאת, ודיבורו יתברך נצחי לעולם וקיים לדורי דורות, ואנחנו צריכים לעורר רחמים על זה שהקדוש ברוך הוא יטעון בשבילנו למה הרעותה לעם הזה וגו' שכבר סבלנו די והותר מחבלי משיח, ומעתה נזכה לעבוד השי"ת בהרחבה ובלי צרה ועקתא ונזכה במהרה לישועת השי"ת בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And even though it is written in the Torah, "And He said to him, I am the Lord," what Moses said, "Why have You afflicted this people?"—this is also something that the Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, claims against the attribute of judgment. For a king establishes the land through justice, and the kingdom of heaven is like the kingdom of the earth. And when, Heaven forbid, there is an awakening of judgment above, then the Lord will rebuke the Satan, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will argue against him. However, there is a need for an awakening from below; for this, there is a need for the words of a true tzaddik to arouse mercy above. And behold, then Moses was causing himself distress over the troubles of Israel and argued for them, "Why have You afflicted this people?" and through this, he aroused mercy upon them. However, what will the Jews do in those generations when Moses our teacher will not be in the world, and who will argue for them? For from then on, Moses saw that the redemption is not eternal, and for this reason, he was reluctant in his mission because he wanted to wait until there would be an eternal redemption. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, comforted him and said to him, "I am the Lord," meaning that what you said, "Why have You afflicted this people?"—I, the Lord, said this. And His blessed word is eternal forever and established for generations upon generations. And we need to arouse mercy for this, that the Holy One, blessed be He, will argue for us, "Why have You afflicted this people?" for we have already suffered enough from the birth pangs of the Messiah. From now on, may we merit to serve the Blessed One with abundance and without trouble and distress, and may we quickly merit the salvation of the Blessed One with the revelation of the glory of heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between Moses and God, highlighting the tension between divine justice and mercy. It emphasizes that when there is a heavenly decree of judgment, God, in a sense, argues against it, but this requires a lower-world awakening, often initiated by the righteous. Moses' self-sacrifice for the suffering of the Israelites serves to evoke divine compassion, raising the concern for future generations who may lack such an advocate. Ultimately, it expresses a hope for God's eternal promise of redemption and the desire for relief from suffering, leading to a future of divine revelation and salvation.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה', במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' א') הה"ד (קהלת ב') ופניתי אני לראות חכמה והוללות וסכלות כי מה האדם שיבוא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשהו וכו ', לפי שכבר הודיע הקב"ה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך שנא' וכו' ואני אחזק את לבו. ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למה הרעותה לעם הזה. וע"ז נאמר שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות הי' כי מה האדם שיבוא אחרי המלך וכו ', ועל דבר זה בקשה מדה"ד לפגוע במשה הה"ד וידבר אלקים אל משה, ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צער ישראל דיבר כן חזר ונהג עמו במדה"ר ויאמר אליו אני ה' עכ"ד המדרש וכולו מוקשה דאיך יתכן לומר שמשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה דנראה כאילו שכח או עבר ח"ו על דברי השי"ת, ולא יתכן לחשוב כן על מרע"ה מובחר היצורים אבי כל הנביאים. גם צ"ב מה שאמר שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות הי', דממנ"פ אם הי' חכמה ודעת אין כאן הוללות וסכלות, ואם הוללות וסכלות אין כאן חכמה ודעת, והם ב' הפכים רחוקים מן הקצה אל הקצה.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord," as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 1), "And I turned to see wisdom and folly and madness, for what can man do who comes after the king, what has already been done?" This is because the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed that Pharaoh would not let them go, as it is written, "And I will harden his heart." And Moses did not heed this matter but came to outsmart the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and began to say, "O Lord, why have You harmed this people?" And concerning this, it is said that that wisdom and knowledge of Moses was folly and madness, for what can man do who comes after the king, etc. And regarding this, the attribute of justice sought to strike Moses, as it is stated, "And God spoke to Moses." And since the Holy One, Blessed be He, saw that it was because of the suffering of Israel that he spoke this way, He returned and dealt with him in the attribute of mercy, and said to him, "I am the Lord." Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is all difficult to understand how it can be said that Moses did not heed this matter, as it seems to imply that he forgot or transgressed, Heaven forbid, the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and it is not fitting to think this of our teacher Moses, the chosen of all creatures, the father of all prophets. It is also puzzling what is meant by saying that that wisdom and knowledge of Moses was folly and madness, for if it was wisdom and knowledge, there is no folly and madness here, and if there is folly and madness, there is no wisdom and knowledge here, and they are two opposites, far apart from one another.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between God and Moses, highlighting the tension between divine decree and human understanding. It critiques Moses for questioning God's plan regarding Pharaoh's hardened heart, suggesting that his wisdom in this context is misguided and akin to folly. The text emphasizes the complexity of divine justice and mercy, illustrating that even a prophet like Moses can struggle with the implications of God's will, raising profound questions about faith, obedience, and the nature of wisdom in the face of suffering.

passage_content: ב) במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' ב') הה"ד (קהלת ז') כי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה, כי העושק יהולל חכם זה משה, עשק שעשקו אותו דתן ואבירם יהולל חכם עירבבו אותו, ויאבד את לב מתנה וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, אלא הם שהקניטוהו ואמרו לו ירא ה' עליכם וישפוט, ואף הוא הקפיד ואמר ומאז באתי לדבר אל פרעה וכו ', באותה שעה בקשה מדה"ד לפגוע בו שנא' וידבר אלקים אל משה, א"ל הקב"ה וכי בשר ודם אני במדותי שאיני מרחם הה"ד ויאמר אליו אני ה', וצ"ב שהקשה בעל המדרש וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, ותירץ שהם הקניטו אותו ועל ידם הי' מתאבד כמ"ש ויאבד את לב מתנה, ולכאורה עדיין הקושיא במקומה עומדת וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, דגם אם הקניטוהו דתן ואבירם לא יתכן לומר שהי' משה מתאבד ח"ו. גם צ"ב הלשון ויאבד את לב מתנה שאין לו ביאור עפ"י פשוטו, ובידי משה פי' שחסר כאן בדברי המדרש וצריך להגיה מתונה כתיב, וכ"ה הגירסא במדרש קהלת על פסוק הזה, ויאבד את לב מתנה מתונה כתיב, אילו הי' משה מתון הי' ניצול אלא שהקניטוהו והקפידו אותו ואמר ומאז באתי לדבר אל פרעה וגו' עכ"ל. אמנם קשה לומר שבכל דפוסי המדרש חסר גירסא זו, גם בלשון הכתוב מתנה כתיב ולא מתונה וצ"ב .
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, section 2), it is stated (Ecclesiastes 7) that "the oppression will cause the wise man to be confused and will cause him to lose the heart of a gift." The oppression that confuses the wise man refers to Moses, the oppression that Datan and Aviram inflicted upon him confused him, and he lost the heart of a gift. And would you think that Moses would commit suicide? Rather, they provoked him and said to him, "Fear the Lord upon you and He will judge," and he too was upset and said, "And since I came to speak to Pharaoh..." At that moment, the attribute of judgment sought to strike him, as it is said, "And God spoke to Moses." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Am I flesh and blood that I do not have mercy?" As it is written, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord.'" And it is difficult, as the master of the Midrash asked, "Would you think that Moses would commit suicide?" And he answered that they provoked him, and through them he would have committed suicide, as it is said, "and he lost the heart of a gift." And seemingly, the question still stands: would you think that Moses would commit suicide? For even if Datan and Aviram provoked him, it cannot be said that Moses would commit suicide, Heaven forbid. It is also difficult regarding the wording "and he lost the heart of a gift," which does not have a clear explanation according to its simple meaning. In the hands of Moses, it means that there is something missing here in the words of the Midrash, and it should be corrected to "he was moderate," as the version in the Midrash Kohelet on this verse states, "and he lost the heart of a gift, he was moderate." If Moses had been moderate, he would have been saved, but since they provoked him and upset him, and he said, "And since I came to speak to Pharaoh..." However, it is difficult to say that in all versions of the Midrash this version is missing. Also, in the wording of the verse, it is written "gift" and not "moderate," and it is difficult.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by Moses, particularly the provocations from Datan and Aviram, which led to a moment of despair. It emphasizes that despite Moses' elevated status, he was affected by their taunts, illustrating the human vulnerability even in great leaders. The phrase "and he lost the heart of a gift" suggests that his emotional state was compromised, and the text questions whether such despair could truly be attributed to Moses. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of maintaining composure and humility in the face of adversity, suggesting that a more measured response could have altered the outcome.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם מ"ד בגמ' (תענית כ"ג ע"א) ת"ר פעם אחת יצא רוב אדר ולא ירדו גשמים שלחו לחוני המעגל התפלל ולא ירדו גשמים, עג עוגה ועמד בתוכה וכו' אמר לפניו רבש"ע נשבע אני בשמך הגדול שאיני זז מכאן עד שתרחם על בניך, התחילו גשמים מנטפין וכו' אמר לא כך שאלתי אלא גשמי בורות שיחין ומערות, ירדו בזעף וכו' אמר לפניו לא כך שאלתי אלא גשמי רצון ברכה ונדבה וכו ', שלח לו שמעון בן שטח אלמלא חוני אתה גוזרני עליך נידוי וכו ', אבל מה אעשה לך שאתה מתחטא לפני המקום ועושה לך רצונך כבן שמתחטא על אביו ועושה לו רצונו, פרש"י מתחטא לשון חטא כלומר הולך וחוטא, עוד שם בגמ' (דף כ"ה ע"א) לוי גזר תעניתא ולא אתא מיטרא אמר לפניו רבש"ע עלית וישבת במרום ואין אתה מרחם על בניך אתא מיטרא ואיטלע , א"ר אלעזר לעולם אל יטיח אדם דברים כלפי מעלה שהרי אדם גדול הטיח דברים כלפי מעלה ואיטלע ומנו לוי עכ"ד הגמ ', הרי מצינו בצדיקים וקדושים שהטיחו דברים כלפי מעלה בשביל טובת ישראל, אף שידעו שיחשב להם לחטא ופגם ויענשו על זה, מ"מ מסרו נפשייהו לטובת ישראל ונתקבלה תפילתם להמשיך ישועה לישראל, וכמו"כ מרע"ה שאמר למה הרעותה בשביל צערן של ישראל. אף שידע בנפשי' כי יענש עלי' מ"מ מסר נפשו לטובת ישראל.
translation: And we will explain in advance what is stated in the Gemara (Taanit 23a): Our Rabbis taught: Once, most of Adar had passed and no rain fell. They sent for Choni the Circle Maker, he prayed, and no rain fell. He drew a circle and stood inside it, etc. He said before Him, Master of the Universe, I swear by Your great Name that I will not move from here until You have mercy on Your children. The rains began to drip, etc. He said, "Not like this did I ask, but for the rains of pits, ditches, and caves." They fell in a downpour, etc. He said before Him, "Not like this did I ask, but for the rains of favor, blessing, and generosity," etc. Shimon ben Shetach sent to him, "If not for you, Choni, I would decree a ban upon you," etc. But what can I do for you, since you are pleading before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He fulfills your will like a son who pleads with his father and has his will fulfilled. Rashi explains that "pleading" means to go and sin. Furthermore, it is stated in the Gemara (25a) that Levi decreed a fast and rain did not come. He said before Him, Master of the Universe, You have ascended and sat on high, and You do not have mercy on Your children. Rain came and fell. Rabbi Elazar said, "A person should never hurl accusations upward, for a great man hurled accusations upward and rain fell, and who was that? Levi." Thus we find that the righteous and holy ones hurled accusations upward for the good of Israel, even though they knew it would be counted as a sin and a blemish, and they would be punished for it. Nevertheless, they risked their lives for the good of Israel, and their prayers were accepted to bring salvation to Israel, just as Moshe Rabbeinu said, "Why have You harmed Your people?" Even though he knew in his soul that he would be punished for it, he nevertheless risked his life for the good of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intercessory prayer and the willingness of righteous individuals to confront God on behalf of the Jewish people, as exemplified by Choni HaMa'agal and Rabbi Levi. It highlights the tension between divine justice and mercy, illustrating that even great figures in Judaism, aware of the potential consequences of their boldness, chose to advocate for the welfare of Israel. This reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between humanity and the divine, emphasizing the importance of self-sacrifice for the greater good and the power of sincere prayer.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי ק"ז הייטב לב זי"ע (פ' נח) לבאר אמרם ז"ל (זבחים קט"ז ע"א) נח איש צדיק תמים וגו' צדיק במעשיו תמים בדרכיו, פרש"י ז"ל תמים עניו וסבלן, עפי"מ שפי' הגה"ק מבארדיטשוב זצ"ל הכ ' שיש יתרון לחכמה מן הסכלות כיתרון האור מן החושך, כי אור משמעותי' יממא ומשמעותי' אורתא כדאי' בפ"ק דפסחים , משא"כ חושך אין משמעותי' רק לילה וכו ', זה עצמו ההבדל שבין חכמה לסכלות, כי החכם אם שהוא חכם לפעמים ישנה טעמו וריחו לפי הצורך ויעשה עצמו כסיל, ע"ד שעשה דוד בשנותו את טעמו לפני אבימלך, משא"כ הכסיל אין בידו לעשות עצמו חכם בשום פעם ואופן עכ"ד, והוא נאות לענינינו כי זה גדר החכם להיות עניו ושפל, וכל גאה שוטה, אך לפעמים צריך להתלבש בלבוש הגאות לצורך הזמן לקנא קנאת ה' צבאות להשיב רבים מעון וכו' וגם לאפושי ברחמים אבני דורו. וזהו גדר החכמה להשתמש בתרי אנפין גבר ענותן ושפל ולפעמים גאה וגאון הכל לפי שעה שמע לו וזהו ענין התחכמות וכו' ומי שמתנהג בדרך הנ"ל חכם מתקרי, משא"כ מי שאינו בידו רק ע"ד אחד ומהנמנע אצלו להתלבש בלבוש הגאות ולחלף שמלותיו יקרא תם שאינו יודע לרמות, ולכן יקרא נח בשם תמים כי לא הי' לו ענין התחכמות לעשות פעם כך ופעם כך וכו' אתד"ק יעיי"ש .
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z, may his merit protect us (Parshat Noach), to explain their saying, of blessed memory (Zevachim 116a), "Noach was a righteous man, perfect in his generations," righteous in his deeds, perfect in his ways. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "perfect" means humble and patient. According to what the holy Gaon from Berdichev, may his memory be a blessing, explains, there is an advantage of wisdom over foolishness, like the advantage of light over darkness, for light signifies day and darkness signifies only night, etc. This itself is the difference between wisdom and foolishness, for the wise man, even though he is wise, sometimes changes his taste and demeanor according to the need and makes himself appear foolish, as David did when he changed his demeanor before Avimelech. However, the fool cannot make himself wise at any time or in any way. Thus, it is fitting for our discussion, for this is the definition of the wise man: to be humble and lowly, while every arrogant person is a fool. Yet sometimes it is necessary to don the garment of arrogance for the sake of the time, to zealously pursue the zeal of the Lord of Hosts to bring back many from sin, etc., and also to plead for mercy for the stones of his generation. And this is the definition of wisdom: to use two faces, sometimes humble and lowly, and sometimes proud and haughty, all according to the moment. Whoever behaves in this manner is called wise, while one who is only capable of one way and cannot don the garment of arrogance and change his attire will be called "perfect," for he does not know how to deceive. Therefore, he is called Noach, which means "perfect," because he had no inclination for cunning to act one way at one time and another way at another time, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of wisdom and foolishness, emphasizing that true wisdom involves humility and adaptability, as exemplified by the biblical figure Noah, who is described as "perfect" and "righteous." It contrasts the wise person, who can adjust their demeanor for a greater purpose, with the fool, who lacks the ability to change. The text highlights that wisdom requires a balance of humility and, at times, the ability to adopt a more assertive stance for the sake of divine service. Ultimately, it portrays Noah as a model of integrity, lacking the cunning or pretense that characterizes the wise who can navigate different situations.

passage_content: והנה מרע"ה הי' עניו מכל האדם אשר על פני האדמה כמו שהעידה עליו התוה"ק , וכאן לבש לבוש הגאות להתפלל על ישראל ולדבר כלפי מעלה דברים שאינם מן המוסר לומר להקב"ה למה הרעותה , וזה הי' לו מגודל מעלת חכמתו שהי' בידו לשנות טעמו ולעשות דבר שנראה כהוללות וסכלות בשביל טובת ישראל, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש שאותה חכמה של משה של הוללות וסכלות היתה , דמה שמשה לא שמר את הדבר ואמר למה הרעותה הי' בכוונה גדולה מאתו בשביל טובת ישראל, ואף שהי' עניו מכל אדם מ"מ לצורך השעה לבש לבוש הגאות ע"י גודל חכמתו ועשה דבר שנראה כהוללות וסכלות בשביל טובת ישראל. והנה מדריגה זו שיוכל האדם להשתמש בתרי אנפין לשני הפכים זהו מתנה מהקב"ה, כי האדם מצד יגיעת עבודתו א"א להגיע לידי מדה זו שהיא למעלה מן הטבע, ורק הקב"ה שהוא כל יכול יש לו מדה זו שיכול לעשות שני הפכים בנושא אחד, אלא שהוא יתב"ש נותן מתנה זו לצדיקים אמיתיים העובדים אותו באמת שגם הם יוכלו להשתמש במדה זו לעת הצורך.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu was the most humble of all men on the face of the earth, as the Torah testifies about him. Yet here he donned the garment of arrogance to pray for Israel and to speak to the Holy One, Blessed be He, words that are not fitting to say, asking Him, "Why have You done evil?" This was due to the greatness of his wisdom, for he had the ability to change his nature and to do something that appeared as arrogance and foolishness for the sake of the good of Israel. In this, we understand the words of the Midrash that this wisdom of Moshe, which seemed like arrogance and foolishness, was indeed a great intention on his part for the good of Israel. And although he was the most humble of all men, nonetheless, for the sake of the moment, he donned the garment of arrogance through the greatness of his wisdom and did something that appeared as arrogance and foolishness for the good of Israel. And this level, where a person can use two faces for two opposites, is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He, for a person, through the toil of his service, cannot reach this measure, which is above nature. Only the Holy One, Blessed be He, who is all-powerful, possesses this measure, to do two opposites in one matter. However, He, Blessed be He, grants this gift to the true righteous ones who serve Him sincerely, so that they too can use this measure when the need arises.
summary: The passage highlights the humility of Moses, who, despite being the most humble man, donned the "garment of pride" to advocate for the Israelites, demonstrating a profound wisdom that allowed him to act contrary to his nature for their benefit. This act, perceived as folly, was intentional and rooted in his deep love for the people. It emphasizes that the ability to embody opposing traits is a divine gift from God, granted to true righteous individuals who serve Him sincerely, enabling them to navigate complex spiritual challenges beyond natural human capacity.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש כי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה, ע"ד שאמה"כ ארמי אובד אבי ודרשו רז"ל בקש לבן לעקור את הכל , ואף שלא עלה בידו נחשב לו המחשבה כמעשה, וכמו"כ מה שדרשו רז"ל על עושק של דתן ואבירם ויאבד את לב מתנה, לפי שרצו לאבד נחשב להם כעשי', ומ"ש את לב מתנה פי' מתנה זו שנתן הקב"ה למרע"ה שיהי' בידו להשתמש בשני הפכים, ואף להפלגת ענותנותו יוכל להשתמש בלבוש הגאות ולהפציר בתפלתו על ישראל, מתנה זו רצו דתן ואבירם לאבד ממרע"ה ע"י שהקניטוהו, וז"פ ויאבד את לב מתנה שרצו לאבד מלבו של משה המתנה שניתן לו מהקב"ה, ולזה הקשה המדרש וכי תעלה על דעתך שהי' משה מתאבד, ותירץ אלא שהקניטוהו ואמרו לו ירא ה' עליכם וישפוט ורצו לאבד מלבו של משה המתנה שקיבל מהקב"ה, אבל לא עלתה בידם הרצון ההוא, ומרע"ה נשאר בגדולתו וקדושתו ואף הוא הקפיד וכו' ולבש לבוש הגאות בשביל טובתן של ישראל ונתקבלה תפלתו אצל הקב"ה, אולם אעפ"כ אמר הכתוב ויאבד עד"ש בלבן ארמי אובד אבי לצד הרצון שלו.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash, for the oppressor will praise the wise and will cause the heart of the gift to be lost, as it is stated, "An Aramean sought to destroy my father," and our Sages interpreted that Laban sought to uproot everything, and even though he did not succeed, his intention is considered as an action. Likewise, what our Sages interpreted regarding the oppression of Datan and Aviram, and they caused the heart of the gift to be lost, because they wanted to destroy it is considered as if they acted. And what is meant by "the heart of the gift" refers to the gift that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave to Moshe Rabbeinu, that he should have the ability to use two opposites, and even in the extreme of his humility, he could use the garment of pride and plead in his prayer for Israel. This gift, Datan and Aviram wanted to take away from Moshe Rabbeinu by provoking him. Therefore, it is stated, "and he lost the heart of the gift," meaning they wanted to take away from the heart of Moshe the gift that was given to him by the Holy One, blessed be He. To this, the Midrash asks, "Could it enter your mind that Moshe would become despondent?" And it answers, "Rather, they provoked him and said to him, 'Fear the Lord upon you and He will judge,' and they wanted to take away from the heart of Moshe the gift he received from the Holy One, blessed be He, but their desire did not succeed, and Moshe Rabbeinu remained in his greatness and holiness, and he was particular, etc., and he wore the garment of pride for the sake of the goodness of Israel, and his prayer was accepted by the Holy One, blessed be He. However, nevertheless, the verse states, 'And he lost' in connection with 'An Aramean sought to destroy my father' due to his own desire.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention versus action in the context of spiritual leadership, highlighting that even the desire to harm, as seen with Datan and Aviram's attempts to undermine Moses, is considered significant. It emphasizes that Moses was endowed by God with the ability to navigate both humility and authority, which they sought to diminish through provocation. Despite their efforts, Moses maintained his greatness and holiness, and his prayers for Israel were accepted by God. Ultimately, the text illustrates the profound impact of intention in spiritual matters and the resilience of true leadership.

passage_content: עוד נל"פ אומרו ויאבד את לב מתנה, עפי"מ שפירשתי מ"ש ישמח משה במתנת חלקו כי עבד נאמן קראת לו, דלכאו ' צ"ב מ"ש במתנת חלקו שהי"ל במתנה מה שנקרא עבד נאמן, והלא בודאי יאות לו שם זה ע"ש עבודתו שהי' עבד נאמן להקב"ה ומסר נפשו בכל רגע על קדושת שמו ית ', ופירשתי עפי"מ דאיתא בגמ' (ברכות ל"ד ע"ב) מעשה בר' חנינא בן דוסא שהלך ללמוד תורה אצל ריב"ז וחלה בנו של ריב"ז א"ל חנינא בני בקש עליו רחמים ויחי', הניח ראשו בין ברכיו ובקש עליו רחמים וחי', א"ר יוחנן בן זכאי אלמלי הטיח בן זכאי את ראשו בין ברכיו כל היום כולו לא היו משגיחים עליו, אמרה לו אשתו וכי חנינא גדול ממך. אמר לה לאו אלא הוא דומה כעבד לפני המלך ואני דומה כשר לפני המלך, פרש"י כעבד בן בית נכנס ויוצא שלא ברשות, כשר לפני המלך שאינו רגיל לפניו ע"כ, מבואר שאע"פ שמעלת השר ודאי גדול יותר ממעלת העבד, מ"מ לענין ליכנס לפני המלך גם בלי רשות גדלה מעלת העבד יותר שהוא יוצא ונכנס תמיד, והנה מרע"ה לגודל מעלתו הי' בבחי ' שר לפני המלך מלכי המלכים הקב"ה, אבל לטובת ישראל הי' צריך למעלת העבד להיות עייל בלא בר, ולפעול בתפלתו רחמים על ישראל, ונתן לו הקב"ה מעלה זו בתורת מתנה, וז"פ ישמח משה במתנת חלקו כי עבד נאמן קראת לו: אף שכליל תפארת בראשו נתת לו והי' בבחי ' שר לפני המלך, מ"מ ניתן לו במתנה גם בחי' עבד להיות יוצא ונכנס תמיד להתפלל על ישראל, וזאת המעלה רצו דתן ואבירם לאבד ממנו ע"י שהקניטוהו ואמרו ומאז באתי וגו' וז"פ כי העושק יהולל חכם ויאבד את לב מתנה שרצו לאבד מלבו של משה אותה המתנה שנתן לו הקב"ה להיות יוצא ונכנס ומתפלל על ישראל תמיד, אלא שלא עלתה בידם, מ"מ ע"ש הרצון אמר הכתוב ויאבד לב מתנה וכנ"ל.
translation: Furthermore, we can explain the phrase "and he lost the heart of the gift," according to what I have explained regarding "Moses will rejoice in the gift of his portion because you called him a faithful servant." It is indeed puzzling what is meant by "the gift of his portion" that he should be called a faithful servant. Surely, this title is fitting for him due to his service, as he was a faithful servant to the Holy One, blessed be He, and he risked his life at every moment for the sanctity of His Name. I have explained according to what is stated in the Gemara (Berakhot 34b) about the story of Rabbi Hanina ben Dosa, who went to learn Torah from Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai, and the son of Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai fell ill. Rabbi Hanina said, "My son, ask for mercy for him, and he will live." He placed his head between his knees and prayed for mercy, and he lived. Rabbi Yochanan ben Zakkai said, "If not for the fact that Ben Zakkai placed his head between his knees all day long, they would not have paid attention to him." His wife said to him, "Is Hanina greater than you?" He replied, "No, but he is like a servant before the king, and I am like a minister before the king." Rashi explains that a servant of the household enters and exits without permission, while a minister before the king is not accustomed to being before him. It is clear that although the status of the minister is certainly greater than that of the servant, nevertheless, in terms of entering before the king even without permission, the status of the servant is greater, as he is always entering and exiting. Now, Moses, due to his great stature, was in the category of a minister before the King of Kings, the Holy One, blessed be He. However, for the benefit of Israel, he needed the status of a servant to enter without permission and to pray for mercy on behalf of Israel. The Holy One, blessed be He, granted him this status as a gift, and thus it is said, "Moses will rejoice in the gift of his portion because you called him a faithful servant." Even though he was adorned with glory on his head and was in the category of a minister before the king, nevertheless, he was also given as a gift the status of a servant to be always entering and exiting to pray for Israel. This status was what Datan and Aviram wanted to take away from him by provoking him and saying, "And since I came..." Therefore, it is said, "For the oppressor will praise the wise, and he will lose the heart of the gift," as they wanted to remove from Moses' heart that gift which the Holy One, blessed be He, had given him to always enter and exit and pray for Israel. However, they did not succeed in their plan. Nevertheless, regarding their desire, the verse states, "and he lost the heart of the gift," as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the unique relationship between Moses and God, emphasizing Moses' role as a faithful servant (עבד נאמן) who continually intercedes for the Israelites. It contrasts the status of a servant with that of a minister, highlighting that while the minister holds a higher rank, the servant's constant access to the king allows for a more intimate connection. The text illustrates that Moses, despite his elevated status, was granted the gift of being an ever-present advocate for the people, a role that his adversaries sought to undermine. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the divine gift of this role and the challenges posed by those who wished to diminish it.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה', יל"ד דפתח במדת הדין וידבר אלקים ומסיים אני ה' שהוא שם של רחמים.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." It is known that He begins with the attribute of judgment, as it says, "And God spoke," and concludes with "I am the Lord," which is a name of mercy.
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the interplay between divine justice and mercy. It begins with God speaking in the attribute of judgment, indicating a serious tone, but concludes with the declaration "I am the Lord," which represents the essence of mercy. This transition emphasizes that even in moments of strict judgment, God's ultimate nature is one of compassion and kindness. The text reflects a core Hasidic belief in the balance of divine attributes, where mercy ultimately prevails over judgment.

passage_content: ב) (פרשה ו' סי' א') הה"ד ופניתי אני וגו' כי מה האדם שיבא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשוהו (קהלת ב'), הפסוק הזה נאמר על שלמה ועל משה וכו' כיצד נאמר על משה, לפי שכבר הודיע הקב"ה למשה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך, שנא' ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך ואני אחזק את לבו, ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למה הרעותה לעם הזה וכו' עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב הכוונה במ"ש את אשר כבר עשוהו.
translation: B) (Parashat Vayakhel, Siman Aleph) This is as it is written: "And I turned, and behold..." (Ecclesiastes 2:14), for what is man that he should come after the king to that which has already been done. This verse is said about Solomon and about Moses, etc. How is it said about Moses? Because the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses that Pharaoh would not let them go, as it is said: "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go..." (Exodus 3:19), and I will harden his heart. And Moses did not heed this matter, but came to outsmart the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and began to say: "O Lord, why have You harmed this people..." etc. Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is necessary to understand the intention of what is meant by "that which has already been done."
summary: The passage discusses the idea that human actions can sometimes contradict divine will, as illustrated by Moses questioning God about the suffering of the Israelites despite knowing Pharaoh would not let them go. It highlights the tension between human reasoning and divine knowledge, emphasizing that Moses, despite being informed of God's plan, attempted to challenge it. The reference to "what has already been done" suggests a deeper understanding of the futility of opposing God's decrees, reflecting key Hasidic themes of humility and submission to divine authority.

passage_content: ג) שם במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' ב') א"ל הקב"ה חייך יש לך לידע שנאמר טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים וכו ', וצ"ב .
translation: 3) There, in the Midrash (Parashat Vayikra, Section 2), the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: "Rejoice, you should know that it is said, 'The end of a matter is better than its beginning.' The good end of the Jewish people is better than the beginning when I gave it to them in Egypt, etc. And this requires further explanation."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is emphasized that God assures Israel of a positive outcome, stating that the end is inherently good, even from the beginning. This reflects the Hasidic belief in divine providence and the idea that the ultimate purpose of creation and history is for the benefit of the Jewish people. The reference to their redemption from Egypt underscores the notion that despite challenges, there is a predetermined goodness in their journey. This encapsulates the theological insight that faith in God's plan leads to hope and assurance of a favorable conclusion.

passage_content: ד) הקמתי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו' דרשו רז"ל (סנהדרין צ' ע"ב) לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים מן התורה, ראוי להבין כוונת דרשתם ז"ל מדוע רמז הכתוב להבטחת תחיית המתים בפרשה זו דייקא .
translation: I established My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, etc. The Sages taught (Sanhedrin 90b) that it is not said "to you" but "to them," from here we learn about the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. It is fitting to understand the intent of their teaching, why the verse hints at the promise of the resurrection of the dead specifically in this section.
summary: The passage discusses the divine promise of the land of Canaan and highlights a rabbinic interpretation that connects this promise to the concept of resurrection of the dead. The phrase "to them" rather than "to you" suggests that the assurance of inheriting the land is linked to the future revival of the deceased. This connection emphasizes the enduring nature of God's covenant and the hope for redemption, reflecting a key Hasidic belief in the ultimate restoration of life and the fulfillment of divine promises.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפי"מ דאיתא בספה"ק נועם אלימלך (פ' ויחי) לפרש אמרם ז"ל (ברכות ל"ד ע"ב) אמרו עליו על ר"ח בן דוסא כשהי' מתפלל על החולה הי' אומר זה חי כו ' אמרו לו מנין אתה יודע, אמר להם אם שגורה תפלתי בפי יודע אני שהוא מקובל וכו ', לכאורה מלת שגורה בפי אינו מובן, הי' לו לומר אם תפלתי יוצא מפי בלי גמגום בידוע שהוא מקובל, אך הענין הוא דהנה לכאורה יש להבין הסיבה הזאת שהצדיק מתפלל על החולה והוא מתרפא, ונראה הדבר כמו השתנות חלילה אצל הבורא האחד הפשוט האמיתי וחלילה לחשוב ולומר כך, אך הענין דהנה כל העולמות וכל הנבראים היו מתחילה קודם בריאת העולם בכח אין סוף ב"ה ואח"כ כשעלה ברצונו הפשוט לבוראם הוציאם מכח אל הפועל וכל מה שיהי' הוא שהי' בכח האין סוף ב"ה וב"ש, ונמצא אין כאן שום השתנות כי כל זאת הי' בכח הא"ס שזה יהי' חולה והצדיק יתפלל עליו ויעתר בתפלתו וכו' עכלה"ק לענינינו עיי"ש, המורם מדבה"ק דרק תפלה שהי' בכח הא"ס ב"ה מתחלת הבריאה מתקבלת ולא זולת, אמנם תפלה זו שהתפלל משרע"ה למה הרעותה וגו' לא היתה ראוי' שתתקבל, כי הכבדת השעבוד הי' לטובתן של ישראל כמבואר בדרז"ל , ועוד טעמים כמבואר בדברנו להלן, נמצא תפלה זו לא הי' בכח הא"ס ב"ה מתחילת הבריאה, אלא שנסתבב לו מן השמים בבחי ' נורא עלילה ועי"ז נענש ולא נכנס לארץ, וכל זה הי' לתועלת הצלתן של ישראל כמבואר להלן, וז"פ דברי המדרש כי מה האדם שיבא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשוהו ר"ל בתחלת הבריאה, ולא יתכן בחי' השתנות אצל הבוי"ת ורק תפלה שהי' בכח הא"ס ב"ה מתקבלת, ומשה לא שמר את הדבר הזה אלא בא להתחכם על גזירתו של הקב"ה והתחיל אומר ה' למה הרעתה וכו ', ותפלה זו לא הי' מוכנת ולא היתה ראוי' להתקבל, וז"פ אידך דברי המדרש הי' לך לידע טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, היינו טוב אחרית דבר להתפלל תפלה שהוא מראשיתו מוכנת בכח הא"ס ב"ה מתחלת בריאת העולם, ולא כן תפלה זו שאמר למה הרעתה.
translation: And it is possible to explain according to what is stated in the holy book Noam Elimelech (Parashat Vayechi) regarding the statement of our sages (Berakhot 34b) about Rabbi Chiya ben Dosa, that when he would pray for the sick, he would say, "This one will live," etc. They asked him, "How do you know?" He replied, "If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know that it is accepted," etc. At first glance, the term "fluent in my mouth" is not understood; he should have said, "If my prayer comes out of my mouth without stuttering, it is known that it is accepted." However, the matter is that there is a need to understand the reason why the righteous prays for the sick and he is healed. It seems as if there is a change, Heaven forbid, in the Creator, the One, the Simple, the True, and it is forbidden to think or say such a thing. However, the matter is that all the worlds and all creations were initially in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He, and afterwards, when it arose in His simple will to create them, He brought them from potential to actual. Everything that will be is what was in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He, and thus there is no change here, for all of this was in the potential of the Infinite, that this one will be sick and the righteous will pray for him and his prayer will be answered, etc. Thus, it is stated in our matter, as it is known that only a prayer that was in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of creation is accepted, and not otherwise. However, this prayer that Moshe prayed, "Why have You harmed Your servant?" was not worthy of being accepted, because the hardening of the servitude was for the benefit of Israel, as explained in the words of our sages, and other reasons as explained in our discussion below. Therefore, this prayer was not in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of creation, but rather it was caused to him from Heaven in a state of "fearful accusation," and as a result, he was punished and did not enter the land. All of this was for the benefit of saving Israel, as explained below. This is the meaning of the words of the Midrash: "What is man that he should come after the King with that which has already been done," meaning from the beginning of creation. It is not possible for there to be a change in the Creator, and only a prayer that was in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He is accepted. And Moshe did not guard this matter, but rather he came to outsmart the decree of the Holy One, Blessed Be He, and began to say, "Lord, why have You harmed?" And this prayer was not prepared and was not worthy of being accepted. This is the meaning of the other words of the Midrash: "You should know the good end of a matter from its beginning," meaning the good end of a matter is to pray a prayer that is prepared from its beginning in the potential of the Infinite Blessed Be He from the beginning of creation, and not like this prayer that he said, "Why have You harmed?"
summary: The passage discusses the nature of prayer and its acceptance by God, emphasizing that only prayers aligned with the divine will, as established from the beginning of creation, are truly effective. It references the story of Rabbi Chiya ben Dosa, who knew a sick person would recover based on the fluency of his prayer, indicating a deep connection to the divine. The text contrasts this with Moses' prayer, which was not accepted because it was not in accordance with God's original plan, highlighting the importance of understanding the divine purpose behind events. Ultimately, it asserts that true prayer must resonate with the infinite potential of God, as nothing can change the divine will.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי המדרש (איכה רבתי פ"ד סי' י"ד) מזמור לאסף אלקים באו גוים בנחלתך (תהלים ע"ט) לא הוה קרא צריך למימר אלא בכי לאסף נהי לאסף קינה לאסף, ומה אומר מזמור לאסף אלא משל למלך וכו' כך אמר להם מזמר אנו ששפך הקב"ה חמתו על עצים ואבנים ולא שפך חמתו על ישראל וכו ', והנה אלמלי נכנס מרע"ה לא"י הי' בונה ביהמ"ק ולא היו האויבים יכולים לשלוט במעשה ידיו כאמרם ז"ל (סוטה ט' ע"א), ואין מקום לתקנה של שפך חמתו על עצים ואבנים, וע"י שלא נכנס משרע"ה לא"י ניצולו ישראל מכלי' ששפך הקב"ה חמתו על עצים ואבנים.
translation: And we will precede the words of the Midrash (Eicha Rabbah, Perek 4, Siman 14): A psalm for Asaf, "God, the nations have come into Your inheritance" (Psalms 79). It does not need to be said except for the weeping for Asaf, the lament for Asaf, the dirge for Asaf. And what does it mean, a psalm for Asaf? Rather, it is a parable for a king, etc. Thus He said to them, "We sing, for the Holy One, blessed be He, has poured out His wrath upon trees and stones and has not poured out His wrath upon Israel," etc. And behold, had Moshe Rabbeinu entered the Land of Israel, he would have built the Holy Temple, and the enemies would not have been able to dominate his handiwork, as our sages of blessed memory said (Sotah 9a). And there is no place for the remedy of His wrath being poured out upon trees and stones. And because Moshe Rabbeinu did not enter the Land of Israel, Israel was saved from the destruction that the Holy One, blessed be He, poured out upon trees and stones.
summary: The passage discusses the lamentation of Asaf in Psalms, emphasizing that God's wrath was directed towards inanimate objects rather than the people of Israel. It suggests that had Moses entered the Land of Israel, he would have built the Holy Temple, preventing the enemies from having power over the works of his hands. The text highlights a theological insight that God's anger, while severe, ultimately spared the Jewish people from destruction, illustrating a divine mercy that protects them even in times of judgment.

passage_content: והנה איתא במד"ר (פ' ה' סי' כ"ג) ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה וגו' מכאן אתה למד שנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, אמנם ע"י תוקף הדין שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לא"י נסתבב אח"כ לישראל רחמים גדולים שעי"ז ניצולו מכלי', וזה ירמוז הכתוב וידבר אלקים היינו במדה"ד שנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, ומזה נמשך מדת הרחמים לישראל ויאמר אליו אני ה' שם של רחמים שינצלו עי"ז מכלי'.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Ha'azinu, section 23) "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Now you shall see...'" From here you learn that Moses accepted the decree that he would not enter the Land. However, through the severity of the decree that was imposed upon him not to enter the Land of Israel, great mercies were later aroused for Israel, by which they were saved from destruction. This is hinted at in the verse "And God spoke," which refers to the attribute of judgment that Moses accepted regarding the decree of not entering the Land, and from this, the attribute of mercy was drawn down for Israel. And He said to him, "I am the Lord," a name of mercy, by which they would be saved from destruction.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that Moses accepted the judgment of not entering the Promised Land, which initially appears as a harsh decree. However, this very severity of judgment ultimately led to great mercy for the Israelites, allowing them to be saved from destruction. The text highlights the interplay between divine justice and mercy, illustrating how the acceptance of strict judgment can lead to compassionate outcomes for others. The mention of God's name as a symbol of mercy reinforces the idea that through the acceptance of difficult circumstances, greater spiritual benefits can arise.
