passage_content: ובזה יתבארו עוד דברי מדרשים הנ"ל בהקדם אמרם ז"ל ( ב"ר פ' י"ב סי' ט"ו) בראשית ברא אלקים וגו' בתחלה עלה במחשבה לברוא את העולם במדת הדין וראה שאין העולם מתקיים הקדים מדת הרחמים ושתפה למדה"ד , ומקשים דאם כן שלא נתקיימה מידה ההוא, מדוע רמז עלי' הכתוב במאמר בראשית ברא אלקים ולמה נכתב בתורה דבר שלא נתקיים, אך נראה שבאמת נשאר גם כח מדת הדין שלפעמים יש בו צורך לתיקון העולם, וכמו שמצינו כאן שע"י תוקף מדה"ד שפגעה במשה רבינו נמשך רחמים מרובים לישראל, וע"כ גם מידה ההוא נתקיים ושפיר פתח בראשית ברא אלקים , ובזה יתבאר כוונת דברי המדרש כי מה האדם שיבא אחרי המלך את אשר כבר עשוהו, היינו המדה"ד שכבר הוכן מתחלת הבריאה לצורך החסד והרחמים, ולכן נטל משרע"ה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ ועי"ז ניצולו ישראל, וז"פ המדרש הי' לך לידע טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשיתן שהי' להם במצרים, היינו טובה אחריתן של ישראל שניצולו מכלי' בעת חורבן ביהמ"ק , מראשיתן שהי' להם במצרים, שע"י קישוי השעבוד אמר משרע"ה למה הרעתה ונטל את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ ועי"ז ניצולו ישראל, ומה שנסתבב כן למרע"ה הי' בבחי ' נורא עלילה וע"ד שאמרז"ל בתנחומא (פ' וישב) בחטא אדה"ר ומכירת יוסף שהגזירה היתה מוכרחת ונסבב מן השמים חטא זה לידם בבחי ' נורא עלילה על בני אדם כדי שיתקיים מה שמוכרח להיות, וכעי"ז כתב האוהחה"ק (ריש פ' אחרי) בענין הריגת ר"ע עייש"ד , וכמו כן מה שאמר מרע"ה למה הרעתה הי' בבחי ' נורא עלילה שעי"ז יטול את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, והי' גזירה זו מוכרחת להצלתן של ישראל.
translation:
And in this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified, as they said (B'reishit Rabbah, Parashah 12, Section 15): "In the beginning, God created..." At first, it was in His thought to create the world with the attribute of judgment, and He saw that the world could not endure, so He preceded the attribute of mercy and combined it with the attribute of judgment. It is asked, if the attribute of judgment was not established, why does the verse hint at it in the statement "In the beginning, God created," and why is it written in the Torah about something that did not come to pass? However, it seems that in truth, the power of the attribute of judgment remains, as sometimes it is necessary for the rectification of the world. And as we find here, that through the force of the attribute of judgment that struck Moses our teacher, abundant mercy was drawn forth for Israel. Therefore, that attribute was also established, and it is fitting that it began with "In the beginning, God created." 

And in this, the intention of the Midrash's words will be clarified, for what is man that he should come after the king to that which has already been done? This refers to the attribute of judgment that was already prepared from the beginning of creation for the purpose of kindness and mercy. Therefore, Moses was taken the judgment that he should not enter the land, and by this, Israel was saved. And the Midrash's statement, "You should know the good at the end of a matter from its beginning," refers to the good of Israel at the end, which they had in Egypt, meaning the good of Israel that they were saved from destruction at the time of the destruction of the Holy Temple, from the beginning that they had in Egypt. 

Because of the oppression of servitude, Moses said, "Why have you done evil?" and he took the judgment that he should not enter the land, and by this, Israel was saved. And the reason that this happened to Moses was in the aspect of "a terrible accusation," as our sages said in Tanchuma (Parashah Vayeshev) regarding the sin of Adam and the sale of Joseph, that the decree was necessary and this sin was caused from heaven in a terrible accusation against mankind so that what must be will be fulfilled. And similarly, the holy author wrote (at the beginning of Parashah Acharei) regarding the killing of Rabbi Akiva, may his memory be blessed. And likewise, what Moses said, "Why have you done evil?" was in the aspect of "a terrible accusation," so that he would take the judgment that he should not enter the land, and this decree was necessary for the salvation of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the interplay between the attributes of justice and mercy in creation, emphasizing that while God initially intended to create the world through strict justice, He ultimately combined it with mercy to ensure the world's survival. It highlights that the presence of justice is still necessary for the world's correction, as seen in the case of Moses, where the severity of justice led to greater mercy for the Israelites. The text suggests that the hardships faced by the Israelites, such as their suffering in Egypt, were part of a divine plan that ultimately resulted in their salvation, illustrating the concept of "necessary evils" for the greater good. This reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of divine providence and the complexities of human suffering within the framework of God's overarching mercy.

passage_content: עוד יתבאר במאמה"כ עפי"מ שאמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' ואתחנן פ"ב סי' ט') שנקבר מרע"ה במדבר כדי שיבואו כל דור המדבר עמו בתחי ' דלעתיד , נמצא ממה שנטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ נמשך רחמים גדולים לישראל שעי"ז יקומו עמו כל מתי מדבר, והנה תחה"מ יהי' ע"י רחמיו ית"ש וכמו שאומרים בתפלת י"ח מחי' מתים ברחמים רבים, וז"פ הפסוק וידבר אלקים אל משה במדה"ד ומכאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, ויאמר אליו אני ה' במדת הרחמים שממנו נמשך רחמים גדולים על ישראל בתה"מ דלעתיד , וזה ג"כ פי' המדרש טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשיתן שהי' להם במצרים פי' ממה שנטל משה את הדין במצרים נמשך לישראל אחרית ותקוה טובה בתחה"מ , ולזה א"ש מה שרמז הכתוב כאן ענין תחה"מ , ונמשך להתחלת הפרשה ויאמר אליו אני ה' במדת הרחמים, ורמז הכתוב להבטחת תחיית המתים להודיע שעליו הוא מזכיר שם הרחמים תחלה, ונזכה במהרה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן ובהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: It will be further explained in the holy writings according to what our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'etchanan, Chapter 2, Section 9) that Moshe Rabbeinu was buried in the desert so that all the generation of the desert would come with him in the resurrection of the dead in the future. It follows that because Moshe took the judgment upon himself not to enter the land, great mercies were extended to Israel, as through this, all the dead of the desert would rise with him. Behold, the resurrection of the dead will be through His great mercies, as we say in the Amidah prayer, "Who revives the dead with abundant mercies." This is the meaning of the verse, "And God spoke to Moshe in the measure of judgment," and from here Moshe took the judgment not to enter the land. And He said to him, "I am the Lord," in the measure of mercy, from which great mercies are extended to Israel in the resurrection of the dead in the future. This is also the explanation of the Midrash that the good end of Israel is better than their beginning, as they had in Egypt. This means that from the judgment Moshe took in Egypt, a good end and hope for Israel in the resurrection of the dead was extended. Therefore, it is clear why the verse hints here at the matter of the resurrection of the dead, and it connects to the beginning of the section, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord,' in the measure of mercy." The verse hints at the promise of the resurrection of the dead to indicate that He mentions the name of mercy first. May we merit soon to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy, and in the uplifting of the horn of the Torah and Israel with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses being buried in the desert, which allows for the resurrection of all the souls from the generation of the desert in the future. It emphasizes that Moses' acceptance of the judgment not to enter the Promised Land resulted in great mercy for Israel, as it connects to the future resurrection of the dead. The text highlights that God's attribute of mercy is central to this hope, linking the past suffering of the Israelites in Egypt to a promising future. Ultimately, it expresses a yearning for the redemption and joy of all Israel, alongside the revelation of divine glory.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ה' פירש"י ז"ל אני ה' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי שדברתי לאבות הראשונים, ראוי להבין קישור תשובה זו על טענת משרע"ה למה הרעתה, גם מה צורך להודעה זו למשרע"ה , ודבר ידוע שהקב"ה נאמן לשלם שכר טוב להולכים לפניו, והוא מי"ג עיקרי האמונה שהבוי"ת מעניש לעוברי מצותיו ומשלם שכר לשומרי מצותיו. אלא שהזהירנו רז"ל שלא להתכוין בעשיית המצות ע"מ לקבל פרס, וכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בתפלה למשה (קפיטל קמ"ג) וזל"ק אמרו החכמים שעיקר עבדות השי"ת הוא, שיהי' על בחי' שגם אם ענוש יענש בגיהנם על קיום המצוה מ"מ יעשה בחשקות גדול להשלים רצונו, וזה דבר קשה מאוד כיון שהוא א' מי"ג עיקרים שהקב"ה משלם שכר טוב לעושי רצונו, רק שצריך לחשוב ולכוין שאני עושה דבר זה גם ע"מ שאסבול בגיהנם וכו' עכל"ק , ומשרע"ה הי' רחוק מבחי ' זו לעשות רצון ה' בשביל קבלת השכר, ומה צורך בהודעה זו אליו, גם צ"ב מה שאמר לו הקב"ה לא לחנם שלחתיך וכו' וכי עלה ח"ו על דעתו של משרע"ה שהשליחות הי' לחנם, וכבר הבטיחו הקב"ה אעלה אתכם מעני מצרים וגו', ובוודאי שדיבורו ית ' לא ישוב ריקם.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Me, and I did not send you for naught, but rather to fulfill the words I spoke to the forefathers." It is fitting to understand the connection of this response to Moses' claim of why he was treated harshly, and also what the need is for this message to Moses. It is well known that the Holy One, blessed be He, is faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Him, and this is one of the thirteen principles of faith that the Creator punishes those who transgress His commandments and rewards those who observe His commandments. However, our sages warned us not to intend in performing the commandments in order to receive a reward. And it is written in "Yismach Moshe," may his memory be blessed, in the prayer for Moses (Psalm 103), and thus it is said: The sages said that the essence of serving the Holy One, blessed be He, is that one should serve in such a way that even if he were to be punished in hell for fulfilling the commandment, nonetheless, he should do so with great desire to fulfill His will. This is a very difficult matter since it is one of the thirteen principles that the Holy One, blessed be He, pays good reward to those who do His will. One must think and intend that he is doing this thing also in order to suffer in hell, etc. All this is to say, and Moses was far from this state of doing the will of the Lord for the sake of receiving a reward. What is the need for this message to him? It is also puzzling what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "I did not send you for naught," etc. Did it ever enter Moses' mind, heaven forbid, that the mission was for naught? For the Holy One, blessed be He, had already promised him, "I will bring you up from the affliction of Egypt," etc., and certainly His word will not return empty.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses emphasizes the faithfulness of God in rewarding those who walk before Him and fulfilling the promises made to the patriarchs. It highlights the importance of serving God not for the sake of reward, but out of genuine devotion, even in the face of potential punishment. The text reflects on the challenge of maintaining such pure intent, as Moses is reassured that his mission is not in vain, reinforcing the belief that God's promises are always fulfilled. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of faith, where one must balance the understanding of divine reward with the intrinsic motivation to fulfill God's will.

passage_content: ב) (פרשה ו' סי' ב') אמר לו הקב"ה אנכי הכתבתי עליך שאתה עניו ואתה מקפיד על דברי, חייך יש לך לידע שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים, עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב .
translation: B) (Parashat Vayikra, Siman Bet) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: "I have written about you that you are humble, and you are particular about My words. By your life, you should know that it is said, 'Good is the end of a matter from its beginning.' The good end of Israel began from the moment I gave it to them in Egypt." Thus concludes the Midrash, and it requires further explanation.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, God addresses an individual, highlighting the importance of humility despite their grievances. The text emphasizes that the ultimate goodness for the Jewish people was predetermined from the beginning, specifically referencing the positive outcomes that would arise from their time in Egypt. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine providence and the belief that every hardship is part of a greater, benevolent plan. The passage invites contemplation on the relationship between humility, faith, and the unfolding of divine goodness in history.

passage_content: ד) הקמותי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו', בגמרא (סנהדרין דף צ' ע"ב) מנין לתחיית המתים מן התורה שנאמר וגם הקמותי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחה"מ מן התורה, פירש"י דמשמע שהבטיח הקב"ה לאבותינו שיתן להם א"י, וכי להם ניתנה והלא לבניהם ניתנה. אלא מלמד שעתידין לחיות, ועתיד הקב"ה ליתן להם את א"י עכ"ל, ראוי להבין קישור הבטחה זאת לפרשה זו, ואיך הוא תשובה למרע"ה על מ"ש למה הרעתה וגו'
translation: 4) "And I will establish My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, etc." In the Gemara (Sanhedrin 90b), it is asked from where in the Torah do we learn about the resurrection of the dead, and it is stated: "And I will establish My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan" — it is not said "to you" but "to them." From here we learn about the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. Rashi explains that this implies that the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised our forefathers that He would give them the Land of Israel, and indeed it was given to them, but it was given to their children. Rather, it teaches that they will live again, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will give them the Land of Israel. It is appropriate to understand the connection of this promise to this section, and how it serves as a response to Moses regarding what he said: "Why have You made it worse, etc."
summary: The passage discusses God's promise to the patriarchs regarding the land of Canaan, highlighting the concept of resurrection of the dead (Techiyat HaMetim) as derived from the Torah. It emphasizes that although the land was given to their descendants, the patriarchs themselves will also partake in this promise, indicating a future revival where they will receive the land. This assurance serves as a response to Moses' concerns about the suffering of the Israelites, reinforcing the idea of divine faithfulness and the ultimate fulfillment of God's covenant.

passage_content: ה) אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי, יל"ד מ"ש ואזכור את בריתי בלשון עתיד, אחר שאמר וגם הקמותי את בריתי וגו' וגם אני שמעתי בלשון עבר, הול"ל וזכרתי את בריתי, דזכירת הברית הוא המסבב לשמיעת צעקתם וא"כ קדמה אלי' בזמן.
translation: 5) I heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom Egypt is enslaving, and I will remember My covenant. Why does it say "I will remember My covenant" in the future tense, after it already said "And I established My covenant" and "And I also heard" in the past tense? It should have said "And I remembered My covenant," for the remembrance of the covenant is what causes the hearing of their cry, and thus it precedes it in time.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between God's remembrance of the covenant and His response to the cries of the Israelites in Egypt. It highlights the distinction between the future tense "I will remember" and the past tense "I have heard," suggesting that God's remembrance of the covenant is a precursor to His hearing their suffering. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that divine awareness and action are interconnected, emphasizing the importance of the covenant in God's relationship with His people. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological insight that God's commitment to His promises drives His intervention in human affairs.

passage_content: ו) אמור לבנ"י אני ה' וגו', צ"ב הלא כבר הודיעם דבר זה בשליחות הראשון: והוא עיקר ליסוד כל התורה ומצותי ' ידיעת השי"ת ומציאותו ית ', ולא יצוייר מצוה בלתי מצוה. ומדוע צוהו הבוית"ש להודיעם עוה"פ אני ה' ובמסורה לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ה', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', וצ"ב .
translation: And say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, etc. It is puzzling, for did He not already inform them of this through the first mission? This is a fundamental principle of the entire Torah and My commandments: the knowledge of the Blessed One and His existence, and it cannot be conceived that there is a commandment without a commandment. And why did He command him to inform them in this world, "I am the Lord," and in tradition, therefore say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord," therefore say, "Here I am giving him My covenant"? And it is puzzling.
summary: The passage emphasizes the fundamental principle of knowing God and His existence as the foundation of all Torah and commandments. It questions why God instructed Moses to reiterate this message to the Israelites, suggesting that understanding God's presence is essential for fulfilling His commandments. The repetition of "I am the Lord" serves to reinforce the covenant and the importance of this knowledge in the spiritual life of the Jewish people. Ultimately, it highlights the inseparable connection between divine awareness and the observance of mitzvot.

passage_content: ז) אתכם אל הארץ אשר נשאתי את ידי לתת אותה לאברהם ליצחק וליעקב ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה אני ה', במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' ד') אעשה להן מה שאמרתי לאבותיהן, שאתן להן את הארץ ויהי' יורשין אותה בזכותן, עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב דכל זה מפורש בפסוק, ומה הוסיפו רז"ל בדרשתם.
translation: (7) To you I bring to the land which I raised My hand to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, and I have given it to you as a heritage, I am the Lord. In the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 4) it is stated: I will do for them what I said to their forefathers, that I will give them the land and they will inherit it by their merit. Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is puzzling why all this is explicitly stated in the verse, and what the sages added in their interpretation.
summary: The passage emphasizes God's promise to give the land to the descendants of the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, highlighting the concept of inheritance through merit. It suggests that the land is not merely a physical possession but a spiritual legacy that is granted in recognition of the righteousness of the ancestors. The reference to the Midrash indicates a deeper understanding of this promise, suggesting that the relationship between God and the Jewish people is rooted in the covenant established with their forefathers. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the continuity of divine favor and the importance of spiritual lineage.

passage_content: ח) משה כן אל בנ"י ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה במדרש ילקוט (רמז קע"ח) וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח, א"כ מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז, ויל"ד דעדיין לא נתיישב נתינת טעם שאמה"כ מקוצר רוח, דלטעם זה הי' ראוי שישמחו על בשורת הגאולה
translation: Moses spoke thus to the Children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, as stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 378). And is there a person who receives good tidings and is not happy? Therefore, what does it mean that they did not listen to Moses? Rather, it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry. It seems that the reason for their lack of response has not yet been settled, for if it were due to shortness of spirit, they should have rejoiced at the tidings of redemption.
summary: Moses conveyed God's message of redemption to the Israelites, but they did not listen due to their shortness of spirit and hard labor. The passage highlights the difficulty of letting go of idolatry, suggesting that their suffering made it hard for them to embrace the joyous news of salvation. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the struggle between spiritual awakening and the burdens of physical existence, emphasizing the challenge of faith amidst adversity. Ultimately, it illustrates the tension between despair and hope in the process of redemption.

passage_content: י) משה לפני ה' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים הקשו המפורשים דק"ו פריכא הוא, שבנ"י לא שמעו אליו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה כמפורש בכתוב, וטעם זה אינו שייך אצל פרעה, גם יש להבין אומרו ואני ערל שפתים וכבר אמר טענה זו כי כבד פה וכבד לשון אנכי, והשיב לו הקב"ה מי שם פה לאדם וגו' הלא אנכי ה', ומדוע חזר ושנה טענתו ואמר ואני ערל שפתים, גם צ"ב טעם שינוי הלשון דלעיל אמר כבד פה וכבד לשון וכאן אמר ערל שפתים וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation: Moses said before the Lord, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me? I am of uncircumcised lips." The commentators have difficulty with this, as it is a fortiori reasoning. The children of Israel did not listen to him due to shortness of breath and hard work, as is explicitly stated in the text, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh. One must also understand his statement, "I am of uncircumcised lips," for he has already presented this claim, saying, "I am heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue." The Holy One, blessed be He, responded to him, "Who made man's mouth... is it not I, the Lord?" Why then did he return and repeat his claim, saying, "I am of uncircumcised lips"? Additionally, it is puzzling why he changed his wording; previously he said, "heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue," and here he said, "uncircumcised lips," and the intention behind this is also unclear.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores Moses' hesitations in speaking to Pharaoh, emphasizing the contrast between the Israelites' inability to listen due to their suffering and Pharaoh's different circumstances. The text highlights Moses' claim of being "uncircumcised of lips," which reflects a deeper spiritual struggle and a sense of inadequacy in fulfilling his prophetic role. The repetition of his objections, shifting from "heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue" to "uncircumcised of lips," invites contemplation on the nature of divine communication and the challenges faced by a leader in conveying God's message. Ultimately, it underscores the tension between human limitations and divine empowerment.

passage_content: יא) ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה מלך מצרים להוציא את בנ"י מארץ מצרים, צ"ב דאינו מבואר מה הי' הציווי אל בנ"י , ומ"ש להוציא את בנ"י וגו' זה הי' ציווי לפרעה שבידו להוציא ולא ביד ישראל.
translation: 11) The Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and commanded them to speak to the Children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the Children of Israel out of the land of Egypt. It is puzzling, for it is not explained what the command was to the Children of Israel, and when it says to bring the Children of Israel out, this was a command to Pharaoh, who had the power to bring them out, and not to Israel.
summary: In this passage, the command from God to Moses and Aaron emphasizes the distinction between divine authority and human agency, highlighting that the directive to free the Israelites from Egypt was primarily directed at Pharaoh, who held the power to release them. The lack of explicit instruction to the Israelites suggests a deeper theological insight into their reliance on divine intervention rather than their own strength. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of faith in God's will and the understanding that true liberation comes from a higher source. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that human efforts are secondary to divine orchestration in the process of redemption.

passage_content: יב תנחומא (סי' ב') ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה עשה אותן שווים עכ"ד המדרש, והוא פליאה דהרי הקב"ה שלחו לגאול את ישראל ולהבדילם מטומאת מצרים ומהו הכוונה להשוותם, גם הלא בנ"י הי' להם הרבה מדות טובות כמפורש במדרשי חכז"ל , ואיך יתכן להשוותם אל פרעה, ורש"י ז"ל פי' ויצום אל בנ"י צוה עליהם להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום עליו לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם עכ"ל, וצ"ב מדוע לא נצטוה על זאת בשליחות הראשונה שינהיגם בנחת ויחלקו כבוד לפרעה, ומדוע דייקא עכשיו נצטוה על זה
translation: Verse 12: Tanchuma (Section 2) "And He commanded the Children of Israel and Pharaoh to make them equal." Thus says the Midrash. It is indeed wondrous, for the Holy One, blessed be He, sent to redeem Israel and to separate them from the impurity of Egypt, and what is the intention of making them equal? Moreover, the Children of Israel had many good traits, as is explicitly stated in the Midrashim of our Sages, and how can it be that they are to be compared to Pharaoh? Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that "He commanded the Children of Israel" to lead them gently and to bear with them, and "to Pharaoh, King of Egypt," He commanded to show him honor in their words. Thus far his words. It is puzzling why they were not commanded about this in the first mission, to lead them gently and to show honor to Pharaoh, and why specifically now were they commanded about this.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of God commanding Moses to treat both the Israelites and Pharaoh equally, despite the Israelites being chosen for redemption from Egyptian impurity. It highlights the inherent goodness of the Israelites, as noted in various Midrashim, and questions why this instruction to show respect to Pharaoh was not given earlier. The emphasis on leading the Israelites gently and honoring Pharaoh reflects a deeper Hasidic teaching on the importance of humility and respect, even towards oppressors, as part of the divine plan for redemption.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי האוהחה"ק (פ' שופטים) עה"פ כי תצא למלחמה על איבך וגו', שרמז הכתוב מלחמת האדם עם יצרו וכו ', דאחר שנכשל האדם בעבירות רבות, נתוספו כוחות הרע שנולדו ממעשיו הרעים וכו ', והרי הוא ביניהם כחררה שאין לה הופכין, לזה בא דבר ה' כאן ואמר, כי תצא למלחמה וראית בעיני שכלך סוס ורכב, כנגד מה שהוא היצר סוס מוכן למלחמה וכו ', עם רב ממך כנגד כוחות הרע שנתוספו ממנו מצד מעשיו הרעים וכו ', אעפ"כ בא דברו הטוב ואמר לא תירא מהם והטעם כי ה' אלקיך עמך, פי' הן אמת אם היית בא למלחמה בכחך אין בך כח לעמוד במלחמה זו, אבל כיון שה' אלקיך עמך, כחו גדול להצילך וכו ', וגמר אומר המעלך מארץ מצרים, כי זה מופת חותך כי ה' מפרק הקליפה מן הקדושה ומבררה וכו' וזה לך האות כדי שתתחזק במלחמה עכלה"ק , וכעי"ז פי' בספה"ק זרע קודש (פ' שופטים) וז"ל עם רב ממך יל"פ על כוחות הסט"א וז"ש ממך שאתה בראתם ע"י עונותיך, לא תירא מהם לאמר איך אשוב על כל עונותי המרובים, כי ה' אלקיך עמך, כי אלמלא הקב"ה עוזרו וכו' ואצלו ית ' אין חילוק בין רב למעט, וז"ש המעלך מארץ מצרים שהי' הגלות דוקא במקום ערות הארץ להעלות הניצה"ק עכ"ל, ובספה"ק דברי חיים פי' בזה תחלה למקראי קודש זכר ליציאת מצרים, כשיתחיל האדם להתחזק בדרך הקדושה, אף כי קשה הוא מאוד מפני גודל התגברות כוחות הטומאה למנעהו , אבל הסגולה לזה זכר ליציאת מצרים, דע"י זכרון יצי"מ יתחזק לבך ובטחונך בהשי"ת , כי גם שם היו ישראל משוקעים בשורש הטומאה ערות הארץ, ועשה הקב"ה עמהם נסים ונפלאות להוציאם משם, ונתרוממו בקבלת התורה למדריגה גדולה למעלה מהשגה אנושית עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will precede with the words of the holy Baal Shem Tov (Parashat Shoftim) on the verse "When you go out to war against your enemies," which hints at the battle of a person with their evil inclination, etc. For after a person has stumbled in many transgressions, the forces of evil that were born from their bad deeds are added, etc. And he is among them like a thorn that has no remedy. Therefore, the word of the Lord comes here and says, "When you go out to war and see with your intellect horses and chariots," against what is the evil inclination, a horse prepared for battle, etc., "a multitude greater than you," against the forces of evil that have been added from their bad deeds, etc. Nevertheless, His good word comes and says, "Do not be afraid of them," and the reason is "for the Lord your God is with you." It is true that if you were to go to war with your own strength, you would not have the power to stand in this battle, but since the Lord your God is with you, His strength is great to save you, etc. And He concludes by saying, "Who brought you up from the land of Egypt," for this is a decisive sign that the Lord removes the shell from the holiness and clarifies it, etc. This is the sign for you so that you may strengthen yourself in the battle, etc. Similarly, it is explained in the holy book Zera Kodesh (Parashat Shoftim) that "a multitude greater than you" refers to the forces of the Other Side, and this is said "from you," for you created them through your sins. "Do not be afraid of them," to say, "How can I return from all my numerous sins?" For the Lord your God is with you, for were it not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping you, etc., and with Him, there is no distinction between many and few. And this is said, "Who brought you up from the land of Egypt," which was the exile specifically in the place of the nakedness of the land to elevate the sparks of holiness, etc. And in the holy book Divrei Chaim, it is explained that initially, in the holy scriptures, it is a remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt. When a person begins to strengthen themselves on the path of holiness, even though it is very difficult due to the great intensification of the forces of impurity that prevent them, the remedy for this is the remembrance of the Exodus from Egypt. Know that through the remembrance of the Exodus, your heart and trust in the Blessed One will be strengthened, for there too the Israelites were immersed in the root of impurity, the nakedness of the land, and the Holy One, blessed be He, performed miracles and wonders to take them out from there, and they were elevated in receiving the Torah to a great level beyond human comprehension.
summary: The passage discusses the internal struggle of a person against their evil inclination, likening it to a battle where the forces of negativity are amplified by one's sins. Despite the overwhelming nature of these forces, the text reassures that with God's presence, one can overcome these challenges, as demonstrated by the miraculous redemption from Egypt. The remembrance of the Exodus serves as a source of strength and faith, emphasizing that divine assistance transcends the limitations of human effort, allowing individuals to rise above their spiritual struggles.

passage_content: ובזה יל"פ במאמה"כ וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, ר"ל דזה הי' עיקר נאקתם של ישראל, מה שכוחות הטומאה של קליפת מצרים מעבידים אותם, היינו מכריחים אותם להרבות עוד חטאים, ולז"א מעבידים בלשון מפעיל, וע"ד שכתב המהרש"א ז"ל (מכות י' ע"ב) דאלו המלאכים הנבראים ממעשה או ממחשבת עבירה, המה מוליכים אותו להשלים ענינו עייש"ד , וכמעט שנמנע הבחירה ממנו ולולא עזר אלקי אין בכח אנושי לעמוד ולהתגבר עליהם, וכבר פירשתי מ"ש אתה זוכר את כל המפעל וגם כל היצור לא נכחד ממך, ר"ל שהשי"ת זוכר את כל המפעל ועל כל מעשה האדם יבוא בדין, אבל גם כל היצור לא נכחד ממך, היינו המלאך הנוצר מעבירה המכריחו לחטוא אף זה לא נכחד ממך, ויש בזה לימוד זכות כי אין בכח בשר ודם להתגבר נגד מלאך ומכ"ש אם רבים המה, אמנם אם יכאב לב האדם ומתחרט חרטה גמורה על עונותיו, מחליש בזה כח המלאך הנברא מהעבירה, וכמ"ש הרה"ק מוה"ר זושא זלה"ה שמעולם לא ראה מלאך שנברא מעונות ישראל בשלימות איבריו, ולא' חסר עינו או מוחו תבירא , דע"י הרהור תשובה מחסרין ומחלישין כח המשחית עכת"ד ז"ל, ולז"א וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, שצועקים אלי מכאב לבם על התגברות כוחות הטומאה המכריחים אותם כנ"ל, ולזה ואזכור את בריתי לסייע להם לשמור קדושת הברית, שא"א לולי עזר אלקי , אלא שצריך האדם לעשות כל מה שביכלתו והבוית"ש עוזר לו להתגבר על כל המניעות.
translation: And in this, it can be explained according to the verse, "And I have also heard the cry of the children of Israel, whom Egypt is enslaving," meaning that this was the main cry of Israel, that the forces of impurity of the shell of Egypt are enslaving them, compelling them to commit even more sins. Therefore, it says "enslaving" in the active form. This is in line with what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote (Makkot 10b) that those angels created from an act or thought of sin lead a person to complete their matter, as is known. And almost the choice is taken away from him, and were it not for divine assistance, no human power could stand against and overcome them. I have already explained what it means when it says, "You remember all the deeds and all the creations are not hidden from You," meaning that the Holy One, blessed be He, remembers all the deeds, and for every action of man, He will come to judgment. But also, "all the creations are not hidden from You," meaning the angel created from sin that compels him to sin is also not hidden from You. And there is a merit in this, for no flesh and blood can overcome an angel, and certainly if they are many. However, if a person's heart aches and he sincerely regrets his sins, this weakens the power of the angel created from the sin. As the holy Rabbi, our teacher Zusha, may his memory be blessed, said that he never saw an angel created from the sins of Israel in complete form, lacking an eye or a brain, God forbid. For through the thought of repentance, they diminish and weaken the power of the destroyer, as he said. Therefore, it says, "And I have also heard the cry of the children of Israel, whom Egypt is enslaving," that they cry out to Me from the pain of their hearts over the overpowering forces of impurity that compel them, as mentioned above. And for this, I will remember My covenant to assist them in keeping the sanctity of the covenant, which cannot be done without divine assistance. However, a person must do all that is within his power, and the Holy One, blessed be He, helps him to overcome all the obstacles.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Israelites under the oppression of Egypt, emphasizing that the forces of impurity compel them to sin. It highlights the idea that human beings struggle against these spiritual forces, which can diminish their free will without divine assistance. However, sincere repentance can weaken the power of these negative influences. Ultimately, it conveys that while divine help is essential, individuals must also exert their own efforts to overcome obstacles and maintain their spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר המשך הכתובים לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ה' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים וגו', וידעתם כי אני ה' המוציא אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, היינו שנצטוה משרע"ה להורות לישראל שרק בכוחו ית"ש התגברו על כוחות הטומאה של מצרים, וידיעה זו מתחייבת להם לעולם, שידעו לי אני ה' המוציא אתכם וגו', וזהו התחזקות לישראל בכל הדורות, שאף שאין בכוחם לעמוד נגד התגברות הנורא של כוחות הטומאה והמלאכים רעים שנבראו מעבירות, אבל כבר הבטיחנו ית ' בתורתו הק ' כי ה' אלקיך עמך להצילך, וכנ"ל בדברי האוהחה"ק שמופת חותך לזה מיציאת מצרים, ולז"א ואזכור את בריתי בלשון עתיד שהוא הבטחה לדורות שהבוית"ש יסייע בידינו לשמור קדושת הברית כמו שעשה עמנו במצרים.
translation: And according to our path, the continuation of the verses will be clarified. Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," etc. "And you shall know that I am the Lord who brings you out from under the burdens of Egypt." This means that Moshe Rabbeinu was commanded to instruct Israel that it is only through His blessed power that they overcame the forces of impurity of Egypt. This knowledge is a perpetual obligation for them, to know that I am the Lord who brings you out, etc. This is a strengthening for Israel in all generations, that even though they do not have the power to stand against the terrible onslaught of the forces of impurity and the evil angels created from transgressions, He has already promised us in His holy Torah that "the Lord your God is with you to save you." And as mentioned above in the words of the holy Baal Shem Tov, the clear proof of this is from the Exodus from Egypt. Therefore, I will remember My covenant in the future tense, which is a promise for generations that the Blessed One will assist us in preserving the sanctity of the covenant as He did with us in Egypt.
summary: The passage emphasizes the fundamental belief that God, as the redeemer, empowers the Jewish people to overcome the forces of impurity and evil, as exemplified by their liberation from Egypt. It highlights the importance of recognizing God's continuous presence and assistance throughout generations, assuring that despite the overwhelming challenges posed by negative spiritual forces, divine support remains steadfast. The reference to God's covenant serves as a promise for future generations, reinforcing the commitment to uphold the sanctity of the covenant, just as God aided them during the Exodus.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר במאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו', דלכאורה יש לתמוה דמתחלה כשבאו משה ואהרן לבשר לישראל בשורת הגאולה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ה' את בני ישראל וכי ראה את ענים ויקדו וישתחוו. ואיך נשתנה בחינת מדריגתם בזמן קצר, והטעם שנתן הכתוב שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ולפי"ד רז"ל על שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, לכאורה הרי גם מאז היו משוקעים בע"ז ועבדו עבודה קשה, ואעפ"כ שמחו על הבשורה וקבלוהו בשמחה, וצ"ב טעם ההשתנות בשליחות זו, אך נראה שהסיבה לזה לפי שהי' רוב גדול בישראל שלא רצו לצאת ממצרים ומתו בג' ימי אפילה, ורז"ל דרשו במדרש (ילקוט רמז רכ"ז) עה"פ וחמשים עלו בנ"י מארץ מצרים א' מחמשה יצאו וד' חלקים מתו בג' ימי אפילה, ולחד מ"ד א' מחמשים יצאו ובגמ' (סנהדרין קי"א ע"א) דריש ר' סימאי שיצאו ממצרים שנים מס' רבוא , ופירש"י שהשאר מתו כולן בג' ימי אפילה.
translation: And we will explain in the matter of "and they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit," etc. It is seemingly puzzling that initially, when Moses and Aaron came to announce to Israel the tidings of redemption, it is written, "And the people believed and heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, and they bowed their heads and prostrated themselves." How did their level change in such a short time? The reason given in the text is that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and from hard work. According to the words of our Sages, it was because it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. Seemingly, even then they were immersed in idolatry and worked hard, and nevertheless, they rejoiced at the tidings and accepted it with joy. The reason for this change in their response to this mission seems to be that there was a large majority in Israel who did not want to leave Egypt and died during the three days of darkness. Our Sages expounded in the Midrash (Yalkut, Remez 267) on the verse "And fifty went up from the land of Egypt," that one out of five went out, and four parts died during the three days of darkness. And according to one opinion, one out of fifty went out, and in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 111a), Rabbi Simai expounds that two out of six hundred thousand went out of Egypt, and Rashi explains that the rest all died during the three days of darkness.
summary: The passage discusses the initial acceptance of Moses and Aaron's message of redemption by the Israelites, who believed and rejoiced at the news of their liberation. However, it later notes a significant change in their attitude, attributed to their "shortness of spirit" and the burdens of hard labor, which made it difficult for them to heed Moses' call. The text suggests that a large portion of the Israelites were unwilling to leave Egypt, leading to their demise during the three days of darkness, highlighting the struggle between spiritual liberation and attachment to the familiar, even in the face of suffering. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the challenges of faith and the complexities of redemption.

passage_content: ומעתה אלו שהאמינו למשרע"ה ורצו לצאת היו רק מיעוטא דמיעוטא , והי' להם נסיון גדול להתקיים באמונתם נגד רוב גדול, ומכש"כ כשהשיגו רשעי ישראל שנתקרבה עת הגאולה, התאמצו בכל תוקף לקלקל האמונה אצל בנ"י הכשרים שהאמינו בבשורת הגאולה, וכוונתם היתה לדחות עי"ז את הגאולה לגמרי, מפני שידעו והשיגו שאם יזכו ישראל להיגאל יהי' אחריתם מרה וכמו שאירע להם שמתו בג' ימי אפילה, והם היו תקלה גדולה לישראל יותר מהמצריים, וע"ד שכתב רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' בחקותי) עה"פ ורדו בכם שונאיכם וגו' איני מעמיד שונאים אלא מכם ובכם, שבשעה שאוה"ע עומדים על ישראל אינם מבקשים אלא מה שבגלוי וכו ', אבל בשעה שאעמיד עליכם מכם ובכם הם מחפשים אחר המטמוניות שלכם וכו' ע"כ, ואין הכוונה על מטמוניות של ממון ונכסים, שגם אומה"ע משיגים לחפש אחר מטמוניות אלו, אמנם הכוונה על המטמוניות שבסתרי הלב, שאומה"ע אינם משיגים כ"כ לידע במה להכשילם, משא"כ רשעי ישראל יודעים דרכי הסתה יותר איך ליכנס לפנימיות לבבות בני ישראל ולהכניס בהם ספיקות באמונת השי"ת ותורתו הק ', וכמו שרואין בעוה"ר בדורינו הזה שקמו רשעי ישראל להפיץ ארס המינות בכל העולם כולו, עד שגם חלק גדול משומרי תורה ומצות נתפסו ברשתם בעוה"ר , וכמו"כ במצרים שהרשעים והערב רב היו מרובים פי כמה על הכשרים, והתגברו עליהם בכל תוקף להעבירם מאמונתם, והם היו הגורמים שלא שמעו אל משה עכשיו בשליחות זו אף הכשרים שבישראל, ולזה אמר הפסוק ולא שמעו אל משה, דלכאורה אל משה מיותר דמובן שסובב על משה שהוא הי' המדבר אליהם (עיין קושיא ט') ואפ"ל הכוונה דלא רק בענין הגאולה לא רצו עוד לשמוע את משה, אלא בכל דבריו של משה מה שהזהיר אותם על שמירת התורה והמצות בכולן פנו עורף מעכשיו, אף שמתחלה כתיב ויאמן העם וגו' ויקדו וישתחוו, שהיו משתוקקים להתקרב אל הקדושה, אלא שהיו משוקעים בשערי הטומאה והנסיונות הגדולים מנעו אותם, וכשראו מלאכי אלקים משה ואהרן נפלו לרגלם והיו מצפים שכח קדושתם הנשגב יסתייע להם להשתחרר מכוחות הטומאה, אולם אחר שנתגברו עליהם רשעי ישראל הפכו עורף לכל דברי מרע"ה , ולא רצו לשמוע לדבריו כלל לא בענין הגאולה ולא בשאר ענינים של שמירת התורה והמצות.
translation: And from now on, those who believed in Moshe Rabbeinu and wanted to leave were only a small minority, and they had a great trial to maintain their faith against a large majority. Moreover, when the wicked of Israel realized that the time of redemption was approaching, they exerted all their strength to undermine the faith of the righteous among the Children of Israel who believed in the tidings of redemption, and their intention was to completely delay the redemption, because they knew and understood that if Israel were to merit redemption, their end would be bitter, just as it happened to them when they died during the three days of darkness. They were a great stumbling block for Israel, more than the Egyptians, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Parashat Bechukotai) regarding the verse "And your enemies shall rule over you," that I do not establish enemies except from among you and within you. When the nations of the world stand against Israel, they seek only what is revealed, etc. But when I establish against you from among you and within you, they search for your hidden treasures, etc. Therefore, the intention is not regarding treasures of money and possessions, which the nations of the world can also seek, but rather the treasures that are in the hidden recesses of the heart, which the nations of the world do not grasp so well to know how to ensnare them. In contrast, the wicked of Israel know the ways of seduction better, how to enter into the innermost hearts of the Children of Israel and instill doubts in their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, and His holy Torah, as we see in our generation that the wicked of Israel have arisen to spread the poison of heresy throughout the entire world, to the extent that even a large part of those who observe the Torah and commandments have been caught in their net in our times. Similarly, in Egypt, the wicked and the mixed multitude were many times more numerous than the righteous, and they overpowered them with all their might to lead them away from their faith. They were the cause that even the righteous among Israel did not listen to Moshe at this time regarding this mission. Therefore, the verse states, "And they did not listen to Moshe," for seemingly the phrase "to Moshe" is superfluous, as it is understood that it refers to Moshe who was speaking to them (see the question in Talmud). One might say that the intention is that not only regarding the matter of redemption did they no longer want to listen to Moshe, but in all of Moshe's words, what he warned them about the observance of the Torah and the commandments, they turned their backs from now on. Even though at first it is written, "And the people believed," etc., and they bowed down and prostrated themselves, as they were eager to draw close to holiness, they were, however, sunk in the gates of impurity, and the great trials prevented them. And when they saw the angels of God, Moshe and Aharon, they fell at their feet, expecting that the power of their exalted holiness would assist them in freeing themselves from the forces of impurity. However, after the wicked of Israel overpowered them, they turned their backs on all the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, and they did not want to listen to his words at all, neither regarding the matter of redemption nor in other matters of observing the Torah and the commandments.
summary: The passage discusses the struggle of the faithful minority among the Israelites during the time of Moses, who faced immense challenges to maintain their belief in redemption against a majority that sought to undermine it. It highlights the danger posed by the wicked among Israel, who, unlike external enemies, know how to sow doubt in the hearts of the faithful, leading many to abandon their commitment to God and His Torah. The text emphasizes that this internal strife was a significant obstacle to the redemption, as even those who initially believed were swayed by the overwhelming influence of the wicked. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound spiritual battle between faith and doubt, particularly in the face of impending redemption.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי האלשי"ך הק ' לפרש הפסוק (משלי ד' י"ד) באורח רשעים אל תבוא ואל תאשר בדרך רעים וגו', כי לחמו לחם רשע ויין חמסים ישתו, ואורח צדיקים כאור נוגה הולך ואור עד נכון היום וז"ל כי דרכו ית ' עם משרתיו עושי רצונו, לשמור להם הבטחתו אל עולם שכולו טוב, אמנם השטן המחטיא יורה שכר עבירה נגד פניהם, ויראו דרך רשעים צלחה וצדיקים שמגיע אליהם כמעשה הרשעים, וזה אמר כי לחמו לחם רשע וגו' ומתיירא אני פן תכשל, כי הלא עיניך הרואות כי ע"י רשעתם קרובה הנאתם, כי אכלו מיד בהרעותם לחם רשעתם , וע"ז יתחמץ לבבי מדוע דרך רשעים צלחה והצדיקים דחיקא להו שעתא , ע"כ בא לתת טוב טעם ואמר ואורח צדיקים שדרך צדיקים נמשל לדרך צר ואפל בראשיתו ואחריתו רחב וטוב, וזה יאמר ואורח צדיקים שהוא דרך צר הנקרא אורח הוא להם לאור עולם, שעי"כ הוא הולך ואור עד נכון היום הבא, כאמרם ז"ל כי דרך מדחי יסורים הוא המביאה את האדם לחיי עוה"ב עכלה"ק בקיצור, ובזה יובן טעם הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, כי הרשעים שהיו מתגברין בפתויים על בנ"י הכשרים, הבטיחו להם כל טוב העוה"ז מיד, וכמו שהי' להם כל טוב ולא חסרו מאומה שהיו פטרונים אצל פרעה, וכמו"כ הבטיחו גם להם כל טוב אם ישמעו וילכו בדרכם, נמצא דהצלחת הרשעים הי' נגד פניהם, משא"כ דרכו של מרע"ה הי' קשה לעמוד בה כי לעת עתה היו צריכים עוד לסבול עול המצריים, והבטחת הטוב הוא רק על העתיד, וע"כ הטו אוזן לדברי הרשעים ולא אל דברי מרע"ה , וזה טעם הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, דלפי דבריו של משה צריכים לסבול עוד שעבוד ועבודה קשה, משא"כ לפי דבריהם של רשעי הדור יופסק מהם עול השעבוד מיד וינתן להם כל טוב העוה"ז, ומה"ט התגברו עליהם הרשעים בפתויים נגד מרע"ה .
translation: And we will precede the words of the holy Alshich to explain the verse (Proverbs 4:14) "Do not enter the path of the wicked, and do not walk in the way of evil ones," for they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence, and the path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, which shines brighter until the day is complete. And it is said that His way is with His servants who do His will, to keep for them His promise of a world that is entirely good. However, the Satan, who causes to sin, shows the reward for transgression before their faces, and they see the way of the wicked prospering, while the righteous seem to suffer as the deeds of the wicked. This is said: "For they eat the bread of wickedness," and I fear that you may stumble, for behold, your eyes see that through their wickedness their enjoyment is close, for they eat immediately through their evil deeds the bread of their wickedness. And for this my heart is pained, why the way of the wicked is prosperous and the righteous are in distress for a time. Therefore, he came to give a good reason and said: "And the path of the righteous," which is likened to a narrow and dark way at its beginning, but in the end it is wide and good. This is to say that the path of the righteous, which is a narrow way called a path, is for them a light of the world, for through it he goes and shines until the coming day, as our sages of blessed memory said, for the way of suffering leads a person to the life of the World to Come, thus concludes. And with this, the reason for the verse is understood: "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work," for the wicked who were overpowering the righteous children of Israel promised them all the good of this world immediately, and just as they had all good and lacked nothing, being patrons of Pharaoh, so too they promised them all good if they would listen and walk in their way. It turns out that the success of the wicked was before their faces, whereas the way of Moses was hard to endure, for at that time they still needed to bear the yoke of the Egyptians, and the promise of good was only for the future. Therefore, they turned their ears to the words of the wicked and not to the words of Moses. This is the reason for the verse: "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work," for according to the words of Moses, they needed to endure further servitude and hard work, whereas according to the words of the wicked of the generation, the yoke of servitude would be lifted from them immediately, and all the good of this world would be given to them. And for this reason, the wicked were strengthened against them with temptations against Moses.
summary: The passage discusses the contrasting paths of the wicked and the righteous, emphasizing that while the wicked may seem to prosper in the short term, their success is deceptive and leads to spiritual downfall. In contrast, the path of the righteous is described as narrow and difficult at first, but ultimately leads to lasting light and goodness. The text highlights the temptation faced by the Israelites, who were swayed by the immediate promises of the wicked, leading them to disregard the future rewards promised by Moses. This illustrates the struggle between immediate gratification and the enduring value of faith and perseverance in the face of hardship.

passage_content: ולדרכינו אפ"ל במאמה"כ הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי דקאי על הרוב רשעים שנקראים ג"כ בני ישראל, וע"ד שפי' בתרגום יונתן עה"פ ואמר פרעה לבנ"י נבוכים הם בארץ וגו', ויימר פרעה לדתן ואבירם בני ישראל דמשתיירין במצרים וכו ', דק"ל איך יאמר לבנ"י אחר שכבר יצאו מארצו, לכך פי' שיאמר לבנ"י המה דתן ואבירם שעמדו במרדם ונשארו במצרים ואחר שנטבעו המצרים בים נתחברו אל ישראל להחטיאם, מבואר שדתן ואבירם קראם הכתוב בני ישראל והם היו יועצי פרעה לרדוף אחר בני ישראל וכמו"כ רשעי ישראל שעלה מספרם לרבבות היו כולם מאוחדים עם המצריים ואנשי עצתם להרע לישראל כמ"ש ז"ל מכם ובכם, והמה נקראים ג"כ בני ישראל, ולפי"ז נאמר דמ"ש משה רבינו הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי אין הכוונה על בנ"י הכשרים שסבלו שעבוד קשה, ולא שמעו אליו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה דלא יוצדק לגביהם כח הק"ו , אך כוונתו הי' על רשעי ישראל דוגמת דתן ואבירם שנקראים ג"כ בשם זה כנ"ל בת"י , וז"פ הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי לא מפני קוצר רוח ועבודה קשה, אלא כח רשעתם וכח הטומאה שבהם מנע אותם לשמוע ולהאזין לדיבורי השי"ת, ואיך ישמעני פרעה שיתחזק על ידיהם יותר ולא יאבה לשמוע אלי כלל וא"ש הק"ו .
translation: And according to our path, it can be said that in the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the children of Israel did not listen to Me, referring to the majority of the wicked who are also called the children of Israel. This is in line with what is explained in the Targum Yonatan on the verse where Pharaoh said to the children of Israel, "They are confused in the land," etc. Pharaoh then referred to Datan and Aviram, the children of Israel who remained in Egypt, etc. The question arises: how could he say to the children of Israel after they had already left their land? Therefore, it is explained that he was referring to the children of Israel, namely Datan and Aviram, who stood in rebellion and remained in Egypt, and after the Egyptians were drowned in the sea, they joined with Israel to lead them astray. It is clear that the scripture calls Datan and Aviram the children of Israel, and they were advisors to Pharaoh in pursuing the children of Israel. Likewise, the wicked of Israel, whose number rose to the thousands, were all united with the Egyptians and their counsel to do evil to Israel, as our sages have said, "from you and with you," and they are also called the children of Israel. According to this, when Moses our teacher said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to Me," he was not referring to the righteous children of Israel who suffered under hard labor and did not listen to him due to shortness of spirit and hard work, for it would not be justified regarding them as a fortiori. Rather, his intention was towards the wicked of Israel, like Datan and Aviram, who are also called by this name, as mentioned above in the Targum. Thus, it is clear that when he said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to Me," it was not due to shortness of spirit and hard work, but rather the power of their wickedness and the impurity within them prevented them from hearing and listening to the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And how will Pharaoh listen to me, that he should strengthen himself through them even more and not want to listen to me at all? And this is understood as a fortiori.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the righteous and the wicked among the Israelites, particularly focusing on figures like Datan and Aviram, who, despite being called "children of Israel," actively opposed Moses and aligned with Pharaoh. It emphasizes that the refusal of the wicked to listen to God's message is not due to their suffering but rather stems from their inherent evil and spiritual impurity. This highlights a theological insight that the presence of wickedness can obstruct divine communication, illustrating the struggle between righteousness and sin within the community of Israel. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true listening and obedience to God are contingent upon one's moral and spiritual state.

passage_content: והנה הגם שמאמר ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח סובב בהכרח על הכשרים שבישראל שהיו אנוסים ולטעם זה לא שמעו, אולם מאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי אפ"ל דהכוונה על רשעי ישראל, ויתחלק הכתוב לנושאים מחולפים וכעין שפי' הרמב"ן הק ' (פ' בשלח) עה"כ ופרעה הקריב וגו' וייראו מאוד ויצעקו בנ"י אל ה' ויאמרו אל משה המבלי אין קברים במצרים וגו', וזל"ק איננו נראה כי בנ"א הצועקים אל ה' להושיעם, יבעטו בישועה אשר עשה להם ויאמרו כי טוב להם שלא הצילם, אבל הנכון שנפרש הם כתות, והכתוב יספר כל מה שעשו כולם, אמר כי הכת האחת צועקת אל ה', והאחרת מכחשת בנביאן ואינה בוחרת בישועה הנעשית להם וכו' עיי"ש, ועד"ז נפרש הכתוב כאן בנושאים שונים זה מזה, ומה שאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי וגו' איננו אותם שהזכיר במאמר ולא שמעו וגו', מקוצר רוח וגו' וכנ"ל, ולדרכינו יובן מ"ש משרע"ה ואני ערל שפתים אף שכבר אמר כבד פה וכבד לשון אנכי והשיב הקב"ה מי שם פה לאדם וגו' הלא אנכי ה' (עיין קושיא י'), אמנם אז נצטוה לדבר אל פרעה בשליחותו ית ' וע"ז טען כבד פה וכבד לשון אנכי ואיני ראוי לדבר אל המלך. והשיבו הקב"ה מי שם פה לאדם וגו' שיתרפא לשונו ויהי' ראוי לדבר לפני המלך, אבל כאן נתגלה לעיניו גודל רעתם של רשעי ישראל איך שהשפיעו על בנ"י הכשרים למנעם מלשמוע אליו, ועדיין לא הי' לו הבטחה ע"ז שיוכל לדבר גם אל רשעי ישראל ויכנסו דבריו בלבם , ומשרע"ה הי' משתוקק להמשיך אל הקדושה גם אותם, ולזה אמר דלפי שהם משוקעים כ"כ בטומאה, לא יתקבל על לבם דיבורי קדושה, ואני ערל שפתים שאין לי דיבורים אליהם ואיך אוכל להחזירם למוטב.
translation: And behold, even though the statement "and they did not listen to Moses" necessarily refers to the righteous among Israel who were coerced and for this reason did not listen, however, the statement "but the children of Israel did not listen to me" can be understood as referring to the wicked of Israel. The text can be divided into different subjects, similar to what Ramban explained (in Parashat Beshalach) regarding the verse "and Pharaoh drew near... and the children of Israel cried out to the Lord and said to Moses, 'Is it because there are no graves in Egypt...'" The implication is that it does not seem that the people are crying out to the Lord to save them, but rather they kick against the salvation that He has done for them and say that it is better for them that He did not save them. However, it is correct to interpret that they are factions, and the text recounts all that they did. It states that one faction cries out to the Lord, while the other denies His prophet and does not choose the salvation that is being done for them, etc. Thus, we can interpret the text here as referring to different subjects from one another, and what is said "but the children of Israel did not listen to me" is not the same as those mentioned in the statement "and they did not listen" due to shortness of spirit, as mentioned above. According to our approach, we can understand what is said about Moshe Rabbeinu, "and I am of uncircumcised lips," even though he already said, "I am heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue," and the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded, "Who made man's mouth..." Is it not I, the Lord? (see question Y). However, then he was commanded to speak to Pharaoh in His name, and for this he claimed, "I am heavy of mouth and heavy of tongue; I am not worthy to speak to the king." And the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded, "Who made man's mouth..." that his tongue would be healed and he would be worthy to speak before the king. But here he was shown the great wickedness of the wicked of Israel and how they influenced the righteous among Israel to prevent them from listening to him. And he still did not have a promise regarding this that he could speak even to the wicked of Israel and that his words would enter their hearts. And since Moshe Rabbeinu longed to bring holiness even to them, he said that because they are so deeply immersed in impurity, the words of holiness would not be accepted in their hearts, and I am of uncircumcised lips, for I have no words for them, and how can I bring them back to the good.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the righteous and the wicked among the Israelites, emphasizing that the latter's rejection of Moses' message stems from their deep moral corruption. It highlights the struggle of Moses, who feels inadequate to communicate with the wicked due to their spiritual state, despite his previous encounters with God. The text reflects on the tension between divine communication and human receptivity, illustrating the challenge of reaching those entrenched in sin. Ultimately, it underscores the hope for redemption, as Moses yearns to uplift even the most fallen among his people.

passage_content: או אפשר לפרש שמשה רבינו התפלל גם על הרשעים שינצלו ויזכו לצאת מהגלות, אבל ראתה חכמתו ית ' שטוב יותר להפרידם מעל ישראל, וע"כ לא נתקבלה תפלתו עליהם, ומשרע"ה הרגיש בזה וע"ד שאמרז"ל ברחב"ד (ברכות דף ל"ד ע"א) שאמר אם שגורה תפלתי בפי יודע אני שהוא מקובל, וז"פ ואני ערל שפתים שתפלתו עליהם אינו שגורה בפי, וזהו סימן שלא נתקבלה וכאשר הי' להם באמת שמתו בג' ימי אפילה ולא זכו לצאת ממצרים, ולפי"ז א"ש הקישור לדלעיל מיני' שאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי, והכוונה על דתן ואבירם וכת דלהון שבגודל רשעתם לא רצו לשמוע אל משה, ולכך התנצל ואמר ואני ערל שפתים שתפלתי לא נתקבל עבורם, או ע"ד הנ"ל שאיני יכול להחזירם בתשובה ולא עשו דיבורי רושם אצלם, וע"ז בא תשובתו ית ' במאמה"כ וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה מלך מצרים להוציא את בנ"י מארץ מצרים שנצטוו משה ואהרן לדבר עוה"פ אל רשעי הדור ואל פרעה, ויש בזה הבטחה שיועילו דבריהם להוציא את בני ישראל הכשרים מארץ מצרים ולא ימנעו בהם פרעה והערב רב שבישראל, וז"ש במדרש תנחומא ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה עשה אותם שוים , ואין הכוונה על בנ"י הכשרים שא"א להשוותם לפרעה, רק על הרשעים שלא רצו לשמוע אל משה והם שוים לפרעה ואליהם נצטוה עכשיו לדבר, להוציא את בנ"י הכשרים דייק לומר את לרבות שכינה הקדושה כביכול עמו אנכי בצרה, דאלו בנ"י שהשכינה עמהם בגלות הם יצאו מארץ מצרים, ויועילו דבריכם להפריד בנ"י הכשרים מהערב רב וינצלו מהסתתם, ומתפלתו של מרע"ה נמשך ישועה לכל הדורות שהמיעוט הכשרים ינצלו מהתגברות הרוב שעומדים לנגדם, וכ"ז עפי"ד המדרש תנחומא יתכן לפרש ויצום אל בנ"י על בנ"י הרשעים ומה"ט השוה אותם לפרעה.
translation: It is also possible to interpret that Moshe Rabbeinu prayed for the wicked to be saved and merit to leave the exile, but the wisdom of the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that it is better to separate them from Israel. Therefore, his prayer for them was not accepted. When Moshe realized this, as it is stated in the Sages' teaching in Berachot (34a), that he said, "If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know it is accepted," and this is the meaning of "I am of uncircumcised lips," that his prayer for them is not fluent in his mouth, which is a sign that it was not accepted. And indeed, they truly died during the three days of darkness and did not merit to leave Egypt. According to this, it is understandable the connection to the earlier statement that he said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me," referring to Datan and Aviram and their faction, who, due to their great wickedness, did not want to listen to Moshe. Therefore, he excused himself and said, "I am of uncircumcised lips," that my prayer was not accepted for them, or in the sense that I cannot bring them to repentance, and my words did not make an impression on them. In response to this, the Holy One, blessed be He, spoke to Moshe and Aharon and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt. They were commanded to speak to the wicked of the generation and to Pharaoh, and there is a promise that their words will be effective in bringing the righteous children of Israel out of Egypt, and Pharaoh and the mixed multitude among Israel will not prevent them. This is what is said in the Midrash Tanchuma, "And He commanded the children of Israel and Pharaoh," making them equal. The intention is not regarding the righteous children of Israel, as it is impossible to compare them to Pharaoh, but rather regarding the wicked who did not want to listen to Moshe, and they are equal to Pharaoh, and to them he was now commanded to speak, to bring out the righteous children of Israel. It is precise to say that this includes the Divine Presence, as it were, "I am with him in distress," for those children of Israel with whom the Divine Presence is in exile will leave the land of Egypt, and your words will help to separate the righteous children of Israel from the mixed multitude and they will be saved from their oppression. From the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu, salvation extends to all generations, that the minority of the righteous will be saved from the overwhelming majority that stands against them. All this can be explained according to the Midrash Tanchuma, that it is possible to interpret "And He commanded the children of Israel" as referring to the wicked children of Israel, and for this reason, He equated them with Pharaoh.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' prayer for the wicked to be saved from exile, which was ultimately not accepted by God, as it was deemed better to separate them from Israel. It highlights the idea that the wicked, like Datan and Aviram, were resistant to Moses' message, leading to God's command for Moses and Aaron to address both the Israelites and Pharaoh. This reflects the assurance that their words would help redeem the righteous from Egypt, emphasizing the connection between the Divine presence with the righteous and the importance of their separation from the wicked. The text underscores the enduring impact of Moses' prayer, suggesting that the salvation of the righteous minority throughout generations is linked to this divine intervention.

passage_content: אמנם לפי מה שפרש"י ז"ל צום עליהם להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, מבואר שהציווי הי' אל בנ"י הכשרים נל"פ מאמה"כ באופן אחר, בהקדם דברי ק"ז בייט"פ עה"פ כי ידעתיו למען אשר יצוה את בניו ואת ביתו אחריו ושמרו דרך ה' לעשות צדקה ומשפט למען הביא ה' על אברהם את אשר דיבר עליו, ולכאורה תמוה וכי אאע"ה עבד עבודת השי"ת על מנת לקבל פרס, ופי' עפי"ד הרמב"ם ז"ל סוף ה' תשובה (ה"ה) וז"ל אמרו חכמים לעולם יעסוק אדם בתורה ואפילו שלא לשמה שמתוך שלא לשמה בא לשמה, לפיכך כשמלמדין את הקטנים ועמי הארץ אין מלמדין אותן אלא לעבוד מיראה וכדי לקבל שכר עד שתרבה דעתן וכו ', ומרגילין אותן לענין זה בנחת עד שישיגוהו וידעוהו ויעבדוהו מאהבה עכ"ל הרמב"ם ז"ל, וזשה"כ למען אשר יצוה את בניו ואת ביתו וגו' ושמרו דרך ה' למען הביא ה' על אברהם וגו' דאף שאאע"ה בעצמותו עבד מאהבה, עכ"ז כשצוה לבניו וב"ב, ציום למען הביא וגו' שזה בשביל קבלת פרס, וכדי להרגילם לעבודה עד שיבואו לעבוד מאהבה עבודה תמה וישרה עכלה"ק , ועד"ז יתבאר לענינינו עפי"מ שפירשנו לעיל ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה עפי"ד האלשיך הק ' עה"כ כי לחמו לחם רשע וגו', שסיבת הטעם שאף הכשרים שבישראל לא שמעו אל משה, מפני שהע"ר ורשעי ישראל הבטיחו להם טוב עוה"ז כמו שהי' להם כל טוב ולא חסר להם מאומה, וע"כ לפי בחינתם של אותה שעה והנסיונות שהי' להם א"א לצוותם שיהי' עבודתם שלא ע"מ לקבל פרס, אמנם משה רבינו הי' מופשט מגשמיות עוה"ז לגמרי והי' דבוק תמיד בעולמות העליונים ע"כ כשבא אל בנ"י בשליחותו דיבר עמהם כפי בחינתו לעבוד מאהבה ושלא עמלק"פ , ודבר זה הי' קשה להם לקבל אז ולטעם זה לא שמעו אל משה וע"כ צוה הקב"ה למשה ואהרן להנהיגם בנחת וללמדם עמלק"פ עד שישיגו ויעבדו מאהבה, וז"פ ויצום אל בנ"י וכפרש"י ז"ל צוה עליהם להנהיגם בנחת והכוונה על בנ"י הכשרים, שיבטיח להם שאם ילכו בדרך השם יזכו לישועה וינצלו מכל צרה וצוקה. והאמנם שאין זה דרך השלימות לעבוד ע"מ לקבל פרס, אבל ראתה חכמתו ית ' שההכרח להרגילם בתחלה ע"מ לקבל פרס ועי"ז ינצלו מהסתת הרשעים.
translation:
Indeed, according to what Rashi, of blessed memory, explained, the fast was upon them to lead them gently and to bear with them. It is clear that the command was to the righteous among the Children of Israel, as derived from the verse, "For I have known him, that he will command his children and his household after him, and they shall keep the way of the Lord, to do righteousness and justice, that the Lord may bring upon Abraham that which He has spoken of him." At first glance, it is puzzling: did our forefather Abraham serve the Holy One, blessed be He, in order to receive a reward? The explanation according to the Rambam, of blessed memory, at the end of the Laws of Repentance (Chapter 10) states: "The sages said, a person should always engage in Torah even if not for its own sake, for from not for its own sake, he will come to do it for its own sake." Therefore, when teaching children and the common people, one does not teach them except to serve out of fear and to receive a reward until their understanding increases, etc. They are accustomed to this matter gently until they attain it, know it, and serve it out of love. Thus, the verse "that he will command his children and his household" and "they shall keep the way of the Lord" is for the purpose of bringing upon Abraham, etc., that even though Abraham himself served out of love, nevertheless, when he commanded his children and his household, it was a command for the purpose of receiving a reward, and to accustom them to service until they come to serve out of love, a complete and straight service. 

Similarly, this will be explained in our matter according to what we have explained above, that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, according to the explanation of the Alshich, of blessed memory, on the verse "for they made their lives bitter with hard service," that the reason why even the righteous among Israel did not listen to Moses was because the wicked and the evildoers of Israel promised them good in this world, just as they had all good and lacked nothing. Therefore, according to their state at that time and the trials they faced, it was impossible to command them that their service should be not for the sake of receiving a reward. However, our teacher Moses was completely detached from the physicality of this world and was always attached to the higher worlds. Therefore, when he came to the Children of Israel in his mission, he spoke to them according to his level to serve out of love and not for the sake of reward. This was difficult for them to accept at that time, and for this reason, they did not listen to Moses. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Moses and Aaron to lead them gently and to teach them for the sake of reward until they would attain and serve out of love. And this is the meaning of "and He commanded the Children of Israel," as Rashi, of blessed memory, explained, commanded them to lead them gently, and the intention is towards the righteous among the Children of Israel, to assure them that if they walk in the way of the Lord, they will merit salvation and be saved from all trouble and distress. Indeed, it is not the way of perfection to serve for the sake of receiving a reward, but the wisdom of the Blessed One saw that it was necessary to accustom them at first to serve for the sake of receiving a reward, and through this, they would be saved from the enticement of the wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of initially guiding the righteous among the Jewish people to serve God out of a desire for reward, as a means to eventually lead them to serve out of love. It references the teachings of the Rambam, emphasizing that while Abraham served God out of love, his command to his descendants was framed in terms of reward to instill proper behavior. The text highlights the challenges faced by the Israelites, who were influenced by their circumstances and the promises of the wicked, necessitating a gentle approach to teaching them. Ultimately, this method aims to prepare them for a more profound and sincere devotion to God.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר מה שדרשו רז"ל ויאמר אליו אני ה' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו ', ויש בזה תשובה על טענת משרע"ה למה הרעתה לעם הזה, דהנה משרע"ה ראה דאחר שהלך בשליחותו לבשר גאולתם של ישראל, נעשו משוקעים יותר ולא רצו עוד לשמוע אל דבריו מפני שנתגברו עליהם רשעי ישראל וכנ"ל, לזה טען למה הרעתה לעם הזה ולמה זה שלחתני שע"י שליחותי נעשו ישראל רעים וחטאים יותר, וע"ז השיב לו השי"ת אני ה' נאמן לשלם שכר ר"ל שיאמר כן לישראל, דמפני שהרשעים מבטיחים להם טוב העוה"ז מיד, ע"כ א"א לקרבם לעבודתו ית ' בהבטחה רחוקה בתשלום גמול לעוה"ב, אלא תאמר להם אני ה' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני, ותדריכם בדרך הזה שיתקרבו לדרך התורה ע"מ לקבל פרס, וסרה בזה קושיא הנ"ל (קושיא א') כי הודעה זו אני ה' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו' נאמרה למשרע"ה ע"מ שיאמרנה לישראל, אף שאין זה דרך השלימות ומשרע"ה בעצמותו הי' רחוק ומופשט מבחי ' זו, מ"מ הי' הכרח לזה לפי מצב הדור וכובד הנסיונות , ונצטוה משרע"ה להנהיגם בנחת ולהרגילם בהתחלת העבודה ע"מ לקבל פרס.
translation: And this will clarify what our Sages of Blessed Memory interpreted, "And He said to him, I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward," etc. There is a response to Moshe Rabbeinu's complaint, "Why have You harmed this people?" For Moshe Rabbeinu saw that after he went on his mission to announce the redemption of Israel, they became even more sunk and no longer wanted to listen to his words because the wicked of Israel had overpowered them, as mentioned above. Therefore, he argued, "Why have You harmed this people, and why have You sent me, since through my mission the Israelites have become worse and more sinful?" To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward," meaning that he should say this to Israel. Because the wicked promise them immediate good in this world, it is impossible to draw them closer to His service with a distant promise of reward in the World to Come. Rather, he should tell them, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Me," and guide them in this way so that they will draw closer to the path of the Torah in order to receive a reward. And thus the above question (Question 1) is resolved, for this announcement, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward," etc., was said to Moshe Rabbeinu so that he would convey it to Israel, even though this is not the way of perfection and Moshe Rabbeinu himself was inherently distant and abstracted from this aspect. Nevertheless, it was necessary for him according to the state of the generation and the weight of the trials, and Moshe Rabbeinu was commanded to lead them gently and to accustom them to the beginning of the service in order to receive a reward.
summary: The passage discusses the response of God to Moses' complaint about the suffering of the Israelites after he began his mission to redeem them. God reassures Moses that He is faithful to reward those who walk in His ways, emphasizing the need to encourage the Israelites to serve Him with the promise of reward, even if this approach is not the highest spiritual level. This guidance is necessary due to the challenges and trials faced by the generation, highlighting the importance of adapting spiritual leadership to the needs of the people.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל באמרם ז"ל צוה להנהיגם בנחת עפי"מ שפירשתי מה דאיתא במד"ר (פ' בא פ' ט"ז סי' ב') עה"פ משכו וקחו לכם צאן וגו' הה"ד ( ישעי ' ל') בשובה ונחת תושעון , דהנה דרשו חכז"ל משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן למצוה , ולכאורה הלא אינו מועיל תשובה לחוד כדאיתא בגמרא (יומא פ"ו ע"א) עבר על כריתות ומיתת ב"ד תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, אמנם כתב הט"ז ריש הלכות שבת על מה שארז"ל (שבת קי"ח ע"ב) כל השומר שבת כהלכתה אפי' עובד ע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו, דמיירי שעשה תשובה אלא דהתשובה לחוד לא מהני בע"ז, קמ"ל כאן דאם בעשותו תשובה שומר שבת כהלכתו, מהני תשובה שיהא נמחל לו עכת"ד ז"ל, והנה איתא במד"ר (קהלת ד') טוב כף מלא נחת, זה יום השבת ממלא חפנים עמל ורעות רוח אלו ששת ימי המעשה, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל משכו וקחו לכם צאן, הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון ר"ל ע"י תשובה בצירוף שמירת שבת תושעון ויועיל לכפר על חטא ע"ז, ואפשר שנרמז זה באמרז"ל צוה להנהיגם בנחת ר"ל להשריש בקרבם שמירת השבת, ועי"ז יועיל תשובתם ויהי' נשפע עליהם קדושה וטהרה ויתקרבו להשי"ת .
translation: It can also be said, as our sages of blessed memory stated, that He commanded to lead them gently, as I explained regarding what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Bo, section 16, item 2) on the verse "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," which is similar to the verse (Isaiah 30) "In returning and rest you shall be saved." Behold, our sages have interpreted that "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for a mitzvah." At first glance, it seems that repentance alone is not sufficient, as it is stated in the Gemara (Yoma 86a) that if one transgresses the prohibitions of karet and the death penalty of the court, repentance suspends [the punishment] but death atones. However, the Taz wrote at the beginning of the laws of Shabbat regarding what our sages said (Shabbat 118b) that anyone who observes Shabbat properly, even if he worships idols like the generation of Enosh, he is forgiven. This refers to one who has repented, but repentance alone is not effective for idolatry. Here it teaches us that if, in doing repentance, he observes Shabbat properly, repentance is effective for him to be forgiven, as stated by our sages. And it is stated in the Midrash (Ecclesiastes 4) "Better is a handful of rest," this refers to the day of Shabbat which fills the hands with labor and vexation of spirit, these are the six days of work. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," which is similar to "In returning and rest you shall be saved," meaning through repentance combined with the observance of Shabbat, you shall be saved and it will help atone for the sin of idolatry. And it is possible that this is hinted at in the statement of our sages "He commanded to lead them gently," meaning to instill within them the observance of Shabbat, and through this their repentance will be effective, and holiness and purity will be poured upon them, and they will draw closer to the Holy One, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of leading a life of tranquility and observance of the Sabbath as a means to achieve repentance and atonement for sins, particularly idolatry. It emphasizes that while repentance alone may not suffice for certain transgressions, combining it with proper Sabbath observance can lead to forgiveness. The text highlights the idea that nurturing a commitment to the Sabbath instills holiness and purity, ultimately drawing individuals closer to God. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of integrating spiritual practice with daily life to attain divine connection and redemption.
