passage_content: ואפשר שירמוז הכתוב וארא אל אברהם ואל יצחק ואל יעקב וגו' הכוונה בו על ההוה , כי היו שם האבוה"ק בעצמם ובזכותם שמע הקב"ה נאקתם של ישראל, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל וארא אל האבות שזכות האבות סייע להם, והבטיח הקב"ה להם וגם הקימותי את בריתי אתם, ר"ל על אותם הזמנים שלא יהי' עוד זכות אבות אושיע את ישראל בכח ברית אבות, וז"ש וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל בעבר, שהי' להם במצרים זכות אבות ובזכותם שמעתי תפלתם של ישראל, ואזכור את בריתי בכל הדורות אף לאחר שתמה זכות אבות אזכור להם ברית אבות.
translation: And it is possible that the verse "And I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob" refers to the present, for the Patriarchs themselves were there, and by their merit, the Holy One, Blessed be He, heard the cries of Israel. This is what Rashi, of blessed memory, means when he says "I appeared to the Patriarchs," that the merit of the Patriarchs assisted them, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised them, "And I will also establish My covenant with them," meaning that in those times when the merit of the Patriarchs will no longer exist, I will save Israel by the strength of the covenant of the Patriarchs. This is what is meant by "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," for they had the merit of the Patriarchs in Egypt, and by their merit, I heard the prayers of Israel. And I will remember My covenant in all generations, even after the merit of the Patriarchs has ceased, I will remember the covenant of the Patriarchs for them.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—in relation to God's covenant with the Israelites. It emphasizes that their merit allowed God to hear the cries of the Israelites in Egypt, highlighting the enduring power of the patriarchs' righteousness. Even after the merit of the patriarchs has diminished, God promises to remember the covenant made with them and to continue to support the Israelites. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the lasting impact of the righteous on future generations and God's unwavering commitment to His promises.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד', דקדקו המפרשים דהתחיל הכתוב בשם אלקים מדת הדין, וסיים אני ד' שם הרחמים, גם שהתחיל וידבר דיבור קשה ומסיים ויאמר אמירה רכה.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord." The commentators note that the verse begins with the name of God, which represents the attribute of judgment, and concludes with "I am the Lord," which signifies the attribute of mercy. Furthermore, it begins with "spoke," a harsh expression, and ends with "said," a gentle expression.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the contrast between the names of God—Elohim, representing the attribute of justice, and the Tetragrammaton (YHWH), symbolizing mercy—is highlighted. The text notes that God begins His communication with a stern "speaking" (dibur) and concludes with a gentle "saying" (amira), reflecting a transition from strict judgment to compassionate guidance. This duality emphasizes the balance between divine justice and mercy, a key theme in Hasidic thought, illustrating how God's interactions with humanity encompass both severity and kindness.

translation: 3) "I did not make Myself known to them," as Rashi explains, "I did not reveal Myself to them in My true measure, for which My name is called 'Faithful to the truth of My words,' since I promised them and did not fulfill it, etc." The commentators question, however, that initially there was the promise that "the fourth generation will return here," and the time for the promise of inheriting the land has not yet arrived, while other promises that the Holy One, blessed be He, made regarding the seed and protection from enemies have all been fulfilled, and there is no place for complaint at all.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of God's name and His faithfulness to truth, emphasizing that God's promises, while seemingly unfulfilled at times, are ultimately reliable. The text addresses the apparent contradiction between God's assurances and their realization, particularly regarding the promise of returning to the land and the inheritance of the land. It highlights that many of God's promises have indeed been fulfilled, suggesting that the timing of divine promises may not align with human expectations, yet they remain steadfast and true. This reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of faith and the understanding of divine timing in the fulfillment of promises.

passage_content: ד) כתב רש"י ז"ל רבותינו דרשוהו לענין של מעלה שאמר משה למה הרעותה , א"ל הקב"ה חבל על דאבדין וכו' יש לי להתאונן על מיתת האבות, הרבה פעמים נגליתי עליהם בשם שי"ן דל"ת יו"ד, ולא אמרו לי מה שמך, ואתה אמרת מה שמו מה אומר אליהם, ואין המדרש מתיישב אחר המקרא מפני כמה דברים, שלא נאמר ושמי ד' לא שאלו לי. וא"ת לא הודיעם שכך שמו והרי כ"פ דבר אליהם בשם הוי' בברית בין הבתרים ובפרשת המילה, ועוד קשה לדבריהם איך נמשך מאמר הזה לפסוקים שלאחריו וגם אני שמעתי וגו' לכן אמור לבנ"י וגו' לכך אני אומר יתיישב המקרא על פשוטו וכו' עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל והראב"ע והרמב"ן ז"ל מתרצים דרשת רבותינו ז"ל, דהכוונה דבבחינת שם הוי' לא נגלה הקב"ה לאבות הקדושים לברוא להם חדשות בשנוי התולדות, ולעשות להם נסים חוץ לדרך הטבע אבל נגלה להם בבחי ' השם שי"ן דל"ת יו"ד שהוא מנצח מערכות השמים, לעשות עמם נסים גדולים שלא נתבטל בהם נוהג העולם, ברעב פדה אותם ממות, ובמלחמה מידי חרב וכו' עיי"ש, אולם עדיין אינו מתורץ לפי דבריהם מה שהקשה רש"י, דאיך נמשך המאמר הזה לפסוקים שלאחריו וגם אני שמעתי וגו' וצ"ב .
translation: 4) Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote that our sages interpreted this in relation to the upper realms, as Moses said, "Why have You harmed?" The Holy One, blessed be He, replied, "It is a pity for what is lost..." I have reason to lament the death of the patriarchs; many times I revealed Myself to them with the name Shindalet Yud, and they did not ask Me, "What is Your name?" Yet you asked, "What is His name, what shall I say to them?" And the midrash does not align with the verse for several reasons, as it was not said, "And My name, the Lord, they did not ask Me." And if you say that He did not inform them that this is His name, behold, He spoke to them many times in the name of the Lord in the covenant between the parts and in the section of circumcision. Furthermore, it is difficult according to their words how this statement connects to the verses that follow, "And I have also heard..." Therefore, I say that the verse should be understood in its simple meaning, etc. Thus far is Rashi, may his memory be blessed. And the Ra'avad and the Ramban, may their memories be blessed, explain our sages' interpretation, that the intention is that in the aspect of the name of the Lord, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not reveal Himself to the holy patriarchs to create new things by changing the natural order, nor to perform miracles outside of the way of nature, but He revealed Himself to them in the aspect of the name Shindalet Yud, which conquers the hosts of heaven, to perform great miracles with them without nullifying the natural order, redeeming them from death in famine, and from the sword in war, etc. However, it is still not resolved according to their words what Rashi questioned, how this statement connects to the verses that follow, "And I have also heard..." and it remains a question.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of God's revelation to the patriarchs, emphasizing that while He appeared to them using the name associated with natural order, He did not disclose the name YHWH, which signifies a deeper, transformative relationship. This distinction highlights that the patriarchs were not privy to the full scope of God's identity and power, which would later be revealed to Moses. The text reflects on the tension between divine revelation and human understanding, suggesting that the nature of God's name influences the miracles and interventions in the world. Ultimately, it raises questions about the continuity of divine communication and the unfolding of God's plan through history.

passage_content: ה) ( פ"ר ו' ס"ב) א"ל הקב"ה למשה אני הכתבתי עליך שאתה עניו, ואתה מקפיד על דברי, חייך יש לך לידע, שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו. טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים, עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה ענין ענו' להכא , ומהו כוונת התשובה טוב אחרית דבר וצ"ב .
translation: 5) (P.R. 6:62) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: "I have written about you that you are humble, and you are particular about My words. By your life, you should know that it is stated, 'The end of a matter is better than its beginning.' The good end of Israel is better than the beginning I gave them in Egypt." Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is fitting to understand what the matter of humility has to do with this, and what the intent of the response 'The end of a matter' is, and it requires clarification.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, God tells Moses that He has written about Moses' humility, yet Moses is concerned about God's words. The phrase "the end of a matter is better than its beginning" suggests that the ultimate outcome for the Israelites, starting from their time in Egypt, is positive. This highlights the Hasidic concept that humility is essential in understanding divine providence and the unfolding of events, emphasizing that the true value of a situation may only be revealed in its conclusion.

translation: 7) In Parashat Va'era, it is written that Moses spoke thus to the Children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. summary: In this passage, the text highlights the struggle of the Israelites to listen to Moses due to their overwhelming suffering and hardship. The repetition of the phrase "and they did not listen to Moses" emphasizes the depth of their despair and spiritual disconnection. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that external circumstances can profoundly affect one's ability to connect with spiritual leadership and divine guidance. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of compassion and understanding in the face of human suffering.

passage_content: ח) מ"ש מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, נתינת טעם זה צ"ב, דאדרבה מכח טעם זה הי"ל לשמוע, כמ"ש לעיל בפ ' שמות ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' את בנ"י וכי ראה את ענים ויקדו וישתחוו. ובמכילתא הקשו כן, וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח וכו ', א"כ מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, והי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז עכ"ל המכילתא, ועדיין צ"ב מה נשתנה דעתם, דמתחלה שמחו בבשורת הגאולה כמשה"כ ויקדו וישתחוו, ועכשיו לא שמעו אל משה וצ"ב .
translation: (8) Regarding what is said about shortness of spirit and hard work, the reason for this is questionable, for on the contrary, due to this reason they should have listened, as mentioned above in Parashat Shemot, "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, and they bowed their heads and worshipped." And in the Mekilta they posed a similar question: "Is there a person who receives good news and is not happy, etc.?" If so, what does it mean that they did not listen to Moses? Rather, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, and it was hard in their eyes to separate from idolatry, thus concludes the Mekilta. Yet, it is still questionable what changed their minds, for initially they rejoiced at the tidings of redemption, as it is written, "and they bowed their heads and worshipped," and now they did not listen to Moses, and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' initial joy upon hearing the news of their impending redemption, contrasted with their later refusal to listen to Moses. It raises the question of why they became disheartened despite the promise of salvation, suggesting that their suffering and hard labor led to a spiritual numbness that made it difficult for them to embrace the message of hope. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the struggle between faith and despair, highlighting the challenges of maintaining spiritual awareness in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ט) בפרשה הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, פרש"י ז"ל בשם המדרש זה א' מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה והקשו המפורשים דק"ו פריכא הוא. דמה שלא שמעו ישראל הי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה כמפורש בכתוב, משא"כ פרעה שלא הי"ל קוצר רוח ולא עבודה קשה, ולא ראוי זה כראוי זה.
translation: In the section, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips," Rashi, of blessed memory, explains in the name of the Midrash that this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah. The commentators have questioned that an a fortiori argument is problematic, for the reason that the children of Israel did not listen due to shortness of spirit and hard work, as is explicitly stated in the text, whereas Pharaoh did not have shortness of spirit nor hard work, and this is not fitting to compare one to the other.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the verse where the Israelites did not listen to God due to their anguish and hard labor, contrasting their situation with that of Pharaoh, who lacked such burdens. The text highlights the theological concept of divine communication and the human condition, suggesting that the Israelites' inability to hear God's message stemmed from their suffering, while Pharaoh's lack of similar hardships makes his refusal to listen less justifiable. This reflects a deeper understanding of the relationship between suffering, spiritual receptivity, and the nature of divine expectation.

passage_content: י) צ"ב מ"ש ואני ערל שפתים, דעל טענה זו כבר השיב לו השי"ת מי שם פה לאדם, גם צירף עמו את אהרן שיהי' לו לפה ולמליץ, ולמה חזר מרע"ה עוד הפעם על טענתו הקודמת.
translation: 11) It is puzzling what is meant by "I am of uncircumcised lips," for to this claim the Holy One, Blessed be He, already responded to him, "Who made man's mouth?" He also joined with him Aaron, to be his mouth and advocate. So why did Moshe Rabbeinu return once again to his previous claim?
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on Moses' claim of being "uncircumcised of lips," which signifies his feelings of inadequacy in speaking. God responds by reminding Moses that He is the one who gives speech to humanity and appoints Aaron as his spokesperson. The repetition of Moses' objection highlights the deep struggle between self-doubt and divine purpose, emphasizing the theme of reliance on divine assistance in fulfilling one's mission. This interaction illustrates the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of faith and the importance of community support in spiritual endeavors.

passage_content: יא) בפרשה כי ידבר אלכם פרעה לאמר תנו לכם מופת, ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך וגו', במד"ר (פ' ט' סי' א') ר"פ הכהן בר"ח פתח, ( ישעי ' מ"ו) מגיד מראשית אחרית וגו' שהגיד הקב"ה למשה מראשית אחרית, אם ידבר אלכם פרעה אכ"כ , אלא כי ידבר, עתיד הוא לומר לכם כן עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב וכי צריך ראי' ודרשא ללמוד זה שהקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית: ומהו כוונת דרשתם ז"ל בזה.
translation: 11) In the section "When Pharaoh speaks to you saying, 'Give yourselves a sign,'" you shall say to Aaron, "Take your staff," etc. (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'era, Section 1) Rabbi Pinchas the Kohen opened (with Isaiah 46:10), "Declaring the end from the beginning," which teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, informed Moses from the beginning about the end. If Pharaoh speaks to you, thus, it is future that he will say to you this. So says the Midrash. And it is puzzling: does one need a proof and a teaching to learn that the Holy One, Blessed be He, declares from the beginning about the end? And what is the intent of their teaching, may their memory be blessed, in this?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the Midrashic interpretation of God's communication to Moses regarding Pharaoh's future demands for signs. The key Hasidic concept highlighted is the idea that God reveals the end from the beginning, indicating a divine foreknowledge of events. This underscores the belief that God's guidance is present even in challenging circumstances, suggesting that the unfolding of history is part of a greater divine plan. The inquiry into the necessity of such a revelation emphasizes the importance of understanding God's providence in the face of adversity.

passage_content: יב פרעה לחכמים ולמכשפים ויעשו גם הם חרטמי מצרים בלהטיהם כן, אמרז"ל במדרש רבה (פ' ט' סי' ו') באותה שעה התחיל פרעה משחק עליהם ומקרקר אחריהם כתרנגולת, ואמר להם כך אותותיו של הקב"ה וכו ', שלח והביא תינוקות מן אסכולי שלהם, ועשו אף הם כך וכו' שנא' ויעשו גם הם: מהו גם שאפי' תינוקות של ד' וה' שנים קרא ועשו כן, ולכאורה קשה, הרי הקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית, ולמה צו' למשה ואהרן לעשות אות המטה שעי"ז התלוצצו עליהם, והרי תכלית האותות כדי שיאמין לשלוחי השי"ת, ואדרבה עי"ז נתפקר עוד יותר.
translation: 12. Pharaoh called the wise men and the sorcerers, and they too did so, the magicians of Egypt, with their enchantments. Thus, our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'eira, Section 6): At that time, Pharaoh began to mock them and clucked after them like a rooster, and said to them, "These are the signs of the Holy One, Blessed be He," etc. He sent and brought children from their schools, and they too did likewise, as it is stated, "And they did so too." What does "too" mean? Even the children of four and five years old were called and did so. At first glance, this is difficult, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, reveals the end from the beginning. Why then did He command Moses and Aaron to perform the sign of the staff, through which they were ridiculed? After all, the purpose of the signs is so that they would believe in the emissaries of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and on the contrary, this caused them to be even more irreverent.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's mockery of the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron, as he summoned his own magicians to replicate these signs, even using young children to do so. This raises a theological question about why God commanded Moses and Aaron to perform these signs if they would only lead to further disbelief. The text highlights the tension between divine signs meant to inspire faith and the human tendency to dismiss or mimic them, emphasizing the complexity of faith and the challenges faced by God's messengers. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of belief and the role of divine intervention in the face of skepticism.

passage_content: יג (רמז קפ"א) כי ידבר אלכם פרעה לאמר תנו לכם מופת, אמר להם למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים, ואני נותן להם את התורה שנא' בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא ונתן אליך אות או מופת עכ"ד הילקוט, וצ"ב איך שייכא מצות הנביא שעתיד להתחדש במתן תורה, אל מה שישאל פרעה מופת, הרי ודאי לא במצות התורה ישאל כן.
translation: 13 (Hint 121) For when Pharaoh speaks to you saying, "Give yourselves a sign," he said to them, "Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt, and I will give them the Torah," as it is stated, "If a prophet arises among you and gives you a sign or a wonder." Thus far the Yalkut. And it is to be questioned how the commandment of the prophet, which is destined to be renewed with the giving of the Torah, relates to what Pharaoh will ask for a sign, for certainly he will not ask for such in the commandments of the Torah.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses Pharaoh's request for a sign as a precursor to the Israelites' liberation from Egypt and the giving of the Torah. The text raises a question about the relevance of the future commandment regarding prophets in the context of Pharaoh's demand for a miracle, suggesting a deeper connection between the signs requested by Pharaoh and the divine authority established through the Torah. This highlights the Hasidic emphasis on the transformative power of the Torah and the prophetic tradition that emerges from it, illustrating the interplay between divine revelation and human experience.

passage_content: יד) במכת ברד כתיב, ויאמר ד' אל משה השכם בבקר והתיצב לפני פרעה וגו', במד"ר (פ' י"ב סי' י"א) הה"ד (איוב ל"ו) הן ק"ל ישגיב בכחו מי כמוהו מורה, א"ר ברכי' הקב"ה מעצים כח הצדיקים לעשות רצונו, מי כמוהו מורה, שהוא מורה דרך לעשות תשובה וכו ', שלא חפץ לשלוח המכה עד שיזהירנו לעשות תשובה, שכ"כ השכם בבקר והתיצב לפני פרעה עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה נשתנה מכת ברד שדרשו בו חז"ל כן, והרי גם בשאר המכות לא הכה בהם עד שהתרה בם, ובה' מכות הראשונות הי' בהם התראה לדברי הכל ומפורש כן בפסוקים, ואיכא למ"ד דבכל המכות הי' התראה, אפי' באלו שאין ההתראה מפורש בהם, וצ"ב הכוונה שדרשו כן במכת ברד דוקא .
translation: In the plague of hail, it is written, "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Get up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh...'" (Exodus 9:13). In the Midrash (Parashat 12, Section 11), it is stated (Job 36:22), "Behold, God is exalted in His power; who is a teacher like Him?" Rabbi Berachiah said: The Holy One, blessed be He, empowers the righteous to fulfill His will; who is a teacher like Him, for He teaches the way to repent, etc. He did not wish to send the plague until He warned us to repent, as it is written, "Get up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh." Thus far the Midrash. It is worth understanding what is different about the plague of hail that the Sages expounded this way, for in all the other plagues, He did not strike them until He warned them. In the first five plagues, there was a warning according to all opinions, and it is explicitly stated in the verses. And there is an opinion that in all the plagues there was a warning, even in those where the warning is not explicitly mentioned. It is necessary to clarify the intention behind the specific emphasis on the plague of hail.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of God's command to Moses to warn Pharaoh before the plague of hail, emphasizing the theme of repentance. The Midrash highlights that God empowers the righteous to fulfill His will and that He desires to guide humanity towards repentance rather than punishment. The unique focus on the hail plague suggests a deeper theological insight into God's mercy and the importance of warning before judgment, reflecting a consistent divine approach across all plagues. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of repentance and the compassionate nature of God.

passage_content: טו) בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך וגו' פרש"י למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות, הקשה הרא"ם ז"ל מכת בכורות מאן דכר שמי', ולמה לא יתפרש על מכת ברד שמדבר בה הכתוב, ותירץ בשם ר"ת מאורליינו"ש שהגירסא צ"ל בכורות, והוא הברד שנלקה בו האביב הממהר להתבכר , כמשה"כ כי השעורה אביב, והכוונה ללמדנו על מכת ברד שהוא שקולה כנגד כל המכות, והקשה ע"ז הגו"א זלל"ה דלעיל ( בפ ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, פרש"י שמכת בכורות קשה מכולם, ואם נפרש כאן דברי רש"י על מכת ברד, א"כ יהיו דבריו סותרין זא"ז .
translation: 15) "This time I am sending all My plagues upon your heart," etc. Rashi explains that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. The Ra'ah"m questioned why the plague of the firstborn is mentioned specifically, and why it should not be interpreted as referring to the plague of hail that the verse discusses. He answered in the name of R"T Ma'or L'einu"sh that the correct reading should be "firstborn," and it is the hail that struck during the spring, hastening to ripen, as it is written, "for the barley is in the ear." The intention is to teach us that the plague of hail is equivalent to all the plagues. The G'ra"v Z"L questioned this in regard to the earlier verse (in Parashat Shemot) on the verse "Behold, I am killing your firstborn," where Rashi explains that the plague of the firstborn is the hardest of all. If we interpret Rashi's words here as referring to the plague of hail, then his statements would contradict each other.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the plague of the firstborn, which is considered equivalent to all the other plagues combined. The text highlights a debate regarding the interpretation of the plagues, particularly focusing on the plague of hail and its connection to the concept of "firstborn." The theological insight emphasizes the severity of the firstborn plague, suggesting that it embodies a culmination of divine judgment, while also exploring the intricate relationships between the different plagues and their meanings within the context of divine retribution.

passage_content: טז קשה על תירוצו ממה שדרשו חז"ל והנה לא שמעת עד כה, עד שתשמע ממני מכת בכורות שאפתח בכה שנא' כה אמר ד' בחצות לילה, ואיך יתכן שהביא עליו מכת ברד ששקולה כנגד כל המכות ולא נכנע, ואח"כ יביא עליו מכה שהוא יותר קלה ובזה יכנע לבבו ויניחם לצאת.
translation: It is difficult to reconcile his explanation with what our Sages have taught, and behold, you have not heard until now, until you hear from me about the plague of the firstborn, as it is stated: "Thus says the Lord, at midnight." And how is it possible that He brought upon him the plague of hail, which is equivalent to all the plagues, and he did not relent, and then He would bring upon him a plague that is lighter, and through this, his heart would be softened and he would let them go.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of God's plagues, particularly how the severe plague of hail, which is equal to all the plagues, did not lead Pharaoh to relent, while a seemingly lighter plague, the death of the firstborn, ultimately broke his resistance. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine intervention, where the nature of God's actions can transcend human logic. It emphasizes the idea that sometimes a gentler approach can achieve what harsher measures cannot, highlighting the complexity of divine will and the human heart's response to suffering.

passage_content: יז יונתן פי' עה"פ בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך , ארי בזמנא הדא אנא שלח מחתא לך מן שמיא, ותתיב ית כל מחתי וכו' דמן קדמי הוון משתלחין ולא מן חרשיותא וכו' וכ"כ האוהחה"ק כי בכל המכות עד הנה, לא הי' פרעה מחליט בלבו כי הם מאלקי היכולת, והי' תולה במכשפות ומעשה שדים וכו ', ע"כ א"ל ד' כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי שכבר באו עליך, אל לבך שתדע בכולם כי לא מעשה כשפים המה אלא מעשה אלקים עכ"ד ז"ל. אמנם צ"ב איך נתברר לו ע"י מכת ברד יותר מבשאר המכות, הגם שדרשו חז"ל הביאו רש"י בשם מדרש אגדה שהגביהו הקב"ה למשה למעלה מן השמים בשעה שהביא עליהם הברד, ואיתא במד"ר נתן הקב"ה למשה רשות לשלוט במעשה שמים, שנא' נטה את ידך על השמים וגו' אבל איך הבחין פרעה בכל זה, וכמו שאמר בשאר המכות כולן שמעשה כשפים הם, כמו"כ הי' אפשר שיאמר גם במכת ברד כן.
translation: 17. Jonathan explains the verse, "At this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," that in this time, I am sending a sign to you from Heaven, and all My plagues will settle upon you, etc. For previously they were sent from the front, and not from the back, etc. And so it is written in the holy books that until now, Pharaoh did not decide in his heart that they were from the God of might, and he attributed it to sorcery and the works of demons, etc. Therefore, God said to him, "For at this time I will send all My plagues that have already come upon you, upon your heart, so that you will know in all of them that they are not the works of sorcery, but the works of God." Thus far his words. However, it is questionable how he was clarified by the plague of hail more than by the other plagues, even though our Sages have taught and Rashi brought in the name of the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, raised Moses above the heavens when He brought the hail upon them, and it is stated in the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave Moses permission to control the works of Heaven, as it is said, "Stretch out your hand toward heaven," etc. But how did Pharaoh discern all this, just as he said about all the other plagues that they were works of sorcery, so too it was possible for him to say the same about the plague of hail.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the plagues sent to Pharaoh, particularly emphasizing that the purpose of the plagues was to reveal God's sovereignty and power over nature, rather than attributing them to sorcery or witchcraft. The text highlights that, unlike previous plagues, the plague of hail was intended to penetrate Pharaoh's heart and make him recognize the divine origin of the afflictions. The author questions why Pharaoh was able to discern this truth specifically through the hail, suggesting that God's intervention allowed Moses to demonstrate control over heavenly phenomena, thereby reinforcing the notion of divine authority. Ultimately, the passage underscores the theme of recognizing God's omnipotence in the face of human denial and the limitations of magical practices.

passage_content: יח ברד ואש מתלקחת בתוך הברד, פרש"י בשם המדרש נס בתוך נס. האש והברד מעורבין והברד מים הוא, ולעשות רצון קונם עשו שלו' ביניהם. ולכאורה צ"ב דלא מצינו מבואר למה הי' צורך לנס זה, ולפי משמעות הכתוב הברד לבדו הכה בהם ולא האש שנא' ויך הברד וגו', וכתיב הנשארת לכם מן הברד, אשר הותיר הברד, ובכ"מ נזכר הברד לבד, והמכה נקראת ע"ש הברד ולא ע"ש האש, ואם הי' רצונו ית ' לשלוח עליהם גם אש ממרומיו, אבל לאיזה תכלית הי' הנס שיהיו מעורבין זב"ז , וכללא הוא דלא עביד קוב"ה ניסא למגנא .
translation: 18. Hail and fire were ignited within the hail; Rashi explains in the name of the Midrash that it was a miracle within a miracle. The fire and the hail are mixed together, and the hail is water, and to fulfill the will of their Creator, they made peace between them. And seemingly, it is difficult to understand why this miracle was necessary, for according to the meaning of the verse, the hail alone struck them, and not the fire, as it is said, "And the hail struck," etc., and it is written, "The remnant that remains from the hail," which the hail left behind, and everywhere the hail is mentioned alone, and the plague is named after the hail and not after the fire. And if the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to send fire upon them from on high, for what purpose was the miracle that they should be mixed together? And the general principle is that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles for mere protection.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous combination of hail and fire during the plagues in Egypt, highlighting the concept of "a miracle within a miracle." It emphasizes that while the hail was the primary agent of destruction, the presence of fire alongside it serves a deeper purpose, reflecting God's will and the complexity of divine intervention. The text questions the necessity of this dual phenomenon, suggesting that God's miracles are not merely for protection but also carry profound theological significance. Ultimately, it illustrates the intricate relationship between divine action and the fulfillment of God's intentions in the world.

passage_content: יט בפ ' שמות ויאמר פרעה מי ד' אשר אשמע בקולו לשלח את ישראל, לא ידעתי את ד' וגם את ישראל לא אשלח. יש להבין מלת וגם למאי אתי, דידוע דגמין רבויין הן ומהו אתי לרבויי .
translation: 19 In Parashat Shemot, Pharaoh said, "Who is the Lord that I should heed His voice to let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and I will not let Israel go." It is necessary to understand the word "and" (וגם) what it comes to add, for it is known that the term "also" (וגם) is used for inclusion, and what is it coming to include?
summary: In this passage, Pharaoh's refusal to recognize God and his insistence on not releasing the Israelites highlights the theme of divine authority versus human arrogance. The use of the word "also" suggests that Pharaoh's ignorance extends beyond just God to include the Israelites themselves, emphasizing a broader rejection of spiritual truth. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the struggle between the material world and the divine, illustrating how ignorance of God leads to a lack of compassion and understanding for others. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of recognizing God's presence in all aspects of life and the consequences of denial.

passage_content: כ) אלהם מלך מצרים למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו לכו לסבלותיכם, פרש"י לכו למלאכתכם שיש לכם בבתיכם, אבל מלאכת שעבוד מצרים לא היתה על שבטו של לוי, ותדע לך שהרי משה ואהרן יוצאים ובאים שלא ברשות עכ"ל, וצ"ב דלמה הזהירם פרעה על כך שיחזרו למלאכתם שבבית, ומאי נפק"מ לדידי' אם יחזרו אלי' או יהיו בטלים ממלאכה לגמרי, ועיקר כוונת אמירתו היתה שלא להפריע את העם ממלאכה, וכבר מילתו אמורה למה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ודי בזה, ומאמר לכו לסבלותיכם מיותר ומחוסר הבנה.
translation: (10) The king of Egypt said to them, "Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people from their work? Go to your burdens." Rashi explains, "Go to your work that you have in your homes," but the work of the servitude of Egypt was not upon the tribe of Levi. And you should know that Moses and Aaron were coming and going without permission. This raises a question: why did Pharaoh warn them to return to their work at home, and what difference does it make to him if they return to it or if they are completely idle? The main intent of his statement was not to disturb the people from their work, and his words are already stated: "Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb..." and that is sufficient. The statement "Go to your burdens" is superfluous and lacks understanding.
summary: In this passage, the Pharaoh's admonition to Moses and Aaron highlights the tension between spiritual leadership and the burdens of physical labor. The emphasis on not disturbing the people's work reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the struggle between the material and spiritual realms. The mention that the tribe of Levi was not subjected to the same labor signifies a distinction in spiritual responsibility, suggesting that true devotion transcends physical toil. Ultimately, the text invites reflection on the balance between fulfilling divine purpose and the demands of worldly existence.

passage_content: כא קשה דרש"י ז"ל פי' בפ ' וארא סבלות מצרים, טורח משא מצרים, ובת"א פי' דחוק פולחן מצראי , מבואר דמלת סבלות ביאורו משא כבידה שטורח לסובלו, ואיך יתפרש כאן לסבלותיכם למלאכתכם שבבית, ואין זה טורח משא, ולא יפול לשון סבלות במה שהאדם עושה מלאכת עצמו לרצונו, עוד יל"ד דעל מלאכת העם אמר תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, והוא היתה עבודה קשה וטורח משא, כמשה"כ וימררו את חייהם בעבודה קשה וגו' את כל עבודתם אשר עבדו בהם בפרך, ופרש"י בעבודה קשה המפרכת את הגוף ומשברתו , וע"ז יוצדק מילת סבלותם , ולמה הפך סדר הלשונות, והול"ל איפכא למה תפריעו את העם מסבלותם לכו למעשיכם.
translation: In difficult times, Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained in Parashat Va'era that "the burdens of Egypt" refers to the toil of the burdens of Egypt, and in the Targum it is explained as the oppression of the Egyptian service. It is clear that the term "burdens" refers to a heavy load that is difficult to bear. How can it be interpreted here as "your burdens for your work at home," which is not a heavy toil? The term "burdens" does not apply to what a person does for his own will. Furthermore, it should be noted that regarding the work of the people, it is said, "You shall disrupt the people from their deeds," and this was indeed hard work and a heavy burden, as it is written, "And they embittered their lives with hard work... all their work which they did with rigor." Rashi explains that "hard work" is that which crushes the body and breaks it. Therefore, the term "their burdens" is justified. But why did he reverse the order of the phrases? It should have been stated the other way around: "Why do you disrupt the people from their burdens? Go to your deeds."
summary: The passage discusses the term "suffering" in the context of the Israelites' burdens in Egypt, emphasizing that true suffering arises from oppressive labor rather than voluntary work. It contrasts the heavy toil imposed by the Egyptians with the notion of personal labor, suggesting that the term "suffering" is more appropriately applied to the harsh conditions that break the spirit and body. The text highlights the theological insight that divine concern is for the genuine suffering of the oppressed, as opposed to the mundane tasks of daily life. Ultimately, it questions the phrasing used in the text, suggesting a deeper understanding of the nature of suffering and labor.

passage_content: כב קשה מ"ש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ומה מקום לשאלת למה, הרי אמרו לו שהם שלוחי ד', אלא שלא הי' רצונו לשמוע בדבר ד', וכבר אמר לא ידעתי את ד' וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, ומה הוסיף כאן בשאלתו למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, ואין בזה דברי טעם, וגם בלא"ה אין מקום לתמי' זו כלל, כי אחרי שראו בדחוק פולחן ועבודת משא מצרים על ישראל, באו לבקש ממנו להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד, ומה זה שאמר למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, וכי לא ידע למה.
translation: It is difficult to understand what is meant by the question of why Moses and Aaron are disturbing, etc. And what place is there for the question of why, since they told him that they are the messengers of G-d? Rather, he did not want to hear the word of G-d, and he already said, "I do not know G-d," and "I will not send Israel." What does he add here in his question of why Moses and Aaron are disturbing? There is no reasoning in this, and even without that, there is no place for this wonder at all, because after they saw the difficult service and labor of Egypt upon Israel, they came to ask him to lighten the yoke of servitude from upon them. What is this that he said, "Why are Moses and Aaron disturbing"? Does he not know why?
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's questioning of Moses and Aaron's interference, highlighting the absurdity of his inquiry given that he was already aware of their divine mission. It emphasizes that Pharaoh's refusal to acknowledge God and his own oppressive actions against the Israelites reflects a deeper spiritual blindness. The text suggests that Pharaoh's questioning stems from a lack of understanding of the divine will and the suffering of the Israelites, illustrating the tension between human authority and divine purpose. Ultimately, it underscores the futility of questioning God's plan in the face of evident suffering and the need for liberation.

passage_content: כג למה הזכיר את שמותם, ואין זה מדרך הלשון, שהרי דבר אלהם לנוכח, וכבר כתיב ויאמר אלהם , והול"ל למה תפריעו את העם, ומ"ש למה משה ואהרן מיותר.
translation: 23. Why did he mention their names, as this is not the way of language, for he spoke to them directly, and it is already written, "And he said to them," and it could have said, "Why do you disturb the people?" And the mention of "Why Moses and Aaron" is superfluous.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of mentioning the names of Moses and Aaron in a context where it seems unnecessary, as God spoke directly to them. This highlights the importance of individual leadership and the unique roles of Moses and Aaron in guiding the people. The emphasis on their names suggests a deeper connection to their spiritual authority and the responsibility they bear in addressing the community's challenges. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the power of personal connection and the impact of righteous leaders on the collective spiritual journey.

passage_content: כד) ראוי להבין תכלית כוונתו במ"ש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, וכי הי' בידם להפריע את העם ממעשיו, הלא פרעה הי' בידו שבט המושל, ולא הניחם בלא"ה שיפריעו את העם, כמשה"כ ויצו פרעה את הנוגשים בעם וגו' תכבד העבודה על האנשים וגו', ובודאי לא זה הי' כוונתו להזהירם שלא יפריעו את העם כי לא הוצרך לכך, וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: It is fitting to understand the ultimate intention behind the statement, "Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people?" For could they have actually prevented the people from their actions? After all, Pharaoh held the rod of governance, and he did not allow them, without a doubt, to disturb the people, as it is written, "And Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters over the people, saying, 'You shall make the work heavier upon the men...'" Certainly, this was not his intention to warn them not to disturb the people, for there was no need for that. The intention behind this remains a question.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in Pharaoh's command to Moses and Aaron not to interfere with the people, despite his own oppressive control over them. It raises the question of why Pharaoh would caution them against disrupting the people's actions when he was already enforcing harsh labor. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the nature of authority and the spiritual struggle between divine will and human agency, emphasizing the complexity of leadership and the challenges faced by those who seek to guide others in faith.

passage_content: כה) (פ' ה' סי' ט"ז) למה משה ואהרן תפריעו, מהו למה, אמר להם אתם למה ודבריכם למה וצ"ב .
translation: "Why do you disturb, Moshe and Aharon? What does 'why' mean? He said to them, 'You, why, and your words, why?' And it is a question."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author addresses the questioning of Moses and Aaron, emphasizing the significance of their inquiries. The term "why" reflects a deeper spiritual search, suggesting that their questions are not mere doubts but a quest for understanding divine purpose. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the importance of engaging with God through inquiry, as such questioning can lead to greater insight and connection with the divine. Ultimately, it underscores the value of seeking answers in the context of faith and spiritual growth.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נ"ל עוד כוונה נוסף על פשוטו בוויכוח שבין משה ואהרן עם פרעה, דהנה משה ואהרן כשבאו בשליחות השי"ת אל ישראל, וראו שאין להם לישראל די זכותים להגאל , הגם שהי' להם מידות טובות כמ"ש בזוה"ק דאסתמרו ישראל מנדה ובת אל נכר , ואיתא בגמ' בשביל ד' דברים נגאלו אבותינו ממצרים שלא שינו את שמם ואת לשונם וכו ', אעפ"כ היו משוקעים בע"ז ובמ"ט שערי טומאה, והי' תנאי לגאולתם שיקדים לה בחי' התשובה, כמאמרם ז"ל ( במד"ר פ' ט"ז סי' ב') משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן של מצו'. ע"כ משה ואהרן עוררו אותם אל התשובה, כמבואר בדברי המכילתא הנ"ל מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, ומצינו בכתוב (יחזקאל כ') שאהרן התנבא אלהם איש שקוצי עיניו השליכו וגו', והי' אז הזמן מסוגל לתשובה, כי רצה הקב"ה להוציא את ישראל מתחת טומאת מצרים, ולא הי' בכוחם לפרוש ממנה, כי היו משוקעים. במ"ט שערי טומאה, ולולי עזר אלקי לא היו יוצאים משם לעולם, ועשה השי"ת פלאות להפרישם מטומאת מצרים, כמו שפירשנו בדברנו כ"פ מאה"כ , הנסה אלקים לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, שהוציא הקב"ה מקרבם טומאת מצרים, והי' הזמן מסוגל לבירור הניצה"ק , שתקנו ישראל והוציאו משם כל הניצה"ק כמ"ש וינצלו את מצרים, וע"כ מסוגלים ימי השובבים לתיקון חטא הידוע, והם ימים מסוגלים לתשובה, כי הקריאה מעורר סגולת הזמן, הגם דכל השנה כולה אין לך דבר שעומד בפני התשובה, אבל סגולת הימים אלו מסייעים שיתעורר האדם בהם לשוב אל בוראו יתברך.
translation: To clarify the matter, it seems to me that there is an additional intention beyond the simple meaning in the argument between Moses and Aaron with Pharaoh. Behold, when Moses and Aaron came on the mission of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Israel, and saw that the Israelites did not have sufficient merits to be redeemed, even though they had good traits, as it is written in the Zohar that Israel was preserved from impurity and from the daughter of a foreign god, and it is stated in the Gemara that for four things our ancestors were redeemed from Egypt: they did not change their names, nor their language, etc. Nevertheless, they were steeped in idolatry and in the forty-nine gates of impurity, and the condition for their redemption was that they should first engage in the aspect of repentance, as our sages of blessed memory said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat 16, Section 2), "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for the commandments." Therefore, Moses and Aaron urged them towards repentance, as explained in the words of the aforementioned Mekilta, "What does it mean that they did not listen to Moses?" It means that they fasted to separate from idolatry. And we find in the scripture (Ezekiel 20) that Aaron prophesied to them, "Each man cast away the abominations of his eyes," etc. At that time, it was a suitable moment for repentance, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, wanted to take Israel out from under the impurity of Egypt, and they were unable to separate from it because they were steeped in the forty-nine gates of impurity. Had it not been for divine assistance, they would never have left there. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed wonders to separate them from the impurity of Egypt, as we have explained in our words many times regarding the verse, "Has God attempted to take for Himself a nation from the midst of a nation?" that the Holy One, Blessed be He, removed the impurity of Egypt from among them. And it was a time suitable for the rectification of the sparks of holiness, which Israel rectified and took out from there all the sparks of holiness, as it is written, "And they plundered the Egyptians." Therefore, the days of the Shovavim are suitable for the rectification of the known sin, and they are days suitable for repentance, for the call awakens the quality of the time, even though throughout the entire year there is nothing that stands before repentance. However, the quality of these days assists a person to awaken in them to return to his Creator, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual state of the Israelites before their redemption from Egypt, emphasizing that despite their inherent virtues, they were deeply entrenched in idolatry and impurity. Moses and Aaron's mission was to inspire them to repent, as their redemption required a prior return to God. The text highlights that divine assistance was crucial for their liberation, as they were unable to extricate themselves from the spiritual filth of Egypt. It also notes that certain times, like the "Shovavim" period, are particularly conducive to repentance, reinforcing the idea that specific moments can enhance one's ability to return to God.

passage_content: וכתב השלה"ק דפרעה הי' חכם להרע, וידע כי תקנתם וגאולתם של ישראל תלוי בתשובה, ע"כ רצה למנוע מהם דרכי התשובה ולהחטיאם, כי ידע שעי"ז יעכב גאולתם ויאריך עת גלותם, ופי' בזה מ"ש וירעו אותנו המצרים, שעשו אותנו רעים וחטאים, וכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ ' בא שנתארך להם זמן הגלות ל' שנים, כי לא הי' הגזרה רק ועבדום וענו אותם ארבע מאות שנה, ולבסוף יצאו לת"ל שנים מגזירת ברית בין הבתרים, לפי שגרם החטא להתארך גלותם, כמשה"כ איש שקוצי עיניו לא השליכו ואת גילולי מצרים לא עזבו (יחזקאל כ'), וע"כ השקיעו פרעה ומצרים כל כוחותם להחטיא את ישראל ולמנעם מתשובה, כי ידעו שגאולתם תלוי בתשובה, ואיכא למ"ד במס' סנהדרין (קי"א) שלא יצאו אלא ב' מס' רבוא , והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה שלא היו רוצים לצאת, וכ"ז הי' ע"י גודל התגברות טומאת מצרים עליהם, כמבואר במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) שאמר הקב"ה לס"מ שלא עבדו ישראל לע"ז אלא מתוך שעבוד וטירוף הדעת שגרמו להם המצריים.
translation: The Shlah HaKadosh wrote that Pharaoh was wise in doing evil, and he knew that the rectification and redemption of Israel depended on repentance. Therefore, he wanted to prevent them from the ways of repentance and to cause them to sin, for he knew that through this he would delay their redemption and prolong their time of exile. He explained this regarding what is written, "And the Egyptians made us serve with rigor," that they made us wicked and sinful. The Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Bo that the time of their exile was prolonged for 430 years, for the decree was only that they would serve and afflict them for 400 years, and in the end, they left after 210 years from the decree of the covenant between the pieces, because sin caused their exile to be prolonged, as it is written, "A man whose eyes are sharp did not cast them away, and the idols of Egypt they did not forsake" (Ezekiel 20). Therefore, Pharaoh and the Egyptians invested all their strength to cause Israel to sin and to prevent them from repentance, for they knew that their redemption depended on repentance. And there is a teaching in the tractate Sanhedrin (111) that they only went out in two out of six hundred thousand, and the rest died in three days of darkness because they did not want to leave. All this was due to the great intensification of the impurity of Egypt upon them, as explained in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 234) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the Satan that Israel did not serve idols except out of servitude and madness that the Egyptians caused them.
summary: The passage discusses the cunning of Pharaoh, who sought to prevent the Israelites from repenting, knowing that their redemption depended on their return to God. It emphasizes that the Egyptians aimed to corrupt the Israelites and lead them into sin, which ultimately prolonged their exile. The text also highlights that a significant portion of the Israelites did not leave Egypt due to their spiritual degradation caused by the Egyptians, illustrating the profound impact of external oppression on faith and redemption.

passage_content: והנה פשטות הכתוב מורה שהסיבה שלא שמעו אל משה הי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, אבל חז"ל דרשו שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ר"ל שהי' התגברות כוחות היצר כבד עליהם מאוד והיו משוקעים כ"כ בטומאת מצרים עד שהי' קשה להם להתגבר ולפרוש מע"ז. ואפ"ל דהא בהא תליא , והדרש והפשט א' הם, ויובן עפימ"ש בס' הישר לר"ת שיש ב' מדריגות בעבודת השי"ת: דהאדם שנחלשו כוחות נפשו, יעשה המצוה והמדות טובות שאין עליהם התנגדות היצר כ"כ וניקל עליו לעשותם, אבל באלו שניגוד היצר קשה בהם, ונפשו של אדם מחמדתן, אין בו כח לעמוד נגד יצרו ולהתגבר עליו, וכאשר יזדמנו לו מניעות וסיבות המעכבים, ימנעו אותו מעבודתו ית ', אבל לצדיק אמת כל המניעות שבעולם לא יקשו בעיניו מלהתגבר עליהם, ולבו כלב הארי ללחום עם יצרו עד שיתגבר עליו, וכמו"כ ישראל במצרים שמשה רבינו לימד אותם דעת לעבודת השי"ת, והורה להם הדרך שיפרשו מכל מידה רעה ותולדה של ע"ז, וכמ"ש חז"ל (שבת דף ק"ה ע"ב) ולא יהי' בך אל זר איזהו אל זר שבגופו של אדם זה יצה"ר , היום אומר לו עשה כך וכו' עד שאומר לו לך ועבוד ע"ז והוא הולך ועובד, וגם מע"ז ממש צום לפרוש ממנו, ואילולי היו משוקעים כל כך בעבודה קשה, ואילו הי' להם פנאי ודעת מיושבת להתבונן בדברי תוכחה הנאמרים אליהם מפי משרע"ה , לא הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, אבל לפי שהי' להם קוצר רוח מעבודה קשה של מצרים, לא הי' בהם דעת להתבונן, וע"כ בצירוף ההתגברות הגדול הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ונמצא כי שני הטעמים א' הם והא בהא תליין
translation: And behold, the simplicity of the text indicates that the reason they did not listen to Moses was due to shortness of spirit and hard labor. However, our Sages expounded that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, meaning that the overpowering forces of the yetzer (evil inclination) were very heavy upon them, and they were so immersed in the impurity of Egypt that it was hard for them to overcome and separate from idolatry. And it can be said that these two matters are interconnected, and the interpretation and the simple meaning are one. It can be understood according to what is stated in the Book of the Straight (Sefer HaYashar) by R. Tzadok, that there are two levels in the service of the Blessed One: that a person whose spiritual powers have weakened should perform the mitzvot and good traits that do not face much opposition from the yetzer, and it is easier for him to do them. But for those in whom the opposition of the yetzer is strong, and the soul of a person desires them, he does not have the strength to stand against his yetzer and overcome it. And when obstacles and reasons that hinder him arise, they will prevent him from serving the Blessed One. But for a true righteous person, all the obstacles in the world will not seem difficult to him to overcome, and his heart is like that of a lion to fight with his yetzer until he overcomes it. Likewise, Israel in Egypt, whom Moses our teacher taught the knowledge to serve the Blessed One, and showed them the way to separate from every bad trait and the offspring of idolatry, as our Sages said (Shabbat 105b), "And there shall not be in you a foreign god," what is a foreign god in a person's body? This is the yetzer hara (evil inclination), today it tells him to do this, etc., until it tells him, "Go and serve idolatry," and he goes and serves. And even from idolatry itself, he should fast to separate from it. Had they not been so immersed in hard labor, and had they had the leisure and settled mind to contemplate the words of rebuke spoken to them by Moses, it would not have been hard for them to separate from idolatry. But since they had shortness of spirit from the hard labor of Egypt, they did not have the mind to contemplate. Therefore, in conjunction with the great overpowering, it was hard for them to separate from idolatry, and it turns out that both reasons are one and are interconnected.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the Israelites in Egypt struggled to heed Moses' call to abandon idolatry, attributing their difficulty to both their harsh labor and the overwhelming influence of their desires. It highlights a duality in spiritual struggle: those with weakened spiritual faculties may find it easier to perform commandments that do not face strong opposition from their desires, while the truly righteous can overcome any obstacles. The text emphasizes that if the Israelites had the mental space to reflect on Moses' teachings, they could have more easily rejected idolatry. Ultimately, it suggests that their inability to detach from idolatry stemmed from both external pressures and internal spiritual challenges, indicating a profound connection between their physical and spiritual states.

passage_content: אמנם אעפ"כ לגודל צדקתם של משה ואהרן לא ימלט שלא הכניסו בלבם הרהורי תשובה, וכמ"ש הבינה לעתים (דרוש ס"ו) לפרש משה"כ על מלך המשיח ושפט בצדק דלים, דלכאורה מהו רבותי' בהא, וכי צריכא למימר שלא יעשה עול במשפט, הרי מדה זו מצוי בהכרח אצל כל אדם בינוני, אמנם אמר הנביא שלא יצטרך לשפוט באמירת פיו, אלא שהוא בעצמו בכל פעולותיו ובכל מעשיו יעשה הצדק המוחלט, ובאותו צדק הנמצא בו, יעשה רושם חזק בלב כל אדם, ויתרחקו מעשות דבר מעוקל, ולא יצטרכו להתקרב למשפט, ונמצא המשפט נעשה מאליו ע"י צדקתו, וז"ש ושפט בצדק ר"ל ע"י צדקתו וכו '. וק"ז הייטב לב זלל"ה כתב בפ ' מעות בשם הארי' דבי עילאי זלל"ה לפרש הפסוק ומבן חמשים שנה ישוב מצבא העבודה, שבן לוי נפסל בשנים, ולא יעבוד עוד בפועל ממש, אבל ושרת את אחיו לשמור משמרת לעורר הלבבות, הגם שעבודה לא יעבוד עוד, אבל בכל פעולותיהם ומעשיהם יכניסו רושם התעוררות לתשובה בלב ישראל, עכ"ד, ועל אחת כמה וכמה שמשה ואהרן בגודל צדקתם ועל ידי פעולותיהם ומעשיהם הטובים ובדיבורי תוכחתם הכניסו רושם הרהורי תשובה בלבבות בני ישראל, ואף על פי שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, והי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז לגמרי. אבל אעפ"כ הפריעו את העם ממעשיהם, ונתגרה בקרבם מלחמה בין כוחות המנגדים היצ"ט והיצה"ר , ונתרפו מע"ז ומטומאת מצרים, כמ"ש בספה"ק זכרון זאת מההצה"ק מלובלין זי"ע בפ ' קרח, עה"פ ונלחמו אתך ולא יוכלו לך כי אני ד' אתך להצילך, דלכאורה הול"ל ולחמו אתך, דנלחמו משמע שנפעלים ע"י אחרים, אמנם הכוונה דע"כ הרשעים שונאים הצדיקים ורוצים להרע להם, דע"י עבודתם של הצדיקים נכנס בהם השפעה של יר"ש, ועי"ז מתגרה מלחמה בפנימותם ובקרבם, היצ"ט עם היצה"ר , ואינם רוצים בכך, וע"כ הם שונאים לצדיקים, וז"ש ונלחמו אתך, שעל ידך הם נפעלים למלחמה, אבל לא יוכלו להרע לך כי ד' אתך להצילך עכ"ל.
translation:
Indeed, despite this, due to the greatness of the righteousness of Moses and Aaron, they could not help but have thoughts of repentance in their hearts, as it is explained in the understanding of the times (Drush S"V) to interpret the verse regarding the Messiah, "and he shall judge the poor with righteousness." At first glance, what is the significance of this, my friends? Is it necessary to say that he will not commit injustice in judgment? This measure is necessarily found in every average person. However, the prophet said that he will not need to judge by the utterance of his mouth, but rather he himself, in all his actions and deeds, will perform absolute justice, and with that justice found within him, he will make a strong impression on the heart of every person, and they will distance themselves from doing anything crooked, and they will not need to approach judgment, and thus judgment will occur by itself through his righteousness. This is what is meant by "and he shall judge with righteousness," meaning through his righteousness, etc.

And thus, the holy Rabbi Z"L wrote in the section of "Maalot" in the name of the Ari, the holy one from above, to explain the verse "and from the age of fifty he shall return from the service of work," that a Levite is disqualified by age and will no longer work in actual service, but he will serve his brothers to guard the watch to awaken the hearts, even though he will no longer work in service, but in all their actions and deeds, they will instill an impression of awakening to repentance in the hearts of Israel. Thus far his words. And all the more so, Moses and Aaron, due to the greatness of their righteousness and through their good actions and their words of reproof, instilled an impression of thoughts of repentance in the hearts of the children of Israel, even though they did not listen to Moses due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and it was difficult for them to completely separate from idolatry. Nevertheless, they disturbed the people from their actions, and a war was stirred up among them between the forces of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the evil inclination, and they were weakened from idolatry and the impurity of Egypt, as it is written in the holy book "Remember this" from the holy one of Lublin, may his memory be a blessing, in the section of Korach, on the verse "and they will fight against you and will not be able to harm you, for I am the Lord with you to save you." At first glance, it should have said "and they will fight with you," for "fighting" implies that they are acted upon by others. However, the intention is that the wicked indeed hate the righteous and want to do them harm, for through the work of the righteous, an influence of fear of Heaven enters them, and thus a war is stirred up within them, between the good inclination and the evil inclination, and they do not want this, and therefore they hate the righteous. This is what is meant by "and they will fight against you," that through you they are acted upon to war, but they will not be able to harm you, for the Lord is with you to save you. Thus far his words.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound righteousness of Moses and Aaron, suggesting that their actions and teachings instilled a sense of repentance in the hearts of the Israelites, even amidst their struggles with idolatry and oppression. It highlights the idea that true justice, as exemplified by the Messiah, transcends mere verbal judgment and manifests through the inherent goodness of one's actions, which can inspire others to turn away from wrongdoing. The text also illustrates the internal spiritual conflict between the good inclination and the evil inclination, suggesting that the righteous provoke this struggle within others, leading to a transformative impact on their spiritual state. Ultimately, it reassures that despite opposition, divine support ensures the triumph of the righteous.

passage_content: ופרעה הרשע רצה למנוע בנ"י מלעשות תשובה, כי ידע כי בנפשו הוא, שעי"ז יזכו ישראל לצאת ממצרים, וע"כ אמר למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, ולא הי' כוונתו על סבלותם , כי ע"ז הי' לו עצה ע"י הנוגשים והשוטרים, שלא יניחו אותם לפרוע מעבודתם, אבל כוונתו הי' שלא להפריע אותם "ממעשיהם שבבית", כי עד שלא באו משה ואהרן היו עושים מתועבת מצרים, ועכשיו הפריעו אותם ממעשיהם, וע"כ לא אמר סבלותם כי לא היתה כוונתו על סבלות משא. וטענתו של פרעה היתה שבלא"ה לא יעשו ישראל תשובה גמורה, ואין בכוחכם לבטלם מע"ז לגמרי שכבר הם משוקעים בטומאה כ"כ, ואין זה אלא הפרעה לשעה, וכל עבודתכם ללא תועלת, וכיון שכן מצו' שלא לומר להם, כי בודאי לא ישמעו לדבריכם, וכמ"ש חז"ל במס' יבמות (ס"ה ע"ב) כשם שמצו' לומר דבר הנשמע, כך מצו' שלא לומר דבר שאינו נשמע, רבי אבא אמר חובה הוא שנא' אל תוכח לץ פן ישנאך, והטעם פן ישנאך כי השנאה תעורר בו ההיפך, ויהי' גרוע עוד יותר ויוסיף רעה על רעתו, וע"כ חובה שלא להוכיחו כל היכא שברור שלא ישמע, וז"ש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' כי אין זה לטובתם אלא לרעתם, שעי"ז יהיו מקולקלים יותר ובלא"ה לא ישמעו לכם ומ"ש לכו לסבלותיכם הכוונה למלאכתכם שבבית כמו שפרש"י ז"ל, ומה הי' מלאכתם של משה ואהרן עבודת השי"ת, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דמנהג כל עם להיות להם חכמים מורי תורתם, ולכן הניח פרעה להם שבט לוי שיהיו חכמיהם וזקניהם, והי' כ"ז סיבה מאת ד' עכ"ד ז"ל. והנה ידע פרעה שלא יעלה בידו להמנע קדושים אלו מעבודת השי"ת, אלא שלא רצה שיפריעו גם את העם ממעשיהם הרעים, ולעוררם אל התשובה ע"כ אמר לכו לסבלותיכם אל עבודתכם שבבית, ובין תנור לכיריים תעבדו עבודת ד' לעצמכם, ואל תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, כי בלא"ה לא יועיל אלא יזיק. ועד"ז הי' כוונת אמירתו הרעה אל משה ואהרן.
translation: And the wicked Pharaoh wanted to prevent the Children of Israel from repenting, for he knew that it was a matter of life and death for him, as through this they would merit to leave Egypt. Therefore, he said, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb the people from their work?" His intention was not regarding their suffering, for he had advice from the taskmasters and officers to not allow them to cease from their labor. Rather, his intention was to not disturb them "from their actions at home," for before Moses and Aaron came, they were engaged in the abominations of Egypt, and now they disturbed them from their actions. Therefore, he did not mention their suffering, as his intention was not concerning the burden of labor. Pharaoh's claim was that regardless, the Israelites would not achieve true repentance, and you do not have the power to completely remove them from idolatry, as they are already so deeply entrenched in impurity. This is merely a temporary disturbance, and all your efforts are without benefit. Since this is the case, it is a command not to speak to them, for they will certainly not listen to your words, as our Sages have said in Yevamot (65b), "Just as it is a command to say something that is heard, so it is a command not to say something that is not heard." Rabbi Abba said it is a duty to say, "Do not reprove a scorner, lest he hate you," and the reason is that the hatred will provoke the opposite response in him, and he will become even worse and add evil to his evil. Therefore, it is a duty not to reprove him wherever it is clear that he will not listen. This is what he meant when he said, "Why do Moses and Aaron disturb the people?" For this is not for their benefit but for their detriment, as through this they will become more corrupted, and regardless, they will not listen to you. And when he said, "Go to your burdens," his intention was for your work at home, as Rashi explains. And what was the work of Moses and Aaron? The service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as Nachmanides explains that it is the custom of every nation to have wise men who teach their Torah. Therefore, Pharaoh allowed them the tribe of Levi to be their wise men and elders, and all this was a reason from God, blessed be He. And behold, Pharaoh knew that he would not be able to prevent these holy ones from the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, but he did not want them to also disturb the people from their evil actions and to awaken them to repentance. Therefore, he said, "Go to your burdens, to your work at home," and between the oven and the stove, serve God for yourselves, and do not disturb the people from their actions, for regardless, it will not help but will harm. And similarly was the intention of his evil words to Moses and Aaron.
summary: Pharaoh's wicked intent was to prevent the Israelites from repenting, as he understood that their redemption from Egypt depended on their ability to do so. He argued that Moses and Aaron were disrupting the people's sinful practices, which he believed were deeply ingrained, and that any attempt to encourage repentance would ultimately be futile and counterproductive. Pharaoh's directive to the Israelites to return to their burdens was a strategy to keep them occupied with their mundane tasks, thereby hindering their spiritual awakening and connection to God. This reflects the Hasidic concept that true spiritual work must come from within, and external pressures can often lead to greater spiritual degradation rather than upliftment.

passage_content: וא"ש מה שקרא עבודת ישראל בשם מעשיו, ועל עבודת משה ואהרן אמר לשון סבלותם , דעבודת השי"ת הי' נחשב בעיניו לסבלות וטורח משא, כמו שדרך הרשעים ששמירת התורה והמצות הם בעיניהם לטורח ולמשא כבידה, ובאמת אמרו בגמ' מצות לאו להנות נתנו אלא לעול על צאווריהם ניתנו, ועבודה קשה הוא להשיג אף תנועה קלה של אמת, ולהתגבר נגד היצה"ר הוא חוץ לדרך הטבע, כמ"ש ז"ל (קידושין דף ל' ע"ב) דאלמלא הקב"ה עזרו אינו יכול לו, אלא שאינה טורח וסבלות בעיני הצדיקים, אדרבה כל מאוים וחשקתם ותשוקתם לקיים רצונו ית ', אף שקשה מאוד ולפום צערא אגרא, אבל בעיני הרשעים נחשב העול הזה לטורח וסבלות, וע"כ קרא פרעה לעבודת משה ואהרן בשם סבלות, וא"ל לכו לסבלותיכם. ומעשיהם של ישראל שהיו עושין בביתם מבחי ' ע"ז ומבחינת מעשיהם של מצרים, זה קרא בשם מעשים, כי אלו לא הי' סבלות וטורח משא בעיניו, שהיו ערבים וטובים בעיניו כמ"ש ז"ל על יצה"ר שתחלתו מתוק וסופו מר, וז"ש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו שבבית, לכו לסבלותיכם שאתם תעבדו העבודה קשה בעבודת השי"ת, ואצלם בלא"ה לא תפעלו כלום.
translation: And it is understood why he called the work of Israel by the name of their deeds, and regarding the work of Moshe and Aharon he used the term "their burdens." For the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, was considered by him as burdensome and a toil, just as it is the way of the wicked that the observance of the Torah and the commandments is seen by them as a burden and a heavy load. And indeed, it is said in the Gemara that the commandments were not given for enjoyment but to place a yoke upon their necks. And it is a hard work to achieve even a slight movement of truth, and to overcome the evil inclination is beyond the natural way, as our sages have said (Kiddushin 30b) that if not for the Holy One, Blessed be He, helping him, he cannot succeed. However, it is not a burden and toil in the eyes of the righteous; on the contrary, all their fears and desires and longings are to fulfill His will, even though it is very difficult, and according to the pain is the reward. But in the eyes of the wicked, this yoke is considered a burden and toil. Therefore, Pharaoh called the work of Moshe and Aharon by the name of burdens, and he said to them, "Go to your burdens." And the deeds of Israel, which they were doing in their homes, were from the aspect of idolatry and from the aspect of the deeds of Egypt, he called by the name of deeds, for these were not burdens and toil in his eyes, as they were pleasing and good in his sight, as our sages have said about the evil inclination that its beginning is sweet and its end is bitter. And this is what he meant when he said, "Why do you, Moshe and Aharon, disturb the people from their deeds at home? Go to your burdens, for you will work the hard work in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and with them, you will not accomplish anything anyway."
summary: The passage contrasts the perceptions of spiritual labor between the righteous and the wicked. It suggests that for the righteous, serving God is a source of joy and fulfillment, despite its inherent difficulties, while for the wicked, it is viewed as a burdensome toil. The text highlights that the true essence of divine service is often misunderstood, with the righteous finding value and purpose in their struggles, whereas the wicked see it merely as a heavy yoke. This dichotomy is illustrated through the example of Pharaoh, who dismisses the spiritual work of Moses and Aaron as mere burdensome labor.

passage_content: וז"ש חז"ל במדרש שא"ל פרעה אתם למה ודבריכם למה, שהי' פרעה הרשע מהביל את כוחם של משה ואהרן. שלא יוכל לפעול אצל ישראל לעוררם אל התשובה, לא בכח עבודתם ולא ע"י דיבורי תוכחה ומוסר, כמ"ש לעיל דהצדיק בכח עבודתו ומעשיו הטובים, יוכל להאיר בלבבות בנ"י ולהחזירם בתשובה, וכמו"כ ע"י דיבורי תוכחה, אבל פרעה אמר להם שלא יועילו אצל ישראל, כי כבר הם משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, וטוב שלא לומר דבר שאינו נשמע, וז"ש אתם למה, לא יועיל עצמיות שלכם לעשות רושם עליהם לטובה, ודבריכם למה, גם דבריכם לא יועילו, ובחנם כל טרחכם, ע"כ לכו לסבלותיכם והניחו את ישראל לעשות כחפצם וכרצונם.
translation: And this is what our Sages said in the Midrash: Pharaoh said to them, "Why are you here, and what is the purpose of your words?" For Pharaoh the wicked was diminishing the strength of Moshe and Aharon, so that he would not be able to act upon the Israelites to awaken them to repentance, neither through the power of their service nor through words of rebuke and moral instruction. As mentioned above, the righteous, through the power of their service and good deeds, can illuminate the hearts of the Children of Israel and bring them back to repentance, and likewise through words of rebuke. But Pharaoh told them that they would not be effective with the Israelites, for they were already sunk in the impurity of Egypt, and it is better not to speak words that will not be heard. Therefore, he said, "Why are you here?" Your very essence will not make a positive impression on them, and "What is the purpose of your words?" Even your words will not be effective, and all your efforts are in vain. Therefore, go to your burdens and leave the Israelites to do as they please and according to their will.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's attempt to undermine the spiritual influence of Moses and Aaron over the Israelites, asserting that their efforts to inspire repentance would be futile due to the Israelites' deep entrenchment in the impurities of Egypt. It highlights the Hasidic belief that a righteous person's actions and words can illuminate the hearts of others and lead them to repentance. However, Pharaoh dismisses this potential, suggesting that their intrinsic qualities and messages would not resonate with the Israelites, ultimately urging them to abandon their mission and return to their burdens. This reflects a broader theme of the struggle between spiritual redemption and the forces of oppression.

passage_content: ומ"ש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו וגו' ולכאורה למה הזכיר שמותם, ואין זה מדרך הלשון שהרי דבר עמהם לנוכח, אמנם ג"ז הי' מעין הטענה, ויובן עפימ"ש ק"ז הייטב לב בשם האו"י , שאין תוכחת מוסר מועיל לזולתו, בלתי ממי שהוא דומה לו, ואם יוכיחנו מי שלא טעם טעם חטא מעולם, יאמר בלבו שזה אינו יודע כמה קשה לפרוש מזה ולשוב, וע"כ לא יקבל ממנו תוכחה, אבל אם יוכיחנו מי שחטא ושב, ה"ה יודע טעמו של חטא והנסיון לפרוש ממנו, ע"כ יכנסו דיבוריו בלבו יותר, ופי' בזה מאה"כ טוב לשמוע גערת חכם מאיש שומע שיר כסילים, ר"ל מאיש כזה שכבר שמע שיר כסילים ופירש הימנה ועשה תשובה עיי"ש. וז"ש פרעה למה משה ואהרן צדיקים כמותכם תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, שבלא"ה לא יקבלו ישראל מכם, כי איך יקחו ראי' מדרך עבודתכם לעזוב דרכם הרעה ולשוב, כי יאמרו אתם לא חטאתם מעולם לפיכך אין אתם יודעים כמה קשה הוא לפרוש ממנה, וע"כ חדלו מהם כי בלא"ה לא יועילו דבריכם ומעשיכם כלום.
translation: And what is meant by Pharaoh's question, "Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people from their works?" At first glance, why did he mention their names? It is not the way of language, for he was speaking to them directly. However, this was also a kind of accusation, and it can be understood according to what is stated in Kabbalistic teachings, that no rebuke is effective for another unless it comes from someone who is similar to him. If someone who has never tasted the flavor of sin tries to rebuke us, he will say in his heart that he does not know how difficult it is to separate from it and return. Therefore, he will not accept rebuke from him. But if someone who has sinned and repented rebukes us, he knows the taste of sin and the struggle to separate from it; thus, his words will penetrate our hearts more deeply. This is explained by the verse, "It is better to hear the rebuke of a wise man than the song of fools," meaning from a person who has already heard the song of fools, separated from it, and repented, as explained there. And this is what Pharaoh meant: "Why do you, righteous ones like you, disturb the people from their works?" For in any case, the Israelites will not accept anything from you, for how can they take a sign from your way of serving to abandon their evil path and return? They will say that you have never sinned, therefore you do not know how difficult it is to separate from it. Thus, he told them to cease, for in any case, your words and actions will not help at all.
summary: The passage discusses the challenge of effective moral rebuke, emphasizing that only those who have experienced sin and repentance can truly guide others. It highlights that Moses and Aaron, as righteous figures, may be perceived by the Israelites as lacking the understanding of the struggle against sin, which diminishes the impact of their admonitions. Pharaoh's objection reflects a deeper theological insight that genuine repentance and the ability to inspire change come from shared experiences of sin and redemption. Thus, the text underscores the importance of relatable authority in spiritual guidance.

passage_content: ובזה אפ"ל מ"ש הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה, דהול"ל ולא שמעו אליו שהרי מוזכר בפסוק שמשה הי' המדבר אליהם, אמנם גם זה הי' טעם הסיבה שלא שמעו אליו, לצד שמשה הי' המדבר ולצד גדולתו וצדקתו, לפי שהי' ההבדל ביניהם רב, ורחוק מאוד מדריגתו ממדריגתם , ע"כ לא לקחו ראי' מגדולתו וצדקתו, כי חשבו שאין כוחם ככוחו בעבודת השי"ת, וכמ"ש לעיל דאין תוכחת המוכיח מוצלחת כ"א כשיוכיח רעהו הדומה לו.
translation: In this, one can explain what the verse states, "And they did not listen to Moses," for it could have said, "And they did not listen to him," since it is mentioned in the verse that Moses was speaking to them. However, this was also a reason for their failure to listen to him, because Moses was the one speaking and due to his greatness and righteousness, as the difference between them was vast, and his level was very far from their level. Therefore, they did not take evidence from his greatness and righteousness, for they thought that their strength was not like his in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as mentioned above, that the reproof of the one who reproves is only successful when he reproves a peer who is similar to him.
summary: The passage discusses the reason why the Israelites did not listen to Moses, despite him being the one speaking to them. It emphasizes the significant gap between Moses' greatness and righteousness compared to the people, which led them to feel inadequate and believe they could not match his level of service to God. This reflects the Hasidic idea that effective rebuke or guidance is only impactful when the one being addressed can relate to the speaker's level of spiritual attainment.

passage_content: ובפשטות אפשר לתרץ מה שלא שמעו אל משה עכשיו, ולעיל כתיב בפ ' שמות ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' את בנ"י וכי ראה את ענים וגו', הרי ששמעו אליו אע"פ שהיו ג"כ בקוצר רוח מעבודה קשה, ומה נשתנה עכשיו שלא שמעו אליו, אולם אפשר לחלק דשם לא נתבשרו רק בבשורת הגאולה לבד, ע"כ שמעו אליו, וכמ"ש במדרש וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה טובה ואינו שמח בתמי'. אבל עכשיו נתבשרו גם על קבלת התורה שא"ל משה מאמר השי"ת ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם והייתי לכם לאלקים וגו', וכתב הראב"ע והרמב"ן ז"ל, דבישר להם על מעמד הר סיני וקבלת התורה, כי שם נאמר והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים, וגם אמר להם לפרוש מע"ז שנא' והייתי לכם לאלקים וגו' ע"כ ולא שמעו אל משה עכשיו, שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, לצד שהיו משוקעים בטומאת מצרים כ"כ, ולגודל התגברות כוחות מצרים עליהם, ונראה כי זה הי' עיקר הסיבה שלא שמעו אליו שהרי במדרש לא הזכירו רק סיבה זו, שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז לצד שהיו משוקעים במ"ט שערי טומאה. ומ"ש הכתוב טעם הסיבה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, זהו טעם מצורף לזכותן של ישראל, דמצרים גרמו להם כל זאת ע"י שעבוד וטרוף הדעת, וע"כ לא הי' להם דעת מיושבת להתבונן בדברי משה רבינו, ואלולי העבודה קשה היו מתגברים על כוחות הטומאה לפרוש מע"ז כנ"ל.
translation: And simply, it is possible to explain why they did not listen to Moses now, whereas earlier it is written in Parashat Shemot, "And the people believed and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and that He had seen their affliction," thus they listened to him even though they were also short of spirit from hard work. What has changed now that they did not listen to him? However, it is possible to differentiate that there they were only informed of the good tidings of redemption, therefore they listened to him, as it is said in the Midrash, "Is there a person who is informed of good news and does not rejoice wholeheartedly?" But now they were also informed about the acceptance of the Torah, as Moses told them the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, "And I took you to be a people for Me, and I will be your God," etc. The Ra'avad and the Ramban, may their merit protect us, wrote that he informed them about the event at Mount Sinai and the acceptance of the Torah, for there it was said, "And you shall be to Me a treasured people from among all the nations," and he also told them to separate from idolatry, as it is said, "And I will be your God," etc. Therefore, they did not listen to Moses now, as it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, because they were so deeply immersed in the impurity of Egypt and due to the great overpowering of the forces of Egypt over them. It seems that this was the main reason they did not listen to him, for in the Midrash, only this reason is mentioned, that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry because they were immersed in the forty-nine gates of impurity. And what the verse states as the reason for their shortness of spirit and hard work is an additional reason in favor of the merit of Israel, for Egypt caused them all this through servitude and confusion of mind, and therefore they did not have settled minds to contemplate the words of our teacher Moses. Had it not been for the hard work, they would have overcome the forces of impurity to separate from idolatry, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses why the Israelites initially listened to Moses regarding the promise of redemption but later struggled to accept the message of receiving the Torah. It suggests that while they were joyful about the good news of redemption, the additional requirement to separate from idolatry was difficult for them due to their deep entrenchment in the impurities of Egypt. The text emphasizes that their suffering and hard labor in Egypt clouded their ability to fully comprehend and respond to Moses' teachings, highlighting the struggle between spiritual elevation and the weight of past transgressions. Ultimately, it reflects on the challenges of spiritual awakening amidst the burdens of oppression and impurity.
