passage_content: ובזה יתבאר המסורה הנ"ל הובא בבעה"ט לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ד' לכן אמור לו הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', עפימ"ש חז"ל (סנהדרין דף פ"א ע"ב) שנתעלמה ממשרע"ה הלכה זו דבועל ארמית קנאים פוגעין בו, כדי שיבא פנחס ויטול את הראוי לו, עוד אמרו חז"ל במדרש ילקוט (רמז תשע"א) פנחס זה אלי', ולפי שעשה שלו' בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים בעוה"ז, ע"כ עתיד הוא להיות מבשר הגאולה כמ"ש והשיב לב אבות על בנים וגו', מבואר דזה הי' שכרו שיהי' מבשר הגאולה בסוף יומיא , וכן כתב תרגום יוב"ע עה"פ לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', בשבועא אימר לי' וכו' ואעבדיני ' מלאך קיים, ויחי לעלמא למבשרא גאולתא בסוף יומיא . ואפשר שזה כוונת המסורה דבא לתרץ דאיך יתכן שלא הודיע הקב"ה לאבות העולם בחי' שם הוי' וסוד הגאולה הרמוז בה, והודיע אותה למשה רבינו, ע"כ אחר שאמר הכתוב ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם, נתן טעם על שהודיע אותה למשה במ"ש לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', כי טעם ההודעה למשה היתה לצורך ישראל, לפי שהוא הי' השליח לגאול את ישראל, ובהבטחת שם הוי' בישר אותן על גאולתן, ובכח השם הזה עשה להם נסים נגליים להוציאם ממצרים כנ"ל וכמ"ש בתנחומא הנ"ל. וכמו"כ הי' בפנחס דע"כ נתעלמה הלכה זו ממשה כדי שיבא פנחס ויטול את הראוי לו, שהיא עתיד להיות מבשר הגאולה כנ"ל, וזה מאמר המסורה לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ד', שגילה הקב"ה למשה מה שנתעלם מאבות העולם מפני שהוא הי' השליח לגאולתן של ישראל, ומה"ט לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', שנתגלה לפנחס מה שנתעלמה ממשרע"ה , מפני שהי' מוכן להיות השליח לגאולתן של ישראל, וחדא טעמא לתרוייהו , ואפשר שמ"ש רש"י ז"ל וארא אל האבות, ר"ל דמה שנתעלמה הודעה זו מהאבות הקדושים ונתגלה למשרע"ה , לא לצד שמעלתו גדלה על מעלתם. כי הם היו אבות העולם ושורש אומה הישראלית, וכל מה שיש בענף יש בשורש, אלא לצד שהי' מוכן הודעה זו למשה, שהוצרך אלי' לצורך גאולתן של ישראל כמ"ש בתנחומא הנ"ל.
translation: And this will clarify the aforementioned tradition brought in the Ba'al HaTurim: therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord; therefore say to him, here I am giving him My covenant, as our Sages have said (Sanhedrin 81b) that this law was hidden from Moshe Rabbeinu, that a zealot may take action against him, so that Pinchas would come and take what is due to him. Our Sages also said in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 911) that Pinchas is Eliyahu, and because he made peace between Israel and their Father in Heaven in this world, therefore he is destined to be the herald of redemption, as it is written, and He will turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, etc. It is clear that this was his reward, to be the herald of redemption at the end of days. And so the Targum Yonatan wrote on the verse, therefore say, here I am giving him My covenant, in the week I will say to him, etc., and I will serve him, a standing angel, and he will live forever to herald the redemption at the end of days. And it is possible that this is the intention of the tradition, coming to explain how it could be that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not inform the forefathers of the world about the name Havayah and the secret of the redemption hinted at therein, and He informed it to Moshe Rabbeinu. Therefore, after the verse states, and My name the Lord was not known to them, it gives a reason for why He informed it to Moshe, saying, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, for the reason for the revelation to Moshe was for the sake of Israel, since he was the messenger to redeem Israel, and with the assurance of the name Havayah, he would inform them of their redemption, and by the power of this name, he performed open miracles to take them out of Egypt, as mentioned above and as stated in the aforementioned Tanchuma. Likewise, it was with Pinchas, that this law was hidden from Moshe so that Pinchas would come and take what is due to him, which is destined to be the herald of redemption, as mentioned above. And this is the statement of the tradition, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, that the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed to Moshe what was hidden from the forefathers of the world because he was the messenger for their redemption. And for this reason, therefore say, here I am giving him My covenant, that what was revealed to Pinchas was hidden from Moshe Rabbeinu, because he was prepared to be the messenger for their redemption. And there is one reason for both of them, and it is possible that what Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote, and I appeared to the forefathers, means that what was hidden from the holy forefathers and revealed to Moshe Rabbeinu was not because his stature was greater than theirs. For they were the forefathers of the world and the root of the Jewish nation, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root, but because this revelation was prepared for Moshe, who needed it for the sake of the redemption of Israel, as stated in the aforementioned Tanchuma.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's revelation to Moses regarding the name of the Divine and the secret of redemption, which was previously hidden from the patriarchs. It emphasizes that Moses was chosen as the messenger for the redemption of Israel, and thus received this crucial knowledge for their sake. Additionally, it highlights that the law concerning zealots was concealed from Moses to allow Pinchas to fulfill his role as a future herald of redemption, illustrating the interconnectedness of divine revelation and the roles of key figures in Jewish history. Ultimately, the text underscores the idea that the revelations were tailored to the needs of the people and their redemption process.

passage_content: וידבר אלקים אל משה ויאמר אליו אני ד' וגו' כבר דקדקו המפרשים שהתחיל במדת הדין, וסיים אני ד' שהוא שם של רחמים.
translation: And God spoke to Moses and said to him, "I am the Lord," etc. The commentators have already noted that He began with the attribute of judgment and concluded with "I am the Lord," which is a name of mercy.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the transition from the attribute of justice to the attribute of mercy. The text emphasizes that while God initially addresses Moses with a tone of strict judgment, He concludes with the name of the Divine that signifies compassion. This shift illustrates the balance between justice and mercy in God's relationship with humanity, underscoring the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of divine mercy. Ultimately, it reflects the theological insight that even in moments of strictness, God's essence is rooted in compassion.

passage_content: ב) ז"ל פי' דבר אתו משפט על שהקשה לדבר ולומר למה הרעותה וגו' ויאמר אליו אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו' ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי שדברתי לאבות הראשונים וכו ', וצ"ב כוונת המאמר, וכי עבד משרע"ה שליחותו ע"מ לקבל פרס, ומה צורך בהבטחה זו נאמן לשלם שכר לענין השליחות. גם מ"ש לא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי צ"ב, מה צורך בהודעה זו למשרע"ה אדון כל הנביאים, וידע שדברו ית ' לא ישוב ריקם ולא לחנם שלחו כ"א שתתקיים שליחותו, וכבר הבטיחו ית ' ע"ז ונתן לו אות, כמ"ש לעיל וזה לך האות בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ופרש"י זה לך האות שתצליח בשליחותי וכו ', ומה צורך לכפול הדברים וכבר ידע בזה. גם מ"ש לקיים דברי שדברתי לאבות הראשונים, כבר נאמר לו כ"ז בתחילת השליחות שהוא לקיים הבטחתו ית ' לאבות הראשונים, כמבואר לעיל בפ ' שמות ומה צורך לכפול, גם מה טעם בטענות אלו לסתור דברי משה רבינו שאמר למה הרעותה בשביל צערן של ישראל, ובודאי לא הי' מסופק בכל אלה ולא נעלמו מידיעתו.
translation: B) Blessed be His name, the explanation is that he spoke with Him a judgment for questioning why He had caused harm, etc. And He said to him, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward," etc., "and I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill the words that I spoke to the forefathers," etc. And it is to be wondered what the intent of this statement is, and did Moshe Rabbeinu perform his mission in order to receive a reward? What need is there for this assurance of being faithful to pay a reward regarding the mission? Also, what is meant by "I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill My words"? What need is there for this notification to Moshe Rabbeinu, the master of all the prophets, who knows that the words of the Holy One, blessed be He, do not return empty and that He did not send him for naught, but rather that his mission would be fulfilled? And He has already assured him of this and gave him a sign, as it is said above, "And this shall be the sign to you that when you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." And Rashi explains, "This shall be the sign that you will succeed in My mission," etc. What need is there to repeat these words when he already knows this? Also, regarding the statement "to fulfill the words that I spoke to the forefathers," it was already told to him all this at the beginning of the mission, that it is to fulfill His promise to the forefathers, as explained above in the portion of Shemot. What need is there to repeat it? Furthermore, what is the reason for these claims to refute the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, who said, "Why have You harmed them" because of the suffering of Israel? Certainly, he was not in doubt about any of these matters, nor were they hidden from his knowledge.
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between God and Moses, emphasizing the assurance that God is faithful to fulfill His promises and that Moses's mission is not in vain. It questions why God reiterates His commitment to reward and the purpose of Moses's mission, given that Moses is already aware of God's intentions and the significance of his role. The text highlights the importance of divine promises made to the patriarchs and the necessity of their fulfillment, suggesting that Moses's concerns stem from the suffering of the Israelites rather than doubt in God's word. Ultimately, it reflects on the deep relationship between divine assurance and human agency in the context of prophetic missions.

passage_content: ג) (ריש פרשה זו) הה"ד (קהלת ב') ופניתי אני לראות חכמה והוללות וסכלות וגו', הפסוק הזה נאמר על שלמה ועל משה וכו ', כיצד נאמר על משה לפי שכבר הודיע הקב"ה למשה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך וכו ', ומשה לא שמר את הדבר ובא להתחכם וכו' והתחיל אומר למה הרעותה , וע"ז נאמר שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה, של הוללות וסכלות היו, וכי מה הי' לו להרהר אחר מדותיו של הקב"ה, ועל דבר זה בקשה מדה"ד לפגוע במשה וכו' ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צערן של ישראל דבר כן, חזר ונהג עמו במדת הרחמים ע"כ. ראוי להבין דאם חכמה ודעת יש כאן. סכלות והוללות אין כאן. והם ב' הפכים רחוקים מקצה אל הקצה.
translation: 3) (Beginning of this section) As it is written (Ecclesiastes 2): "And I turned to see wisdom and folly and madness," this verse is said about Solomon and Moses, etc. How is it said about Moses? Because the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses that Pharaoh would not let them go, etc. And Moses did not keep this matter and began to seek wisdom, etc., and started to say, "Why have You harmed Your people?" And concerning this, it is said that that wisdom and knowledge of Moses were of folly and madness. And what right did he have to question the attributes of the Holy One, Blessed be He? And for this reason, the attribute of judgment sought to strike Moses, etc. And since the Holy One, Blessed be He, saw that this was due to the suffering of Israel, He returned and acted with him in the attribute of mercy. Therefore, it is fitting to understand that if there is wisdom and knowledge here, there is no folly and madness. And these are two opposites, far apart from one another.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between wisdom and folly as exemplified by Moses and Solomon, highlighting that Moses questioned God's intentions despite being forewarned about Pharaoh's refusal to let the Israelites go. This questioning is characterized as a form of folly, as it reflects a lack of trust in God's wisdom. However, God's response to Moses' distress for the suffering of the Israelites demonstrates divine compassion, indicating that true wisdom aligns with understanding and accepting God's ways. The text emphasizes the distinction between genuine wisdom and the folly of doubting divine providence.

passage_content: ד) שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה יל"ד דהול"ל ולא שמעו אליו, דכבר נזכר בפסוק דמשה הי' המדבר אליהם, גם צ"ב דמה נתינת טעם בזה דמפני עבודה קשה לא שמעו אליו ואדרבה לפי גודל הצרה הי"ל לשמוח יותר בבשורת הגאולה, ובמכילתא הקשו כן, וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח וכו' אלא שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, וראוי להבין דלעיל בפ ' שמות כשנתבשרו בתחלה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' את בנ"י וכי ראה את ענים, ואיך עתה נהפכו כולו ולא שמעו אליו, וקשה הן לטעם המכילתא והן לטעם המפורש בפסוק מפני קוצר רוח וגו'
translation: D) Listen to Moses, because of shortness of spirit and hard work, they did not listen to him. It should have been stated, "and they did not listen to him," as it is already mentioned in the verse that Moses was speaking to them. Furthermore, it is puzzling why the reason given is that due to hard work they did not listen to him; on the contrary, given the magnitude of their distress, they should have been even more joyful at the tidings of redemption. And in the Mekilta, they posed a similar question: is there a person who hears good news and does not rejoice, etc.? Rather, it was difficult for them to part from idolatry. It is worth understanding that earlier in Parashat Shemot, when they were first informed, it is written, "And the people believed and heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and had seen their affliction." How is it now that they have all turned away and did not listen to him? This is difficult both for the reason given in the Mekilta and for the reason explicitly stated in the verse, due to shortness of spirit, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites not listening to Moses due to their suffering and hard labor, despite the promise of redemption. It questions why, after initially believing in God's message, they became despondent and unresponsive. The text suggests that their attachment to idolatry made it difficult for them to embrace the news of salvation, highlighting the struggle between faith and the burdens of oppression. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the challenges of spiritual awakening amidst physical and emotional distress.

passage_content: ה) משה לפני ד' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה וגו', צ"ב מלת לאמור דבכ"מ פירושו שיאמר לאחרים, וכאן שדיבר משה אל ד' מהו לאמר , ובספרי ר"פ ואתחנן הקשו כן על פסוק הזה שאין ת"ל לאמר , ומהו ת"ל לאמור, אמר לו הודיעני אם אתה גואלם אם לאו, וצ"ב למה הוצרך להודעה זו, אחרי שהשי"ת שלחו והזכיר לו ד' לשונות של גאולה והוצאתי והצלתי וגאלתי וגו', והבטיחו ית ' כמה פעמים שיגאלם וע"ד כן שלחו, ולמה ביקש עוד הודיעני אם אתה גואלם אם לאו.
translation: 5) Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" etc. It is puzzling why the word "to say" (לאמור) is used here, as in every other place it means to say to others, and here, since Moses was speaking to God, what does "to say" mean? And in the Sifrei, in Parashat Va'etchanan, they posed a similar question on this verse, asking why it says "to say." What does "to say" mean? He was told, "Inform me if You are redeeming them or not." It is puzzling why this information was necessary, after the Holy One, Blessed be He, had sent him and reminded him of the four expressions of redemption: "I will take you out," "I will save you," "I will redeem you," etc., and He promised him several times that He would redeem them, and according to this, He sent him. Why did he still ask, "Inform me if You are redeeming them or not"?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores Moses' dialogue with God, particularly focusing on the term "saying" (לאמר) in the context of Moses expressing doubt about the Israelites' willingness to listen to him. The text raises the question of why Moses seeks confirmation of God's role as the Redeemer despite already receiving multiple assurances of redemption through the four expressions of deliverance. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of faith and the human need for reassurance in the face of divine promises.

passage_content: ו) בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, במדרש רז"ל ( ב"ר פ' צ"ב סי' ז') זה אחד מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה, והקשו המפורשים דק"ו פריכא הוא. דהלא מפורש בפסוק מפני קוצר רוח ועבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך אצל פרעה.
translation: And the children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me? In the Midrash, our Sages of blessed memory (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 7) state that this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah. The commentators have questioned this, saying that the a fortiori argument is weak. For it is explicitly stated in the verse, "because of shortness of breath and hard work," and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the Israelites' lack of faith and their inability to listen to God, questioning how Pharaoh, who is even more distant from divine communication, could be expected to heed God's message. The text references a midrash that highlights this as one of the ten logical deductions in the Torah, emphasizing the paradox of expecting Pharaoh to respond when the Israelites themselves are unresponsive due to their suffering and oppression. This illustrates a key Hasidic concept of the struggle between divine will and human resistance, as well as the profound implications of faith and redemption amidst hardship.

passage_content: ז) בפ ' שמות ויען משה ויאמר והן לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד', הקשו המפורשים מה מקום לטענת לא יאמינו לי אחר שהבטיחו הבוי"ת ושמעו לקולך גם יל"ד בלשון והן לא יאמינו לי, דמלת והן מיותר ויספיק שיאמר ולא יאמינו וגו', או והם לא יאמינו, ומהו הכוונה במלת והן.
translation: 7) In Parashat Shemot, Moses answered and said, "But behold, they will not believe me and they will not listen to my voice, for they will say, 'The Lord did not appear to you.'" The commentators questioned what place there is for the claim of "they will not believe me" after the Holy One, Blessed be He, assured him that they would listen to your voice. It is also asked regarding the wording "but behold, they will not believe me," that the word "behold" is superfluous, and it would suffice to say "and they will not believe" or "and they will not believe." What is the intention of the word "behold"?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores Moses' concern about the Israelites' disbelief in his mission, despite God's assurance that they would listen to him. The use of the word "והן" (and they) is examined, suggesting a deeper layer of doubt and the complexity of faith. This highlights the struggle between divine promise and human skepticism, emphasizing the need for a profound connection to faith that transcends mere belief in miracles. The text reflects on the nature of trust in God and the challenges of leadership in the face of doubt.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי המד"ר ( בפ ' שמות פ' ה' סי' ט"ז) ויאמר אלהם מלך מצרים למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם וגו', מהו למה, אמר להם אתם למה ודבריכם למה וצ"ב הכוונה (וכבר פירשנוהו לעיל בדברנו פ' שמות). וכעת נ"ל באופן אחר בהקדם דברי המד"ר (שמות פ"ג סט"ז ) ויאמר שלח נא ביד תשלח, א"ר חייא הגדול אמר לפניו רבש"ע איזה חביב לאדם בן אחיו או בן בנו הוי אומר בן בנו, כשבקשת להציל את לוט בן אחי אברהם, ביד המלאכים שלחת להצילו, בניו של אברהם שהם ס' רבוא בידי אתה משלח להצילם, שלח נא ביד המלאכים שאתה רגיל לשלח עכ"ד המדרש. והקשה בס' תוס ' חן ממ"ד במס' ב"ב (דף קכ"ח ע"א) שלח לי' ר' אבא לר ' יוסף בר חמא , הלכה שלישי בשני כשר להעיד וכו ', מר בר רב אשי אכשר באבא דאבא , ולית הלכתא כמר בר רב אשי, ופי' הרשב"ם אכשר באבא דאבא שיעיד הבן לאבי אביו וכו ', ולית הלכתא כוותי' דבני בנים ובני בני בנים עד אלף דורות לא יעידו לאבותיהם, דבן ירך אביו הוא, וכתבו התוס ' ואין נראה לר"י כיון דאתפלג דרא כ"כ עכ"ל, וכן כתבו התוס ' הך סברא בסנהדרין (דף כ"ח ע"א) עיי"ש, ולפי"ז לכאורה לא קשה קושית משרע"ה כלל, דלוט שהי' בן אחיו של אברהם הי' שני בראשון, והוא קרבות הפסול לעדות, אבל ישראל כבר אפלוג דרא מאברהם. והנה מדברי המדרש הנ"ל מוכח כדברי הרשב"ם ז"ל דבבנו וב"ב עד סוף כל הדורות לא אמרי' אפלוג דרא , משום דבן ירך אביו הוא. אבל באמת לית הלכתא כדברי הרשב"ם , והתוס ' והרא"ש וכל הפוסקים חולקים עליו, ובש"ע לא הובא דעת הרשב"ם כלל, ופסקינן הלכתא דדור רביעי כשר לעדות דכבר אפלוג דרא , וא"כ מה הי' קושיתו של משרע"ה , והרי ישראל במצרים כבר היו אחר כמה דורות, ולא דמי לבן אחיו שהוא שני בראשון וצ"ב .
translation:
To clarify the matter, we will begin with the words of the Midrash (in Parashat Shemot, chapter 5, section 16): "And the king of Egypt said to them, 'Why do you, Moses and Aaron, disturb the people...?' What does 'why' mean? He said to them, 'You are the reason, and your words are the reason,' and the intention is unclear (and we have already explained this above in our discussion of Parashat Shemot). Now it seems to me in another way, by prefacing the words of the Midrash (Shemot 3:16): 'And he said, "Please send by the hand of whom You will send."' Rabbi Chiya the Great said before Him, 'Master of the Universe, which is more beloved to a person, the son of his brother or the son of his son?' You would say, 'the son of his son.' When You sought to save Lot, the son of Abraham's brother, You sent him by the hands of the angels. The sons of Abraham, who are six hundred thousand, You send to save them by Your own hand. Please send by the angels that You are accustomed to send.' Thus far the Midrash. 

And it is difficult in the book Tosafot, as mentioned in Bava Batra (page 128a): 'Rabbi Abba sent to Rabbi Yosef bar Chama, "The third law in the second is valid to testify, etc." Mar bar Rav Ashi said, "It is valid through the father of the father," and the law is not like Mar bar Rav Ashi. And the explanation of the Rashbam is that it is valid through the father of the father, that the son may testify for his grandfather, etc. But the law is not like them, for sons of sons and sons of sons of sons up to a thousand generations do not testify for their ancestors, for a son is the thigh of his father. And the Tosafot wrote, 'And it does not seem to Rabbi Yochanan, since the generations have split so much.' Thus far. And so the Tosafot wrote this reasoning in Sanhedrin (page 28a), see there. 

According to this, it seems that the question of Moshe Rabbeinu is not difficult at all, for Lot, who was the son of Abraham's brother, was second in the first generation, and he is disqualified for testimony. But Israel had already split from Abraham. And behold, from the words of the aforementioned Midrash, it is evident according to the words of the Rashbam, that in the case of a son and a grandson until the end of all generations, we do not say they have split from the generation, because a son is the thigh of his father. But in truth, the law is not like the words of the Rashbam, and the Tosafot and the Rosh and all the poskim disagree with him, and in the Shulchan Aruch, the opinion of the Rashbam is not brought at all, and we rule that the law is that a fourth generation is valid for testimony, for they have already split from the generation. And if so, what was Moshe Rabbeinu's question? And behold, Israel in Egypt were already after several generations, and it is not comparable to the son of a brother who is second in the first generation, and the intention is unclear."
summary: The passage discusses the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh, emphasizing the significance of familial relationships in the context of divine intervention and redemption. It highlights the idea that while Moses sought to save the Israelites, who were several generations removed from Abraham, the connection to their ancestor still held spiritual weight. The text contrasts different interpretations of lineage and its implications for testimony, ultimately suggesting that the bond between generations remains relevant in the eyes of God. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the enduring connection between the Jewish people and their patriarchs, underscoring the importance of faith and divine mercy in their salvation.

passage_content: ויתבאר עפימ"ש ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה ( בפ ' תולדות) הטעם על שהיו אבותינו אברהם ויצחק עקרים דאי משום שהקב"ה מתאוו ' לתפילתן של צדיקים כאמרם ז"ל, הי' מספיק באמהות עקרות והבן, ועוד יעקב בחיר שבאבות מ"ט לא הי' עקר משום טעם זה והי' די ברחל. ואמרתי הטעם דצפה הקב"ה שמאברהם ויצחק יצאו גם ישמעאל ועשו הרשעים, ורצה השי"ת שלא יגן עליהם זכותן, וענין זכות אבות הוא כי כל תולדותיו הם אצלו בכח , וא"כ כל מה שמסגל מצות ומע"ט תולדותיו מסגלין עמו, וע"כ יש להם מזכות מצות ומע"ט של האבות. ולכך היו אבותינו עקרים בטבע, ואם כן לא הי' בהם התולדות בכח הגוף כלל, רק כרגע נעשה להם נס והולידו, ומה"ט אין להם לעשו וישמעאל זכות אבות כלל, דלא היו בהם בכח לא בגוף ולא בנפש אבל ישראל היו בכח נשמתן כנודע דאברהם ויצחק הם מקור נשמת ישראל, ומעתה יובן מה שהיו אבותינו אברהם ויצחק עקרים ויעקב לא הוצרך לזה שלא הי' פסול בזרעו והבן, עכת"ד ק"ז זלל"ה .
translation: And it is explained according to the words of the holy Rabbi (in Parashat Toldot) the reason why our forefathers Abraham and Isaac were barren. If it were because the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous, as our sages of blessed memory said, it would have been sufficient for the matriarchs to be barren and then give birth. Furthermore, Jacob, the chosen one among the patriarchs, was not barren for this reason, and it was enough for Rachel. And I said the reason is that the Holy One, blessed be He, foresaw that from Abraham and Isaac would come also Ishmael and Esau, the wicked, and the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted that their merit should not protect them. The matter of the merit of the forefathers is that all their descendants are with Him in potential, and therefore all that they acquire through commandments and good deeds, their descendants acquire with them. Thus, they have a share in the merit of the commandments and good deeds of the forefathers. For this reason, our forefathers were naturally barren, and therefore there was no potential for offspring in them at all, only at that moment a miracle occurred and they gave birth. And for this reason, Ishmael and Esau do not have the merit of the forefathers at all, for they did not have it in potential, neither in body nor in soul, but Israel had it in the potential of their souls, as is known that Abraham and Isaac are the source of the soul of Israel. From this, it can be understood why our forefathers Abraham and Isaac were barren, and Jacob did not need this, for there was no flaw in his offspring. Thus is the conclusion of the holy Rabbi.
summary: The passage discusses the reason why the patriarchs Abraham and Isaac were childless, suggesting that God desired their prayers and wanted to prevent the merit of their lineage from protecting the wicked descendants, such as Ishmael and Esau. It emphasizes that the spiritual potential of their descendants was inherent in their souls, rather than in their physical bodies, which is why Abraham and Isaac experienced miraculous births. In contrast, Jacob did not face this issue because his lineage was free from any spiritual blemish, allowing for natural offspring. Thus, the concept of "merit of the ancestors" is highlighted, indicating that only the righteous descendants of Abraham and Isaac possess this spiritual legacy.

passage_content: ומעתה א"ש קושית משרע"ה כיון דקרבות ישראל אל האבות הקדושים מצד שורש נשמתם שהיו כלולים בהם בכח , ולא מצד הגופים, ע"כ לא שייך אצלם סברת איפלוג דרא , כי קרבתם במקור עליון באילן הנשמות, ואין שם פירוד ולא הפלגה, וע"כ ישראל נחשבים בנים לאבוה"ק עד סוף כל הדורות ואין לומר בהם איפלוג דרא , וא"ש טענתו של משרע"ה איזה חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כנ"ל בדברי המדרש רבה.
translation: And from now on, I understand the question of Moshe Rabbeinu, since the closeness of Israel to the holy forefathers is from the root of their souls, which were included in them in potential, and not from their bodies. Therefore, the concept of "Iplug D'ra" does not apply to them, because their closeness is in the supreme source in the tree of souls, where there is no separation or division. Thus, Israel is considered children of the holy forefathers for all generations, and one cannot say "Iplug D'ra" about them. And I understand the argument of Moshe Rabbeinu regarding which beloved is the son of his brother or the son of his son, as mentioned in the words of Midrash Rabbah.
summary: The passage discusses the intrinsic connection between the Jewish people and the holy patriarchs, emphasizing that this bond is rooted in the spiritual essence of their souls rather than their physical forms. It asserts that because this connection exists at a higher, unified source of souls, there is no division or separation among them, making the Jewish people eternally regarded as children of the holy ancestors. Consequently, the concept of "Ipalug D'ra," or division of generations, does not apply to them, reinforcing their unique and enduring relationship with their spiritual lineage. This theological insight highlights the unity and continuity of the Jewish soul across generations.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המד"ר הנ"ל למה משה ואהרן וגו' אמר להם פרעה אתם למה ודבריכם למה, דפרעה הקשה להם ג"כ קושיא הנ"ל, איזה חביב לאדם בן אחיו או בן בנו, וא"כ למה שלח הקב"ה אתכם להציל את ישראל, ולמה לא שלח מלאכים כאשר שלח להציל את לוט גם לצד שבן בנו חביב יותר ובן ירך אביו הוא, ראוי הי' שהקב"ה בעצמו יגאל את ישראל ולא ע"י שלוחים, כדאיתא במד"ר (פ' ג' סי' ד') שטען משרע"ה כן ואמר רבון העולמים כשירד יעקב למצרים, לא כך אמרת לו אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, ועכשיו אתה אומר לי לכה ואשלחך אל פרעה, לא אנכי הוא שאמרת ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, וז"ש מי אנכי כי אלך וגו' לא אנכי אני שהבטחת לאבותיהם עכ"ד המדרש. וכמו"כ פרעה הקשה קושיא זו למשה ואהרן, כי לצד קרבות של האבות דבן ירך אביו הוא, הי' ראוי שהקב"ה בעצמו יגאל אתכם, אלא ע"כ דכבר איפלוג דרא וא"כ בטלה זכות אבות, וכיון שכן אין לכם זכות להיותכם נגאלים, כמבואר במד"ר פ' בא ( פט"ו ס"ד) אמר הקב"ה אם אני מסתכל במעשיהם של ישראל אינם נגאלים לעולם, אלא למי אני מסתכל לאבותיהם הקדושים ובזכות אבותם אני גואלם, לכך כתיב מדלג על ההרים ואין הרים אלא אבות וכו ', וכן דרשו ז"ל במס' ר"ה (דף י"א ע"א) ומבואר כן במדרשי חז"ל בהרבה מקומות דהגאולה הי' רק בזכות אבות. דאל"ה לא הי' הזמן עדיין שיצאו ממצרים. גם לא הי' זכותם מספיק. ומעתה טען פרעה ממנ"פ אתם למה, ר"ל למה באתם אתם להיות הגואלים, והי' ראוי שהקב"ה בעצמו יגאלם לצד הקרבות דבן בנו חביב יותר, אאע"כ דאיפלוג דרא ואין להם זכות אבות, וא"כ דבריכם למה, לא יועיל דבריכם להוציא את ישראל, כי בלי זכות אבות אינם נגאלים לעולם כנ"ל בדברי המדרש רבה, ופרעה הי' חכם גדול בטומאה והשיג את כל אלה, אלא שלא ידע שקרבת ישראל לאבות הקדושים מצד שורש נשמותיהם, ולא שייך בהם איפלוג דרא . ומה שלא גאלם הקב"ה בעצמו אלא ע"י שליחות משה ואהרן לפי שלא הי' עדיין גאולה נצחיות, והטעם לפי שלא נשלם עדיין בירור כל הניצה"ק כמבואר בדברי האריז"ל , והוצרכו ישראל להשלים זאת בשאר גליות, ולעתיד הקב"ה בעצמו יגאלנו, ואז יהי' גאולה נצחי שאין אחרי' גלות עוד. כמ"ש ז"ל ופדויי ד' ישובון ( ישעי ' נ"א) אין אומר ופדויי משה ואהרן אלא ופדויי ד', שגאולה העתידה יהי' ע"י הקב"ה בעצמו, ואיתא בילקוט (רמז תקע"ז) אמר הקב"ה בעוה"ז הייתם נושעים ע"י בנ"א, במצרים ע"י משה ואהרן בימי סיסרא ע"י דבורה וברק וכו ', ולפי שהיו ע"י בשר ודם הייתם חוזרים ומשתעבדים, אבל לע"ל אני בעצמי גואל אתכם ועוד יותר אין אתם משתעבדים שנא' ישראל נושע בד' תשועת עולמים ע"כ.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash as to why Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, "You, why are you here, and what are your words?" For Pharaoh also posed them the above question: which is more beloved to a person, a son of his brother or a son of his son? If so, why did the Holy One, blessed be He, send you to save Israel, and why did He not send angels as He sent to save Lot? After all, a son of his son is more beloved, being a descendant of his loins; it would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem Israel Himself and not through messengers, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, section 4) that Moses argued this point and said, "Master of the Universe, when Jacob descended to Egypt, did You not say to him, 'I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you up'? And now You say to me, 'Go and I will send you to Pharaoh'? Is it not I who You promised, 'I will also bring you up'?" Therefore, he said, "Who am I that I should go..."—I am not the one You promised to their forefathers, thus concludes the Midrash. Similarly, Pharaoh posed this question to Moses and Aaron, for due to the closeness of the forefathers, being a descendant of his loins, it would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem you Himself. However, since the generation has already become corrupt, the merit of the forefathers is nullified, and since that is the case, you have no merit to be redeemed, as explained in the Midrash, Parashat Bo (15:34). The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "If I look at the deeds of Israel, they will never be redeemed, but whom do I look at? To their holy forefathers, and in the merit of their forefathers, I will redeem them." Therefore, it is written, "leaping over the mountains," and mountains refer to the forefathers, etc. And so our sages expounded in Tractate Rosh Hashanah (11a), and it is explained in many places in the Midrashim of the sages that the redemption was only in the merit of the forefathers. Otherwise, the time for them to leave Egypt had not yet come, nor was their merit sufficient. From now on, Pharaoh argued, "You, why are you here?" meaning, why have you come to be the redeemers? It would have been fitting for the Holy One, blessed be He, to redeem them Himself due to the closeness of the forefathers, unless it is that the generation has become corrupt and they have no merit of the forefathers. Therefore, your words are for what? Your words will not help to bring out Israel, for without the merit of the forefathers, they will never be redeemed, as stated above in the words of the Midrash. And Pharaoh was a great wise man in impurity and understood all of this, except that he did not know that the closeness of Israel to the holy forefathers is due to the root of their souls, and that the corruption of the generation does not apply to them. And the reason the Holy One, blessed be He, did not redeem them Himself but through the agency of Moses and Aaron is because there was not yet an eternal redemption, and the reason is that the clarification of all the sparks of holiness had not yet been completed, as explained in the words of the Arizal. The Israelites needed to complete this in the other exiles, and in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will redeem us Himself, and then there will be an eternal redemption with no subsequent exile. As our sages said, "And the redeemed of the Lord shall return" (Isaiah 51), it does not say, "And the redeemed of Moses and Aaron," but "And the redeemed of the Lord," for the future redemption will be by the Holy One, blessed be He Himself. And it is stated in the Yalkut (Remez 877), "The Holy One, blessed be He, said, 'In this world, you were saved by human beings, in Egypt by Moses and Aaron, in the days of Sisera by Deborah and Barak, etc. Because they were through flesh and blood, you would return and be enslaved. But in the future, I Myself will redeem you, and even more, you will not be enslaved,' as it is said, 'Israel is saved by the Lord, a salvation of worlds.'"
summary: The passage discusses the question posed by Pharaoh to Moses and Aaron regarding why God did not redeem the Israelites Himself, given the closeness of the patriarchs to God. It emphasizes that the redemption of Israel is ultimately dependent on the merit of the ancestors, as the current generation lacks sufficient merit for redemption. The text highlights that while Moses and Aaron were sent as agents of redemption, the ultimate and eternal redemption will come directly from God in the future, ensuring that it will be a lasting salvation without subsequent exile. This reflects a key Hasidic belief in the importance of the connection to the patriarchs and the eventual divine intervention in the redemption process.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יבואר מאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' והדקדוקים הנ"ל ( בקושיא ז'), ואפשר על כי ראו ישראל שהוכבד עליהם עול השעבוד, כמאמר משרע"ה ומאז באתי אל פרעה וגו' הרע לעם הזה והצל לא הצלת את עמך, ע"כ חששו שאין להם הגנת זכות אבות עוד, דכבר איפלוג דרא , ובלי זכות אבות א"א שיהיו נגאלים כדברי המדרש הנ"ל, והי' להם ראי' ע"ז דאיפלוג דרא דאל"כ לא הי' משה רבינו השליח, דאיזה מהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כטענת משרע"ה לפני הקב"ה, וז"ש הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה ר"ל לפי שמשה רבינו הי' השליח, ע"כ חששו דכבר איפלוג דרא ואין מספיק זכותם להיות נגאלים, וזכות אבות כבר נפסקה, והראי' מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שהוכבד פרעה עולו עליהם ולא הגין עליהם זכות אבות כנ"ל.
translation: And it will be explained according to our way from the Holy Scriptures, and they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit, etc., and the aforementioned difficulties (in question 7). It is possible that the Israelites saw that the yoke of servitude was heavy upon them, as stated by Moshe Rabbeinu, "And since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has harmed this people, and You have not rescued Your people at all." Therefore, they feared that they no longer had the merit of the Patriarchs, for the generation had already split, and without the merit of the Patriarchs, they cannot be redeemed, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash. They had a proof for this from the splitting of the generation, for otherwise, Moshe Rabbeinu would not have been the messenger, as which of them is more beloved, a son of his brother or a son of his son, as Moshe Rabbeinu argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He. And thus it is written, "And they did not listen to Moses," meaning that since Moshe Rabbeinu was the messenger, they feared that the generation had already split and their merit was insufficient for them to be redeemed, and the merit of the Patriarchs had already ceased. The proof is from the shortness of spirit and from the hard work, for Pharaoh had laid his yoke upon them and did not protect them with the merit of the Patriarchs, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' despair during their enslavement in Egypt, highlighting their fear that the merit of their ancestors was no longer sufficient for their redemption. It reflects on Moses' role as a messenger of God and the concern that the Israelites felt disconnected from their ancestral rights due to their suffering and the harshness of their bondage. The text emphasizes the belief that without the merit of their forefathers, the Israelites would struggle to attain freedom, illustrating a key Hasidic concept of the importance of ancestral merit in spiritual and communal redemption.

passage_content: וכמו"כ עד"ז יתפרש דברי המכילתא שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ומה"ט חששו שאינם ראויים שיגן עליהם זכות אבות, מפני שאינם אוחזין מעשה אבותיהם בידיהם, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה להאמין בבשורת הגאולה שיהי' מיד, כי עכשיו נוכחו לדעת שאינם ראויים לזה דכבר איפלוג דרא ופסקה זכות אבות. ומתורץ קושיא (ז') הנ"ל דאף דמתחילה האמינו דכתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ד' את בנ"י וגו', אבל עכשיו ראו שהורע מצבם והכביד פרעה עולו עליהם גם שהי' קשה עליהם לפרוש מע"ז ע"כ חששו דאיפלוג דרא ולא יגין עליהם זכות אבות ובזכות עצמם א"א שיהיו נגאלים לעולם כמבואר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה.
translation: And likewise, the words of the Mechilta can be explained that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, and for this reason they feared that they were not worthy of the merit of the Patriarchs to protect them, because they did not hold the deeds of their forefathers in their hands. Therefore, they did not listen to Moses to believe in the tidings of redemption that would come immediately, for now they realized that they were not worthy of it, as the generation had already declined and the merit of the Patriarchs had ceased. This resolves the aforementioned question (7) that although initially they believed, as it is written, "And the people believed and heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel," now they saw that their situation had worsened and Pharaoh had increased his burden upon them. Also, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry; therefore, they feared that the generation had declined and the merit of the Patriarchs would not protect them, and by their own merit they could not be redeemed forever, as explained in the words of the aforementioned Midrash. Therefore, they did not listen to Moses.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' struggle to believe in Moses' message of redemption due to their fear of being unworthy of their ancestors' merit, especially as their situation worsened under Pharaoh's oppression. They felt that their disconnection from the righteous deeds of their forefathers left them vulnerable, leading them to doubt their ability to be redeemed solely based on their own merits. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of ancestral merit and the relationship between faith, personal righteousness, and divine redemption. Ultimately, their lack of faith in Moses stemmed from a perceived loss of the protective merit of their ancestors.

passage_content: ובזה יובן הק"ו הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, ולא קשה קושית המפרשים דק"ו פריכא הוא דקוצר רוח ועבודה קשה לא הי' בפרעה כנ"ל, (קושיא ט') אמנם לדרכנו טעם הכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, דמזה שפטו ישראל לומר דכבר איפלוג דרא כנ"ל, וא"כ מכ"ש וק"ו שלא ישמעני פרעה, דכבר טען כן אתם למה ודבריכם למה כנ"ל, ולא הודה באחדות שורש נשמותיהם של ישראל, שהם כלולים באבות הקדושים באילן הנשמות כענף עם השורש, אבל חשב שכל קרבתם אינה אלא מצד הגופים וכבר איפלוג דרא , ואם בנ"י לא שמעו בזה ק"ו שלא ישמעני פרעה, וא"ש כח הק"ו .
translation: And with this, the a fortiori (kal vachomer) is understood: if the Children of Israel did not listen to Me, how will Pharaoh listen to Me? And the difficulty of the commentators is not hard, for the a fortiori is indeed a valid question, that the shortness of spirit and hard work was not present with Pharaoh, as mentioned above. (Question 9) However, according to our path, the reason for the verse is from shortness of spirit and hard work, for from this the Israelites judged that the generation had already been divided, as mentioned above. And therefore, all the more so, it is a fortiori that Pharaoh will not listen to Me, for he has already claimed, "Why should you speak, and what are your words?" as mentioned above. And he did not acknowledge the unity of the root of the souls of Israel, which are included in the holy forefathers in the tree of souls, like a branch with the root, but he thought that all their closeness was only from the bodies, and the generation had already been divided. If the Children of Israel did not listen to this, all the more so, Pharaoh will not listen to Me, and the strength of the a fortiori is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the Jewish people's spiritual connection to their ancestors and the implications of their suffering under Pharaoh. It emphasizes that the Israelites, due to their oppression and hardships, felt a disconnection from their spiritual roots, leading them to believe that their plight was insurmountable. Consequently, if the Israelites, who are inherently connected to their divine lineage, did not heed God's call, it follows logically that Pharaoh, who lacks this spiritual connection, would certainly not listen. This highlights the profound theological insight into the nature of spiritual identity and the challenges faced by the Jewish people in maintaining their faith amidst adversity.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יתורץ קושית המפרשים מ"ש משרע"ה והן לא יאמינו לי ולא ישמעו בקולי, ולכאורה הרי כבר הבטיחו ית ' ושמעו לקולך וגו', (עיין לעיל קושיא ז') והרמב"ן הק ' והאוהחה"ק תירצו שלא נתרגש משה לטעון טענה זו והן לא יאמינו, אלא לצד שאמר לו ד' דבר חדש מה שלא שמע מקודם, והוא אומרו ית ' אליו ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו', וע"כ חשש משרע"ה כי אחרי ראותם בני ישראל שלא ישמע פרעה בקולי, יאמרו ה"ז ראי' ברורה כי לא נראה אליך ד', שאלו היית שליח השם לא ימרה פרעה את דבריו ית ' עכת"ד ז"ל. ועד"ז אפ"ל לדרכנו כי לא נסתפק משה רבינו ע"ה בהבטחתו ית ' ושמעו לקולך, וכן הי' כשבאו בשליחות ראשונה אל ישראל כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו וגו', אמנם אחר שהודיע לו ית ' עוד ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך, מעתה חשש משרע"ה שאחר שיקשה לב פרעה ולא יאבה שלוח, ועוד יכביד עולו עליהם, מאז יפג לבם של ישראל ויסתפקו בשליחותו, ויחששו כיון דלא הועילה להם זכות אבות להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד בודאי אפלוג דרא , וא"כ אין זכותם מספיק שיגאלו מיד.
translation: And according to our path, the question of the commentators is resolved regarding what Moshe said, "And they will not believe me and will not listen to my voice," and seemingly, He has already promised, "And they will listen to your voice," (see above question 7). And the Ramban, blessed be his memory, and the holy Ohr HaChaim explained that Moshe was not moved to argue this claim of "they will not believe," but rather because Hashem told him something new that he had not heard before, which is His statement, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go." Therefore, Moshe was concerned that after the children of Israel see that Pharaoh does not listen to his voice, they will say, "This is clear evidence that Hashem did not appear to you," for if you were the messenger of Hashem, Pharaoh would not defy His words. Thus far, his words, blessed be he. And similarly, we can say according to our path that Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, did not doubt Hashem's promise, "And they will listen to your voice," and so it was when they first came on the mission to Israel, it is written, "And the people believed and listened." However, after Hashem informed him, "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go," from then on, Moshe was concerned that after Pharaoh's heart becomes hardened and he refuses to send them, and he will further increase their burden, then the hearts of Israel will falter and they will doubt his mission, and they will worry that since the merit of the forefathers did not help them to lighten the yoke of servitude, certainly they will be lost to this generation, and thus their merit will not be sufficient for them to be redeemed immediately.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' concern that the Israelites would doubt his divine mission if Pharaoh refused to listen to him, despite God's earlier assurance that they would heed his voice. It highlights the tension between divine promise and human skepticism, emphasizing that Moses feared the Israelites might lose faith if they witnessed Pharaoh's resistance. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the fragility of belief in the face of adversity and the importance of divine intervention in maintaining faith. Ultimately, it underscores the struggle between hope and despair in the context of redemption.

passage_content: וז"ש משה רבינו ע"ה והן לא יאמינו לי, ר"ל שיהי' הצדק אתם שלא יאמינו לי, ובאמת גם משרע"ה טען למה הרעותה לעם הזה ולמה זה שלחתני, דבשביל כך לא האמין פרעה לפי שאני הייתי השליח וע"כ הרע לעם הזה, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל אתם למה ודבריכם למה, שטען פרעה שאלמלי הגיע זמן גאולתם של ישראל, הי' מן הראוי שיהי' גאולתם ע"י שליחות המלאכים או ע"י הבוי"ת בעצמו כנ"ל. ולצד ב' טענות אלו יחלש אמונתם של ישראל בשליחות, וכמו שכן הי' באמת כמאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה לצד שמשה הי' השליח, וגם מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה לפי שהוכבד עליהם עול השעבוד, ומזה ראי' דכבר איפלוג דרא כמו שפירשנו לעיל, וז"ש והן לא יאמינו לי שיהי' אתם טענה הנשמעת שלא יאמינו לי, כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד' ר"ל בשם המפורש, כדאיתא בתנחומא (פ' וארא ) שלא גילה הקב"ה אותה לאבות העולם ולמה גילה אותו למשה על שהלך לגאול את ישראל, מבואר מזה דבחי ' שם הוי' ית ' הוא שם הגאולה, וגילה אותו ית ' למשרע"ה על שהלך לגאול את ישראל וז"ש והן לא יאמינו לי כי יאמרו לא נראה אליך ד' בשם המפורש, להיות שליח לגאולתן של ישראל.
translation: And this is what Moses our teacher, peace be upon him, said: "And they will not believe me," meaning that the truth will be with them that they will not believe me. In truth, even Moshe Rabbeinu argued, "Why have You harmed this people, and why have You sent me?" Because of this, Pharaoh did not believe, since I was the messenger, and therefore he harmed this people. As we explained above, "you" and "your words" refer to Pharaoh's argument that if the time of Israel's redemption had arrived, it would have been appropriate for their redemption to be through the agency of angels or through the Holy One Himself, as mentioned. And because of these two arguments, the faith of Israel in the mission would weaken, and indeed it was so, as it is written, "And they did not listen to Moses" because Moses was the messenger, and also due to their shortness of spirit and hard work, for the yoke of servitude was heavy upon them. From this, it is evident that the generation had already become divided, as we explained above. And this is what he said: "And they will not believe me," meaning that you will have a plausible argument that they will not believe me, for they will say, "We have not seen the Lord," referring to the Ineffable Name, as it is stated in the Tanchuma (Parashat Va'era) that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not reveal it to the patriarchs, and why did He reveal it to Moses? Because he went to redeem Israel. It is clear from this that the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, is the name of redemption, and He revealed it to Moshe Rabbeinu because he went to redeem Israel. And this is what he said: "And they will not believe me," for they will say, "We have not seen the Lord," in the Ineffable Name, to be a messenger for their redemption.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' concerns about the Israelites' lack of faith in his mission as their messenger, emphasizing that their skepticism stems from their suffering and the belief that divine intervention should come directly from God rather than through a human intermediary. It highlights the theological concept that the name of God, particularly the Tetragrammaton, represents the essence of redemption, which was revealed to Moses specifically because he was chosen to lead the Israelites to freedom. The text underscores the tension between divine promise and human doubt, illustrating the challenges faced by a leader in conveying God's will amidst the people's despair.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר דברי הספרי וידבר משה לפני ד' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי וגו' מה ת"ל לאמר , אמר לו רבש"ע הודיעני אם אתה גואלם אם לאו, ולכאורה כבר הבטיחו ית ' על הגאולה כ"פ וע"ד כן שלחו, והודעה זו מה צורך בו (עיין לעיל קושיא ח'). אמנם לדרכנו כל טענתו של משרע"ה היתה דזה הגורם מה שלא שמע פרעה ולא שמעו בני ישראל, לפי שאני השליח, ומן הראוי שהבוי"ת בעצמו יגאלם, דאיזה מהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו כדברי המדרש הנ"ל, וז"ש לאמר השיבני אם אתה גואלם, ר"ל אתה בעצמך ולא ע"י שליח, ולפי שידע משרע"ה שאם הוא יהי' השליח, לא יהיה גאולת עולם, כמבואר בילקוט הנ"ל דגאולות הקודמות לפי שהיו ע"י שלוחי בשר ודם הייתם חוזרים ומשתעבדים, ולעתיד יהי' ישראל נושע בד' ואז יהי' תשועת עולמים. מה"ט לא רצה משרע"ה להיות השליח, ולטובתן של ישראל נתכוין שהבוי"ת בעצמו יגאלם ויהי' גאולה נצחי, ועד"ז יובנו כל טענותיו של משרע"ה מה שסירב ומיאן ולא רצה להיות השליח, והמכוון בהם אחד הוא שמסר נפשו לטובת ישראל וכל דיבוריו היו תפילות ותחנונים לפני הקב"ה לעורר רחמים על ישראל שיגאלם הבוי"ת גאולת עולם מיד.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Sifrei: And Moses spoke before the Holy One, Blessed be He, saying, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me," etc. What does it mean, "saying"? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Inform me if You are redeeming them or not." And seemingly, He has already promised redemption many times, and according to this, He sent them, and what need is there for this information (see above, question 8)? However, according to our approach, all of Moses' argument was that this is the reason why Pharaoh did not listen and the children of Israel did not listen, for I am the messenger, and it is fitting that the Blessed One Himself should redeem them. For which of them is more beloved, a son of his brother or a son of his son, as the aforementioned Midrash states? Therefore, it is said, "saying," meaning You Yourself, and not through a messenger. And since Moses knew that if he were to be the messenger, it would not be a redemption for all time, as explained in the aforementioned Yalkut, for the previous redemptions were through human messengers, and you would return and be enslaved. But in the future, Israel will be saved by the Holy One, Blessed be He, and then it will be an eternal salvation. For this reason, Moses did not want to be the messenger, and for the benefit of Israel, he intended that the Blessed One Himself should redeem them, and it would be an eternal redemption. Likewise, all of Moses' arguments for refusing and rejecting the role of messenger are understood as one: he devoted himself for the benefit of Israel, and all his words were prayers and supplications before the Holy One, Blessed be He, to arouse mercy upon Israel so that the Blessed One would redeem them with an eternal redemption immediately.
summary: In this passage, the author explores Moses' plea to God regarding the redemption of the Israelites, emphasizing his desire for God to personally redeem them rather than through a human messenger. Moses argues that previous redemptions led to subsequent enslavements, and he seeks a permanent, eternal redemption for the people. His refusal to be a mere intermediary reflects his deep commitment to the welfare of the Israelites, as he prays for divine mercy and a lasting salvation directly from God. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the importance of direct divine intervention for true and lasting redemption.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ( בקושיא ו') הה"ד ופניתי אני לראות חכמה והוללות וסכלות וגו', נאמר על משרע"ה על שאמר למה הרעותה וכו ', שאותה חכמה ודעת של משה של הוללות וסכלות היו וכו ', וצ"ב כי איך אפשר שיהיו שני הפכים בנושא א' חכמה ודעת והוללות וסכלות עיין קושיתנו לעיל. ויבואר עפ"י דברי הגמ ' עירובין (דף נ"ד ע"ב) אילת אהבים ויעלת חן באהבתה תשגה תמיד (משלי ה') כגון ר' אלעזר בן פדת , אמרו עליו על ר"א שהי' יושב ועוסק בתורה בשוק התחתון של ציפורי, וסדינו מוטל בשוק העליון של ציפורי וכו ', פרש"י באהבתה תשגה תמיד בשביל אהבתה של תורה תעשה עצמך שוגה ופתי להניח עסקיך ולרוץ לדבר הלכה עכ"ל, עכ"פ מצינו בחי' זו אצל צדיקים וחכמים גדולים, שלגודל אהבתם בלימוד התוה"ק ואהבת הבוי"ת , עשו דברים שהיו משתוללין בהם על הבריות, אבל תוכן ופנימיות מעשיהם הי' בהשכל ודעת ובחכמה נפלאה מאהבת והדביקות בו ית ' ובחכמת התוה"ק , אלא שהחכמה היתה מסותרת ומכוסה וטמיר, וע"כ הי' נראה כלפי הרואים כהוללות וסכלות. וכמו"כ לעניננו במאמר משרע"ה שאמר למה הרעות וגו' מסר נפשו לתועלת ישראל כמ"ש לעיל, והי' בזה חכמה גדולה, שפעל בדיבוריו הצלה לישראל להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד.
translation:
And now we will explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in question 6), as it is written: "And I turned to see wisdom and folly and madness," etc. This is said about Moshe Rabbeinu for having said, "Why have You afflicted Your servant?" etc. For that wisdom and knowledge of Moshe, of folly and madness, were, etc. And it is a question: how is it possible for there to be two opposites in one subject, wisdom and knowledge, and folly and madness? Refer to our question above. 

It can be explained according to the words of the Gemara in Eruvin (54b): "The doe of love and the gazelle of grace, in her love she will always err" (Proverbs 5). For example, regarding Rabbi Elazar ben P'dat, it was said about him that he would sit and engage in Torah in the lower marketplace of Tzipori, while his cloak was spread out in the upper marketplace of Tzipori, etc. Rashi explains: "In her love she will always err, for the love of the Torah will cause you to act foolishly and to leave your business and run to discuss halacha." 

In any case, we find this quality among the righteous and great sages, that due to their great love for the study of the Holy Torah and the love of the Creator, they did things that seemed to be wild among the people. However, the essence and inner nature of their actions were with understanding and knowledge and with wonderful wisdom from their love and attachment to Him, blessed be He, and to the wisdom of the Holy Torah. Yet, the wisdom was concealed and hidden and secret, and therefore it appeared to those who saw it as folly and madness. 

Similarly, in our matter regarding Moshe Rabbeinu, who said, "Why have You afflicted..." etc., he risked his life for the benefit of Israel, as mentioned above, and in this there was great wisdom, for he acted with his words to bring salvation to Israel, to lighten the yoke of servitude from upon them.
summary: The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in Moses' expression of frustration, which seems to reflect folly and madness, yet is rooted in profound wisdom and understanding. It highlights that great tzaddikim (righteous individuals) may act in ways that appear irrational due to their overwhelming love for Torah and God, masking their deep intellectual and spiritual insights. Moses' plea, "Why have You harmed Your people?" is framed as a selfless act aimed at benefiting Israel, demonstrating a hidden wisdom that ultimately leads to their salvation from oppression. This illustrates the concept that true wisdom can sometimes be obscured by outward appearances of folly.

passage_content: ויובן עפ"י מ"ד בגמ' ב"ק (דף נ' ע"א) מעשה בבתו של נחוניא חופר שיחין שנפלה לבור גדול, באו והודיעו את ר' חנינא בן דוסא , שעה ראשונה אמר להם שלו' וכו ', שלישית אמר להם עלתה וכו' א"ל נביא אתה, אמר להם לא נביא אנכי וכו' אלא כך אמרתי דבר שנצטער בו אותו צדיק יכשל בו זרעו, א"ר אחא אעפ"כ מת בנו בצמא, שנא' וסביביו נשערה מאוד מלמד שהקב"ה מדקדק עם סביביו אפי' כחוט השערה והקשו בתוס ' אכתי מנ"ל הא מת בנו בצמא, ותירצו דמ"מ באותו דבר עצמו לא הי' ראוי ליכשל עיי"ש. ובשיטה מקובצת כתב ולרבינו נראה לפרש מ"ש רחב"ד אמרתי דבר שנצטער בו אותו צדיק יכשל בו זרעו, כלומר השמעתי דבר זה לפני הקב"ה, והסכים הקב"ה לדברי שכן דרכו של הקב"ה שמסכים לסברת הצדיקים שבדור, וכשמת בנו בצמא כבר מת ר' חנינא וכו' עיי"ש. ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שביקשה מדת הדין לפגוע במשה, לפי שכלפי חוץ היו נראים הדיבורים כהוללות וסכלות, כמבואר בדברי המדרש שכבר הודיע הקב"ה למשה שלא יניח אותם פרעה לילך וכו' ומשה לא שמר את הדבר ובא להתחכם וכו' והתחיל אומר למה הרעות, והמלאכים מב"ד של מעלה לא הבינו החכמה המסותרת בדבריו, וע"כ ביקשה מדת הדין לפגוע במשה וז"ש וידבר אלקים אל משה במדה"ד , ולפי שנסתכל הקב"ה שבשביל צערן של ישראל דיבר כך, חזר ונהג עמו במדת הרחמים שנא' ויאמר אליו אני ד', דהבוי"ת יודע הנסתרות וכוונה הפנימיות שבדיבוריו, שהי' בזה התחכמות נפלאה והועיל הרבה להצלת ישראל להקל מעליהם עול השעבוד, והקב"ה מסכים לסברת הצדיקים כנ"ל.
translation:
And it is understood according to the teaching of the Gemara in Bava Kamma (page 50a) regarding the incident of the daughter of Nachunia the digger of pits who fell into a large pit. They came and informed Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa. At first, he said to them, "Shalom," etc. In the third hour, he said to them, "She has risen," etc. They said to him, "You are a prophet." He replied to them, "I am not a prophet," etc., but I said that a matter for which that righteous one suffers, his offspring will stumble in it. Rabbi Acha said, "Nevertheless, his son died of thirst," as it is stated, "And around him it was very stormy," teaching that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is meticulous with His surroundings, even as a hair's breadth. And they questioned in the Tosafot, "How do we know that his son died of thirst?" And they answered that nonetheless, in that very matter itself, it was not fitting for him to stumble, as explained there. And in the Shita Mekubetzes, it is written that our Rabbi seems to explain what Rabbi Chanina said: "I said that a matter for which that righteous one suffers, his offspring will stumble in it," meaning I presented this matter before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with my words, for it is the way of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to agree with the reasoning of the righteous of the generation. And when his son died of thirst, Rabbi Chanina had already passed away, etc., as explained there. 

And with this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified, that the attribute of justice sought to strike Moses, for outwardly, the words appeared as folly and foolishness, as explained in the words of the Midrash, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses that Pharaoh would not let them go, etc., and Moses did not heed the matter and came to be clever, etc., and began to say, "Why have You done evil?" And the angels of the heavenly court did not understand the hidden wisdom in his words. Therefore, the attribute of justice sought to strike Moses, as it is said, "And God spoke to Moses in the attribute of justice." And since the Holy One, Blessed be He, saw that because of the suffering of Israel he spoke thus, He returned and dealt with him in the attribute of mercy, as it is said, "And He said to him, 'I am the Lord.'" For the Holy One, Blessed be He, knows the hidden matters and the inner intentions behind his words, that there was in this a wonderful cleverness that greatly benefited the salvation of Israel to lighten the yoke of servitude from upon them, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agrees with the reasoning of the righteous, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice and mercy as it relates to the actions and words of righteous individuals, particularly in the context of Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa and Moses. It highlights that God is attentive to the inner intentions and hidden wisdom behind the words of the righteous, even when their statements may seem foolish or misguided. The text emphasizes that God aligns with the reasoning of the tzaddikim (righteous ones) and ultimately acts with compassion, especially when the suffering of the Jewish people is at stake. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and human righteousness.

passage_content: ולפי הנ"ל אנהיר לן עיינין להבין קצת דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ ויאמר אליו אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב וכו' ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי אשר דברתי לאבות הראשונים וכו' (עיין הדקדוקים לעיל קושיא ב') אמנם כל טענתו של משרע"ה שלא רצה להיות השליח, לפי שידע דבאופן זה א"א שיה' הגאולה נצחי, ועתידין ישראל להיות חוזרין ומשתעבדים בשאר גליות, כמבואר בדברי חז"ל דכל הישועות שהיו ע"י שלוחי בשר ודם לא היו נצחיים, וא"כ מה בצע בגאולתם אם יצטרכו לסבול עוד עול הגליות, וע"כ ביקש והתפלל והפציר שהבוי"ת בעצמו יגאלם ויהי' גאולת עולם שאין אחרי' שעבוד עוד. וע"ז השיב לו ית ' אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר וכו' ולא לחנם שלחתיך וכו ', דבאמת לא הגיע הזמן עדיין לגאולה נצחי, כי לא נשלם בירור הניצה"ק כמבואר בכתבי האריז"ל , אבל אעפ"כ יש צורך והכרח לגאולה זו שהוא רק לפי שעה, ולא לחנם שלחתיך שאין שליחותך בחנם, אלא שיש בזה הכנה ושורש לגאולה העתידה, וע"ד שכתב ק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה ( בפ ' תצו ') לפרש הפסוק תבאמו ותטעמו בהר נחלתך מכון לשבתך וגו', דהמקדשות שנחרבו בעוה"ר לא הי' בנינם פועל ריק ח"ו, אלא שהיו הכנה ע"י קדושת עבודה מעשה הקרבנות ויתר עבודת הקודש אשר עשו שם, להכין כח רוחני וקדושה נפלאה אל הבית השלישי שיהי' קיום נצחי ובית עולמים עיי"ש באריכות.
translation: According to the above, it is clear to us to understand somewhat the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And He said to him, I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward, etc., and I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill the words that I spoke to the forefathers, etc." (see the grammatical points above, question 2). However, all of Moshe Rabbeinu's arguments for not wanting to be the messenger were because he knew that in this way it would be impossible for the redemption to be eternal, and the Israelites would eventually return and be enslaved in other exiles, as explained in the words of our Sages that all salvations that came through human messengers were not eternal. Therefore, what benefit is there in their redemption if they will have to endure the yoke of exiles again? Thus, he requested, prayed, and pleaded that the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself redeem them, and that it be an eternal redemption with no further servitude afterward. To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward, etc., and I did not send you for naught, etc." For in truth, the time for an eternal redemption has not yet arrived, as the clarification of the sparks of holiness has not been completed, as explained in the writings of the Arizal. Nevertheless, there is a need and necessity for this redemption, which is only temporary, and it is not for naught that I sent you, for your mission is not in vain, but there is a preparation and root for the future redemption. This is in line with what the holy Rabbi Yitzchak of blessed memory wrote (in Parashat Tetzaveh) to explain the verse "You shall bring them and plant them on the mountain of Your inheritance, the place, Lord, which You have made for Your dwelling, etc." The sanctuaries that were destroyed in our times were not built in vain, Heaven forbid, but they were a preparation through the sanctity of the service, the work of the sacrifices, and the other holy service that was done there, to prepare a spiritual power and wondrous holiness for the third temple, which will have eternal existence and be a house of worlds, as explained there at length.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' reluctance to be the messenger for the Israelites' redemption, as he feared it would not lead to a permanent salvation, given that past redemptions through human agents were not everlasting. God reassures Moses that his mission is not in vain, as it serves as a necessary preparation for a future, eternal redemption, despite the current redemption being temporary. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the importance of spiritual preparation and the idea that even temporary actions can have lasting significance in the divine plan for ultimate salvation. The text emphasizes that the sanctity of past temples and their destruction were not futile, but rather essential for the eventual establishment of a lasting, holy presence in the future.

passage_content: וכמו כן לעניננו כל הנסיונות שעמדו בהם ישראל, והאמינו בנבואתו של משה רבינו ע"ה, והלכו אחריו במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, כל זה היתה הכנה לגאולה העתידה, ובזכותה יבואו ויחזרו לעתיד, כאמרם ז"ל בסנהדרין (דף ק' ע"ב) דאחרים באין בזכותם עיי"ש, ולעתיד כשהקב"ה בעצמו יבוא ויגאלנו, יהי' התגלות האור כ"כ גדול ונורא, עד שלא יהי' במציאות נסיון כלל, וכמ"ש ז"ל במס' שבת (קנ"א ע"ב) הגיעו שנים אשר תאמר אין לי בהם חפץ (קהלת י"ב) אלו ימי המשיח, שאין בהם לא זכות ולא חובה, ולא יהיו נסיונות ולא קיבול שכר, אבל בגאולת מצרים הגם שעשה השי"ת מופתים גדולים ונוראים, אבל לא הי' בבחי ' התגלות כמו שיהי' לעתיד, ובמה שהוקשה ד' את לב פרעה והכביד עולו על ישראל, והעיז פניו נגד משה ואהרן שלוחי ד', כל זה הי' בגדר נסיונות לישראל, ואעפ"כ האמינו ויצאו למדבר ארץ לא זרועה, וע"כ שכרם אתם להיות נגאלים לעתיד בזכות זה, כדברי הגמ ' אחרים באים בזכותם הן עצמן לא כ"ש, וז"ש לו ית ' אני ד' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני ולא לחנם שלחתיך כ"א לקיים דברי שדברתי לאבות הראשונים, ובזה השיב לו הבוי"ת על חששתו הנ"ל, דלא שייך אצל ישראל איפלוג דרא לפי שקרבתם אל האבות הקדושים משורש נשמותיהם, ועדיין זכות האבות קיימת, ומוכרח אני לגאלם לפי שעה, אע"פ שלא יהי' עדיין גאולה נצחיות, אבל הצורך בשליחותך לקיים דברי שהבטחתי לאבות הראשונים.
translation: And likewise, concerning our matter, all the trials that the Jewish people faced, and their belief in the prophecy of our teacher Moses, peace be upon him, as they followed him in the wilderness, in a land that was not sown, all of this was a preparation for the future redemption. And through it, they will come and return in the future, as our sages, of blessed memory, said in Sanhedrin (page 100b) that others come in their merit, as stated there. And in the future, when the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself will come and redeem us, the revelation of the light will be so great and awesome that there will not be any trials at all, as our sages, of blessed memory, said in the tractate Shabbat (101b), "There will come years when you will say, 'I have no desire in them'" (Ecclesiastes 12), these are the days of the Messiah, in which there will be neither merit nor obligation, and there will be no trials nor receiving of reward. However, in the redemption from Egypt, even though the Holy One, blessed be He, performed great and awesome miracles, it was not in the aspect of revelation as it will be in the future. And regarding the hardening of Pharaoh's heart and the burden he placed upon Israel, and his defiance against Moses and Aaron, the messengers of the Holy One, all of this was within the framework of trials for Israel. Nevertheless, they believed and went out to the wilderness, a land that was not sown. Therefore, their reward is to be redeemed in the future because of this, as the Gemara states, "Others come in their merit," certainly not less so. And this is what He, blessed be He, said: "I am the Lord, faithful to pay good reward to those who walk before Me, and I did not send you for naught, but to fulfill the words I spoke to the forefathers." And in this, the Blessed One responded to his aforementioned concern, that it is not applicable to Israel to be divided by generations, for their closeness to the holy forefathers is from the root of their souls, and the merit of the forefathers still exists. I must redeem them for the time being, even though there will not yet be an eternal redemption, but the necessity of your mission is to fulfill the words I promised to the forefathers.
summary: The passage discusses the trials faced by the Israelites and their faith in Moses during their journey through the wilderness, viewing these experiences as a preparation for the future redemption. It emphasizes that in the Messianic era, there will be no trials or obligations, contrasting this with the earlier redemption from Egypt, which involved significant challenges. The text highlights the enduring merit of the patriarchs, asserting that God's promise to redeem the Israelites is rooted in their connection to their ancestors, ensuring their eventual salvation despite the current lack of a permanent redemption.

passage_content: וע"כ הסמיך הכתוב לומר וארא אל אברהם אל יצחק ואל יעקב וגו' וגם הקימותי את בריתי לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו' לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ד' והוצאתי אתכם וגו' לקיים אותה הבטחה והשבועה שנשבעתי לאבות הראשונים. ואפשר דזהו כוונת רש"י ז"ל שפי' וארא אל האבות והבטחתים הבטחות וכו ', ולכאורה מה הוסיף רש"י ז"ל בביאורו, אבל לדרכנו תוכן וכוונת אמרו ית ' למשה הי' להסיר מלבו החששא , דכבר איפלוג דרא ופסקה זכות אבות, דאל"ה הי' ראוי שיהי' השליחות ע"י מלאכים או הבוי"ת בעצמו יגאלם, כדברי המדרש הנ"ל ששאל איזה מהם חביב בן אחיו או בן בנו, וע"כ להסיר תלונה זו מלבו הזכיר לו הבוי"ת זכות והבטחת האבות שעדיין קיימת, והצורך בשליחותך לקיים הבטחתי שהבטחתי לאבות הראשונים.
translation: And therefore the scripture connects to say, "And I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, etc." and "I also established My covenant to give them the land of Canaan, etc." Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have brought you out, etc." to fulfill that promise and the oath that I swore to the forefathers. And it is possible that this is the intention of Rashi, of blessed memory, who explained "And I appeared to the forefathers and I promised them promises, etc." And at first glance, what did Rashi, of blessed memory, add in his explanation? But according to our way, the content and intention of His words to Moses was to remove from his heart the concern, for it had already been debated in the generation and the merit of the forefathers had ceased. For otherwise, it would have been fitting for the redemption to be through angels or for the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself to redeem them, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash, which asked which of them is more beloved, a son of a brother or a son of a son. And therefore, to remove this complaint from his heart, He reminded him of the merit and the promise of the forefathers that is still in effect, and the necessity of your mission is to fulfill the promise that I promised to the forefathers.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of God's covenant with the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, highlighting that the redemption of the Israelites is rooted in this promise. It suggests that God reassured Moses of the ongoing merit of the ancestors, countering any doubts about the effectiveness of their legacy in light of the current suffering of their descendants. The reference to the patriarchs serves to affirm that the divine mission to redeem the Israelites is a fulfillment of the longstanding commitment made to their forefathers. Ultimately, this underscores the continuity of God's promises and the significance of the patriarchs in the unfolding of the Jewish narrative.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בחי' בפסוקים הנ"ל, דהנה מתנאי הגאולה שיקדים אלי' התשובה כמאמרם ז"ל (מדרש שוח"ט ק"ו ט') אין ישראל נגאלים אלא בתשובה, ומשה ואהרן עוררו אותם אל התשובה, כמבואר בדברי המכילתא מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה אלא שצום לפרוש מע"ז, וכל ישראל הרהרו תשובה בלבם כמבואר במד"ר שמות ( סו"פ א') עה"פ וירא אלקים את בני ישראל וידע אלקים , רבנן אמרי וירא אלקים שעשו תשובה הבינונים, וגם הרשעים הרהרו לעשות תשובה וכו ', וידע אלקים שאפי' א' בחבירו לא הי' יודע אלא הקב"ה לבדו, וזה מכוון את לבו וזה מכוון את לבו ועושין תשובה, ואע"פ שעשו תשובה לא יצאו משם לעולם אלמלא זכות האבות וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, אולם לא הי' בחי' תשובתם שלימה ובאתגליא , וכנראה שלא בא לכלל מעשה אלא בהרהורי לבבם בלבד עשו תשובה, דהרי מבואר בדרז"ל דעדיין היו משוקעים במ"ט שערי טומאה, אבל הבוי"ת בחסדו הגדול ובזכות האבות הקדושים קיבל בחי' תשובתם אף שלא הי' בגדר השלימות, אבל חשבם ית ' לפי ערך הנסיונות ובערך גודל התגברות כוחות טומאת מצרים עליהם, וכמו שפירשנו לעיל (פ' שמות) במאמה"כ ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נוגשיו , שלצד גודל התגברות כוחות הטומאה של מצרים עליהם, עשו כל החטאים בבחי ' כפי' ואונס עיי"ש. והכלל הוא שהבוכ"ע דן את ישראל בערך מצב הדור, וכמ"ש דוד המע"ה ראה עניי ועמלי ושא לכל חטאתי, כשהבוי"ת רואה עניי ועמלי וגודל הנסיונות ראוי שיסלח לכל חטאתי וכמו"כ ישראל במצרים אף שלא הי' בידם אלא הרהורי תשובה בלבד, אעפ"כ קיבלם הבוי"ת בצירוף זכות האבות, וסייע בידם להוציאם ולהפרישם מטומאת מצרים לגמרי, אבל עכ"פ הי' מוכרח שתקדים לגאולתם איזה בחי' של תשובה כמאמרם ז"ל, וכל בחי' של תשובה ואפי' הרהורי תשובה לבד מביא תיקון קצת להתקרב אל הבוי"ת , ויכולין להגיע עי"ז לתיקון האמיתי והשלימות בחסד הבוי"ת .
translation: And even though there is another aspect in the aforementioned verses, behold, one of the conditions of redemption is that repentance precedes it, as our sages of blessed memory said (Midrash Shochar Tov 106:9), "Israel is not redeemed except through repentance." And Moses and Aaron stirred them to repentance, as explained in the words of the Mekilta, "What does it mean that they did not listen to Moses? It means they fasted to distance themselves from idolatry." And all of Israel contemplated repentance in their hearts, as explained in Midrash Shemot (Parashat 1) on the verse "And God saw the children of Israel, and God knew," the Rabbis said, "God saw that they repented, the average ones, and even the wicked contemplated doing repentance, etc." And God knew that even one among another would not know, only the Holy One, blessed be He, alone. This one directs his heart, and that one directs his heart, and they do repentance. And although they repented, they would not have left there forever were it not for the merit of the forefathers, etc., thus said the Midrash. However, their repentance was not complete and revealed, and it seems that they did not reach the level of action but only contemplated in their hearts, for it is explained in the words of our sages that they were still immersed in the forty-nine gates of impurity. But the Holy One, blessed be He, in His great kindness and in the merit of the holy forefathers accepted their form of repentance even though it was not in the realm of completeness, but He considered them according to the value of the trials and the magnitude of the overpowering forces of the impurity of Egypt upon them, and as we explained above (Parashat Shemot) in the verse "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," that due to the great overpowering of the forces of impurity of Egypt upon them, they committed all the sins in a state of coercion and compulsion, as stated there. And the general principle is that the Holy One, blessed be He, judges Israel according to the state of the generation, as King David, peace be upon him, said, "I see my affliction and my toil, and forgive all my sins." When the Holy One, blessed be He, sees my affliction and my toil and the magnitude of the trials, it is fitting that He forgives all my sins. Likewise, Israel in Egypt, even though they had only the thoughts of repentance, nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, accepted them in conjunction with the merit of the forefathers and assisted them to take them out and completely separate them from the impurity of Egypt. However, it was necessary that some aspect of repentance precede their redemption, as our sages of blessed memory said, and any aspect of repentance, even mere thoughts of repentance alone, brings some rectification to draw closer to the Holy One, blessed be He, and through this they can reach true rectification and completeness through the kindness of the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the essential role of repentance (teshuva) in the redemption of the Jewish people, emphasizing that their liberation from Egypt was contingent upon their return to God, even if it was only in thought. It highlights that although the Israelites were still steeped in impurity and their repentance was not complete, God accepted their sincere intentions and the merit of the patriarchs. The text underscores that any form of repentance, even mere contemplation, can lead to divine mercy and ultimately to true redemption, reflecting the profound connection between human effort and divine grace.
