passage_content: ועד"ז יובנו התכת וקישור הפסוקים ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז כדרשת המכילתא, ולא עלה בידם של משה ואהרן להביאם אל התשובה גמורה ושלימה, ומעתה דאג משה רבינו דאיך יהי' אפשר לגאלם, והרי מתנאי הגאולה שתקדים אלי' התשובה כמאמרם ז"ל, וז"ש הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, כי לא יהיו דברי נשמעים אליו ולא יאבה לשלוח ולהוציא את ישראל, כיון שלא שמעו אלי בני ישראל לעשות תשובה גמורה ושלימה, ותשובתו ית ' מבוארת בפסוק שלאח"ז וידבר ד' אל משה ואהרן ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה מלך מצרים להוציא את בנ"י מאמ"צ ויתורץ מה שהקשה האוהחה"ק דאינו מבואר מה ציום אל בני ישראל, ומאמר להוציא את בנ"י מאמ"צ , ציווי זו שייך אל פרעה ולא לישראל, ולדרכנו היתה בזה תשובה מספקת להשקיט רוחו של משה רבינו, שהי' דואג ומתמרמר שלא עלה בידו להביאם לידי תשובה גמורה ועדיין הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולסיבה זו הי' דואג שלא ישמע גם פרעה כנ"ל, וע"ז הי' דבר ד' אליו ויצום אל בני ישראל להחזירם בתשובה, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים שישלחם ויפעלו הדיבורים להוציא את בנ"י מארץ מצרים, כי הבוי"ת יסייע בידם לעשות תשובה, וגם יקבל בחי' תשובתם בערך הנסיונות ושפלות מצבם כנ"ל, והבטיחו ית ' כי יעלה בידו להוציא את ישראל ממצרים.
translation: And similarly, the connection and linking of the verses will be understood, and they did not listen to Moses due to shortness of spirit, etc., for it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, as the Midrash explains. And Moses and Aaron were unable to bring them to complete and true repentance. From this point onward, Moses our teacher was concerned about how it would be possible to redeem them, for one of the conditions of redemption is that repentance should precede it, as our sages have said. Therefore, he said, "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?" For his words would not be heard by him, and he would not be willing to send and bring out Israel, since the children of Israel did not listen to me to achieve complete and true repentance. And His response is clarified in the verse that follows: "And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt." This resolves the difficulty raised by the holy commentators, for it is not clear what the command to the children of Israel is, and the statement to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt pertains to Pharaoh and not to Israel. According to our approach, this was a sufficient response to calm the spirit of Moses our teacher, who was worried and distressed that he had not succeeded in bringing them to true repentance, and it was still difficult for them to separate from idolatry. For this reason, he was concerned that Pharaoh would not listen as mentioned above. And to this, the word of the Lord came to him, commanding the children of Israel to return to repentance, and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to send them, and the words would work to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, for the Blessed One will assist them in achieving repentance, and He will also accept their repentance in relation to their trials and the lowliness of their situation, as mentioned above, and He promised them that He would succeed in bringing Israel out of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges faced by Moses and Aaron in leading the Israelites to complete repentance from idolatry, which is a prerequisite for their redemption. Moses expresses concern that if the Israelites do not listen to him, Pharaoh will also refuse to release them. However, God reassures Moses that He will command both the Israelites and Pharaoh, indicating that the Israelites' repentance, even if incomplete, will be sufficient for their eventual liberation. This reflects the Hasidic belief in God's mercy and the transformative power of sincere, albeit imperfect, repentance amidst suffering.

passage_content: והנה מבואר בספה"ק דימי השובבים המה מסוגלים מאוד לתקן חטא הידוע ר"ל, האמנם מבואר בזוה"ק פ' ויחי דלא מהני תשובה כלל על חטא זה, ובמקו"א איתא דהני מילי כד לא עבד תיובתא שלימתא , תיובתא דאיהו אתחזיא לחפייא על כל עובדוי , מבואר דעכ"פ צריך תשובה גדולה על זה, ובעוה"ר רחוקים אנו מאוד מבחי ' זו, וא"כ איפו' יש לנו תקו ' ונחמה, ואיך נוכל להתקרב לפניו ית ' ולשוב על חטא הנורא הזו. וכבר דברנו מזה פעמים אין מספר ועלה בידינו למצוא בדברי רז"ל המלצת זכות באופנים שונים, שבערך דור חלש כדורנו קשה להשיג אפי' בחי' קטנה של תשובה, וע"כ ראוי שהבוי"ת יקבל תשובתינו אף שאינו ע"צ השלימות, וכעת נ"ל לומר עוד עפי"מ שהבאתי בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' מ') מדברי הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשנה בפרק חלק, בפלוגתת החכמים אם עשרת השבטים עתידים לחזור לעוה"ב, וכתב שם וז"ל כבר זכרתי לך פעמים רבות, שכל מחלוקת שיהי' בין החכמים שאינו בא לידי מעשה, אלא שהוא אמונת דבר בלבד, אין צד לפסוק הלכה כא' מהם, וכן כתב עוד בפי' המשנה במס' סוטה פרק הי' נוטל, לענין פלוגתא דמתנונת והולכת יעיי"ש , וק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה בפ ' תשא כתב דמבואר כן בכל הספרים דכל כללי הלכות אינם אלא בדינים הנהוגין בינינו והלכות הניתנים לנו אבל לא בדיני שמים בדבר שביד הקב"ה לעשותו, אין לנו ע"ז שום כללי הלכה להכריע בפלוגתת חז"ל בענינים כאלו עכ"ד ז"ל.
translation: And behold, it is explained in the holy books that the days of the Shovavim are very capable of rectifying the known sin, may G-d save us. Indeed, it is explained in the Zohar, Parashat Vayechi, that repentance does not help at all for this sin. And in another place, it is stated that these words apply only when a complete refutation has not been established, a refutation that is revealed to the one who is involved in all deeds. It is explained that, nevertheless, a great repentance is required for this, and in our current state, we are very far from this level. So where is our remedy and comfort, and how can we draw close before Him, blessed be He, and return from this terrible sin? We have already spoken about this countless times and have managed to find in the words of our Sages various merits, that in a weak generation like ours, it is difficult to achieve even a small degree of repentance. Therefore, it is fitting that the Blessed One should accept our repentance even if it is not complete. And now, I would like to add, as I have brought in my book Vayoeil Moshe (Article 1, Section 40), from the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in his commentary on the Mishnah in Chapter Chelek, regarding the dispute among the sages about whether the Ten Tribes are destined to return to the World to Come. He wrote there, and I quote: "I have already mentioned to you many times that any dispute among the sages that does not come to practical action, but is merely a matter of belief, there is no basis to rule halacha like one of them." He also wrote in his commentary on the Mishnah in Masechet Sotah, Chapter 8, regarding the dispute of the Tannaim, see there. And thus, the holy Yeshiva, may their memory be blessed, in Parashat Tisa, wrote that it is explained so in all the books that all the general rules of halacha are only regarding the laws that are practiced among us and the laws that are given to us, but not regarding heavenly laws in matters that are in the hands of the Holy One, blessed be He, to do. We have no general halachic rules to decide in the disputes of our Sages in such matters, thus he concluded, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the challenges of repentance for severe sins, particularly in the context of the current generation's spiritual weaknesses. It emphasizes that while traditional teachings suggest that complete repentance may not be attainable, there is still hope for divine acceptance of even partial repentance. The text references the teachings of the Rambam regarding disputes among sages, highlighting that matters of faith and divine judgment are beyond human legal frameworks, suggesting a reliance on God's mercy in the face of human limitations. Ultimately, it conveys a message of seeking connection with the Divine despite the difficulties in achieving full repentance.

passage_content: והסבר הענין דאלו ההלכות הנהוגין לבנ"א לעשותם, א"א שיפול בהם השתנות, וכבר נמסרה בידינו כללי ההלכה מפי התלמוד והפוסקים, ועליו אין להוסיף וממנו אין לגרוע, דהתוה"ק ניצחי ולא יפול בה שינוי וגרעון ותוספת, אמנם בהלכות הנהוגים בהקב"ה לעשותם, א"א לנו להכריע בהם עפ"י כללי ההלכה, דהבוי"ת מתנהג עם עולמו כפי המדות , וא"א לנו לידע איזה מידה אשר ישלוט אז, וכפי המידה ההיא יכריע השי"ת להתנהג עם בריותיו. ומבואר כענין הזה בספה"ק דגל מ"א (פרשה זו) עה"פ וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י וגו' ותו"ד דהתורה ניתנה תמיד לידרש לפי ענין ראשי הדור ובחינתם ומדריגתם, כמו שראיתי באיזה ספר וכו' ששם המפורש היא נמסר לדרוש בו בכל דור לפי אותו הדור וכו ', וידוע דכל התורה כולה שמותיו של הקב"ה, נמצא בודאי ג"כ נדרשת בכל דור ודור לפי דורשיו ולפי נשמת אותו הדור, והביא שפסוק הנ"ל הי' נדרש בימי בעש"ט זלל"ה וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל, שצועקים עבור השכינה כביכול לקרב השכינה הקדושה וכו ', כך הי' נדרש בימי הבעש"ט זלל"ה ואנשי דורו, שהיו במדריגה גדולה כזו שלא להתפלל כלל על חסרון עצמי רק על חסרון השכינה כביכול. ועתה לפי דורותינו נדרש הפסוק וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בני ישראל, אפי' אם הם צועקים עבור עצמם אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם, אעפ"כ לגודל רחמיו וחסדיו ית ' מקבל אפי' תפלה וצעקה שהוא עבור עצמם עכת"ד ז"ל. וברור דמ"ש ז"ל דהתוה"ק נדרשת בכל דור ודור לפי דורשיו ולפי נשמת אותו הדור, אין הכוונה על הלכות ודינים הנהוגים לישראל לעשותם, כי א"א שיפול בהם שינוי או מגרעת, והתוה"ק לא ישתנה לעולם, אלא הכוונה על הענינים שהבורא ב"ה מתנהג בהם כפי התורה, ובהם נדרשת התוה"ק בכל דור ודור כפי מצב הדור ובחינתו, וכמו שמפרש אח"כ דבדורו של הבעשטה"ק הי' פשט הפסוק באופן אחר, ואח"כ שנחלשו מצב הדורות הבוי"ת שומע לקול שועתם גם אם מתפללין עבור עצמם, והתוה"ק נדרשת באופן אחר.
translation: And the explanation of the matter is that these laws which are customary for human beings to observe cannot undergo change. We have already received the principles of halacha from the Talmud and the poskim, and upon them, one should neither add nor subtract, for the Torah is eternal and cannot be subject to change, reduction, or addition. However, regarding the laws that are customary to be performed for the Holy One, Blessed be He, we cannot decide them according to the principles of halacha, for the Creator conducts His world according to the attributes, and we cannot know which attribute will prevail at that time, and according to that attribute, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will decide how to conduct Himself with His creations. This is clarified in the holy book Degel Machaneh Ephraim (in this section) on the verse "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," etc. It is explained that the Torah is always given to be interpreted according to the matter of the leaders of the generation and their qualities and levels, as I have seen in some book, etc., where it is explicitly stated that it is given to be interpreted in every generation according to that generation, etc. It is known that the entire Torah is the names of the Holy One, Blessed be He, thus it is certainly also interpreted in every generation according to its interpreters and according to the soul of that generation. It is brought that the above verse was interpreted in the days of the Baal Shem Tov, may his memory be blessed, as "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel," who cry out for the Shechinah, as it were, to bring closer the holy Shechinah, etc. Thus it was interpreted in the days of the Baal Shem Tov, may his memory be blessed, and his contemporaries, who were at such a high level that they did not pray at all for their own deficiencies, but only for the deficiency of the Shechinah, as it were. And now, according to our generations, the verse "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel" is interpreted even if they are crying out for themselves because the Egyptians are enslaving them; nevertheless, due to His great mercy and kindness, the Holy One, Blessed be He, accepts even a prayer and cry that is for themselves, thus said he, may his memory be blessed. And it is clear that when they said, may their memory be blessed, that the Torah is interpreted in every generation according to its interpreters and according to the soul of that generation, it does not refer to the laws and statutes that are customary for Israel to observe, for they cannot undergo change or reduction, and the Torah will never change. Rather, it refers to the matters by which the Creator, Blessed be He, conducts Himself according to the Torah, and in these, the Torah is interpreted in every generation according to the state of the generation and its qualities, as he later explains that in the generation of the Baal Shem Tov, the verse was understood differently, and afterwards, as the state of the generations weakened, the Creator, Blessed be He, listens to the sound of their cries even if they pray for themselves, and the Torah is interpreted differently.
summary: The passage discusses the unchanging nature of Jewish law (halacha) as transmitted through the Talmud and legal authorities, emphasizing that it cannot be altered. In contrast, the way God interacts with the world is dynamic and varies according to the spiritual state of each generation. The text highlights that the Torah is interpreted differently in each era, reflecting the needs and spiritual level of the people, as seen in the differing interpretations of the same biblical verse across generations. Ultimately, it underscores God's compassion, as He listens to the prayers of individuals even when they are focused on their own needs, adapting His response to the circumstances of the time.

passage_content: וכעי"ז כתב רבינו יונה זלה"ה לפרש עת לעשות לד' הפרו תורתיך , שבדור שפל כשהפרו תורתיך , אז הוא עת לעשות לד', דחשוב מאוד כל מה שעושין לכבוד השי"ת, עכ"פ מבואר מכל הלין דהבוי"ת דן ומתנהג עם ישראל כפי הערך מצב הדור, והגם שהחמירו בזוה"ק דלא מהני תשובה על חטא הידוע רק בתיובתא שלימתא וכו ', אבל בערך נסיונות העצומים של דורנו בכל תנועה ופסיעה, וגודל ההסתרה השורה בימינו, קשה להשיג אפי' נקודה קלה של תשובה, וע"כ אפי' הרהור תשובה בלבד ג"כ חשובה לפני הקב"ה, וא"א לומר הלכה ברורה דלא מהני תשובה על חטא הידוע, אלא צריך לבקש רחמים ותחנונים שנזכה לעשות תשובה אמיתיות ולהתקרב להקב"ה, ואם נעשה כל מה שביכולתינו , בודאי הבוי"ת יקבל תשובתינו כפי ערך שפלות מצב הדור, וע"כ הימים האלו מסוגלים יותר שיתקבל בחי' תשובתינו , דהקריאה מעורר הזמן, ובמצרים הי' ג"כ על בחי' זו שנתקבל לפני הבוי"ת מה שהרהרו תשובה בלבם , אף שלא זכו לתשובה שלימה, שדנם ית ' לפי המצב ורבוי כובד הנסיונות כנ"ל. והשי"ת יזכנו לשוב בתשובה שלימה, ולעשות נחת רוח לפניו ית ', ונזכה לגאולה שלימה בקרוב בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל, ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And similarly, our teacher Yonah, may his memory be blessed, wrote to explain "A time to act for the Lord, they have made void Your Torah," that in a lowly generation, when they have made void Your Torah, then it is a time to act for the Lord. It is very important that everything done is for the honor of the Holy One, Blessed be He. It is clear from all of this that the Holy One, Blessed be He, judges and conducts Himself with Israel according to the value of the state of the generation. And although the Zohar has been stringent that repentance does not help for a known sin except for complete rectification, etc., in relation to the immense trials of our generation in every movement and step, and the great concealment that prevails in our days, it is difficult to attain even a slight point of repentance. Therefore, even a mere thought of repentance is also important before the Holy One, Blessed be He. One cannot say a clear halacha that repentance does not help for a known sin; rather, one must seek mercy and supplications that we merit to make true repentance and draw close to the Holy One, Blessed be He. If we do all that is within our power, certainly the Holy One, Blessed be He, will accept our repentance according to the lowliness of the state of the generation. Therefore, these days are more capable of having our repentance accepted, for the call awakens the time. And in Egypt, it was also in this manner that what they thought of repentance in their hearts was accepted before the Holy One, Blessed be He, even though they did not merit complete repentance, as He judges according to the state and the weight of the trials, as mentioned. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, grant us to return with complete repentance, to bring Him joy, and may we merit complete redemption soon with the uplifting of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes that in times of spiritual decline, when the Torah is neglected, it is a crucial moment to act for God's honor. Despite the challenges and concealment of divine presence in the current generation, even a mere thought of repentance is significant to God. The text encourages seeking mercy and striving for genuine repentance, asserting that God evaluates each individual's efforts in light of the prevailing difficulties. Ultimately, it expresses hope for complete repentance and the imminent redemption, highlighting the importance of Torah and the glory of God.

passage_content: ב) ה' לא נודעתי להם פירש"י לא נכרתי להם במדת אמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ומהו ההבטחה וגם הקמותי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען וגו', והקשו המפורשים הרי עדיין לא הי' זמנה להבטחה זו שתתקיים, ומעיקרא היתה ההבטחה ודור רביעי ישובו הנה ואין מקום לתרעומת כלל, גם איך יתקשר כל זה אל סיום המאמר וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י וגו', ואל מ"ש משרע"ה למה הרעותה לעם הזה, ואיך יתנחם בזה מה שלא נתקיים עדיין הבטחת ירושת הארץ לאבות.
translation: B) "I did not make Myself known to them," Rashi explains, "I did not reveal to them My true measure," etc., for I promised them and did not fulfill. And what is the promise? "And I also established My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan," etc. The commentators ask, "But the time for this promise to be fulfilled had not yet arrived," for initially the promise was that "the fourth generation will return here," and there is no place for complaint at all. Also, how does all this connect to the conclusion of the statement, "And I have heard the groaning of the children of Israel," etc., and to what Moshe said, "Why have You afflicted this people?" And how can he find comfort in that which the promise of inheriting the land to the forefathers has not yet been fulfilled?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of God's hiddenness and the nature of divine promises, particularly regarding the land of Canaan. It highlights the tension between God's assurances to the patriarchs and the current suffering of the Israelites, questioning how the unfulfilled promise can provide comfort amidst their distress. The text emphasizes that the promise of land was not yet due to be realized, suggesting a deeper understanding of divine timing and the unfolding of God's plan. Ultimately, it reflects on the relationship between faith, expectation, and the reality of human experience in the face of divine silence.

translation: 3) "I established My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, etc." And our Sages, of blessed memory, expounded in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 90b) that it is written "to you" but not "to them," from here is a source for the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. Thus far the Gemara. And it is puzzling how their interpretation connects here, and what the matter of the promise of the resurrection of the dead has to do with what was said to Moshe, "Why have You done evil to this people?"
summary: The passage discusses the covenant made by God with the Israelites, specifically regarding the promise of the land of Canaan. It references a Talmudic interpretation that connects this promise to the concept of resurrection of the dead, suggesting that the assurance of the land is intrinsically linked to the future revival of the deceased. The text raises questions about the relationship between this promise and Moses' concerns about the suffering of the people, highlighting the theological depth of divine promises and the hope for redemption.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נ"ל עפ"י המבואר בדרז"ל דלזכות לירושת הארץ צריך להיות דור זכאי וראוי לכך וכתב הראב"ד ז"ל (פ"ב דעדיות מ"ט) על דברי ר"ע (במתני' שם) ובמספר הדורות והוא הקץ שנא' קורא הדורות מראש וכו ', ופי' הוא ז"ל כלומר אע"פ שנותן קץ לגלויות ישראל ולשעבוד שלהם בשנים, מ"מ לענין הטובות והנחמות האמורות להם, במספר השנים הוא תולה, לפי שהוא רואה את הדור שהוא זכאי, ומתגלגל עמהם עד שמגיע לאותו הדור, וכן הי' בשעבוד מצרים אע"פ שנגאלו בסוף ד' מאות שנה לא שבו לשבת בארץ עד דורו של יהושע וכו' וכן לימות המשיח לא יכנסו לא"י מיד, אבל יוליך אותם למדבר העמים כמפורש בנבואת יחזקאל כ' עכ"ל, ומפורש כן במד"ר (במדבר פי"א ס"ב) עיי"ש.
translation: To clarify the matter, it seems to me according to what is explained in the teachings of our Sages, that in order to merit the inheritance of the land, there must be a generation that is worthy and deserving of it. The Ra'avad writes (in the second chapter of Edyot, Mishnah 49) regarding the words of Rabbi Akiva (in that Mishnah) and concerning the number of generations, and this is the end, as it is said, "He calls the generations from the beginning," etc. His explanation is that although He sets a limit to the exiles of Israel and their subjugation in years, nevertheless, regarding the good and the comforts promised to them, He depends on the number of years, as He sees the generation that is worthy, and He rolls along with them until He reaches that generation. And so it was with the Egyptian bondage; even though they were redeemed at the end of four hundred years, they did not return to dwell in the land until the generation of Joshua, etc. And likewise, in the days of the Messiah, they will not enter the Land of Israel immediately, but He will lead them to the wilderness of the nations, as is explicitly stated in the prophecy of Ezekiel 20. Thus is it explained in the Midrash (in Numbers, chapter 11, section 62).
summary: The passage discusses the concept that in order for the Jewish people to inherit the Land of Israel, they must be a deserving generation. It references the teachings of Rabbi Akiva and the commentary of the Ra'avad, emphasizing that while there is a predetermined end to the exiles and hardships of Israel, the fulfillment of divine promises and blessings is contingent upon the merit of the generation. This idea is illustrated through historical examples, such as the Israelites' delayed entry into the Promised Land after the Egyptian exile, and the future redemption, which will also require a worthy generation.

passage_content: והנה מבואר בדברי רז"ל שקושי השעבוד הי' לתועלתן וטובתן של ישראל, דעי"ז נשלם זמנם מהר ויצאו לסוף רד"ו שנה, ולולא כן הי' הגזירה להשלים ד' מאות שנה, ואלמלי היו מתמהמהים במצרים כ"כ שנים היו משתקעים ח"ו בנ ' שערי טומאה ולא היו יכולים לזכות לירושת הארץ כלל, שא"א כ"א לדור זכאי כשרים וצדיקים, ונקדים עוד מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל ( בפ ' בא) עה"פ ויהי מקץ שלשים שנה וארבע מאות שנה וגו' יצאו כל צבאות ה' מאמ"צ , ותו"ד ז"ל כי הגזירה הי' על ת' שנה מן היום ההוא שנגזר עליהם ברית בין הבתרים, והשלשים שנה הם תוספת עליהם בעבור עון הדור ההוא וכו' שאין שום הבטחה שלא יגרום החטא לבטלה וכו ', ומן הידוע שהיו ישראל במצרים רעים וחטאים מאוד וכו ', וע"כ ארך גלותם ל' שנה וכו ', ולא נתקיים להם ודור רביעי ישובו הנה וכו ', אבל החטאים גרמו הכל ע"כ מקצת לשונו עיי"ש, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, שנתאחר ונדחה זמנו של קיום ההבטחה לסיבת גרמת החטא כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, ולטעם המבואר בדברי הראב"ד ז"ל שגלגל הקב"ה עמהם עד שמגיע לדור זכאי הראויים לירושת הארץ, וכל זה הי' תשובת נחמה למשרע"ה שהי' מיצר ומצטער בצרתן של ישראל בקושי השעבוד והקשה לומר למה הרעותה וגו', והשיב לו הקב"ה כי כ"ז הכרח לטובתן של ישראל, כדי שיזכו לירושת הארץ, ולז"א לו ושמי ה' לא נודעתי להם לא נכרתי להם במדת אמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ונדחה ונתאחר קיום הבטחתי מסיבת גרמת חטאם, ולולא קושי השעבוד הי' ראוי להתאחר יותר ונשתקעו ח"ו שם לעולם, ולז"א וגם אני שמעתי את נאקת בנ"י אשר מצרים מעבידים אותם ואזכור את בריתי, היינו הבטחת ירושת הארץ שהבטחתי להם, דע"י שמצרים מכבידים עליהם השעבוד, יזכו לקיום ההבטחה ולא יתאחר עוד.
translation: And behold, it is explained in the words of our Sages that the difficulty of the servitude was for the benefit and good of Israel, for by this their time was completed quickly and they left after 210 years. Had it not been so, the decree would have been to complete 400 years, and if they had delayed in Egypt for so many years, they would have sunk, Heaven forbid, into the 49 gates of impurity and would not have been able to merit the inheritance of the land at all, for it is impossible for any generation to be worthy, righteous, and just. And we will also precede what the Ramban, of blessed memory, writes (in Parashat Bo) regarding the verse "And it came to pass at the end of 430 years," that the decree was for 400 years from the day it was decreed upon them at the covenant between the parts, and the 30 years are an addition due to the sin of that generation, etc., for there is no promise that sin will not cause the decree to be nullified, etc. And it is known that Israel in Egypt were very wicked and sinful, etc., and therefore their exile was prolonged by 30 years, etc., and the promise "And the fourth generation shall return here" was not fulfilled for them, etc., but the sins caused everything. Therefore, part of his language is found there. And this is what Rashi, of blessed memory, said: "Behold, I promised them and did not fulfill," that the time of the fulfillment of the promise was delayed and postponed due to the cause of their sin, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote. And for the reason explained in the words of the Raavad, of blessed memory, that the Holy One, blessed be He, rolled with them until the generation worthy of inheriting the land arrived. And all this was a comforting response to Moshe Rabbeinu, who was distressed and troubled by the suffering of Israel in the difficulty of the servitude and found it hard to say why He had done evil, etc. And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him that all this was necessary for the benefit of Israel, so that they would merit the inheritance of the land. And this is what He said to him: "And My name, the Lord, was not known to them," meaning I did not make Myself known to them in My true measure, etc., for I promised them and did not fulfill, and the fulfillment of My promise was delayed and postponed due to the cause of their sin. Had it not been for the difficulty of the servitude, it would have been appropriate for it to be delayed even longer, and they would have sunk there, Heaven forbid, forever. And this is what He said: "And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel whom Egypt enslaves," and I will remember My covenant, meaning the promise of the inheritance of the land that I promised them. For by the fact that Egypt burdens them with servitude, they will merit the fulfillment of the promise and it will not be delayed any longer.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the Israelites' suffering in Egypt as a means to ultimately benefit them, allowing them to inherit the Promised Land. It emphasizes that their prolonged enslavement was a result of their sins, which delayed the fulfillment of God's promise. However, this hardship was essential to ensure that only a worthy generation would be able to receive the land. Ultimately, the suffering served as a catalyst for redemption, as God remembered His covenant with them in their time of distress.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד דברי הב"ח ( בשו"ע או"ח סי' קי"ח) ע"ד ששאלוהו על מנהג האשכנזים שאומרים בברכת בונה ירושלים, ובנה אותה בקרוב בימינו בנין עולם וכסא דוד מהרה בתוכה תכין בא"י בונה ירושלים, דלא הוה כדקיי"ל כשמואל ( בפ ' ערבי פסחים) דצריך מעין חתימה סמוך לחתימה, והשיב דשאלת וכסא דוד וכו' הוא שאלת בנין ירושלים ממש, כי בקשתנו על בנין ירושלים שתהי' בה השראת שכינה וראוי' לכונן בה כסא דוד עכת"ד, וע"ד דאיתא בזוה"ק ( ויקהל קצ"א ע"א) אר"א כתיב מן היום אשר הוצאתי את עמי את ישראל ממצרים, לא בחרתי בעיר מכל שבטי ישראל ואבחר בדוד וגו' לבנות בית להיות שמי שם, האי קרא לאו רישי' סיפי' וכו ', דכתיב לא בחרתי בעיר ואבחר בדוד מאי האי עם האי ואבחר בירושלים מבעי' לי', אלא כד קוב"ה אית רעותא קמי' למיבני קרתא אסתכל בקדמייתא בההוא רישא דנהיג עמא דקרתא , ולבתר בני קרתא וכו ', הה"ד לא בחרתי בעיר עד דאסתכלנא בדוד למהוי רעי' על ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, נמצא מבואר דמאמר וכסא דוד בתוכה תכין הוא בקשת בנין ירושלים ממש.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Baḥ (in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim, Siman 118) regarding the question they asked him about the custom of the Ashkenazim who say in the blessing of "Builder of Jerusalem," "and build it soon in our days, the building of the world and the throne of David speedily within it, blessed are You, Builder of Jerusalem." This does not align with what we hold according to Shmuel (in the chapter of Arvei Pesachim) that there needs to be a similar conclusion close to the conclusion. He responded that the phrase "and the throne of David" is indeed a question about the building of Jerusalem itself, for our request regarding the building of Jerusalem is that the Divine Presence should dwell there, and it is fitting to establish the throne of David there, thus he concluded. And according to what is stated in the Zohar (Vayakhel 131a), Rabbi Abba said: "It is written, 'From the day that I brought out My people, the children of Israel, from Egypt, I did not choose a city from all the tribes of Israel, but I chose David...' This verse does not refer to the beginning of the end, etc., for it is written, 'I did not choose a city, but I chose David.' What is the connection between this and that? Should I not choose Jerusalem? Rather, when the Holy One, blessed be He, has a desire to build a city, He looks first at the one who leads the people of the city, and afterwards at the city itself, etc. This is the meaning of 'I did not choose a city until I looked at David to be a shepherd over Israel,' etc. Therefore, it is clear that the statement 'and the throne of David within it, You shall prepare' is indeed a request for the building of Jerusalem itself.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Ashkenazi custom of including the phrase "and prepare the throne of David" in the blessing for the rebuilding of Jerusalem. It emphasizes that this request is intrinsically linked to the desire for the Divine Presence to dwell in Jerusalem, which is seen as a prerequisite for establishing the throne of David. The text references the Zohar, highlighting that God's choice of Jerusalem is connected to His intention for David's lineage to lead and protect Israel, thus intertwining the concepts of divine selection, the importance of Jerusalem, and the Davidic monarchy in the fulfillment of spiritual aspirations.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר קישור דרשתם ז"ל עה"פ וגם הקימותי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים מה"ת , ולדרכינו היתה כוונת הרמז בזה למשרע"ה להרגיע רוחו על שהתמרמר בצרתן של ישראל בקושי השעבוד, לזה הודיעו לו הבוית"ש כי כ"ז הי' הכרח לתועלתן של ישראל שיזכו לירושת הארץ, שהרי הבטחתי לאבוה"ק לתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתחיית המתים וכו ', שהאבוה"ק יקומו בתחי ' וינתן להם בעצמם ירושת הארץ, ולזה צריך להכין דור כזה ובחי' א"י כזה ראויים לכך שיבואו האבוה"ק עמהם ביחד לקבל ירושת הארץ, היינו דור זכאי שיהי' להם התקשרות אל האבוה"ק וא"י מקודשת ומטוהרת ע"ד האבוה"ק וע"ד מ"ש הב"ח שבקשתנו על בנין ירושלים הראוי' לדוד, והיינו הראוי' לאבוה"ק כי בחי' א' להם, ולז"א לו הקב"ה שהרי הבטחתי ולא קיימתי, שלסיבה זו נתאחר ההבטחה עד שתהי' א"י ראוי' בקדושתה ויספיק קדושת הדור לתת "להם" וז"פ רש"י ז"ל וארא אל האבות, שהתגלות הזה בהבטחת ירושת הארץ הי' על תנאי שיהי' לישראל התקשרות עם האבוה"ק ומתנהגים בדרכם עד שיקראו אבות להם וזה טעם הבטחתי ולא קיימתי, וה"ז תשובה על דברי משרע"ה למה הרעותה והבן.
translation: And this will clarify the connection of their teaching, may their memory be blessed, on the verse "And I will establish My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan." It was not said "to you" but "to them," from here to the resurrection of the dead from the Torah. And our intention in this hint to Moshe Rabbeinu was to calm his spirit regarding the suffering of Israel in the hardship of servitude. Therefore, He informed him, blessed be He, that all this was necessary for the benefit of Israel so that they would merit the inheritance of the land, for I have promised the Patriarchs to give them the land of Canaan. It was not said "to you" but "to them," from here to the resurrection of the dead, etc. The Patriarchs will arise in the resurrection and will be given the inheritance of the land themselves. For this, it is necessary to prepare a generation such as this and a land of Israel such as this, worthy that the Patriarchs come together with them to receive the inheritance of the land, meaning a worthy generation that will have a connection to the Patriarchs and a land of Israel that is holy and pure in the manner of the Patriarchs, and in accordance with what the Baḥ says regarding our request for the building of Jerusalem, which is worthy for David, and this is worthy for the Patriarchs because it is one aspect for them. And this is why the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "For I have promised and have not fulfilled," that for this reason the promise was delayed until the land of Israel would be worthy in its holiness, and the holiness of the generation would suffice to give "to them." And this is the explanation of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, "And I appeared to the Patriarchs," that this revelation in the promise of the inheritance of the land was conditional upon Israel having a connection with the Patriarchs and behaving in their way until they would be called "Fathers" to them. And this is the reason for "I have promised and have not fulfilled," and this is a response to Moshe Rabbeinu's words, "Why have You done evil?" and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the promise of the Land of Canaan to the patriarchs and the future resurrection of the dead. It emphasizes that the fulfillment of this promise is contingent upon the spiritual readiness of the Jewish people, who must maintain a connection to their ancestors and uphold the sanctity of the land. The delay in the promise's realization is attributed to the need for a generation that embodies these qualities, ensuring that the patriarchs can join them in receiving the land. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of spiritual merit and divine timing in the unfolding of God's promises.

passage_content: ובדורות הקודמים מנהיגי ישראל הקדושים שבא"י שמרו על קדושת הארץ, וגדרו גדרים ותקנות לשמור חומת הקדושה לבל יפרצו בה פרצות, (הבאתי מקצתם בספרי ויואל משה עמוד שכ"ח ש"נ עיי"ש) ועל דעת כן קראוה מיסדי' לכולל הזה בשם שומרי החומות, אף שבימיהם לא הי' לירושלים חומה סביב לה וכבר נחרבה, אולם כוונת השם הזה לציין מטרת הכולל שנתייסדה ע"ד כן לשמור חומת הקדושה וחומת הדת לבל יבואו בה פריצים ויחללוה, דבמקום שאין חומה שכיחי מתפרצים וע"ד שאמה"כ (משלי כ"ה כ"ח) עיר פרוצה אין חומה, וצריך כ"א להתאמץ שיהי' לו חלק בהחזקת המוסד הקדוש הזה שיהי' לו קיום, וזהו הכנה לביאת הגואל וירושת הארץ שא"א כ"א להמתנהגים בדרכי האבוה"ק , כמו שהבטיח הקב"ה לתת להם ארץ כנען, ונזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקינו בנחת ובשמחה, ולראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: In previous generations, the holy leaders of Israel in the Land of Israel maintained the sanctity of the land, and they established fences and regulations to protect the wall of holiness so that breaches would not occur within it. (I have brought some of them in my book Vayoeil Moshe, page 268, see there.) Based on this understanding, the founders of this community called it "Guardians of the Walls," even though in their time Jerusalem did not have a wall surrounding it and had already been destroyed. However, the intention of this name is to signify the purpose of the community, which was established to protect the wall of holiness and the wall of religion so that intruders would not come and desecrate it, for in a place where there is no wall, breaches are common, as it is written (Proverbs 25:28) "A city broken into, without a wall." Each person must strive to have a share in the support of this holy institution so that it may endure, and this is a preparation for the coming of the Redeemer and the inheritance of the land, which can only be for those who conduct themselves in the ways of our holy forefathers, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised to give them the land of Canaan. May we merit to greet the Messiah, our Righteous One, with ease and joy, and to witness the salvation of Israel and their joy in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the importance of maintaining the sanctity of the Land of Israel, as exemplified by the holy leaders of previous generations who established safeguards to protect its holiness. The term "Shomrei Chomos" (Guardians of the Walls) reflects the mission of the community to uphold religious boundaries and prevent desecration, especially in a time when Jerusalem lacked physical walls. The text underscores the belief that such efforts are essential for the coming of the Messiah and the inheritance of the land, aligning with God's promise to grant the Land of Canaan to those who follow the ways of the forefathers. Ultimately, it expresses hope for the redemption of Israel and the revelation of divine glory in the near future.

passage_content: וארא אל אברהם וגו' באל שדי ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם, פרש"י לא נכרתי להם במדת אמיתית שלי וכו' שהרי הבטחתים ולא קיימתי, ולכאורה מה נפק"מ באיזה שם משמותיו ית ' נתוודע להם, ודיבורו ית ' לא ישוב ריקם בכל אופן ואופן, גם הרי לא הגיע עדיין הזמן שיתקיים ההבטחה, ואין סיבת המניעה מפני שלא נתוודע להם בשם הוי' ית '.
translation: "And I appeared to Abraham, etc., as El Shaddai, and My name YHWH was not known to them." Rashi explains: "I did not make Myself known to them in My true measure," etc., for I had promised them and did not fulfill. And seemingly, what difference does it make by which of His names they were made known? And His word will not return empty in any case, and indeed the time for the fulfillment of the promise has not yet arrived, and the reason for the delay is not because they were not made known by the name YHWH.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses God's revelation to Abraham as El Shaddai, contrasting it with the name YHWH, which had not yet been made known. The commentary suggests that God's true essence was not fully recognized by the patriarchs, as they had received promises that had not yet been fulfilled. The text emphasizes that the name by which God is known does not affect the fulfillment of His promises, as divine speech is always effective, regardless of the timing of the promise's realization. Ultimately, the passage highlights the complexity of divine revelation and the nature of God's relationship with humanity.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם קושית ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (פ' וארא ) דבגמ ' (ב"ב קי"ז ע"א) יליף מקרא ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה, דליוצאי מצרים נתחלקה הארץ עיי"ש, ולהלן (קי"ט ע"א) מסיק דמוחזקת היא ליוצאי מצרים ובניהם נטלו חלק בכורה עיי"ש, ולכאורה קשה ממנ"פ אי זכו משעת הבטחה, א"כ כבר זכו בה האבות והי' ראוי שיתחלק א"י לי"ב חלקים שווין שהם בני יעקב, וכל א' מוריש לבניו כפי הבנים ולא כפי הבני בנים, ואי לא זכו עד שעת ביאתן א"כ הי' ראוי להתחלק לבאי הארץ ולא ליוצאי מצרים ע"כ קושיתו .
translation: And it will be clarified in advance the question of K"Z, that Moshe, peace be upon him (in Parashat Va'era), learns from the Gemara (Baba Batra 117a) the verse "And I have given it to you as a heritage," that the land was divided among those who went out of Egypt, as stated there. And further (119a) it concludes that it is held by those who went out of Egypt, and their children received a portion of the firstborn, as stated there. And at first glance, it is difficult from the perspective of "what's the difference" (M"F) if they merited from the time of the promise, then the forefathers already merited it, and it would have been appropriate for the Land of Israel to be divided into twelve equal parts, which are the sons of Jacob, and each one bequeaths to his sons according to the sons and not according to the grandsons. And if they did not merit until the time of their coming, then it would have been appropriate to divide it among those who entered the land and not among those who went out of Egypt. Therefore, this is his question.
summary: The passage discusses a theological question raised by the Hasidic master Rabbi Moshe of Kobrin regarding the inheritance of the Land of Israel. It examines the implications of the biblical promise of land to the Israelites, questioning whether the patriarchs had already secured this inheritance for their descendants or if it was contingent upon the Israelites' entry into the land. The text highlights the complexities of divine promise and human agency in the context of inheritance, suggesting a deeper understanding of the relationship between God, the patriarchs, and the people of Israel. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of spiritual legacy and the continuity of faith through generations.

passage_content: ויתורץ כ"ז עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהנה ירושת הארץ תליא ג"כ בזה, אם נחשבים להתייחס ע"ש אבותיהם ולא נטמעו באומות, ורק אז זוכים בארץ מכח ירושת אבותיהם, וק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה פי' בזה קישור הפסוקים והייתי לכם לאלקים וגו' והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה, והנה יש לתמוה אם מורשה הוא. אף אם לא יתייחדו לעם לו ית ' לייחד אלקותו עליהם, מ"מ שלהם היא כמו בשאר אומות בארץ ירושתם, ואיך תולה זה בזה, ותוכן תירוצו עפי"ד המהרי"ט ( בתשו ' ח"ב ס"ו) דהגם דעשו ישראל מומר הוי דיורש את אביו. עכ"ז אין לו זרע לירש אותו, כיון שנשא נשים נכריות קרוי בנה וממילא אין להם חלק בארץ, אבל אנחנו בנ"י אברהם יצחק ויעקב זוכים בארץ מכח ירושת אבותינו, כי שם י"ה עדות לישראל שלא נטמעו אף בהיותם במצרים, וז"ש ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם והייתי לכם לאלקים לייחד שמי עליכם, והיינו מפני שמתייחסים אחר האבות, ולכך והבאתי אתכם וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה עכלה"ק , נמצא דבזכות שלא נטמעו באומות זכו ישראל לירושת הארץ, ואפשר דמה"ט ליוצאי מצריים דייקא נתחלקה הארץ, דטרם שיצאו ממצרים עדיין לא הי' מוחזקת להם וקיום ההבטחה עדיין היתה תלוי' ועומדת אם יהיו נחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולא יטמעו ח"ו, ולטעם זה לא נתייחד שם י"ה להעיד עליהם כ"א אחר יציאתם ממצרים, דעד אז הי' תליא בבחירתם ואין הקב"ה מייחד שמו ית ' להעיד בדבר התלוי בבחירה כידוע, וע"כ מוחזקת היא ליוצאי מצרים ולא משעת ההבטחה ומתורץ קושיא הנ"ל.
translation: And it will be explained according to our aforementioned approach, that behold, the inheritance of the land is also dependent on this, whether they are considered to be related to their forefathers and have not been assimilated among the nations, and only then do they merit the land by virtue of the inheritance of their ancestors. And this is what the holy Yismach Moshe explains regarding the connection of the verses: "And I will be your God" and "And I brought you to the land" and "And I gave it to you as an inheritance." And behold, one might wonder if it is indeed an inheritance. Even if they are not distinguished as a nation, He would not have distinguished His Divinity upon them; nevertheless, it belongs to them just like the other nations in their inheritance of the land. And how does this depend on that? The essence of your explanation is according to the words of the Maharitz (in his responsa, part 2, section 66) that although a Jewish apostate is considered to inherit from his father, nevertheless, he has no seed to inherit him, since he married foreign women, his son is called by his name, and consequently, they have no share in the land. But we, the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, merit the land by virtue of the inheritance of our forefathers, for there the Name YH is a testimony to Israel that they were not assimilated even while they were in Egypt. Therefore, it is said: "And I took you to be My people, and I will be your God" to distinguish My Name upon you, and this is because they are related to their forefathers. And thus, "And I brought you" and "I gave it to you as an inheritance" concludes the matter. It follows that due to the fact that they were not assimilated among the nations, the Jews merited the inheritance of the land. And it is possible that for this reason, specifically for those who went out of Egypt, the land was divided, for before they left Egypt, it was not yet secured for them, and the fulfillment of the promise was still dependent on whether they would be considered in the name of their forefathers and would not assimilate, Heaven forbid. And for this reason, the Name YH was not distinguished to testify about them until after their departure from Egypt, for until then it was dependent on their choice, and the Holy One, blessed be He, does not distinguish His Name to testify about something that is dependent on choice, as is known. Therefore, it is secured for those who went out of Egypt and not from the time of the promise, and the aforementioned question is resolved.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of inheriting the land of Israel as contingent upon the Jewish people's connection to their patriarchs and their separation from the nations. It emphasizes that the Jewish people, by not assimilating during their time in Egypt, merit the land as a legacy from their ancestors. The text highlights that God's unique relationship with the Jewish people, marked by His name, is established only after their exodus from Egypt, affirming their identity and divine promise. Thus, the inheritance of the land is tied to their commitment to remain distinct and faithful to their heritage.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל וארא אל האבות, ר"ל שהבטחתי להם בבחי ' אבות לקיים לזרעם הנחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולא נטמעו באומות, ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם. שעדיין לא נודע להם עדות שם י"ה על זרעם כ"ז דתליא בבחירה, ומה"ט הבטחתי ולא קיימתי ר"ל שאינה מוחזקת ירושת הארץ כ"א ליוצאי מצרים ולא משעת הבטחה, לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ד' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, שבשעת יציאתם אייחד שמי להעיד על יחוסיהם שלא נטמעו, ועי"ז יתקיים הבטחתי והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה וגו'.
translation: And in this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: "And I appeared to the Patriarchs," meaning that I promised them, in the aspect of 'Patriarchs,' to fulfill for their descendants who are considered in the name of their forefathers and who were not assimilated among the nations, and My name, the Lord, was not made known to them. For it was still not known to them the testimony of the name YH, concerning their descendants, as this depends on choice. And for this reason, I promised and did not fulfill, meaning that the inheritance of the land is not established except for those who went out of Egypt and not from the time of the promise. Therefore, say to the Children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," for at the time of their departure, I will sanctify My name to testify to their lineage that they were not assimilated, and through this, My promise will be fulfilled, and I brought you to the land, etc., and I gave it to you as an inheritance, etc.
summary: The passage discusses God's promise to the patriarchs, emphasizing that He assured them their descendants would not be assimilated among the nations. It highlights that God's name, represented by the Tetragrammaton (YHWH), was not fully revealed to the patriarchs, as their descendants' status depended on their choices. The text explains that during the Exodus, God uniquely identified Himself to the Israelites to affirm their lineage and fulfill His promise of land inheritance, thus establishing their connection to the covenant made with their forefathers.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המדרש פ' ואתחנן (פר' ב' סי' ט') א"ל הקב"ה למשה אם אתה נקבר כאן אצלן בזכותך הן באין עמך, אר"ל למה"ד דומה לאחד שנתפזרו מעותיו במקום אפילה, אמר אם אומר אני האירו לי שאקבץ מעותי אין ברי' משגחת עלי, מה עשה נטל זהב א' והשליך בתוכם, והתחיל צווח ואומר האירו לי זהב א' הי' לי ונפל ממני כאן והאירו לו, מה עשה משנטל את הזהוב אמר להן בחייהם המתינו לי שאלקט את המעות, בזכות הזהב נתלקטו המעות, כך אמר לו הקב"ה למשה אם נקבר את אצלם במדבר הן באים בזכותך ואתה בא בראשם שנא' וירא ראשית לו וגו' ויתא ראשי עם עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה יהי' מזה סתירה למ"ש במד"ר ( סו"פ שמות) ויאמר ד' אל משה עתה תראה אשר אעשה לפרעה, במלחמת פרעה אתה רואה, ואין אתה רואה במלחמת ל"א מלכים וכו ', מכאן אתה למד שנטל משה עכשיו את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ הרי מבואר שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ בשביל שאמר למה הרעותה , ולפי"ד המדרש הנ"ל הי' מוכרח כן מטעם אחר, דע"י שנקבר משרע"ה במדבר יבואו עמו מתי מדבר לעתיד בעת התחי ', וא"כ לא ע"צ העונש הי' כ"א לטובתן של ישראל, גם צ"ב מדברי רז"ל (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) שהכריחו דדור המדבר יש להם חלק לעוה"ב, ממה שנאמר (ירמי' ב') הלוך וקראת באזני ירושלים לאמר וגו' זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך אהבת כלולותיך לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, ומה אחרים באים בזכותם הם עצמם לא כל שכן עכ"ד הגמ ', הרי מבואר שדור המדבר עצמה זכותם להביא גם אחרים, והבוי"ת יזכור זכותם לכל ישראל שיהנו בזכותם לעוה"ב, ומכ"ש שיספיק זכותם לעצמם, כמ"ש בגמ' הם עצמם לא כש"כ , וה"ז סתירה לדברי המדרש הנ"ל ( בפ ' ואתחנן) שרק ע"י שנקבר משרע"ה במדבר הן באים בזכותו, ואם לא יספיק זכותם לעצמם, איך יבואו אחרים בזכותם, גם צ"ב דלפי"ד המדרש הנ"ל דדור דיעה של מתי מדבר לא יזכו לתחי ' רק ע"י שנקבר משרע"ה עמהם, א"כ איך יהי' תקנתן של דורות אחרים האובדים בארץ אשור והנדחים בארץ מצרים וכל מתי חו"ל שלא נקבר משרע"ה עמהם, ובל"ס שכולן יזכו לתחי ' כמבואר בפסוקים ובאו האובדים בארץ אשור וגו', וצ"ב איך יגרע זכותם של דור המדבר דור דיעה שלא יבואו רק אם נקבר משרע"ה עמהם, וכללית ישראל הבאים רק בזכותם יזכו לתחי ' אף בל"ז .
translation:
And it will be explained in advance the words of the Midrash in Parashat Va'etchanan (Parashat Be'halotecha, Section 9): The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "If you are buried here among them, they will come with you because of your merit." This is similar to a parable of one whose coins were scattered in a dark place. He said, "If I say, 'Light for me so that I can gather my coins,' no one will pay attention to me." What did he do? He took one gold coin and threw it among them, and he began to cry out, saying, "Light for me! I had one gold coin that fell from me here!" And they lit for him. What did he do? After he took the gold, he said to them, "In their lifetime, wait for me while I gather the coins." By the merit of the gold, the coins were gathered. Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "If you are buried among them in the desert, they will come because of you, and you will come at their head," as it is said, "And he saw the beginning of his" (Deuteronomy 33:21). And the heads of the people were gathered, thus concludes the Midrash. 

And at first glance, this seems to contradict what is stated in the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah, Section 6) where it is said, "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh.'" In the war against Pharaoh, you see, but you do not see in the war against the thirty-one kings, etc. From here you learn that Moses took the judgment now that he would not enter the land. It is clear that it was decreed upon him that he would not enter the land because he said, "Why have you afflicted your servant?" According to the aforementioned Midrash, it was necessary for another reason, that by being buried in the desert, Moses would bring with him the dead of the desert in the future at the time of the resurrection. Therefore, it was not merely a punishment but rather for the benefit of Israel. 

It is also puzzling from the words of our Sages (Sanhedrin 110b) who forced that the generation of the desert has a share in the World to Come, from what is said (Jeremiah 2:2), "Go and proclaim in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, 'I remember for you the kindness of your youth, the love of your betrothals, when you went after Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown.'" If others come because of them, how much more so themselves! Thus concludes the Gemara. It is clear that the generation of the desert itself has the merit to bring others as well, and may the Blessed One remember their merit for all of Israel so that they may benefit from their merit in the World to Come, and certainly their merit will suffice for themselves, as it is said in the Gemara, "They themselves, how much more so!" 

And this is a contradiction to the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in Parashat Va'etchanan) that only by being buried in the desert will they come because of him. If their merit does not suffice for themselves, how will others come because of them? It is also puzzling that according to the aforementioned Midrash, the generation of the dead of the desert will not merit resurrection except by being buried with Moses. How then will the remedy of other generations who are lost in the land of Assyria and the exiles in the land of Egypt and all the dead of the diaspora who were not buried with Moses be? And certainly, all will merit resurrection, as it is stated in the verses, "And the lost ones of the land of Assyria will come," etc. It is puzzling how the merit of the generation of the desert, the generation of knowledge, will be diminished that they will not come unless Moses is buried with them, while all of Israel who come only because of them will merit resurrection even so.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of Moses' burial in the desert, suggesting that his burial serves as a merit for the Israelites, allowing them to be resurrected in the future. It contrasts this idea with the notion that the generation of the desert has its own merit for the World to Come, as indicated by their unique relationship with God during their time in the wilderness. The text raises questions about the nature of merit and redemption, emphasizing that the merits of the generation of the desert can benefit others, while also exploring the complexities of divine justice and the interconnectedness of Israel's fate. Ultimately, it highlights the significance of Moses' role in ensuring the spiritual legacy and future redemption of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי הגמ ' כתובות (קי"א ע"א) א"ר אליעזר מתים שבחו"ל אינם חיים שנא' ( ישעי ' כ"ו) ונתתי צבי בארץ חיים, ארץ שצביוני בה מיתיה חיים, שאין צביוני בה אין מיתיה חיים וכו' והקשו בגמ' ולר ' אלעזר צדיקים שבחו"ל אינם חיים (בתמי' ותירצו) א"ר אילעא ע"י גלגול, מתקיף לה ר' אבא סלא רבא גלגול לצדיקים צער הוא, אמר אביי מחילות נעשית להם בקרקע, ונשאתני ממצרים וקברתני בקבורתם אמר קרנא דברים בגו יודע הי' יעקב אבינו שצדיק גמור הי', ואם מתים שבחו"ל חיים למה הטריח את בניו, ותירצו שמא לא יזכה למחילות, (ובעין יעקב הגירסא שלא קבל עליו צער מחילות) כיוצא בדבר אתה אומר וישבע יוסף את בני ישראל וגו', א"ר חנינא דברים בגו יודע הי' יוסף בעצמו שצדיק גמור הי', ואם מתים שבחו"ל חיים למה הטריח את אחיו ד' מאות פרסה, ותירצו שמא לא יזכה למחילות, ( ובע"י הגירסא שלא קבל עליו צער מחילות) עכ"ד הגמ ' לענינינו ולכאורה עדיין צ"ב דלפי"ד ר"א רק הצדיקים שבחו"ל יזכו לתחי ' ע"י גלגול מחילות, ומה יהי' תקנתן של כל מתי חו"ל והאובדים בארץ אשור והנדחים באמ"צ , ובל"ס שכל ישראל יזכו לתחי ' ולא ידח ממנו נדח כמבואר בפסוקים וצ"ב .
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin with the words of the Gemara in Ketubot (111a): Rabbi Eliezer said, "The dead in the Diaspora are not alive," as it is stated (Isaiah 26), "And I will give beauty in the land of the living," meaning a land where those who are beautiful therein are alive; where there are no beautiful ones, there are no living ones, etc. The Gemara asks, "And according to Rabbi Eliezer, the righteous in the Diaspora are not alive?" (with astonishment, and it answers) Rabbi Ila said, "Through reincarnation." Rabbi Abba said, "For the righteous, reincarnation is a suffering." Abaye said, "They are made into pits in the ground." "And You brought me up from Egypt and buried me in their burial," said Karna. "There are matters involved; Jacob our father knew that he was a complete righteous person, and if the dead in the Diaspora are alive, why did he trouble his sons?" They answered, "Perhaps he would not merit the pits." (And in the Ein Yaakov version, it is stated that he did not accept the suffering of the pits.) Similarly, you say, "And Joseph made the sons of Israel swear," etc. Rabbi Chanina said, "There are matters involved; Joseph himself knew that he was a complete righteous person, and if the dead in the Diaspora are alive, why did he trouble his brothers four hundred parasangs?" They answered, "Perhaps he would not merit the pits." (And in the Ba'al HaTurim version, it is stated that he did not accept the suffering of the pits.) Thus far the Gemara. Regarding our matter, it still seems to be a question: According to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, only the righteous in the Diaspora will merit resurrection through the reincarnation of the pits. What will be the remedy for all the dead in the Diaspora and those lost in the land of Assyria and the exiles in the land of Egypt? And certainly, all of Israel will merit resurrection, and none will be cast away from it, as is explained in the verses, and it is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the afterlife for the righteous who die outside of the Land of Israel, referencing a Talmudic debate about whether they are considered alive. It highlights the belief that even the righteous in exile may attain resurrection through reincarnation, but this process is seen as a source of suffering. The text raises questions about the fate of all deceased Jews, particularly those lost in exile, emphasizing the hope that ultimately all of Israel will merit resurrection, as indicated in the scriptures. This reflects a deep theological insight into the connection between the Land of Israel, righteousness, and the promise of life after death.

passage_content: ויתבאר כ"ז עפימ"ש היפה תואר ( בב"ר פר' כ"ו סי' ג') דזמן התחי ' מתי יהי' נמצא מימרות חלוקות בדברי רז"ל, שממ"ש במס' יומא מצנפת ואבנט איזה מהן קודם. ותירצו לכשיבנה ביהמ"ק משה ואהרן עמהם וכו ', נראה שיהי' התחי ' בזמן ביהמ"ק לימות משיחנו, וממ"ש אין בין עוה"ז לימות משיחנו אלא שעבוד מלכיות אינו נראה כן, דא"כ שינוי גדול בין העוה"ז לזמן ההוא שיקומו כל המתים ויהפכו שפה ברורה וכו ', עיי"ש שאסף איש טהור הרבה מאמרי רז"ל שמבואר במקצתם שיתקיים התחי ' בעת ביאת משיחנו בב"א, ובמקו"א נראה שיהי' ליום הדין הגדול, וסוף דבר הביא דעת בעל העקרים מ"ש ( במ"ד פ"א) שבימות המשיח תהי' תחייה לצדיקים גמורים, כדי להקנותם שלימות גדול שלא יכלו לקבל תחלה, ולפרסם בעולם יכולתו הגדול, וליום הדין תהי' תחי ' כוללת, וקרוב לזה כתב הראב"ע ז"ל בפ ' רבים מישיני אדמת עפר, ולפי"ז יצדקו יחד המדרשים האומרים בתחי ' לימות המשיח והאומרים אחר ימות המשיח עכ"ד היפ"ת וכן כתב הרדב"ז ( בתשו ' ח"ב סי' תתל"ט) בשם הריטב"א שהביא כן בשם רבותיו, וכ"כ הרבה מהראשונים עיין בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' נ') העתקתי מקצת דבריהם ועוד ראיות מדברי הש"ס עיי"ש.
translation: And it will be explained as follows, according to the beautiful interpretation (in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashat 26, Section 3) that the time of the resurrection will be when the Holy Temple is built. There are differing statements in the words of our Sages, as it is stated in Yoma regarding the priestly garments, which of them comes first. They answered that when the Holy Temple is built, Moses and Aaron will be with them, etc. It seems that the resurrection will occur at the time of the Holy Temple in the days of our Messiah. And from what is stated, there is no difference between this world and the days of our Messiah except for the subjugation of kingdoms; it does not seem so, for otherwise there would be a great change between this world and that time when all the dead will rise and a clear language will be transformed, etc. It is noted there that a pure man gathered many sayings of our Sages, some of which clarify that the resurrection will take place at the coming of our Messiah, may it be soon, and in other places it seems that it will be on the Day of Judgment. In conclusion, he brought the opinion of the author of the "Ikkarim" who wrote (in the first part) that in the days of the Messiah there will be a resurrection for the completely righteous, in order to grant them a great completeness that they could not receive initially, and to publicize His great power in the world. And on the Day of Judgment, there will be a general resurrection. Closely related to this, the Ra'avad wrote in "Many from the dust of the earth," and according to this, the midrashim that say the resurrection will be in the days of the Messiah and those that say after the days of the Messiah will be reconciled. Thus wrote the Radbaz (in Responsa, Part 2, Section 579) in the name of the Ritva, who brought it in the name of his teachers. Many of the early authorities also wrote similarly; see in my book "Yoel Moshe" (Article 1, Section 50) where I copied some of their words and additional proofs from the Talmud, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of resurrection (techiyat hametim) in relation to the Messianic era, highlighting differing opinions among the sages regarding its timing. It suggests that resurrection will occur during the Messianic age, with a distinction made between the resurrection of the righteous and a more universal resurrection at the Day of Judgment. The text emphasizes that the resurrection serves to demonstrate God's greatness and to grant the righteous a level of completeness they could not achieve earlier. This reflects a broader theological understanding of redemption and divine justice in Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ועפ"י הקדמת דבה"ק אפ"ל דמ"ש רז"ל בגמ' כתובות הנ"ל, מתים שבחו"ל אינם חיים, ורק הצדיקים שבחו"ל יזכו לתחי ', שע"י גלגול מחילות יבואו לא"י ושם נפשם חוזרת אליהן, כ"ז נאמר רק על התחי ' ראשונה לימות המשיח, ומפורש כן בירושלמי (פ"ט דכלאים ) אתהלך לפני ד' בארצות החיים, רשב"ל בשם בר קפרא ארץ שמיתיה חיין תחלה לימות המשיח וכו' אלא מעתה רבותינו שבגולה הפסידו, א"ר סימאי מחליד הקב"ה לפניהן את הארץ והן מתגלגלין וכו' וכיון שהן מגיעין לא"י נפשן חוזרות עליהן, ומ"ט ( דכתיב יחזקאל ל"ז) הנה אני פותח את קברותיכם והעלתי אתכם וגו' והבאתי אתכם אל אדמת ישראל, ואח"כ ונתתי בכם רוחי וחייתם עכ"ד הירושלמי, הרי מבואר בפירוש דתנאי זה שיצרכו לגלגול מחילות ולהחיות על אדמת ישראל, יהי' בתחי ' דימות המשיח ולא יזכו לזה כ"א הצדיקים כמבואר שם, אמנם בתחי ' השני' שלעתיד כל העולם יהי' בבחי ' ארץ ישראל, וכמ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה (בתפלה למשה תהלים פ"ב) לפרש הפסוק קומה אלקים שפטה הארץ וגו' כי ע' קטדראות הם לע' שרי מעלה, אבל לעתיד הכל תחת יד השי"ת לבדו, וכל עולם בבחי ' ארץ ישראל, והיינו קומה אלקים דייקא , כי אתה תנחל ר"ל כי כל העולם יהי' בבחי ' נחלה זו ירושלים והבן עכלה"ק , נמצא דאז לא יצוייר מתי חו"ל כלל, וכל מקום שבעולם יהי' בבחי ' א"י תחת יד השי"ת לבדו בלי ממשלת שרי מעלה, ע"כ לא יהי' צורך לגלגול מחילות שיעלו לא"י וכל ישראל יזכו בתחי ' במקומם.
translation: According to the introduction of the Holy Rebbe, it can be said that what our Sages of blessed memory stated in the Gemara in Ketubot mentioned above, the dead in exile are not alive, and only the righteous in exile will merit the resurrection, as through the reincarnation of their graves they will come to the Land of Israel, and there their souls will return to them. This is said only about the first resurrection in the days of the Messiah, and it is explicitly stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Pe'ah 9) "I will walk before the Lord in the lands of the living," Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish in the name of Bar Kappara said that the land of their graves will be alive first in the days of the Messiah, etc. Therefore, our Rabbis in exile have lost out. Rabbi Simai said that the Holy One, blessed be He, will revive the land before them, and they will be reincarnated, etc. And when they arrive in the Land of Israel, their souls will return to them, and the reason is (as it is written in Ezekiel 37) "Behold, I open your graves and bring you up," etc., "and I will bring you to the land of Israel," and afterwards "and I will put My Spirit in you and you shall live," thus concludes the Jerusalem Talmud. It is clearly stated that this condition, that they will need to reincarnate from their graves and be revived on the land of Israel, will be in the resurrection of the days of the Messiah, and only the righteous will merit this, as explained there. However, in the second resurrection of the future, the entire world will be in the state of the Land of Israel, as it is written in the holy Zohar (in the prayer of Moses, Psalms 82) to explain the verse "Arise, O God, judge the earth," etc., for there are seventy thrones for seventy ministering angels, but in the future, everything will be under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He alone, and the entire world will be in the state of the Land of Israel, and this is "Arise, O God" precisely, for You will inherit, meaning that the entire world will be in the state of this inheritance, Jerusalem. Understand this well. It follows that then there will be no concept of exile at all, and every place in the world will be in the state of the Land of Israel under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He alone, without the governance of ministering angels. Therefore, there will be no need for the reincarnation of graves to rise to the Land of Israel, and all of Israel will merit resurrection in their place.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of resurrection in the context of the Messianic era, emphasizing that only the righteous from the diaspora will experience resurrection through a process of reincarnation that leads them to the Land of Israel. It highlights that this resurrection is specifically for the first resurrection during the Messianic times, as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. In contrast, the second resurrection in the future will encompass the entire world under the sovereignty of God, transforming all places into a state akin to the Land of Israel, thus eliminating the need for reincarnation. Ultimately, it asserts that all of Israel will merit resurrection in their respective places without the necessity of returning to Israel.

passage_content: ובזה יתורצו כל הקושיות הנ"ל, דאה"נ דור המדבר עצמה זכותם מאוד, עד שאף אחרים יבואו בזכותם לעתיד בתחי ' הכללית והם עצמם לא כש"כ שיזכו לעוה"ב כמבואר בגמ' (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) אמנם אעפ"כ הי' ההכרח שיקבר משרע"ה במדבר, דעי"ז ניתוסף זכותם ומעלתם והם באים עמו בזכותו בתחי ' הראשונה, גם ודאי שלא יצרכו לצער גלגול מחילות, כיון שיבואו עמו ובזכותו, ואף צדיקים גדולים הנקברים בחו"ל זולתם ג"כ יקומו בתחי ' הראשונה, אלא שיצטרכו לגלגול מחילות כמבואר בגמ ', ושאר מתי חו"ל שלא הגיעו למעלת הצדיקים יקומו רק בתחי ' הכללית כמבואר בדברי הראשונים הנ"ל מבואר מכל זה דמה שלא נכנס משרע"ה לארץ לא הי' לצד העונש, כ"א להצלת ישראל דור המדבר, ומ"ש רז"ל כאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ כבר ביארנו בדברנו לעיל שהי' בבחי ' נורא עלילה, על שהי' הגזירה מוכרחת לטובתן של ישראל, ולא עביד קוב"ה דינא בלא דינא , ע"כ נסתבב לידו מעשה זה, שבאמת לא הי' חטא שלטובתן של ישראל נתכוין , אלא שלגודל קדושתו של משרע"ה נחשב לפגם ע"ד וסביביו נשערה מאוד, וכ"ז הי' סיבה כדי שיקבר במדבר ויבואו עמו דור המדבר, וא"ש דשני הטעמים שנתנו רז"ל על שלא נכנס משרע"ה לארץ תרווייהו איתנייהו וצריכא לתרווייהו , דלולא הטעם של דור המדבר שיבואו עמו, לא הי' ראוי שיסתבב מעשה זה לידו, ולולא שנסתבב לידו מ"ש למה הרעותה לא הי' נמנע מלכנס לא"י דלא עביד קוב"ה דינא בלא דינא ע"כ הי' הצורך בשניהם והבן.
translation: And with this, all the aforementioned questions are resolved, for indeed, the generation of the desert has great merit, to the extent that even others will come in their merit in the future during the general resurrection, and they themselves, how much more so, will merit the World to Come, as explained in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 110b). However, despite this, it was necessary for Moshe Rabbeinu to be buried in the desert, for through this, their merit and elevation were increased, and they come with him in his merit during the first resurrection. Also, certainly, they will not need to suffer the reincarnation of graves, since they will come with him and in his merit. Even great righteous ones who are buried abroad will also rise during the first resurrection, but they will need to undergo the reincarnation of graves, as explained in the Gemara. And other deceased from abroad who did not reach the level of the righteous will rise only during the general resurrection, as explained in the words of the earlier authorities. From all this, it is clear that Moshe Rabbeinu's not entering the land was not due to punishment, but rather for the salvation of the Jewish people of the desert generation. And what our sages say here, that Moshe took the judgment upon himself not to enter the land, we have already explained in our earlier discussion that it was in the aspect of a terrible accusation, since the decree was necessary for the benefit of the Jewish people. And the Holy One, blessed be He, does not administer judgment without a reason; therefore, this matter came about through him, for in truth, it was not a sin intended for the benefit of the Jewish people, but due to the great sanctity of Moshe Rabbeinu, it was considered a flaw, and around him, there was great turmoil. And all this was a reason for him to be buried in the desert and for the generation of the desert to come with him. And it is understood that both reasons given by our sages for Moshe Rabbeinu not entering the land are both true and necessary, for if not for the reason of the desert generation coming with him, it would not have been fitting for this matter to come about through him. And if not for this matter, why did He cause him to be punished? The Holy One, blessed be He, does not administer judgment without a reason; therefore, the necessity for both exists, and understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses not entering the Promised Land, emphasizing that this was not a punishment but rather a necessary act for the benefit of the generation of the desert. It highlights that Moses' burial in the desert enhances the merit of that generation, allowing them to rise in the first resurrection due to his righteousness. The text also explains that while great tzaddikim buried outside of Israel will eventually rise, they will require a process of reincarnation, unlike the generation of the desert who will ascend directly with Moses. Ultimately, both reasons provided for Moses' exclusion from the land are essential and interconnected, reflecting the divine justice that operates for the sake of the people.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי הגמ ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל, שדרשו רז"ל וגם הקימותי את בריתי אתם לתת להם את ארץ כנען, לכם לא נאמר אלא להם מכאן לתה"מ מן התורה, פרש"י ז"ל לכם לא נאמר אלא להם דמשמע שהבטיח הקב"ה לאבותינו אברהם יצחק ויעקב שיתן להם ארץ ישראל, וכי להם ניתנה והלא לבניהם ניתנה, אלא מלמד שעתידין לחיות ועתיד הקב"ה ליתן להם את ארץ כנען עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, וע"כ הכוונה כאן על תחי ' הראשונה לפני ביאת המשיח שאז יקומו האבות הקדושים מדקאמר לתת להם את ארץ כנען, דבתחי ' הכללית לא יהי' עוד במציאות ארץ כנען. שהמלך המשיח יכבוש את כל העולם ולעתיד יהי' הכל תחת יד הקב"ה וכל העולם יהי' בבחי ' א"י וירושלים כנ"ל, ועכ"ח לימוד זה על תחי ' הראשונה שיקומו האבוה"ק אז, ועל תחי ' הכללית ישנם שם בגמ' הרבה לימודים עיי"ש, ורמז הקב"ה למשרע"ה הבטחה זו להפיס דעתו על שנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ, כאמרז"ל כאן נטל משה את הדין שלא יכנס לארץ, דכל זה הכרח לטובתן של ישראל כדי שיבואו עמו דור המדבר בתחי ' הראשונה כשיקומו משרע"ה והאבוה"ק , וע"כ הודיעו ית ' כאן הבטחת תחה"מ וא"ש.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin mentioned above, which our Sages interpreted: "And I will establish My covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan." It was not said "to you" but "to them," from here to the teachings of the Torah. Rashi explains: "It was not said 'to you' but 'to them,' which implies that the Holy One, blessed be He, promised our forefathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob that He would give them the land of Israel. And indeed it was given to them, but it was given to their children. Rather, it teaches that they will live again, and the Holy One, blessed be He, will give them the land of Canaan." Thus, the intention here is regarding the first resurrection before the coming of the Messiah, at which time the holy forefathers will arise, as it says "to give them the land of Canaan." In the general resurrection, there will no longer be the reality of the land of Canaan, for the Messiah will conquer the entire world, and in the future, everything will be under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the entire world will be in the state of the land of Israel and Jerusalem, as mentioned. Therefore, this teaching is about the first resurrection when the holy forefathers will arise then, and regarding the general resurrection, there are many teachings about it in the Gemara, as noted. And the Holy One, blessed be He, hinted to Moses this promise to calm his mind regarding the decree that he would not enter the land, as our Sages said: "Here Moses accepted the judgment that he would not enter the land," for all this is necessary for the benefit of Israel so that they may come with him, the generation of the desert, in the first resurrection when Moses and the holy forefathers will arise. Therefore, the Blessed One informed him here of the promise of the resurrection of the dead, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the promise made by God to the patriarchs Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob regarding the land of Israel, emphasizing that it is ultimately intended for their descendants. It highlights the belief in the resurrection of the patriarchs before the coming of the Messiah, when they will receive the land of Canaan. The text also reflects on the broader theological concept that, in the Messianic era, the entire world will be under God's dominion, resembling the sanctity of the land of Israel and Jerusalem. Additionally, it reassures Moses about his exclusion from entering the land, framing it as a necessary condition for the benefit of the Israelites.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתורץ קושית האוהחה"ק עה"פ והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ, וז"ל קשה כי דברי ק"ל עליון דברו טהור הוא כי יוצאי מצרים הם הנכנסים לארץ דכתיב והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ. ולא מצינו שכן הי' אלא ואת בניהם הביא שמה, אבל כל דור יוצאי מצרים מבן כ' ולמעלה נפלו פגריהם במדבר, ותגדל הקושיא למה שאמרנו שנשבע ד' על כל הדברים, באמרו לכן ואמרו ז"ל אין לכן אלא לשון שבועה ע"כ קושיתו , ותירץ שהבוי"ת הבטיח ע"ד תנאי והקדים לומר וידעתם כי אני ד' המוציא אתכם וגו' ובזה והבאתי אתכם יעיי"ש , ולדרכנו א"ש שיתקיים ההבטחה ליוצאי מצרים והם דור המדבר, והם בעצמם יבואו לארץ לעתיד בתחי ' הראשונה עם משרע"ה והאבוה"ק , וז"א והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ אשר נשאתי את ידי לתת אותה לאברהם ליצחק וליעקב, והיינו ארץ כנען שהובטח להם בתחי ' הראשונה, ויזכו עמהם גם דור המדבר לכנס לארץ, ולפי"ז מאמר והבאתי הבטחה על זמן גאולה העתידה, והנה אמרז"ל (בירושלמי ע"פ ה"ה) דארבע כוסות תיקנו חז"ל כנגד ד' לשונות של גאולה והוצאתי והצלתי וגאלתי ולקחתי, ויתכן דכוס החמישי שמוזגין לכבודו של אלי' זל"ט , הוא כנגד והבאתי שהוא הבטחה על גאולה העתידה בב"א.
translation: And according to our path, the question of the holy Baal Shem Tov on the verse "And I brought you to the land" is resolved. It is difficult because the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, are pure, for those who went out of Egypt are the ones who enter the land, as it is written, "And I brought you to the land." However, we do not find that it was so, but rather that He brought their children there. But every generation of those who went out of Egypt, from the age of twenty and above, their corpses fell in the desert. The question grows regarding what we said that G-d swore on all matters, as it is said, "Therefore," and our sages said that "therefore" is only a term of an oath. Thus, his question is, and he answered that the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised conditionally and preceded by saying, "And you shall know that I am the Lord who brought you out," and with this, "And I brought you" (see there). According to our path, it is clear that the promise to those who went out of Egypt, who are the generation of the desert, will be fulfilled, and they themselves will enter the land in the future at the first resurrection with Moshe Rabbeinu and the holy forefathers. And this is the meaning of "And I brought you to the land which I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob," which is the land of Canaan that was promised to them at the first resurrection, and they will merit along with them also the generation of the desert to enter the land. According to this, the statement "And I brought" is a promise regarding the time of the future redemption. And behold, our sages said (in the Jerusalem Talmud on the verse "And I will take you") that the four cups were established by the sages corresponding to the four expressions of redemption: "And I took out," "and I saved," "and I redeemed," and "and I took." It is possible that the fifth cup, which is poured in honor of Eliyahu, may his memory be blessed, corresponds to "And I brought," which is a promise regarding the future redemption, speedily in our days.
summary: The passage discusses the promise of entering the Land of Israel, emphasizing that while the generation that left Egypt did not enter, their descendants will ultimately inherit the land. It highlights the concept of divine assurance, where God swore to bring the Israelites into the land, linking this promise to future redemption. The text also connects the four cups of wine at the Passover Seder to the four expressions of redemption, suggesting that a fifth cup, associated with the prophet Elijah, symbolizes the future promise of bringing the people into the land. This reflects a deep theological belief in the continuity of God's covenant and the eventual fulfillment of His promises.
