passage_content: ( אמור וגו' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים ופירש"י כאשר הבטחתי ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול והקשה ק"ז זלה"ה בייטב לב למה מביא רש"י ז"ל סיום הקרא ברכוש גדול לכאן, ואפשר לומר דהנה רש"י ז"ל פירש מתחת סבלות מצרים מטורח משא מצרים, ולכאורה צריך להבין אריכות הזה בפסוק, דאלו הי' נשארים ח"ו במצרים, הי' מקום לומר שהוציאם הקב"ה מסבלותם מטורח משאם שניצולו מזה, אבל הקב"ה הוציאם לגמרי ממדינתם, מובן ממילא שניצולו מעבודתם ומטורח משאם, והי' די לומר והוצאתי אתכם ממצרים, ובזה נכלל הכל ואין מהצורך להזכיר עוד מסבלותם ומשאם, גם ענין הד' לשונות של גאולה שנזכרו בכאן צריך להבין לפי"ז , כיון דהכל נכלל ביציאתם משם א"כ בוהוצאתי די.
translation: "Say, etc., and I will take you out from under the burdens of Egypt." Rashi explains, "as I promised," and afterwards they went out with great wealth. The question arises, why does Rashi bring the conclusion of the verse, "with great wealth," here? It can be said that Rashi explains "from under the burdens of Egypt" as from the toil of the burdens of Egypt. At first glance, one needs to understand this elaboration in the verse, for if they had remained, Heaven forbid, in Egypt, one could say that the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out from their burdens, from the toil of their loads, which they were saved from. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, took them completely out of their land; it is understood by itself that they were saved from their work and from the toil of their loads. It would have sufficed to say, "And I will take you out from Egypt," and in that everything is included, and there is no need to mention their burdens and their loads again. Also, the matter of the four expressions of redemption mentioned here needs to be understood according to this, for since everything is included in their leaving from there, then "and I will take you out" is sufficient.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's promise to liberate the Israelites from the burdens of Egypt, emphasizing that their redemption was not merely from physical labor but from the entire oppressive state of being in Egypt. Rashi's commentary highlights the importance of mentioning their release from suffering, suggesting that true freedom encompasses both the cessation of labor and the complete removal from the land of oppression. The text also questions the necessity of detailing the four expressions of redemption, implying that the act of leaving Egypt itself should suffice to convey their liberation. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of redemption as a holistic transformation rather than just a physical escape.

passage_content: אמנם ביאור הענין נראה לפענ"ד , כי הנה ענין גלות מצרים ויציאתם משם, מלבד שיעבוד הגוף יותר מזה סבלו גלות הנפש, שהיו משוקעים שם במ"ט שערי טומאה ר"ל, והקב"ה הוציאם משם ליכנס תחת כנפי השכינה, והנה נודע כאשר האדם יושב במקום קדושת בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות ובכנופיא של ת"ח ועובדי ה', אף בבואו לביתו אח"כ ונפרד משם מועלת לו הקדושה הזאת, וכמאמרם ז"ל משל לנכנס לחנוני של בושם ריח טוב קלט עמו, וכמו כן להיפך ח"ו בשבתו במקומות הטומאה ועוברי עבירה ר"ל, וע"ז נאמר אשרי האיש אשר לא הלך וגו' ובמושב לצים לא ישב וגו', ולא נאמר לשון הווה אינו עומד ואינו יושב, כי גם אם אינו עומד ואינו יושב כעת בדרך חטאים ובמושב לצים, כ"א עמד וישב מכבר, מזיק לו ריח הטומאה שקלט משם גם אח"כ בבואו לביתו, כי הכח הזה אשר נדבק עמו מלוה אותו לביתו, וחז"ל אמרו לנכנס לחנוני של בושם ריח טוב קולט עמו, ובהיפך ח"ו קולט עמו ריח רע, הנה אמרו זה על הנכנס לחנותם ולא עשה שם מאומה, רק מחמת הכניסה לבדו קלט עמו ריח עכ"פ, אבל אם עוד פעל ועשה שם מעשה במקומות האלו, הנה נתלוה עמו כח ממש בין לטוב בין להיפך ח"ו.
translation: Indeed, the explanation of the matter seems to me to be that the issue of the Egyptian exile and their departure from there, aside from the physical servitude, they suffered even more from the exile of the soul, as they were sunk in the forty-nine gates of impurity, so to speak. And the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out from there to enter under the wings of the Shechinah. It is known that when a person sits in a place of holiness, such as synagogues and study halls, and in the company of Torah scholars and servants of God, even when he later returns home and separates from there, this holiness benefits him. As our sages of blessed memory said, it is like one who enters a perfumer's shop; a good scent accompanies him. Similarly, the opposite is true, God forbid, when sitting in places of impurity and among transgressors. And concerning this, it is said, "Blessed is the man who has not walked..." and "In the seat of scoffers, he did not sit..." It does not say in the present tense, "he is not standing and he is not sitting," because even if he is not currently standing or sitting in the way of sinners and in the seat of scoffers, he has already stood and sat there before, and the scent of impurity that he absorbed from there harms him even later when he comes home. For this power that has attached itself to him accompanies him to his home. And our sages said, "One who enters a perfumer's shop, a good scent accompanies him," and conversely, God forbid, a bad scent accompanies him. They said this about one who enters their shop and does nothing there; just by entering alone, he absorbs at least some scent. But if he also acted and did something in those places, then he has truly attached to himself a power, whether for good or, God forbid, the opposite.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual implications of the Egyptian exile and the subsequent redemption, emphasizing that the suffering in Egypt was not only physical but also a profound spiritual degradation, as the Israelites were immersed in impurity. It highlights the transformative power of holiness found in sacred spaces like synagogues and study halls, suggesting that being in such environments leaves a lasting positive impact on a person's soul. Conversely, exposure to places of sin and impurity can also leave a detrimental spiritual residue, affecting one's spiritual state even after leaving those environments. The text underscores the importance of one's surroundings and actions in shaping their spiritual essence.

passage_content: ומעתה הנה ישראל אשר היו משוקעים במצרים כ"כ בכוחות הטומאה, אין ספק כי ביציאתם ממצרים, נתלוה עמם כח הטומאה הזה, אשר ירשו להם במקום המזוהם ההוא, וא"כ לא די להם הבטחה זו שיצאו ממצרים, כי גם אחר יציאתם משם לא נפטרו עי"ז מהזוהמא שגרמו לנפשם ע"י ישיבתם ביניהם, והנה נודע כי העונות וכח הטומאה הוא כמשא כבידה על האדם, כמשאה"כ כי עונותי עברו ראשי כמשא כבד יכבדו ממנו, ומכביד על האדם כל דרכי עבודתו ית"ש , ובזה מובן משאה"כ והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, כי לא סגי ביציאתם ממצרים אם עדיין נשאר אצלם משא כובד העונות וארס הטומאה שהכניסו בהם המצריים בזוהמתם הגדולה, לכן אמר שהוציא אותם מתחת סבלות מצרים כפירש"י ז"ל מטורח משא מצרים, ר"ל מהמשא הגדולה שהטילו עליהם המצרים בכח טומאתם, אשר אין לך משא כבידה מזה, וממילא לא סגי ביציאתם ממצרים לחוד, כ"א בהצלת נפשותם מזוהמת וטומאת מצרים לעניני פגם הנפש בהרבה בחינות, וא"כ אין קושי' מה שהוצרך לזה די לשונות של גאולה, לאשר בהם נרמז גאולת הנפש בהרבה בחינות.
translation: And from now on, behold, Israel, who were so deeply immersed in Egypt in the forces of impurity, there is no doubt that upon their departure from Egypt, this force of impurity accompanied them, which they inherited in that defiled place. Therefore, it is not enough for them to have this promise that they left Egypt, for even after their departure from there, they did not free themselves from the contamination that they caused to their souls by dwelling among them. And it is known that sins and the force of impurity are like a heavy burden on a person, as it is written, "For my iniquities have gone over my head; they are like a heavy burden; they are too heavy for me." And it burdens a person in all his ways of serving the Blessed One. In this, it is understood as it is written, "And I will take you out from under the burdens of Egypt," for it is not sufficient for them to leave Egypt if the heavy burden of sins and the poison of impurity that the Egyptians instilled in them through their great defilement still remains with them. Therefore, it is said that He took them out from under the burdens of Egypt, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains, from the toil of the burden of Egypt, meaning from the great burden that the Egyptians imposed upon them through the power of their impurity, which there is no heavier burden than this. And consequently, it is not enough for them to leave Egypt alone, but rather to save their souls from the contamination and impurity of Egypt regarding the blemish of the soul in many aspects. Therefore, there is no difficulty in the need for this to be expressed in many terms of redemption, in which the redemption of the soul is hinted at in many aspects.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual implications of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that their liberation was not merely physical but also required a cleansing from the spiritual impurities and burdens they inherited from their time in Egypt. It highlights that sins and the power of impurity weigh heavily on the soul, akin to a burden that hinders one's service to God. Therefore, the exodus involved not only escaping physical oppression but also a profound redemption of the soul from the contamination of Egyptian influences. The text suggests that multiple expressions of redemption are necessary to convey the comprehensive nature of this spiritual liberation.

passage_content: והנה הובא בספה"ק מדרש פליאה הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם וכבר פירשתי בכמה אופנים, וכעת נ"ל גם לבאר המדרש בפ ' בשלח עה"פ אז ישיר משה, הה"ד ואני אשיר עזך וארנן לבוקר חסדך, ואני אשיר עזך אימתי בשעה שעמדו ישראל על הים וכו ', וארנן לבוקר חסדך אותו הבוקר של מתן תורה וכו' גם להבין הפ ' בפ ' שמות והכיתי את מצרים בכל נפלאותי , וגו', ואחרי כן ישלח אתכם וגו' והי' כי תלכון לא תלכו ריקם, וצ"ב יתור הלשון והי' כי תלכון כיון שכבר הזכיר ואח"כ ישלח אתכם, הולל"מ תיכף ולא תלכו ריקם, גם צריך להבין למה אומר לשון שלילה לא תלכו ריקם הול"ל בפי' תלכו מלא, ובאמת הי' כולל אז יותר ממ"ש לא תלכו ריקם, כי אם יהי' להם אף מעט לא יהי' ריקם עכ"פ, אבל באמת הי' ממולאים הרבה מביזת מצרים, כמבואר בגמ' (בכורות ה' ע"ב) אין לך כאו"א מישראל שלא הי' עמו צ' חמורים וכו' מכספה וזהבה של מצרים.
translation: And behold, it is brought in the holy book Midrash P'liya that the sea saw and fled. What did Israel see? They saw that the Egyptians were coming and their possessions were in their hands. I have already explained this in several ways, and now it seems to me to also explain the Midrash in Parashat Beshalach on the verse "Then Moses sang," as it is written, "And I will sing of Your strength, and I will sing in the morning of Your kindness." I will sing of Your strength—when? At the time when Israel stood by the sea, etc. And I will sing in the morning of Your kindness—referring to that morning of the giving of the Torah, etc. Also to understand the verse in Parashat Shemot, "And I will strike Egypt with all My wonders," etc., and afterwards He will send you, etc. And it will be that when you go, you will not go empty-handed. There is a question regarding the superfluous language, "And it will be that when you go," since it has already mentioned "and afterwards He will send you." It should have said immediately, "and you will not go empty-handed." Also, it is necessary to understand why it uses the negative expression "you will not go empty-handed," it should have said explicitly "you will go full." And indeed, it would have included more than what is stated in "you will not go empty-handed," for if they would have even a little, they would not be empty-handed at least. But in truth, they were filled with much from the spoils of Egypt, as it is explained in the Gemara (Baba Batra 5b), there is no one among Israel who did not have with him two hundred donkeys, etc., from the silver and gold of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' departure from Egypt, emphasizing their wealth acquired from the Egyptians as a divine blessing. It highlights the connection between their liberation and the future revelation at Mount Sinai, suggesting that their material abundance is intertwined with spiritual elevation. The use of the phrase "not empty" underscores the idea that their journey is not just physical but also rich in spiritual meaning, reflecting the Hasidic belief in the unity of material and spiritual realms. Ultimately, it conveys that the Israelites were filled with both physical treasures and the promise of divine grace.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עפ"י מה שכתב הגה"ק מהרא"ל מפלאצק זצלה"ה בספרו ברכת השיר על הגדה, במה שאמרו חז"ל דבר נא באזני העם, אמר הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו' ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, וקשה למה הוצרך הזהרה כ"כ על לקיחת הרכוש, דברים שנפשו של אדם מחמדתן, גם קשה הלא איתא בפ ' חלק שדנו אנשי מצרים על הרכוש שהוציאו, והיתה התשובה תנו לנו שכר ד' מאות שנה ששיעבדו , א"כ מגיע להם הרכוש מדינא , ולמה הוצרך לטעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, גם הוא פלא גדול למה הוצרך לתחבולה זו שיקחו הרכוש בשאלה ולא יחזרו אח"כ, הלא אין מעצור לה' להושיע לתת להם חן בעיני המצריים שיתנו להם בפה מלא וכמו שהוציאם משם ביד חזקה, ופי' הג' זלה"ה דודאי כיון שנגזר עליהם ת' שנה, אין להם תביעה על הרכוש בשכר עבודתם, מאחר שלא השלימו זמנם ושכירות אינו משתלמת אלא לבסוף, אלא מחמת שהקב"ה יעד להם נתינת התורה, כמ"ש תעבדון את אלקים על ההר הזה, אתקדשו בקדושת הגוף כמאמרינו אשר קדשנו במצותיו, והקדש מפקיע מידי שיעבוד, וממילא אין להם עוד שיעבוד עליהם, וצריך ליתן להם שכר שיעבוד השנים שעברו, אמנם קודם שקיבלו התוה"ק לא נפקע שעבודם עדיין, ואין מגיע להם הרכוש, לכן עצת ה' היא תקום שיקחו בהלואה עד חג השבועות זמן מתן תורה, וכיון שהי' אצלם הרכוש בשאלה בשעת מתן תורה, זכו בי' מדינא כיון שנפקע השיעבוד והגיע זמן הפרעון , ולכן בשעת הליכתן ממצרים שלא זכו עדיין בהרכוש אלא לקחוהו בשאלה הוצרכו לאזהרה ללקיחת הרכוש, כי הי' בעיניהם טירחא שלא לצורך לישא על הדרך רכוש שלא להם עיי"ש.
translation: And it can be said according to what the holy Rabbi, the Maharal of Płock, may his merit protect us, wrote in his book Berakhat HaShir on the Haggadah, regarding what our Sages said, "Speak now in the ears of the people," that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "Please warn them not to say that righteous one, etc." And afterwards they went out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled in them. It is difficult to understand why such a warning was necessary regarding taking the wealth, things that a person's soul desires. It is also difficult, for it is stated in the section of "Chelek" that the Egyptians argued about the wealth they took out, and the response was, "Give us the wages for four hundred years of servitude." Therefore, they are entitled to the wealth by law, so why was there a need for the reason that they should not say that righteous one? It is also a great wonder why there was a need for this trick to take the wealth as a loan and not return afterwards. Surely there is no barrier for the Holy One, blessed be He, to save them and grant them favor in the eyes of the Egyptians so that they would give them freely, just as He took them out from there with a strong hand. The explanation of the holy Rabbi is certainly that since it was decreed upon them for four hundred years, they have no claim to the wealth as payment for their labor, since they did not complete their time, and wages are only paid at the end. However, because the Holy One, blessed be He, destined for them the giving of the Torah, as it is said, "And you shall serve God on this mountain," they were sanctified with the sanctity of the body, as we say, "Who has sanctified us with His commandments," and sanctity releases from servitude. Therefore, they no longer have servitude upon them, and they need to be given the wages for the years of servitude that have passed. However, before they received the Torah, their servitude had not yet been released, and they were not entitled to the wealth. Therefore, the counsel of the Holy One, blessed be He, will stand that they should take it as a loan until the Festival of Weeks, the time of the giving of the Torah. And since the wealth was with them as a loan at the time of the giving of the Torah, they were entitled to it by law, since the servitude was released and the time of repayment arrived. Therefore, at the time of their leaving Egypt, since they had not yet received the wealth but took it as a loan, they needed a warning to take the wealth, for it seemed to them a burden unnecessarily to carry wealth that was not theirs along the way.
summary: The passage discusses the divine instruction given to Moses to warn the Israelites about taking wealth from the Egyptians, emphasizing that their claim to the riches was not valid until they received the Torah. It highlights the concept that their servitude was not fully completed, and thus they had no rightful claim to compensation until the giving of the Torah, which would release them from their bondage. The strategy of borrowing the wealth until the time of the Torah's giving was necessary to ensure they would be able to claim it legitimately once their servitude ended. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine timing, human actions, and the fulfillment of God's promises.

passage_content: וא"כ לפי"ז מובן היטב מה שלא אמר הכתוב שילכו מלאים, כי יען שלא להם עדיין הרכוש הזה, לא שייך לומר שהיו מלאים, כי אז לא הי' נקנה להם מזה מאומה, אמנם יען כי הי' אצלם עכ"פ בשאלה, להנות מהרכוש הזה לאח"ז לא הי' ריקנים עכ"פ, אבל זו הי' רק בשעת הליכה ע"כ אמר לא תלכו ריקם, שבשעת הליכה א"א באופן אחר אלא שלא הי' ריקנין עכ"פ, אבל לבסוף ישתלשל מזה שהיו מלאים ממש.
translation: And therefore, according to this, it is well understood why the scripture did not say that they would go full, for since this wealth did not yet belong to them, it is not appropriate to say that they were full, for then they would not have acquired anything from it. However, since it was at least in question for them, to benefit from this wealth afterwards, they were not empty at least. But this was only at the time of walking; therefore, it said, "Do not go empty," for at the time of walking, it is impossible otherwise than that they were not empty at least. However, in the end, it will result in them being truly full.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual readiness and potential in the context of receiving blessings. It emphasizes that although the Israelites did not yet possess the wealth, their journey was marked by a sense of anticipation and connection to the divine promise, preventing them from being considered empty. This state of not being "empty" during their journey signifies a deeper spiritual fulfillment that would ultimately lead to their true abundance. The text highlights the importance of faith and expectation in the process of receiving divine gifts.

passage_content: והנה נודע דברי חז"ל ששר של ים טען מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עע"ז והללו עע"ז , ונודע כי גם בעת שהיו עוברים בים סוף עבר עמהם ערב רב ופסל מיכה כמאמר חז"ל עה"כ כי עבר בים צרה, אמנם טענה זו מה בין אלו לאלו לא הי' לו מקום רק עד קבלת התוה"ק , כי בשעת קבלת התורה פסקה זוהמתם ונתקדשו בקדושת הגוף, וגם אם חוטאים אח"כ יש להם תקוה ע"י התוה"ק בהקרבת הקרבן והתשובה, דזהו ההבדל בין ישראל לאוה"ע שמועלת לנו התשובה ע"י התוה"ק כנודע בספה"ק , וא"כ אין מקום לטענת הים מה בין אלו לאלו. כי ישראל המה עתידים לקבל התוה"ק , ולא עשה כן לכל גוי, והנה מאין הי' הדין זה שבודאי ישראל יקבלו התוה"ק , וזה מובן מרכוש מצרים אשר בידם, וקשה מאוד למה עשה ה' ככה להזהירם על כך, ליקח הרכוש שאינו מגיע להם, ולהטריחם בטורח משא הדרך בדבר שאינו שלהם, לולא שיקבלו התוה"ק אח"כ, ויתקדשו קדושת הגוף ויגיע להם הרכוש מדינא , לזה הוצרכו להטריח שיהי' בידם שיזכו בו אח"כ, ובזה מובן היטב דברי המדרש מה ראה ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם, שמזה מוכרח שבודאי יקבלו התוה"ק אח"כ, ונתבטלה טענתו מה בין אלו לאלו.
translation: And behold, it is known the words of our Sages that the minister of the sea claimed, "What is the difference between these and those, these are idol worshippers and those are idol worshippers." It is known that even at the time they were crossing the Sea of Reeds, a mixed multitude accompanied them, and the idol of Micah was with them, as our Sages said regarding the verse, "For he passed through the sea in distress." However, this claim of "What is the difference between these and those" had no place except until the acceptance of the Torah, for at the time of the giving of the Torah, their impurity ceased, and they were sanctified with the sanctity of the body. And even if they sin afterwards, they have hope through the Torah by bringing a sacrifice and through repentance, for this is the difference between Israel and the nations of the world, that repentance is effective for us through the Torah, as is known in the holy books. Therefore, there is no place for the claim of the sea, "What is the difference between these and those?" For Israel are destined to receive the Torah, and He did not do so for any other nation. And behold, from where did this judgment arise that certainly Israel will receive the Torah? This is understood from the wealth of Egypt that was in their hands. It is very difficult to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, did this to warn them about this, to take the wealth that does not belong to them, and to burden them with the toil of the journey regarding something that is not theirs, unless they would receive the Torah afterwards and be sanctified with the sanctity of the body, and the wealth would rightfully belong to them. For this reason, they needed to be burdened so that it would be in their hands to merit it afterwards. In this, the words of the Midrash are well understood: "What did Israel see that they came with the wealth of Egypt in their hands?" From this, it is evident that they would certainly receive the Torah afterwards, and his claim of "What is the difference between these and those" was nullified.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the Jewish people and other nations, emphasizing that the Israelites were destined to receive the Torah, which sanctifies them and provides a path for repentance even after sinning. The argument presented by the angel of the sea, questioning the difference between the Israelites and the Egyptians, is rendered invalid after the giving of the Torah, as it elevates the spiritual status of the Jews. The acquisition of Egyptian wealth before receiving the Torah serves as a divine assurance of their future sanctification and rightful claim to that wealth, reinforcing their unique covenantal relationship with God.

passage_content: ומובן גם דברי המדרש, ואני אשיר עוזיך בשעה שעמדו ישראל על הים וארנן לבוקר חסדך זה בוקרו של מתן תורה, כי אלו השנים שייכו להדדי, שע"י של בוקרו של מ"ת , נעשה עוזו של ים שנתבטלה טענתו, ומעתה מובן היטב מה שמביא רש"י עה"כ והוצאתי אתכם וכו' כאשר הבטחתי ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, שכבר ביארתי שההוצאה מתחת סבלות מצרים, מורה על טורח משא וכובד הזוהמא שלהם, והנה נודע כי לא נפטרו לגמרי מזוהמתן של מצרים עד שעת מ"ת , שאז נתקדשו בקדושת הגוף ממש, ונטהרו מטומאתן הראשונה, ולזה הביא ראי' לכאן מהכתוב דאח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, דלקיחת הרכוש א"א כי אם ע"י קבלת התוה"ק שנתקדשו בקדושת הגוף, וזה הצלתם מטורח משא זוהמתן של מצרים.
translation: And the words of the Midrash are also understood, and I will sing of Your might at the time when Israel stood by the sea, and I will rejoice in the morning of Your kindness; this is the morning of the giving of the Torah, for these years are connected to each other, that through the morning of the giving of the Torah, the might of the sea was nullified, and from now on it is well understood what Rashi brings on the verse "And I will take you out," etc., as I promised, and afterwards they went out with great wealth. For I have already explained that the exodus from under the burdens of Egypt indicates the toil of their load and the heaviness of their impurity. And behold, it is known that they were not completely freed from the impurity of Egypt until the time of the giving of the Torah, at which point they were sanctified with a true sanctity of the body and were purified from their original impurity. And for this, he brought a proof here from the verse that afterwards they went out with great wealth, for the taking of the wealth could only be through the acceptance of the Torah, having been sanctified with the sanctity of the body, and this is their salvation from the toil of the burden of the impurity of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Israelites' crossing of the Red Sea and the giving of the Torah, emphasizing that the spiritual elevation achieved at Mount Sinai was essential for their complete liberation from the impurities of Egypt. It highlights that the Israelites were not fully cleansed from their Egyptian contamination until they received the Torah, which sanctified them physically and spiritually. The reference to their subsequent departure with great wealth signifies that true redemption and spiritual elevation are intertwined with the acceptance of the Torah. Thus, the narrative illustrates the profound relationship between divine assistance, spiritual purification, and the transformative power of the Torah in the lives of the Jewish people.

passage_content: לכן אמור לבנ"י אני ד' והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים וגו' פרש"י כי כן הבטחתיו ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול, וק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה דקדק מדוע הביא רש"י סיפא דקרא ברכוש גדול עיי"ש תירוצו ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation: Therefore, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," etc. Rashi explains that this is how I promised him, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth. And the holy heart, may his merit protect us, was precise in asking why Rashi brought the end of the verse about "great wealth." See there for his answer, and also for the God of words.
summary: The passage emphasizes God's promise to the Israelites, highlighting His role as their liberator from the burdens of Egypt. It references Rashi's commentary, which notes that the mention of leaving with great wealth underscores the fulfillment of divine promises. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine providence and the importance of faith in God's assurances. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between spiritual redemption and material blessings as part of God's covenant with His people.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה ( בפ ' בא) דיש להבין מ"ש לאאע"ה כי גר יהי' זרעך וגו' ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול מה החשיבות של הרכוש גדול בעיני אברהם, ומה לו בבצע כסף, ותוכן תירוצו, דזה להורות שלא יטמעו באומות ויהיו נחשבין ע"ש אבותיהם, שלא יחשוש אברהם דאלו שיצאו יהיו אחרים ולא בניו, דידוע דזה הי' שכר העבודה, דאל"כ האיך יצוה הקב"ה לגזול, ואם נטמעו א"כ אין לו ליטול שכר בשביל אביו וכו ', דמבואר בריש בכורות שאין לך א' מישראל שאין לו תשעים חמורים טעונים מכספם וזהבם של מצרים, ובודאי שכר עבודתו של כל א' לבד לא יעלה להון רב כזה, אם לא בהצטרף שכר עבודת אבותיו ג"כ, והיינו דבר נא וישאלו וגו', הכל להורות זה לבני העולם שהם מתייחסים אחר אבותיהם ולא נטמעו ח"ו, וזהו כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם, היינו בזרעו שנא' כי גר יהי' זרעך ואח"כ יצאו וגו' לא קיים בהם דאלו אינם זרעו וכו ', וע"כ ביקש מהם שישאלו וגו' ואז ידע אותו צדיק שגם אלו הם זרעו, עייש"ד באריכות.
translation: And it is to be understood in advance the words of K.Z. the holy one (in Parashat Ba) that one must understand what is meant by the Holy One, Blessed be He, saying, "For your seed will be a stranger," etc., and afterwards they will go out with great wealth. What is the significance of the great wealth in the eyes of Abraham, and what does he care for a mere sum of money? The essence of your explanation is to indicate that they should not become assimilated among the nations and be considered according to their ancestors, so that Abraham should not be concerned that those who go out will be others and not his children. It is known that this was the reward for the labor, for otherwise how could the Holy One, Blessed be He, command to steal? And if they became assimilated, then he would have no right to take reward for his father, etc. It is explained at the beginning of Bekhorot that there is no one among Israel who does not have ninety donkeys loaded with the silver and gold of Egypt, and certainly the reward for the labor of each one alone would not amount to such great wealth, unless it is combined with the reward for the labor of their ancestors as well. And this is the meaning of "And they will ask," etc., all to indicate this to the children of the world that they are related to their ancestors and have not become assimilated, Heaven forbid. And this is so that that righteous one should not say, "And they will serve them and oppress them" is fulfilled in them, meaning in his seed, as it is said, "For your seed will be a stranger," and afterwards they will go out, etc. It is not fulfilled in them, for they are not his seed, etc. Therefore, he asked them to "ask," etc., and then that righteous one would know that even these are his seed, as explained there at length.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Abraham's descendants being promised wealth upon their departure from Egypt, emphasizing that this wealth serves as a testament to their identity as his progeny. It highlights the concern that they might assimilate into other nations and be regarded as separate from their ancestors. The text asserts that the wealth they acquire is a reflection of the merit of their forefathers' labor, ensuring that they remain connected to their lineage and not lose their identity. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of recognizing one's heritage and the continuity of spiritual legacy through generations.

passage_content: והנה דרשו רז"ל במדרש (הובא ברש"י ז"ל פ' פנחס) עה"פ משפחת החנכי לפי שהיו האומות מבזין אותם ואומרים מה אלו מתייחסין על שבטיהם, סבורים הם שלא שלטו המצריים באמותיהם, אם בגופם היו מושלים ק"ו בנשותיהם, לפיכך הטיל הקב"ה שמו עליהם ה"א מצד זה ויו"ד מצד זה, לומר מעיד אני עליהם שהם בני אבותיהם וזה הוא שמפורש ע"י דוד (תהלים קכ"ב) שבטי יה עדות לישראל, השם הזה מעיד עליהם לשבטיהם עכ"ל, ובזה יתבארו דברי רשיז"ל וקישור הכתוב שא"ל הקב"ה למשרע"ה וארא אל האבות, ר"ל דהבטחתי להם בבחי ' אבות, שיתקיים הבטחתי בזרעם הנחשבים ע"ש אבותיהם ולא יטמעו באומות, ושמי ד' לא נודעתי להם, ר"ל שם י"ה המעיד על ישראל כי עדיין לא נודע להם עדות זה, א"כ עדיין בצער זה שרויים שלא יטמעו זרעם באומות ח"ו, לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד', ששמי מעיד עליהם שלא נטמעו והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים שכן הבטחתיו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, שגם הרכוש יהי' עדות שלא נטמעו ובנ"י עאלו ובנ"י נפקו כנ"ל.
translation: And behold, our sages have expounded in the Midrash (as brought by Rashi, of blessed memory, in Parashat Pinchas) on the verse "the family of the Hanchakim," because the nations were belittling them and saying, "What are these that they are related to their tribes? They think that the Egyptians did not rule over their mothers; if they ruled over their bodies, certainly over their wives." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, placed His name upon them, the letter "He" from this side and the letter "Yud" from that side, to say, "I testify about them that they are the children of their forefathers." This is what is explicitly stated by David (Psalms 122), "The tribes of Yehudah are a testimony to Israel." This name testifies about them to their tribes. Thus, the words of our sages will be clarified, and the connection to the verse that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, "And I appeared to the forefathers," means that I promised them in the aspect of 'forefathers' that my promise would be fulfilled in their offspring, who are considered in the name of their forefathers and will not be assimilated among the nations. And "My name Yud-Heh" was not made known to them, meaning the name Yud-Heh that testifies about Israel, for it had not yet been made known to them as a testimony. Therefore, they are still in this distress, that their offspring should not be assimilated among the nations, Heaven forbid. Thus, say to the children of Israel, "I am the Lord," that My name testifies about them that they have not been assimilated, and I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt, as I promised them. And afterwards, they went out with great wealth, for that wealth will also be a testimony that they have not been assimilated, and the children of Israel entered and the children of Israel exited, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the assurance given by God to the Jewish people regarding their identity and heritage, emphasizing that despite the oppression they faced in Egypt, they remain distinct and connected to their ancestors. It highlights the significance of God's name, which serves as a testimony to their lineage and the promise that they would not be assimilated into other nations. The reference to the names and the connection to the patriarchs underscores the divine commitment to their survival and the fulfillment of God's promises, culminating in their eventual liberation and wealth as a sign of their enduring identity.

passage_content: במסורה לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ה', לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום, פי' החיד"א ז"ל בס' חומת אנך וזל"ק : אפשר לפרש כמ"ש רז"ל דבזכות שהיו גדורים בעריות יצאו ממצרים, וזה רמז לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ה' והוצאתי אתכם. והטעם בזכות שתשמרו אות ברית קודש על דרך שזכה פנחס לכל המעלות' לפי שקנא על ברית, כמש"ה לכן אמור הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום, מכח שקנא על ברית זכה לברית שלום, כן ישראל יצאו בזכות ששמרו את בריתי, ששמרו וגדרו עצמם מעריות, לכן אמור לבני ישראל שכולם בני ישראל ולא נמצא בם פסול בני ישראל עאלו ובני ישראל נפקו אני ה' והוצאתי אתכם עכל"ק , ובדרכו אלך גם אני לבאר הפסוק הסמוכה אליו והיתה לו ולזרעו אחריו ברית כהונת עולם וגו', עפי"ד התרגום יונתן בן עוזיאל בשבועא אימר לי' מן שמי האנא גזר לי' ית קימי שלם ואעבדיני ' מלאך קיים ויחי לעלמא למבשרא גאולתא בסוף יומיא ומכוון למ"ש חז"ל פנחס זה אלי', ומשום שקנא קנאת ה' במסירת נפש על קדושת הברית לכן זה שכרו שיבא לבשר הגאולה באחרית הימים, ויתבאר עפ"י דברי החיד"א ז"ל הנ"ל שגאולת מצרים הי' בזכות שמירת הברית. אמנם מה יהי' הזכות בדורות האחרונים בעיקבא דמשיחא שגבר הצר היצה"ר להיצר לישראל ולהכשילם ח"ו בפגם הברית, וגדלה הפריצות במדה נוראה ומבהילה, ואף האנשים השלמים והיראים נכשלים בהרהורים רעים ומחשבות זרות, ואמרו חז"ל ונשמרת מכל דבר רע שלא יהרהר אדם ביום וכו ', ופשוטי עם נתקלים יותר בעוה"ר , ולמותר להאריך כמה יגיעות צריך ליגע ולעמול שלא להכשל , ובאיזה זכות נזכה לגאולה, אלא שאלי' הנביא יזריח רוח טהרה וקדושה בלבבות בני ישראל ויעשה משמרת לגדר עריות ושמירת הברית, וזה שאמר תיב"ע ויחי לעלמא למבשרא גאולתא בסוף יומיא , וקאי על פסוק הקודם הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלום שהוא שכרו בשביל שקינא על הברית ובזה הכח יוושעו בני ישראל ובזכותו תהי' הגאולה העתידה באחרית הימים.
translation:
In the tradition, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord; therefore say, behold, I give him My covenant of peace. The explanation of the Chida, of blessed memory, in the book Chomat Anach is as follows: It is possible to interpret as our Sages have said, that in merit of their being guarded from immorality, they left Egypt. This is hinted at in the phrase, therefore say to the children of Israel, I am the Lord, and I have taken you out. The reason is that in merit of your keeping the sign of the holy covenant, in the way that Pinchas merited all the virtues, for he was zealous for the covenant, as it is stated, therefore say, behold, I give him My covenant of peace. Because he was zealous for the covenant, he merited the covenant of peace; likewise, Israel left in merit of their keeping My covenant, that they guarded and fenced themselves from immorality. Therefore say to the children of Israel that they are all children of Israel, and there is no blemish among them. The children of Israel went out, I am the Lord, and I have taken you out, all of this is clear. 

And in my way, I will also explain the adjacent verse, and it shall be for him and his descendants after him a covenant of priesthood forever, etc. According to the translation of Jonathan ben Uziel, in the oath, He said to him from My name, I have decreed for him a complete and eternal angel, and he shall live forever to announce the redemption at the end of days. This corresponds to what our Sages have said, Pinchas is Eliyahu. And because he was zealous for the zeal of the Lord, giving his life for the sanctity of the covenant, therefore his reward is that he will come to announce the redemption in the end of days. 

And it will be explained according to the words of the Chida mentioned above that the redemption from Egypt was in merit of the observance of the covenant. However, what will be the merit in the last generations, in the time of the Messiah, when the evil inclination has prevailed to entice Israel and to cause them to stumble, Heaven forbid, in the blemish of the covenant? And the immorality has increased to a terrifying and dreadful degree, and even the righteous and God-fearing people stumble in evil thoughts and foreign ideas. And our Sages have said, and you shall guard yourself from every evil thing, that a person should not entertain evil thoughts during the day, etc. And simple people encounter more in this world, and it is unnecessary to elaborate on how much effort one must exert and toil not to stumble, and by what merit will we merit redemption? 

Rather, let the prophet Eliyahu shine a spirit of purity and holiness in the hearts of the children of Israel and establish a guard against immorality and the observance of the covenant. This is what is said, "And he shall live forever to announce the redemption at the end of days," and it refers to the previous verse, behold, I give him My covenant of peace, which is his reward for being zealous for the covenant. In this merit, the children of Israel will be saved, and through his merit, the future redemption will be in the end of days.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of maintaining the covenant of holiness, particularly in relation to sexual morality, as a key factor in the redemption of the Jewish people from Egypt. It highlights that the merit of the Israelites in preserving this covenant led to their liberation, paralleling the zeal of Pinchas, who was rewarded for his fervor in protecting the sanctity of the covenant. In the context of the challenges faced in the latter days, where moral decay is prevalent, the text calls for a divine infusion of purity and holiness to help the Jewish people uphold their commitments. Ultimately, it asserts that through this renewed dedication to the covenant, the future redemption will be realized.

passage_content: ולקחתי אתכם לו לעם וידעתם כי אני ה' אלקיכם המוציא אתכם וגו' והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה אני ה', יל"ד על אומרו מורשה ולא לשון ירושה, ומשמעות מורשה שיהיו מורישים לאחרים, עיין בגמ' (ב"ב קי"ט ע"ב) וע' פנים לתורה, גם צ"ב אומרו אני ה' שתי פעמים ודרשו רז"ל נאמן לשלם שכר, ונאמן בהבטחתי ומדוע הכפיל עוה"פ .
translation: "And I took you to be My people, and you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out, etc., and I brought you to the land, etc., and I gave it to you as a heritage. I am the Lord. The question arises regarding the term 'heritage' and not 'inheritance,' and the meaning of 'heritage' is that you shall pass it on to others. See in the Gemara (Baba Batra 119b) and also in the 'Faces of the Torah.' It is also puzzling why it says 'I am the Lord' twice, and our Sages have interpreted that He is faithful to pay the reward and faithful in His promise. And why is it repeated in this world?"
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "morasha" (heritage) as opposed to "yerusha" (inheritance), emphasizing that the land is meant to be passed down to future generations, reflecting a communal responsibility. It also highlights the repetition of "I am the Lord" to signify God's faithfulness in fulfilling promises and rewarding those who follow His commandments. This dual emphasis serves to reinforce the idea of a covenantal relationship between God and His people, where the land is both a gift and a responsibility to be shared.

passage_content: ב) כי אני ה' המוציא וגו', בגמ' ברכות (ל"ח ע"א) ורבנן הכי קאמר להו קוב"ה לישראל, כד אפיקנא לכו עבידנא לכו מילתא כי היכי דידעיתו , דאנא הוא דאפיקת יתכון ממצרים דכתיב וידעתם כי אני ה' אלקיכם המוציא, ראוי להבין מה הוא הדבר אשר על ידו יתודע לישראל כי השי"ת הוציא אותם ממצרים, ורז"ל סתמו דבריהם ולא ביארו מהו, גם היכן רמיזא בכתוב.
translation: B) For I am the Lord who brings you out, etc. In the Gemara Berakhot (38a), the Rabbis said to Israel, "When I bring you out, I will do something for you so that you will know, for I am the one who brought you out of Egypt," as it is written, "And you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brings you out." It is fitting to understand what it is that will make Israel aware that the Holy One, Blessed be He, took them out of Egypt, and our Sages left their words ambiguous and did not clarify what it is, nor where it is hinted at in the text.
summary: The passage discusses the divine revelation of God as the one who brought the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing the importance of this knowledge for the Jewish people. It highlights that understanding the significance of their redemption is crucial, yet the sages left this concept somewhat ambiguous without explicit clarification. The text invites contemplation on how this knowledge of liberation is to be recognized and internalized by Israel, reflecting a deeper theological insight into the relationship between God and His people.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"מ שפי' בספה"ק אגרא דכלה בפ ' שופטים וזלה"ק , כי הגוים האלה אשר אתה יורש אותם אל מעוננים וכו' ישמעו ואתה לא כן נתן ה' אלקיך . והנראה להבין הדבר עפ"י קבלתינו מרבותינו כח הפועל בנפעל, ממילא ממונו ורכושו של אדם שהאדם מסגלו ע"י מעשיו, הנה יש בממון ורכוש ההוא כח הפועל, ע"כ נאסר לנו לפרוט מתיבת המוכסין כיון שכח הפועל יש בהממון ההוא, והאדם הכשר יקחנו לעצמו הנה יגרום לנפשו פעולות זרות כפי כח הפועל הנפשיי מבעלים הראשונים וכו ', והנה בכאן השי"ת נתן לישראל את כל טוב ארצות הגוים האלה ממונם ורכושם המה יירשום, הנה יש לחוש כי כח הפועל בנפעל ובכל הרכוש האלה טמון מדות רעות של הגוים , הנה כאשר יהנו ישראל ממנו יש לחוש שיקנו קנין בנפשם לעשות כמעשיהם, אבל לא כן הוא כי ישראל יירשום ירושה ונתונה מאת השי"ת, והשי"ת הוא הבעלים של הרכוש, וזה שהתחיל כי אתה בא אל הארץ אשר ה' אלקיך נותן לך. ואין זה בהשתדלותך ליקח מיד הרשעים האלה רק השי"ת נותן לך, ע"כ אני מבטיחך שעי"ז לא תלמד לעשות כתועבות הגוים ההם עכל"ק בקיצור.
translation: And even though it is explained in the holy book Agra D'Kallah in Parshat Shoftim, as follows: "For these nations that you are about to inherit, they listen to diviners, etc., but you, the Lord your God has not given you so." It seems we can understand the matter according to our tradition from our teachers regarding the power of the active in the passive. By nature, a person's wealth and possessions are acquired through his actions; thus, within that wealth and possessions, there is the power of the active. Therefore, it is forbidden for us to take from the tax collector's box, since the power of the active is contained within that wealth. A righteous person who takes it for himself will cause his soul to engage in foreign actions according to the power of the soul from the original owners, etc. Here, the Holy One, Blessed be He, has given Israel all the good of the lands of these nations; their wealth and possessions they will inherit. There is a concern that the power of the active in the passive and in all that wealth is hidden with the bad traits of the nations. When Israel benefits from it, there is a concern that they will acquire a possession in their souls to act like their deeds. However, it is not so, for Israel will inherit a heritage given by the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Holy One is the owner of the possessions. This is what it begins with: "For you are coming to the land which the Lord your God is giving you." It is not through your efforts to take from the hands of these wicked ones; rather, the Holy One is giving it to you. Therefore, I assure you that through this, you will not learn to do according to the abominations of those nations. All this is said briefly.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine inheritance, emphasizing that the wealth and possessions of the nations are given to the Israelites by God, rather than acquired through their own efforts. It warns that the negative traits associated with these nations could influence the Israelites if they engage with their possessions. However, since this wealth is a gift from God, it is believed that the Israelites will not adopt the immoral practices of the nations. Ultimately, the text reassures that God's provision ensures that the Israelites will remain distinct and not be swayed by the corrupt ways of others.

passage_content: ועפי"ז ביארתי במאמה"כ כי תצא למלחמה על אויביך ונתנו ה' אלקיך בידך וגו', דאולי תחשוש למנוע לבוז בז ולשלול שלל למען לא יוליד בך הממון הבא מידי רשעים תכונה רעה, לזה אמר ונתנו ה' אלקיך בידך דייקא דע כי מתת ה' הוא, ע"כ ושבית שביו ואין לך ליפחד שיגרום לך ירידה רוחניות, אדרבה על כי השי"ת הוא הנותן, יפעול כח הפועל שבו להמשיך לך מדות טובות, ולהביאך לידי קיום מצות ומע"ט , כנודע שתכלית ביאתם לא"י הי' כדי לקיים מצות התליות בארץ, ודין גרמא תוספות זהירות ופרישות ולא יוסיף עצב עמה.
translation: And based on this, I explained in the verse, "When you go out to battle against your enemies, and the Lord your God delivers them into your hand," that perhaps you might be concerned about preventing the spoiling of the spoils and the taking of plunder, so that the wealth that comes from the hands of the wicked does not engender in you a negative trait. Therefore, it says, "and the Lord your God delivers them into your hand" specifically, to emphasize that it is a gift from God. Thus, "and you shall take their captives," and you need not fear that it will cause you a spiritual decline. On the contrary, since the Holy One, Blessed be He, is the giver, He will activate the power of the action within it to draw upon you good traits and to bring you to the fulfillment of commandments and good deeds, as is known that the ultimate purpose of their coming to the Land of Israel was to fulfill the commandments that are dependent on the land, and the law of causation requires additional caution and separation, and it will not add sorrow with it.
summary: The passage discusses the divine assurance given to the Israelites when they go to war, emphasizing that victory is a gift from God. It reassures that one should not fear the potential negative influence of wealth gained from enemies, as it is ultimately a divine provision that can lead to the cultivation of positive traits and the fulfillment of commandments. The text highlights the purpose of entering the Land of Israel, which is to observe the commandments tied to the land, and encourages a mindset of caution and spiritual elevation rather than despair.

passage_content: וזה אומרו ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם וגו' וידעתם כי אני ה' אלקיכם המוציא אתכם מארץ מצרים והבאתי אתכם אל הארץ וגו' שתדעו ותשכילו שלא בכח השתדלותיכם זכיתם לירושת הארץ, והראי' ע"ז ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה אני ה' היינו שביאתכם לארץ יוריש אתכם מדות טובות וידיעת ה' אשר מזה תשכילו ותבחינו כי מתת השי"ת הוא, וזה כוונת חכז"ל עבידנא לכו מילתא כי היכי דידעותו דאנא הוא דאפיקת יתכון ממצרים, והכוונה גם על נתינת א"י להם, כי כאשר יראו שזאת לא גרם להם להרע מעשיהם, ואדרבה יהי' סיבה להיטיב מעשיהם, מזה יוכלו לשפוט בצדק כי לא ע"י השתדלותם ירשו את הארץ, דאז הי' כח הפועל שבו מוליד בהם מדות רעות ומגונות, רק מתת השי"ת הוא וע"י יוסיף קדושה על קדושתכם.
translation: And this is what it means: "And I took you to be My people..." and you shall know that I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt and brought you to the land... so that you should know and understand that it is not through the strength of your efforts that you have merited the inheritance of the land. The proof of this is, "And I gave it to you as a heritage, I am the Lord," meaning that your coming to the land will bestow upon you good traits and the knowledge of the Lord, from which you will understand and discern that it is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He. This is the intent of our sages, who say, "We do this so that you may know that I am the One who took you out of Egypt," and the intention also pertains to the giving of the Land of Israel to them, for when they see that this does not cause them to worsen their deeds, but rather will be a reason to improve their actions, from this they will be able to judge justly that it is not through their efforts that they inherited the land. For then the power of the doer within them would produce bad and disgraceful traits, but rather it is a gift from the Holy One, Blessed be He, and through this He will add holiness to your holiness.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the Israelites' inheritance of the land is not a result of their own efforts but rather a divine gift from God. It highlights the importance of recognizing that their entry into the land should lead to the development of good character traits and a deeper knowledge of God. This understanding serves to reinforce the idea that their actions should improve rather than diminish their spiritual standing, illustrating that true merit comes from God's grace rather than human endeavor. Ultimately, it conveys a profound theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and human responsibility.

passage_content: עוד ירמוז הכתוב כי ע"י ביאתם לא"י ניתוסף להם הרבה מצות התלויים בארץ ולא הי' בידם לקיימם עד הנה, וזהו ונתתי אותה לכם מורשה, כי נתינת א"י יהי' מוריש לכם הרבה מצות ומעשים טובים, ולכך חזר ואמר אני ה' פי' נאמן לשלם שכר טוב למתהלכים לפני ע"ד שפירש"י לעיל בריש הפרשה, ועל כי הובטחו שיתוסף להם מצות בביאת הארץ, לכן הובטחו עוה"פ גם על תוס ' שכר והבן.
translation: The text hints that through their coming to the Land of Israel, many commandments dependent on the land were added to them, which they had not been able to fulfill until now. This is what is meant by "and I gave it to you as an inheritance," for the giving of the Land of Israel will be an inheritance for you of many commandments and good deeds. Therefore, it is repeated, "I am the Lord," meaning that He is faithful to reward good to those who walk before Him, as Rashi explained earlier at the beginning of the section. And because they were promised that commandments would be added to them upon entering the land, they were also promised in the World to Come for the additional reward. Understand this.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the entry into the Land of Israel brings with it an increase in commandments that are tied to the land, which the Israelites were previously unable to fulfill. This is reflected in the phrase "I have given it to you as an inheritance," indicating that the gift of the land also includes the opportunity to engage in many good deeds and commandments. Furthermore, it reassures that God is faithful to reward those who walk in His ways, highlighting the connection between the fulfillment of commandments in the land and the promise of reward in the afterlife. Thus, the text underscores the significance of the land in Jewish spiritual life and the divine assurance of both earthly and eternal rewards.

passage_content: פתיחה משה לפני ה' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה וגו' פירש"י זה א' מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה ( ב"ר ), הקשו המפורשים דק"ו פריכא הוא, דמה שבנ"י לא שמעו אליו מפורש הטעם בפסוק מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך לפרעה.
translation: Opening: Moses said before the Lord, "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" Rashi explains that this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah (B'reishit Rabbah). The commentators question this, for the a fortiori argument seems flawed, since the reason the children of Israel did not listen to him is explicitly stated in the verse: "because of shortness of spirit and hard work," and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on Moses' complaint to God regarding the Israelites' lack of faith and responsiveness, questioning how Pharaoh would listen to him if the Israelites did not. The text references a principle of logical reasoning (kal vachomer) from the Torah, highlighting the difficulty of the situation. It notes that while the Israelites' reluctance is attributed to their suffering and oppression, this rationale does not apply to Pharaoh, suggesting a deeper exploration of faith and divine communication amidst hardship. This underscores the Hasidic theme of the struggle between spiritual aspiration and earthly challenges.

The text highlights the tension between the Israelites' lack of faith and the expectation that Pharaoh will listen. This reflects a deeper Hasidic theme of divine communication and the struggle of faith, emphasizing that even in the face of doubt, God's will can manifest through human agency. Ultimately, it suggests that the act of conveying God's message is itself a form of spiritual response and engagement with the divine.

passage_content: והנ"ל דהנה מנהג ישראל כשאומרים דברי מוסר ותוכחה לעם, מפרשים איזה פסוק בתוה"ק ומלבישים בזה דברי מוסר הראויים לאומרם לפי מקומן ושעתן, וק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה כתב בפ ' דברים רמז נאה ע"ז, אלה הדברים אשר דבר משה וגו' הואיל משה באר את התורה הזאת עיי"ש, ולכאורה טעמא בעי מה צורך להלבישן בביאור המקראות, ולא סגי שיאמר המוכיח תוכחותיו בפירוש, ואפ"ל עפימ"ש הה"ק בעל נועם אלימלך זלה"ה בתפלה אשר תיקן, שנראה כ"א מעלת חברינו ולא חסרונם, והמידה הזאת מצוי באיש אשר השלים א"ע ביר"ש ומדות טובות, וכמו שפירשו מאמר חז"ל כל הנגעים אדם רואה חוץ מנגעי עצמו, דמה שרואה האדם נגעי חוץ באחרים זולתו, הסיבה הוא מנגעי עצמו שלא נשלם עדיין במידה זו, כי אם הוא בתכלית השלימות, אינו רואה חסרונות אחרים, והנה ידוע מאמר חז"ל דברים היוצאים מן הלב נכנסים ללב, דייקו לומר יוצאים מן הלב בה' הידוע, הכוונה על לב מלא חכמה ויר"ש, כי רק דברי מוסר היוצאים מלב כזה, יש להם כח לעורר לב השומע, ולעומת זה צריך ג"כ שהמקבל יהי' לו לב טהור וכלי מוכשר לקבל הדיבורים.
translation: And the above-mentioned, behold, the custom of Israel when they say words of moral instruction and rebuke to the people, is to interpret some verse from the Holy Torah and to clothe in it words of moral instruction that are fitting to be said according to their place and time. And this is well expressed by the holy Rabbi Zal in Parashat Devarim, a beautiful hint to this, "These are the words which Moses spoke..." since Moses explained this Torah, as is written there. And at first glance, one might ask what is the need to clothe them in the explanation of the verses, and it would suffice for the rebuker to state his rebukes explicitly. And it can be said, as the holy one, the Baal Nefesh Hachaim, Zal, mentioned in the prayer he established, that it appears as if each one is highlighting the virtues of our friends and not their shortcomings. And this quality is found in a person who has completed himself in the fear of Heaven and good traits, for as our Sages explained, "A person sees the blemishes of others except for his own," for the reason a person sees external blemishes in others besides himself is due to his own blemishes that he has not yet rectified in this trait. For if he is in a state of complete perfection, he does not see the shortcomings of others. And behold, it is known from our Sages' saying, "Words that come from the heart enter the heart," they were precise to say "come from the heart" with the known letter, meaning from a heart full of wisdom and fear of Heaven, for only words of moral instruction that come from such a heart have the power to awaken the heart of the listener. Conversely, it is also necessary that the recipient has a pure heart and a fitting vessel to receive the words.
summary: The passage discusses the Jewish custom of delivering moral teachings by interpreting verses from the Torah, emphasizing the importance of aligning these teachings with the appropriate context. It highlights that a true moral message must come from a heart filled with wisdom and reverence, as only such words can effectively penetrate the listener's heart. Additionally, it notes that a person who has achieved personal completeness and humility will not see the faults in others, suggesting that self-awareness and spiritual growth are essential for both the speaker and the audience in the process of moral instruction.

passage_content: ועד"ז יבואר לענינינו שכאשר דיבר משרע"ה אל בנ"י במצרים דברי מוסר ותוכחה להפרישם מע"ז ולעוררם אל התשובה, לא נכנסו דבריו בלבם כמ"ש הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה, והטעם מבואר בכתוב מקוצר רוח וגו', כמו שפי' בספה"ק שכח הטומאה החזקה אשר במצרים התגבר עליהם, עד שלא נכנס בלבם דיבורי קודש של משרע"ה אף שהי' בתכלית השלימות, אמנם משרע"ה בראותו שאין דבריו מתקבלים, תלה החסרון בעצמו כדרך הצדיקים, וחשב שהסיבה מפני שאין הדברים יוצאים מן "הלב" השלם בחכמה ויראה, אמנם הי' קשה לו על הנחה זו, הלא בנ"י מורה על מדריגה גדולה, ואיך ראו חסרונותיו אשר מסיבה זו לא שמעו אליו, וע"כ החליט שמצבו כ"כ בשפלות ח"ו שא"א בשום אופן לקבל ממנו, וא"כ איך ישמעני פרעה שהוא רשע בתכלית וה"ה רואה חסרונות אחרים ובוודאי לא ישמע לדברי, וא"ש דיפה כח הק"ו .
translation: And similarly, it will be explained regarding our matter that when Moshe Rabbeinu spoke to the Children of Israel in Egypt words of moral instruction and rebuke to separate them from idolatry and to awaken them to repentance, his words did not enter their hearts, as the verse states, "and they did not listen to Moshe," and the reason is explained in the verse as "because of shortness of spirit," etc. As it is explained in the holy books, the strong impurity that prevailed in Egypt overpowered them, so that the holy words of Moshe Rabbeinu did not enter their hearts, even though he was in the utmost perfection. However, when Moshe Rabbeinu saw that his words were not being accepted, he attributed the shortcoming to himself, as is the way of the righteous, and thought that the reason was that the words did not come from a "heart" complete in wisdom and fear. However, it was difficult for him to accept this assumption, for the Children of Israel represent a great level, and how could they see his shortcomings, which were the reason they did not listen to him? Therefore, he concluded that his state was so lowly, Heaven forbid, that it was impossible for them to accept anything from him. And if so, how would Pharaoh, who is wicked to the utmost, listen to me, as he also sees other shortcomings and will certainly not listen to my words? And thus, the strength of the a fortiori argument is clear.
summary: The passage discusses how Moses' words of rebuke and encouragement to the Israelites in Egypt were not received due to their spiritual state, as indicated by the biblical phrase "they did not listen to Moses." This lack of receptiveness is attributed to the overwhelming impurity of Egypt, which dulled their hearts. Despite Moses' righteousness, he internalized the failure to connect with the people as a personal shortcoming, reflecting the humility of the righteous who often attribute failures to themselves. Ultimately, this leads him to question how he could expect Pharaoh, a wicked ruler, to heed his words when the Israelites themselves were unable to do so.

passage_content: וע"ז בא תשובתו ית ' אל משרע"ה בפסוק וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה מלך מצרים וגו', שיאמר להם הציווי בלשון הנאמרה אליו מפי הגבורה, ולא שייך בזה האי כללא דדברים היוצאים מן הלב דייקא נכנסים אל הלב, דאין אלו דברי המוכיח כ"א דברי ה', ולהפיס דעתו נתן לו הקב"ה עצה הוגנת לפי מדת שפלותו שהחזיק א"ע כאינו ראוי להוכיח, ואפשר שזהו טעם המנהג להלביש דברי תוכחה בביאור הפסוקים כי מי יאמר זכיתי לבי שיהיו הדברים ראויים להתקבל על הלב, והם יוצאים מלב טהור, אמנם כשמלבישים אותם בפסוקי התורה, אין אלו דברי המוכיח כ"א ד"ת (וע"ד שמצינו בה' כיבוד אב, שאין לומר תוכחה לאביו מצד חיוב כיבוד אב, אבל יאמר לו אבא כתוב בתורה כך וכך עיי"ש) ועד"ז ראויים שיכנסו בלב השומעים אף אם לא הגיע מדריגת המוכיח לשלימות הראוי'.
translation: And in this, the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to Moshe in the verse "And the Lord spoke to Moshe and to Aharon and commanded them to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh king of Egypt, etc." to say to them the command in the language that was said to him from the mouth of the Almighty, and the general principle that "words that come from the heart enter the heart" does not apply here, for these are not the words of the reprover but rather the words of the Holy One, blessed be He. To calm his mind, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him a fitting counsel according to the measure of his humility, as he considered himself unworthy to reprove. And perhaps this is the reason for the custom to dress words of reproof in the explanation of the verses, for who can say that he is worthy that the words should be accepted in the heart, and they come from a pure heart? However, when they are dressed in the verses of the Torah, these are not the words of the reprover but rather words of Torah (and in the same way that we find in the commandment of honoring one's father, one should not reprove his father due to the obligation of honoring him, but rather he should say to him, "Father, it is written in the Torah such and such," see there). Similarly, they are worthy to enter the hearts of the listeners even if the level of the reprover has not reached the required perfection.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses God's instruction to Moses and Aaron to convey His commandments to the Israelites and Pharaoh, emphasizing that these are divine words rather than mere human admonitions. The text highlights the importance of delivering messages of rebuke in a manner that aligns with the holiness of the Torah, suggesting that when teachings are framed within scriptural verses, they are more likely to resonate with the hearts of the listeners. This approach reflects a deep understanding of humility and the recognition that true rebuke must stem from a pure heart, yet can be effectively communicated through the authority of the Torah.

passage_content: וידבר משה לפני ה' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, פירש"י זה אחד מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה, הקשו המפורשים דק"ו פריכא הוא, דמה שלא שמעו אליו בנ"י מבואר בפסוק טעמו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך בפרעה א"כ אין כאן ק"ו.
translation: And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying: "Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips." Rashi explains that this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah. The commentators question this, for the a fortiori argument seems flawed, since the reason the children of Israel did not listen to him is explained in the verse as being due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh; therefore, there is no a fortiori argument here.
summary: Moses expresses his doubts about being heard by Pharaoh, citing the Israelites' lack of response to him due to their suffering. Rashi notes that this is an example of a kal vachomer (a fortiori argument) in the Torah, but some commentators question its validity since the Israelites' inability to listen is attributed to their harsh conditions, which does not apply to Pharaoh. This highlights the Hasidic concept of the struggle between divine mission and human limitations, emphasizing the challenges faced in spiritual leadership and communication. Ultimately, it reflects the tension between faith in divine support and the reality of human suffering.

passage_content: ב) קשה איך מקושר סיפא דקרא ואני ערל שפתים לק"ו זה שלא ישמע אליו פרעה, גם הרי כבר השיב לו הקב"ה על טענה זו מי שם פה לאדם וגו' הלא אנכי ה', וצירף אליו את אהרן שיהי' לו לפה ולמליץ, ומה זה שטען עוה"פ ואני ערל שפתים.
translation: B) It is difficult how the end of the verse is connected, "and I am of uncircumcised lips," to this a fortiori argument that Pharaoh would not listen to him. Moreover, the Holy One, Blessed be He, has already responded to this claim, "Who made man's mouth... is it not I, the Lord?" and He appointed Aaron to be his mouth and spokesperson. And what is this that he claimed in this world, "and I am of uncircumcised lips."
summary: The passage discusses Moses' reluctance to speak to Pharaoh due to his perceived speech impediment, highlighting the tension between human limitations and divine empowerment. It emphasizes that God, who created the mouth, equips individuals for their missions, as seen in God's response to Moses and the appointment of Aaron as his spokesperson. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of trusting in divine assistance despite personal shortcomings, illustrating the belief that spiritual leaders are supported by God to fulfill their roles. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that divine purpose transcends human frailty.

passage_content: ג) יל"ד בפירש"י שמפרש מקודם סיפא דקרא ואני ערל שפתים שפירושו אטום שפתים והביא ראיות לדבר, ואח"כ מפרש תחלת המקרא ואיך ישמעני פרעה זה אחד מעשרה ק"ו שבתורה, וצ"ב מדוע שינה רש"י ז"ל את הסדר דהי ' לו לפרש מקודם תחלת הקרא כדרכו בכ"מ .
translation: 3) It is written in Rashi's commentary that he explains first the end of the verse, "and I am of uncircumcised lips," which means sealed lips, and he brings proofs for this. Afterwards, he explains the beginning of the verse and how Pharaoh will hear me; this is one of the ten a fortiori arguments in the Torah. It is puzzling why Rashi changed the order, as he should have explained the beginning of the verse first, as is his custom everywhere.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses Rashi's interpretation of the verse "I am of uncircumcised lips," explaining that it signifies a state of being mute or unable to speak. The text highlights the importance of understanding the sequence in which Rashi presents his commentary, noting that he first addresses the latter part of the verse before the beginning, which raises questions about his usual method of interpretation. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of communication with the Divine and the challenges faced by individuals in expressing their spiritual truths.

passage_content: ד) הקשו המפורשים על אומרו לאמר כי למי יאמר ה' דברי משה, ובמדרש ילקוט (רמז קע"ז) הקשו כן וז"ל וידבר משה לפני ה' לאמר הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי, ר"א בן עזרי' אומר בארבע מקומות בקש משה לפני המקום והשיבו על שאלותיו שנאמר וידבר משה לפני ה' לאמר שאין ת"ל לאמר , אלא שאמר לו השיבני אם גואלן אתה אם לאו, עד שהשיבו המקום ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב ענין שאלה זו, וכבר אמר לו הקב"ה הרבה פעמים שיגאל את ישראל, ומדוע חזר ושאל אם גואלן אתה אם לאו, גם צ"ב מה שאמרו במדרש שהקב"ה השיב לו על שאלתו עתה תראה, ותשובה זו כבר נאמרה אליו בשליחות ראשונה, כשאמר למה הרעותה אז השיב לו הקב"ה עתה תראה וגו', ואין לתרץ דאין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה, ופסוק עתה תראה צריך להיות כתוב כאן, דהרי בחד ענינא לא אמרינן אין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה וזה הכל ענין אחד הוא, וא"כ דברי המדרש צ"ב.
translation:
D) The commentators questioned the phrase "to say" regarding to whom the Lord spoke the words of Moses. In the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 917), they posed a similar question, and it states: "And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying, 'Behold, the children of Israel have not listened to me.' Rabbi Eliezer ben Azariah says that in four places Moses sought before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He answered his questions, as it is said, 'And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying,' which does not need to say 'saying,' but rather that He said to him, 'Answer me whether You will redeem them or not,' until the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him, 'And the Lord said to Moses, "Now you will see."' Thus far the Midrash. 

And the question arises regarding this inquiry, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already told him many times that He would redeem Israel. Why then did he return to ask, 'Will You redeem them or not?' It is also puzzling what the Midrash means when it says that the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him to his question, 'Now you will see,' for this answer had already been given to him in the first mission when he said, 'Why have You harmed this people?' Then the Holy One, Blessed be He, answered him, 'Now you will see,' etc. One cannot explain that there is no earlier or later in the Torah, and the verse 'Now you will see' should be written here, for in one matter we do not say there is no earlier or later in the Torah, and this is all one matter. Therefore, the words of the Midrash are puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses a question raised by the commentators regarding Moses' inquiry to God about the redemption of the Israelites, despite previous assurances of their salvation. It highlights the tension between Moses' doubts and God's prior promises, emphasizing the complexity of divine communication. The midrashic interpretation suggests that God's response, "Now you will see," indicates a deeper understanding of the unfolding redemption process, reflecting the dynamic relationship between divine promise and human questioning. This illustrates key Hasidic themes of faith, trust in divine timing, and the necessity of grappling with uncertainty in spiritual life.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר (פ' ו' סי' ה') עה"פ וידבר משה כן אל בני ישראל ולא שמעו אל משה וגו' שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מעבודת כוכבים וכו ', והנה מרע"ה תלה החסרון בעצמו שאין דבריו יוצאים מאמיתיות הלב, דאל"כ היו ראויים דבריו להתקבל דדברים היוצאים מן הלב נכנסים אל הלב ואמרי' בגמ' (ברכות ו' ע"ב) וא"ר חלבו אמר רב הונא כל אדם שיש בו יראת שמים דבריו נשמעין שנאמר סוף דבר הכל נשמע את האלקים ירא וגו' עכ"ד הגמ ', וע"כ כשראה משרע"ה שלא שמעו אליו בנ"י ולא פעל אצלם לפרוש מע"ז, חשב בענותנותו שהחסרון ממנו, וזה שנשא מרע"ה ק"ו ואמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי, שלא הי' בכח דיבורי להפריש אותם מע"ז ולהכניס בהם כח הקדושה, ק"ו שפרעה לא ישמע אלי שהוא משוקע בטומאתו יותר.
translation: And it can be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Va'era, Section 5) on the verse "And Moses spoke thus to the children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses..." that it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idol worship, etc. Behold, Moshe Rabbeinu attributed the shortcoming to himself, that his words did not come from the truth of the heart, for otherwise his words would have been worthy of acceptance, as it is said that words that come from the heart enter the heart. And we say in the Gemara (Berakhot 6b) that Rabbi Chaviva said in the name of Rav Huna: "Any person who has the fear of Heaven, his words are heard," as it is stated, "The end of the matter, all has been heard: Fear God..." Thus said the Gemara. Therefore, when Moshe Rabbeinu saw that the children of Israel did not listen to him and that he did not succeed in causing them to separate from idol worship, he thought in his humility that the shortcoming was from him. This is what Moshe Rabbeinu reasoned and said: "If the children of Israel did not listen to me, how much more so will Pharaoh not listen to me, for he is deeply entrenched in his impurity."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on Moses' humility and self-criticism when the Israelites did not heed his words, attributing their lack of response to a deficiency in his own sincerity and heartfelt communication. He emphasizes the Hasidic belief that true words, emanating from the heart, resonate with others and that a person's fear of God enhances the effectiveness of their speech. Moses concludes that if the Israelites, who are closer to holiness, do not listen to him, it is even less likely that Pharaoh, steeped in impurity, would heed his call. This highlights the importance of genuine spiritual connection and the power of heartfelt communication in influencing others.

passage_content: ומה שמסיים ואני ערל שפתים יובן עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר פ' דברים (פ"א סי' א') אלה הדברים וכו' אמר הקב"ה ראה לשונה של תורה מה חביבה שמרפא את הלשון. מנין שכן כתיב מרפא לשון עץ חיים, ואין עץ חיים אלא תורה שנא' עץ חיים הוא למחזיקים בה וכו ', ר"ל אמר מה לנו ללמוד ממקום אחר נלמוד ממקומו. הרי משה עד שלא זכה לתורה כתיב בו לא איש דברים אנכי, כיון שזכה לתורה נתרפא לשונו והתחיל לדבר דברים, מנין ממה שקרינו בענין אלה הדברים אשר דבר משה עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הרי משרע"ה עסק בתורה מנעוריו, ואף טרם שנתנה תורה לא פסקה ישיבה מהם כאמרז"ל (יומא כ"ח ע"ב), ואיך אמר ואני ערל שפתים והי' ראוי שע"י התורה יתרפא לשונו מיד, אמנם נראה דכ"ז שלמד תורה לעצמו לא הי' צורך להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה ולא רצה הקב"ה להסירה ממנו, גם משרע"ה לא התפלל ולא חפץ ברפואתו כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל ( בפ ' שמות) לפי שהי' בו ממעשה הנס דעי"ז ניצול מחרב פרעה כאמרז"ל , אמנם כשהוצרך ללמד תורה לישראל ולהשפיע בלבבם אור האמת ודרכי עבודת השי"ת, אז הוצרך להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה כדי שיהיו דבריו נשמעים, וע"כ למדו חז"ל שנתרפא לשונו מאלה הדברים אשר דיבר משה אל כל ישראל, דזה הי' סיבה להסיר ממנו כבדות הפה.
translation:
And what concludes with "and I am of uncircumcised lips" should be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash on Parashat Devarim (1:1) "These are the words..." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "Look at the language of the Torah, how beloved it is, for it heals the tongue." From where do we know this? It is written, "The tongue of the wise is a tree of life," and there is no tree of life except the Torah, as it is said, "It is a tree of life to those who hold fast to it," etc. In other words, He said, "What do we need to learn from another place? Let us learn from its own place." Behold, Moses, before he merited the Torah, it is written of him, "I am not a man of words." Once he merited the Torah, his tongue was healed, and he began to speak words, as we read in the context of "These are the words which Moses spoke." Thus concludes the Midrash. 

At first glance, it seems that since Moshe engaged in Torah from his youth, and even before the Torah was given, he did not cease from his study, as our sages have said (Yoma 28b), how could he say, "And I am of uncircumcised lips," and it would have been fitting that through the Torah his tongue would be healed immediately? However, it appears that all the Torah he learned for himself did not require the removal of the heaviness of his mouth, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not want to remove it from him. Also, Moshe did not pray for nor desire his healing, as Nachmanides, of blessed memory, writes (in Parashat Shemot), because he was part of the miracle, and through this he was saved from Pharaoh's sword, as our sages have said. However, when he needed to teach Torah to Israel and to impart to their hearts the light of truth and the ways of serving the Holy One, Blessed be He, then he needed to have the heaviness of his mouth removed so that his words would be heard. Therefore, our sages learned that his tongue was healed from "These are the words which Moses spoke to all Israel," for this was the reason to remove the heaviness of his mouth.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Moses' speech from being "heavy" to articulate after he received the Torah, emphasizing that the Torah serves as a healing force for the tongue. It highlights that Moses, despite his lifelong study of Torah, did not experience this healing until he was tasked with teaching it to the Israelites, indicating that the purpose of Torah is not only personal but also communal. The text illustrates the idea that true engagement with Torah requires a readiness to share its wisdom with others, which in turn facilitates spiritual and communicative clarity. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of Torah as a source of life and healing for both the individual and the community.

passage_content: והנה מרע"ה תלה החסרון בעצמו שהוא אינו ראוי שיהי' דבריו נשמעים לבני ישראל, והביא ראי' לזה ממה שלא הוסר ממנו כבדות הפה ולא נתרפא לשונו עדיין, ואלמלי הי' ראוי להשפיע על בנ"י בדיבורו הי' ראוי שיתרפא לשונו מיד, אמנם הקב"ה השיב לו ויצום אל בנ"י וגו' להוציא את בני ישראל ממצרים, לא כמו שאתה סובר שאין דיבורך מועילים אצלם כלום, שאין הדבר יכול להעשות בפעם אחת, אבל מעט מעט יתקרבו אל הקדושה, ולבסוף עשו ישראל תשובה שלימה ויצאו ממצרים וזכו לקבלת התורה הקדושה, נמצא לפי"ז אומרו ואני ערל שפתים הוא טעם על תחלת טענתו שאמר הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי, ועכ"ח שאיני ראוי לכך והראי' שעדיין אני ערל שפתים וק"ו שלא ישמע אלי פרעה, ולזה פירש"י תחלה סיפא דקרא ואני ערל שפתים, להורות שמאמר זה מקושר לתחלת הפ ' הן בני ישראל לא שמעו אלי, אלא שהפסוק מסיים את הק"ו ואח"כ מביא את הראי', וז"פ הפסוק וידבר משה לפני ה' " לאמר " פירוש שהתפלל להקב"ה על כח האמירה שיוכל לדבר דברים נכונים שיתקבלו בלבבות בנ"י , לא כמו שהי' עד עכשיו שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ולזה חזר משה לשאול מהקב"ה אם אתה גואלן אם לאו, מפני שראה שלא פעל בדיבוריו אצל ישראל להפרישם מן הע"ז , ע"כ אף שכבר הובטח על הגאולה עדיין חשש מרע"ה פן לא יזכו ח"ו להגאל גאולת עולם ושמא סופם לחזור למצרים.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu attributed the shortcoming to himself, that he is not worthy for his words to be heard by the Children of Israel. He brought proof for this from the fact that the heaviness of the mouth was not removed from him and his tongue was not yet healed. Had he been worthy to influence the Children of Israel with his speech, his tongue would have been healed immediately. However, the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded to him and commanded him to speak to the Children of Israel, etc., to take the Children of Israel out of Egypt, not as you think that your words are of no benefit to them, for this matter cannot be accomplished all at once, but little by little they will draw closer to holiness. In the end, the Israelites repented completely and went out of Egypt, meriting the reception of the Holy Torah. Thus, according to this, his statement "and I am of uncircumcised lips" is a reason for the beginning of his claim that he said, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to me," and therefore I am not worthy of this, and the proof is that I am still of uncircumcised lips, and certainly Pharaoh will not listen to me. For this reason, Rashi explained the beginning of the verse "and I am of uncircumcised lips," to indicate that this statement is connected to the beginning of the verse "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to me," but the verse concludes the inference and then brings the proof. Thus, the end of the verse "and Moshe spoke before the Lord, saying" means that he prayed to the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the strength of speech so that he could speak words that would be accepted in the hearts of the Children of Israel, not as it was until now when they did not listen to Moshe due to shortness of spirit and hard work. For this reason, Moshe returned to ask the Holy One, Blessed be He, if You are redeeming us or not, because he saw that his words did not have an effect on Israel to separate them from idolatry. Therefore, even though he was already promised redemption, Moshe still feared lest they not merit, Heaven forbid, the ultimate redemption and perhaps their end would be to return to Egypt.
summary: Moses expresses a deep sense of inadequacy regarding his ability to communicate effectively with the Israelites, citing his speech impediment as evidence that he is unworthy of being heard. Despite his doubts, God reassures him that the redemption of the Israelites will occur gradually, leading to their eventual repentance and acceptance of the Torah. This highlights the Hasidic concept of gradual spiritual elevation and the importance of divine assistance in the process of redemption. Ultimately, Moses's concerns reflect a profound theological insight into the relationship between human effort and divine intervention in the journey toward holiness.
