passage_content: ובזה יובן דברי המדרש ילקוט שאמר משרע"ה לפני הקב"ה השיבני אם אתה גואלן אם לאו, עד שהשיבו המקום ויאמר ה' אל משה עתה תראה, ואין הכוונה שהקב"ה אמר לו תשובה זו עכשיו, שכבר נאמרה לו על טענת למה הרעותה , אלא שנתן הבוי"ת בדעתו שיתבונן עוה"פ עתה תראה וגו', ובו ימצא תשובה גם על שאלתו של עכשיו, שנאמר עתה תראה כי ביד חזקה "ישלחם", ועפי"מ שדרשו חכז"ל (יבמות קי"ג ע"ב) ושלחה מביתו מי שמשלחה ואינה חוזרת יצתה זו שמשלחה וחוזרת, וע"כ כיון שהי' הבטחת הבוי"ת בלשון ישלחם, מרומז בה שלא יהיו בבחי ' משלחים וחוזרים, ואז השיג מרע"ה הנרמז בהבטחתו ית ' והרגיעה דעתו.
translation: And with this, the words of the Midrash Yalkut will be understood, that Moshe Rabbeinu said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Answer me whether You are redeeming them or not," until the Holy One, Blessed be He, responded and said, "Now you will see." And the intention is not that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said this answer to him now, for it had already been said to him regarding the claim of "Why have You done evil," but rather that the Blessed One placed in his mind to contemplate, "Now you will see," and in this he would find an answer also to his current question, as it is said, "Now you will see that with a strong hand He will send them." And according to that which our Sages of Blessed Memory have interpreted (Yevamot 113b), "And he shall send her from his house," meaning one who sends her and she does not return, this refers to one who sends her and she returns. Therefore, since there was a promise from the Blessed One in the language of "He will send them," it is hinted therein that they will not be in the category of "sending and returning," and thus Moshe Rabbeinu grasped the hint in His promise, Blessed be He, and his mind was calmed.
summary: The passage discusses a dialogue between Moses and God, where Moses questions whether God will redeem the Israelites. God's response, "Now you will see," is interpreted not as a new answer but as an invitation for Moses to reflect on the assurance of redemption already given. The text emphasizes that God's promise implies a definitive and irreversible redemption, suggesting that those who are sent away will not return, thus providing Moses with reassurance and clarity regarding his concerns. This reflects key Hasidic themes of faith in divine promises and the importance of understanding God's intentions in the face of uncertainty.

passage_content: וידבר משה כן אל בני ישראל ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, במדרש (ילקוט רמז קע"ח) וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה ואינו שמח, א"כ מה ת"ל ולא שמעו אל משה, אלא שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז עכ"ד המדרש, ויל"ד דעדיין לא נתיישב נתינת טעם שאמה"כ מקוצר רוח. דלטעם זה הי' ראוי שישמחו על בשורת הגאולה.
translation: And Moses spoke thus to the children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. In the Midrash (Yalkut Remaz 218), it is said: Is there a person who receives good news and is not happy? Therefore, what does it mean, "but they did not listen to Moses"? Rather, it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry, thus concludes the Midrash. And it seems that the reason for their lack of response is still not settled, as it is said, "because of shortness of spirit." For this reason, they should have rejoiced at the tidings of redemption.
summary: Moses spoke to the Israelites, but they did not listen to him due to their shortness of spirit and hard labor. The Midrash suggests that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, indicating a deep attachment to their former ways. This raises a theological question about why they did not rejoice at the news of redemption, as one would expect such a message to bring joy. The passage highlights the struggle between spiritual aspiration and the burdens of physical existence, emphasizing the challenge of faith amidst suffering.

summary: The passage discusses the differing opinions regarding the source of the "Eruv," a concept in Jewish law that allows for the carrying of objects in public spaces on Shabbat. Some say it comes from above, while others argue it originates from below, highlighting a fundamental debate in Hasidic thought about divine influence and human agency. This disagreement reflects deeper theological insights into the nature of God's interaction with the world and the role of human actions in spiritual matters. Ultimately, it emphasizes the complexity of understanding divine providence and the interplay between the heavenly and earthly realms.

passage_content: ונראה לבאר בדרך רמז מוסר, ידוע מספה"ק דימי השובבי"ם המה מסוגלים לתקון חטא הידוע, על שם שבהם קוראים בתורה פרשיות גלות מצרים וזה הי' עבודתם של בני ישראל במצרים להעלות ניצה"ק ולתקן חטא זה ובזה הי' תליא גאולתם, וע"כ הקריאה מעורר הזמן, ואף כי בכל יומא ויומא זמני', אבל הימים האלה מסוגלים יותר וקרוב ד' לכל קוראיו לכל אשר יקראוהו באמת, והנה כתב בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' נח) על מה שאמחז"ל דבקושי גדול מועיל תשובה על חטא הנורא הזה, וטעם הדבר מבואר בספרים דבהחטא פוגם האדם במדותיו , ובמדה שחוטא מסיר עצמו משרשי הקדושה וכו' ומקלקל צנור המשכתו מלמעלה מלקבל קדושה וברכה באותו אבר שפגם וכו' ולכן בעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משורשו אל האבר והצנור שנחלש וכו ', אך בחטא חמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שרשו לגמרי כמבואר בספה"ק , ולכן כמעט אין לו רפואה, ובמקו"א כתב דלפי שחטא זה הוא בכח כל האיברים, וכל האיברים נעשו פגומים ר"ל, ע"כ קשה התשובה בזה, והעצה היעוצה לעבוד השי"ת במסנ"פ אמיתית, וזהו תקנה לכולם עכת"ד ז"ל, עוד אפשר להמציא תקנה לזה שיאנח האדם אנחה תקיפא על עונותיו ועל חורבן ביהמ"ק וגלות השכינה, ואמרז"ל (כתובות ס"ב ע"א) אנחה שוברת כל גופו של אדם, ואף למ"ד דס"ל חצי גופו לבדו מודה באנחה תקיפא דשוברת כל גופו עיי"ש בגמ ', ועד"ז יהי' התקון בכח כל הגוף וכל האיברים.
translation: And it seems appropriate to explain in a hint of moral teaching, it is known from the holy books that the days of the Shovavim are capable of rectifying the known sin, because in them we read in the Torah the portions of the exile in Egypt, and this was the work of the Children of Israel in Egypt to elevate the holy sparks and rectify this sin, and in this their redemption was dependent. Therefore, the reading awakens the time, and although every day has its times, these days are more capable and close to the Holy One, blessed be He, for all who read them sincerely. And behold, it is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parashat Noach) regarding what our Sages said that with great difficulty repentance is effective for this terrible sin, and the reason for this is explained in the books that in this sin a person damages his character traits, and in the trait that he sins, he removes himself from the roots of holiness, etc., and he disrupts the channel of his connection from above to receive holiness and blessing in that limb which he has damaged, etc. Therefore, by doing repentance, he brings new life from his root to the limb and the channel that has weakened, etc. However, in the aforementioned grave sin, it is as if he completely removes his root, as is explained in the holy books, and therefore he has almost no remedy. And in another place it is written that since this sin involves all the limbs, and all the limbs have become blemished, therefore repentance is difficult in this regard. The advised counsel is to serve the Holy One, blessed be He, with true sincerity, and this is a remedy for all, as stated by him. Furthermore, it is possible to find a remedy for this by sighing strongly over his sins and over the destruction of the Holy Temple and the exile of the Shechinah. And our Sages said (Ketubot 62a) that a sigh breaks the entire body of a person, and even according to the opinion that holds that half of his body alone acknowledges that a strong sigh breaks his entire body, as is stated in the Gemara. And similarly, the rectification will be with the strength of the whole body and all the limbs.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the "Shovavim" period, which is associated with rectifying specific sins linked to the exile of the Jewish people in Egypt. It emphasizes that through sincere Torah reading during this time, individuals can elevate their spiritual sparks and facilitate their redemption. The text highlights the profound impact of sin on a person's character and spiritual connection, suggesting that true repentance can restore one's divine flow, while severe sins may sever this connection entirely. It also proposes that heartfelt sighs and expressions of sorrow for one's sins and the destruction of the Temple can serve as a powerful means of atonement, capable of healing the entire being.

passage_content: והנה בני ישראל במצרים אף שהיו שמורים ונקיים מעריות כמו שהעיד עליהם הכתוב, ואמרז"ל (ויקרא רבה פ' ל"ב סי' ה') אחת היתה ופירסמה הכתוב. מכל מקום להיותם בארץ טמאה ערות הארץ, ומשועבדים למזוהמים ומושחתים אומה של מצרים, לא נמלטו מקצתם מהרהור עבירה וחטא הנורא הידוע ר"ל והיו צריכין בהכרח לתקן ולהעלות ניצה"ק שנתפזרו בסיבת החטאים, ולא היו יכולין להיגאל בלא"ה , וע"י קושי השעבוד שעבדו בעבודה קשה המפרכת את כל הגוף ומשברתו , נתקן פגם החטא בתשובת המשקל נגד פגם העבירה שהוא בכח כל הגוף. גם ע"ו אנחה כמשה"כ ויאנחו בנ"י וגו' ותעל שועתם אל האלקים שנאנחו בשביל גלות השכינה, עי"ז תיקנו פגם החטא מידה כנגד מידה.
translation: And behold, the children of Israel in Egypt, even though they were guarded and clean from immorality, as the scripture testified about them, and as our sages of blessed memory said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 5), "There was one [who was guilty], and the scripture made it known." Nevertheless, due to their being in a defiled land, the nakedness of the land, and being enslaved to the polluted and corrupt nation of Egypt, they could not escape some degree of sinful thoughts and the known terrible sin, may it be erased. They were necessarily in need of rectification and to elevate the holy sparks that were scattered because of the sins, and they could not be redeemed otherwise. And through the severity of the servitude, which they toiled in hard labor that crushed the entire body and broke it, the flaw of the sin was rectified through a corresponding repentance against the flaw of the transgression, which is in the power of the whole body. Also, their groaning, as it is written, "And the children of Israel sighed," etc., and their cry ascended to God, for they groaned because of the exile of the Shechinah; through this, they rectified the flaw of the sin measure for measure.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual state of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that despite their purity, they were still affected by the impurity of their surroundings and the corrupt Egyptian society. This led to the need for rectification of their scattered divine sparks due to sin. The harshness of their servitude served as a means of atonement, as their physical suffering corresponded to the spiritual flaws they had incurred. Their cries for help, stemming from the anguish of exile, ultimately facilitated their redemption by addressing their transgressions through a principle of measure for measure.

passage_content: ואולי ירמזו ד' לשונות של גאולה הכתובים בפרשה, על ד' בחי' מדריגות , והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים ירמוז על החלק שבישראל שלא פגמו ולא נכשלו בחטא זה כלל, עכ"ז הי' להם לטורח משא לסבול שעבודם של מצרים ושר של מצרים שהתגברו עליהם להכשילם, והבטיחם השי"ת והוצאתי אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים וכפרש"י מטורח משא מצרים, והצלתי אתכם מעבודתם ירמוז על החלק שנכשלו ופגמו בחטא הנורא, וזה נקרא עבודתם שהקריבו עבודה לסט"א ר"ל כמבואר בספה"ק שהמוציא זרע במקום קדושה ובמקום מצוה נקרא עבד נאמן לד', ולהיפך ח"ו ה"ה בחי' ע"ז שמקריב דורן לסט"א , ועל אלו ירמוז הבטחת והצלתי אתכם מעבודתם, שניצולו מעבודה זו ע"י שהוציאם השי"ת משם, אמנם לא סגי בזה שלא יפגמו עוד, אבל צריך לתקן ולהוציא משם בחי' הקדושה ניצה"ק שנתפזרו בסיבת החטאים, וזה נקרא גאולה כנודע, וזה ירמוז וגאלתי אתכם וגו', ואח"כ ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם, דאיתא בספה"ק שע"י פגם חטא זה נעשה מסך המבדיל בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, ועי"כ אנו מרוחקים כ"כ בעוה"ר מבחי ' הקדושה, אבל לאחר שתתקיים והוצאתי והצלתי שלא יפגמו עוד, ומה שפגמו יתוקן כנרמז בהבטחת וגאלתי כנ"ל, אז יהי' ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם וגו' שיתבטלו כל המסכים המבדילים ויקרב אותנו הבוי"ש לו לעם.
translation: And perhaps the four expressions of redemption written in the portion hint at four levels of degrees. "And I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt" hints at the part of Israel that did not blemish or fail in this sin at all. Nevertheless, they had to endure the burden of the servitude of Egypt and the minister of Egypt who overpowered them to cause them to stumble. The Holy One, blessed be He, promised them, "And I have taken you out from under the burdens of Egypt," as Rashi explains, from the burden of Egypt. "And I have saved you from their work" hints at the part that stumbled and blemished in this terrible sin, and this is called their work, which they offered as service to the Other Side, as explained in the holy books. One who emits seed in a place of holiness and in a place of commandment is called a faithful servant to the Holy One, blessed be He, and conversely, God forbid, it is the aspect of idolatry that offers their seed to the Other Side. And concerning these, the promise "And I have saved you from their work" hints that they were saved from this service by the Holy One, blessed be He, taking them out from there. However, it is not sufficient that they should not blemish further, but they need to rectify and extract from there the holy spark that was scattered due to the sins, and this is called redemption, as is known. This hints at "And I have redeemed you," and afterwards "And I will take you to Me as a people." It is stated in the holy books that through the blemish of this sin, a screen is created that separates between Israel and their Father in Heaven, and as a result, we are so distanced in this world from the aspect of holiness. But after it is fulfilled "And I have taken you out" and "And I have saved" so that they will not blemish further, and what they have blemished will be rectified as hinted in the promise "And I have redeemed," then it will be "And I will take you to Me as a people," that all the screens that separate will be nullified, and He will draw us close to Him as a people.
summary: The passage discusses the four expressions of redemption in the Torah, each representing different spiritual levels among the Jewish people. It emphasizes that while some individuals remained untainted by sin, they still suffered under Egyptian oppression, and God's promise to redeem them signifies a liberation from this burden. For those who sinned, redemption involves not only escape from servitude but also the need for spiritual rectification and the restoration of holiness. Ultimately, the culmination of this process leads to a close relationship with God, removing barriers that separate the Jewish people from their divine source.

passage_content: ועפי"ז אפ"ל בטעם שתקנו חז"ל ד' כוסות יין ע"ש ד' לשונות של גאולה, כי אמרז"ל (ברכות דף ס"ג ע"א, נזיר דף ב' ע"א) הרואה סוטה בקלקולה יזיר עצמו מן היין, כי היין עלול להביא לידי קלקול בפגם הברית, אמנם הזוכה לתקן פגמי חטאו ועובד עבודתו להוציא ניצה"ק ולהעלותם, מותר לו לשתות יין למצוה ובבחי ' קדושה, דנכנס יין יצא סוד היינו הניצה"ק הנקראים כן, כמו שרמזו ז"ל בסודם אל תבוא נפשי זה מעשה זמרי שהי' החטא בענין זה כנודע, וע"כ תקנו חז"ל ד' כוסות יין כנגד והוצאתי והצלתי וגאלתי ולקחתי להוציא בחי' הסוד ולהעלותו, וצריך ג"כ להזהר ולהשגיח על הפה והלשון שיהיו זכים וטהורים, כי ברית הלשון והמעור מכוונים ותליין זב"ז , וע"ז אמרז"ל (שבת דף ס"ז ע"ב) חמרא וחיי לפום רבנן ותלמידיהון , ולא אמרו לרבנן רק לפום רבנן, כי כשמתקנים הפה אז גם בחי' היסוד יתוקן ע"י היין ולא זולת.
translation: And according to this, one can say that the reason the Sages instituted four cups of wine is in the name of the four expressions of redemption, for our Sages said (Berakhot 63a, Nazir 2a) that one who sees a Sotah in her disgrace should abstain from wine, for wine can lead to corruption in the covenant. However, one who merits to rectify the flaws of his sin and works to extract the holy sparks and elevate them is permitted to drink wine for a mitzvah and in a state of holiness, as it is said, "When wine enters, secrets emerge," referring to the holy sparks that are called so, as hinted by our Sages in their secret, "Let not my soul come into their counsel," which refers to the act of Zimri, where the sin was in this matter, as is known. Therefore, the Sages instituted four cups of wine corresponding to "And I will bring you out," "And I will save you," "And I will redeem you," and "And I will take you," to extract the aspect of the secret and elevate it. One must also be careful and watch over the mouth and tongue to ensure they are pure and clean, for the covenant of the tongue and the essence are aligned and dependent on one another. And regarding this, our Sages said (Shabbat 67b), "Wine and life according to the Rabbis and their students," and they did not say "according to the Rabbis" but "according to the Rabbis," for when the mouth is rectified, then the aspect of the foundation is also rectified through the wine and not otherwise.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the four cups of wine established by the sages, which correspond to the four expressions of redemption. It emphasizes the dual nature of wine, which can lead to spiritual downfall if misused, particularly in relation to the covenant of purity. However, for those who strive to rectify their spiritual flaws and elevate the divine sparks, drinking wine for a mitzvah is permissible and can facilitate spiritual elevation. The text highlights the importance of maintaining purity in speech and thought, as these are interconnected with one's spiritual foundation.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר במאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו', דלכאורה איך יתכן שלא שמעו ישראל אל משרע"ה שהי' שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו וכל דבריו דברי השי"ת, ע"ז נתן הכתוב טעם מקוצר רוח ורוח היינו מחשבה כמ"ש רז"ל ( ויק"ר פר' ז' ס"ג) עולה מכפרת על הרהור הלב שנא' (יחזקאל כ') והעולה על רוחכם היו לא תהי' וכשזוכין למחשבות טהורות זה נקרא הרחבת הדעת דקדושה , ולהיפוך ח"ו הוא בחי' קוצר רוח, ולז"א ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח, על שנכשלו ר"ל בפגם ההרהור, ובעבודה קשה שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז היינו מפגם הברית שהוא בחי' ע"ז כנ"ל, על שהניצוץ הקדוש נשבה ביד זרים נוקבא דס"מ וכת דילה , וכי יש מקום זר ועבודה זרה מזה, וע"י החטא הנורא הזה נעשה מסך המבדיל בין ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, וע"כ לא שמעו אל משה דיבורי השי"ת שהי' מדבר אליהם.
translation: And similarly, it will be explained in the verse, "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit," for it seems difficult to understand how it was possible that Israel did not listen to Moshe Rabbeinu, who had the Shechinah speaking from his throat, and all his words were the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He. To this, the verse gives the reason of "shortness of spirit," and "spirit" refers to thought, as our Sages of blessed memory said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 7, Section 63) that "the ascent of the offering atones for the thoughts of the heart," as it is stated (Ezekiel 20), "And the thoughts that come into your mind shall not be." When one merits pure thoughts, this is called the expansion of the mind of holiness; conversely, God forbid, it is the aspect of shortness of spirit. Therefore, it says, "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit," for they stumbled, so to speak, in the blemish of thought, and in the hard work that was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, which is the blemish of the covenant, which is an aspect of idolatry, as mentioned above, because the holy spark was captured by foreign forces, the female side of the Sitra Achra and her faction. And is there a foreign place and idolatry greater than this? And through this terrible sin, a partition was created that separates between Israel and their Father in Heaven, and therefore they did not listen to Moses, the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who was speaking to them.
summary: The passage discusses the inability of the Israelites to listen to Moses, despite his words being divinely inspired, attributing this to "shortness of spirit." This "shortness" is linked to impure thoughts and a lack of spiritual clarity, which hindered their connection to God. The text emphasizes that their struggle with idolatry and the breach of sacred commitments created a barrier between them and the Divine, preventing them from heeding God's message through Moses. Ultimately, the failure to maintain pure thoughts and actions resulted in a separation from their spiritual source.

passage_content: ולתרץ דברי המדרש הנ"ל ( בקושיא ב') אפ"ל בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה ( בפ ' מקץ) לפרש הכתוב (תהלים ק"ד) הכפירים שואגים לטרף ולבקש מאל אכלם וגו', כי הפוגמין בהוצאת ז"ל ר"ל מושכין ניצוצות הקדושות מנשמתו לתוך הטומאה, ונבראים מאלו הטפות משחיתים ומזיקים, והמה צועקים לפני הזן ומפרנס ית"ש שיטול מאביהם אשר בראם הפרנסה הנקצבה לו וכו ', וז"פ הכתוב לדעתי הכפירים היינו אלו הנבראים מהוצאת ז"ל, ונקראו כפירים כי המה משורש הסט"א , והסט"א דעריות נקרא כפיר וארי', כמבואר בגמ' (יומא ס"ט ע"ב) נפק כגוריא דנורא מבית ק"ק עיי"ש, והם שואגים לטרף שיתן להם פרנסתם, ולבקש מאל אכלם של אותן בנ"א שבראם עכלה"ק בקיצור, והנה המצריים היו מושחתים ומזוהמים מאוד ביצרא דעריות כנודע, ואולי ס"ל להך מ"ד שהערוב בא מלמעלה, שהי' בריאה חדשה היינו חיות הטורפות שבאו במכת הערוב, המה היו המזיקין והמשחיתים שנבראו ממעשיהם הרעים, ואידך מ"ד ס"ל דבעכו"ם לא שייך בחי' זו דזרמת סוסים זרמתם, ואין בחי' קדושה בטיפי זרע שלהם וע"כ אין החצונים מתדבקים בהם, כידוע שהחצונים תאבים ומשתוקקים להתדבק בקדושה דייקא , ולזה ס"ל שהערוב בא עליהם מלמטה, חיות טורפות של מדבריות והבן.
translation: To explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash (in question 2), one might say, in advance, the words of K.Z. Yesmach Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Miketz), to interpret the verse (Psalms 104) "The young lions roar for their prey and seek their food from God," etc. This is because those who are involved in the extraction of the holy sparks, may their memory be blessed, draw the holy sparks from their soul into the impurity, and from these drops are created destroyers and harmful beings, and they cry out before the Sustainer and Provider, may He be blessed, to take from their father who created them the sustenance that is apportioned to them, etc. Thus, in my opinion, the "young lions" refer to those created from the extraction of the holy sparks, and they are called "young lions" because they stem from the forces of the Other Side, and the Other Side of immorality is called "young lion" and "lion," as explained in the Gemara (Yoma 69b), that a fiery cub emerged from the Holy of Holies, see there. They roar for their prey to be given their sustenance, and seek from the food of those human beings that were created from the holy drops, in short. Now, the Egyptians were very corrupt and defiled in the evil inclination of immorality, as is known, and perhaps it is the opinion of that sage who holds that the mixed multitude came from above, that it was a new creation, meaning the predatory animals that came with the plague of the mixed multitude; they were the harmful and destructive beings created from their evil deeds. And the other opinion holds that in the case of idolaters, this aspect does not apply, as the flow of horses is their flow, and there is no aspect of holiness in their seed drops, and therefore the external forces do not cling to them, as is known that the external forces crave and desire to cling specifically to holiness. Therefore, it is held that the mixed multitude came upon them from below, predatory animals of the wilderness, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual contamination and the creation of destructive forces from impure actions, particularly in the context of the Egyptians' moral corruption. It explains that these destructive entities, referred to as "kephirim" (young lions), are born from the negative spiritual energy of sinful acts and cry out for sustenance from their Creator. The text contrasts two interpretations of the origin of the plague of wild animals in Egypt, suggesting that one view sees them as a new creation resulting from the Egyptians' sins, while the other posits that they emerged from a lower spiritual realm, emphasizing the connection between human actions and the emergence of spiritual forces.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל במאה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' בהקדם דברי המד"ר פ' שמות (פ"ג סי' ד') ויאמר משה אל האלקים מי אנכי וגו' מהו שאמר לו כי אנכי שלחתיך אמרו רז"ל סימן לגאולה הראשונה שבאנכי ירדו ישראל למצרים שנא' אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה, ובאנכי אני מעלה אותם, וסימן לגאולה האחרונה שבאנכי הן מתרפאין והם עתידים להגאל שנא' הנה אנכי שולח לכם את אלי' הנביא עכ"ד המדרש, והקשה היפ"ת הלא סימן גאולה הראשונה הי' פקד פקדתי ומה צורך לסימן עוד עיי"ש תירוצו, ואפ"ל עוד בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה ( בפ ' בשלח) לפרש כפל הלשון בפקידה כפולה שאמר יוסף פקוד יפקוד וגו', עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' קרח) עה"פ ואם בריאה יברא עיי"ש הכא נמי או פקוד היינו הפקידה שמכבר שהוקצב לסוף ד' מאות שנה, או יפקוד למהר הקץ וכו ', עכת"ד ז"ל, נמצא לדעת שהי' מסורת ביד יורדי מצרים מיוסף הצדיק כי הגאולה אפשר שתהי' בשני אופנים, וע"ד שדרשו רז"ל על גאולה העתידה זכו אחישנה לא זכו בעתה, ותליא בזכות המעשים.
translation:
It can also be said in the verse, "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit," etc. To preface the words of the Midrash in Parashat Shemot (Chapter 3, Section 4), "And Moses said to God, 'Who am I...'" What is meant by His saying, "For I have sent you"? Our Sages of blessed memory said it is a sign of the first redemption, for with "I" the Israelites descended to Egypt, as it is said, "I will go down with you to Egypt," and with "I" I will bring them up. And it is a sign of the final redemption, for with "I" they are healed and they are destined to be redeemed, as it is said, "Behold, I send you Elijah the prophet." Thus far the Midrash. 

And it is difficult to understand: is it not a sign of the first redemption that He said, "I have surely remembered"? What need is there for another sign? See there for the answer. And it can also be said, to preface the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe (in Parashat Beshalach), to explain the doubling of the language in the double remembrance that Joseph said, "I will surely remember," etc., according to what Rashi of blessed memory said (in Parashat Korach) on the verse, "And if a new creation He will create," see there. Here too, either "I will surely remember" refers to the remembrance that was already set for the end of four hundred years, or "He will remember" refers to hastening the end, etc. Thus far his words of blessed memory. 

It is found that there was a tradition in the hands of those who descended to Egypt from Joseph the righteous that the redemption could come in two ways, and according to what our Sages of blessed memory have taught regarding the future redemption: if they are worthy, it will come quickly; if they are not worthy, it will come at its appointed time, and it depends on the merit of their deeds.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of redemption as articulated in Hasidic thought, referencing the biblical narrative of Moses and the Israelites' enslavement in Egypt. It highlights the significance of the phrase "I am" as a symbol of both the first redemption from Egypt and the future redemption, emphasizing that the timing of redemption can depend on the merit of the people's actions. The text also reflects on the teachings of the sages regarding the potential for redemption to occur either hastily or at its appointed time, suggesting a deep connection between human behavior and divine intervention in the process of salvation.

passage_content: והנה אמרו רז"ל במד"ר (פר' ג' סי' ד') עה"פ בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, מה שאמרת באיזה זכות אוציאם ממצרים הוי יודע שבזכות התורה שהן עתידים לקבל על ידך בהר הזה הם יוצאים משם עכ"ד המדרש, ובזה פי' היפ"ת דברי המדרש הנ"ל סימן לגאולה הראשונה שבאנכי ירדו ישראל למצרים וכו ', עפי"מ שנודע כי תכלית גלות מצרים היתה כדי שיקבלו עליהם עול תורה בצאתם ולא יקשה עליהם אחרי שכבר הורגלו בעבודה קשה, וכו ', וז"ש שבסבת אנכי כדי לקבל התורה ירדו למצרים, ובאנכי בשביל קבלת התורה אני מעלה אתכם עכ"ד, וכתב ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה דלא צריכנא לטעמא דע"ש העתיד נגאלו ישראל ממצרים. בזכות שעתידים לקבל את התורה בהר סיני, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם לקבל את התורה ולקיימה ופירשו מע"ז מיד, נחשב להם הקבלה כאלו כבר עשו, ובזכות זה נגאלו ממצרים עכ"ד, וז"פ דברי המדרש סימן לגאולה הראשונה שבאנכי אני מעלה אתכם, היינו אנכי שבעשרת הדברות וזה להם לסימן שא"א שיגאלו כ"א ע"י שיקבלו עליהם עול התורה ויפרשו מדרכי ע"ז, ואה"נ בקץ של בעתה שנקצב לסוף ד' מאות שנה היו נגאלים בכל אופן ואופן, ולא יאוחר בשום פנים, וכמ"ש רז"ל בגאולה העתידה אם תהי' בעתה אפי' בדור שכולו חייב מוכרח להיות הגאולה ולא ידחה ח"ו, אבל להקדים הקץ בבחי ' אחישנה א"א כ"א בזכו , ולזה הי' צורך להם זכות קבלת התורה, ויתורץ לדרכנו קושית היפ"ת דאעפ"י שכבר הי' מסורת בידם הסימן של פקד פקדתי, הי' צורך גם לסימן של אנכי, דהבטחת פקד פקדתי תליא בזכו , ולזה צורך לסימן של אנכי והבן.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parashat Shemot, section 4) regarding the verse "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," that what you asked, "By what merit will I take them out of Egypt?" know that it is by the merit of the Torah that they are destined to receive through you on this mountain that they will be taken out of there. Thus concludes the Midrash. And this explains the words of the Midrash mentioned above as a sign for the first redemption, that "I am the Lord your God" when Israel descended to Egypt, etc. According to the explanation, it is known that the purpose of the Egyptian exile was so that they would accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah upon their exit, and it would not be difficult for them after they had already become accustomed to hard labor, etc. Therefore, it is said that because of "I am the Lord your God" they descended to Egypt, and "I am the Lord your God" for the sake of receiving the Torah, I will elevate you. Thus concludes the text. And Rabbi K. Z. H. writes that we do not need the reason that in the future Israel will be redeemed from Egypt by the merit of receiving the Torah at Mount Sinai, but rather since they accepted upon themselves to receive the Torah and to fulfill it and immediately distanced themselves from idolatry, their acceptance is considered as if they had already done it, and by this merit they were redeemed from Egypt. Thus, the words of the Midrash serve as a sign for the first redemption, that "I am elevating you," meaning "I am" from the Ten Commandments, and this is a sign for them that they cannot be redeemed except by accepting upon themselves the yoke of the Torah and distancing themselves from the ways of idolatry. And indeed, at the end of the appointed time of four hundred years, they would be redeemed in any case, and not delayed in any way, as our Sages of blessed memory said regarding the future redemption, if it will be in its time, even in a generation that is entirely guilty, the redemption must occur and will not be delayed, Heaven forbid. However, to hasten the end in the aspect of "I will hasten it," it can only be by merit, and for this reason, they needed the merit of receiving the Torah. This resolves our question regarding the words of the Midrash, that although they already had the tradition of the sign of "I have surely remembered," there was also a need for the sign of "I am," for the promise of "I have surely remembered" depends on merit, and therefore there was a need for the sign of "I am." Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Israelites' redemption from Egypt and their future acceptance of the Torah at Mount Sinai. It emphasizes that the purpose of their descent into Egypt was to prepare them for the acceptance of the Torah, which would serve as a foundation for their spiritual identity. The text highlights that their commitment to the Torah and rejection of idolatry were essential for their redemption, suggesting that true liberation is intrinsically linked to the acceptance of divine law. Ultimately, it asserts that while redemption is assured, the timing can be influenced by the people's merit and their readiness to embrace the Torah.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפי' על איכה) לפרש הכתוב צדו צעדינו מלכת ברחובותינו קרב קצנו מלאו ימינו כי בא קצנו, עפימ"ש הרב המגיד מקרעמניץ לפרש הפסוק כל רודפי' השיגוה בין המצרים וזל"ק שענין המיצר הוא גבול שבין השדות, וזה משל על הזמנים שהיו גבולים וסיום להשלמת הקץ ונתבטלו בעוה"ר , וכתב בזוהר שזמן הגאולה אם יתבטל בעון ישראל יהפך לאבל וצרה ר"ל ודבר זה נודע ומפורסם, וז"ש כל רודפי' השיגוה לישראל בין המצרים, היינו בין הזמנים וסיומם שהיו מעותדים לגאול אז נהפך לרועץ עכ"ד, וז"ש כאן צדו צעדינו מלכת ברחובותינו, שהם אורבים את פסיעותינו שלא ללכת לרחובותינו כפרש"י , והיינו שלא יגיע הקץ, ואימתי הוא כן כאשר קרב קצנו, שמתקרב הקץ שהוא עת רצון וכו ', ולפי"ז אף שידענו שיש עת רצון, מ"מ יש לחוש שלא יהי' קטרוג ח"ו, וא"כ לפי"ז אין אנו יודעים מתי ימלאו ימינו אם לא כאשר יבא משיחנו ויבנה ביהמ"ק , אז יתוודע לנו שמלאו ימינו כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל וז"ש אימתי מלאו ימינו, כי בא קצנו שכבר בא, אז יתוודע לנו שמלאו ימינו עכתדה"ק , השי"ת ירחם עלינו ויזכנו לראות בישועת ישראל, כי כבר ראינו התעוררת הגאולה, אך בעוה"ר נדחה ונתעכב בעוננו ונתקיים בנו כל רודפי' השיגוה בין המצרים, וע"ד הרמז פירשתי בזה אמרם ז"ל (שבת קי"ח ע"ב) כל המענג את השבת נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים, עפ"י אמרם ז"ל שם אלמלי משמרין ישראל ב' שבתות כהלכתן מיד נגאלים, ובמדרש אמרו שבת א', ופירשתי עפימ"ד בזוה"ק דשבת דלילא ושבת דיממא הוא בחי' ב' שבתות, ולפי"ז שניהם צדקו יחדיו ולא פליגי, והנה דרשו רז"ל בספרי נחלה זו ירושלים, וז"ש כל המענג את השבת נותנין לו נחלה בלי מצרים, שע"י זכות השבת יזכו ישראל לנחלה זו ירושלים ולגאולה שלימה במהרה ולא ידחו לבין המצרים.
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z, may Moses be blessed (in his commentary on Lamentations), to explain the verse "They have laid wait for our steps, that we cannot walk in our streets; our end is near, our days are fulfilled, for our end has come." As the Maggid from Kremenitz explained the verse "All who pursue her have overtaken her between the straits," which means that the concept of the strait is a boundary between the fields, and this is a metaphor for the times that had boundaries and an end for the completion of the end, which have been nullified in our times. And it is written in the Zohar that the time of redemption, if it is nullified due to the sins of Israel, will turn into mourning and trouble, Heaven forbid. And this matter is known and publicized. Therefore, it is said, "All who pursue her have overtaken Israel between the straits," meaning between the times and their ends that were designated for redemption, and then it turns into a stumbling block. Thus, it is said here, "They have laid wait for our steps, that we cannot walk in our streets," meaning they are lying in wait for our footsteps so that we do not walk in our streets, as Rashi explains, which means that the end should not arrive. And when is this so? When our end is near, as the end approaches, which is a time of favor, etc. Therefore, even though we know there is a time of favor, we must still be concerned that there will not be a prosecution, Heaven forbid. And according to this, we do not know when our days will be fulfilled, except when our Messiah comes and builds the Holy Temple, then it will be made known to us that our days have been fulfilled, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, said. And it is said, "When will our days be fulfilled? For our end has come," meaning that it has already come, then it will be made known to us that our days have been fulfilled. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on us and grant us to see the salvation of Israel, for we have already seen the awakening of the redemption, but in our times it has been delayed and postponed due to our sins, and it has been fulfilled in us "All who pursue her have overtaken her between the straits." And according to the hint, I explained their saying, may their memory be blessed (Shabbat 118b), "Whoever delights in the Sabbath is given an inheritance without measure," according to their saying there, "If Israel would observe two Sabbaths properly, they would be redeemed immediately." And in the Midrash, they said one Sabbath, and I explained according to the words of the Zohar that the Sabbath of the night and the Sabbath of the day is in the aspect of two Sabbaths. According to this, both are correct together and do not disagree. And behold, our sages have expounded in the Sifrei that this inheritance is Jerusalem. Therefore, it is said, "Whoever delights in the Sabbath is given an inheritance without measure," that through the merit of the Sabbath, Israel will merit this inheritance, Jerusalem, and complete redemption speedily and will not be delayed between the straits.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "between the straits" (בין המצרים) as a time of limitation and potential suffering, emphasizing that the fulfillment of redemption is contingent upon Israel's actions and merits. It highlights the importance of observing the Sabbath, suggesting that through proper observance, Israel can attain a spiritual inheritance, symbolized by Jerusalem, and ultimately achieve complete redemption. The text reflects a deep connection between time, divine mercy, and the anticipation of the Messiah, underscoring the urgency of spiritual vigilance to avoid negative judgments that could delay redemption.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר לנו ליישב תמיהת המפרשים ז"ל (הובא לעיל) דמתחלה כשבאו משה ואהרן לבשר לישראל בשורת הגאולה כתיב ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ה' את בני ישראל וכי ראה את ענים ויקדו וישתחוו, ואיך נשתנה בחי' מדריגתם בזמן קצר ולא שמעו אל משה, והטעם שנתן הכתוב שלא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ודרשו רז"ל שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, לכאורה צ"ב ועדיין התמי' במקומה עומדת, שהרי גם מאז ומקדם היו משוקעים בע"ז ועבדו עבודה קשה, ואעפ"כ שמחו לקראת הבשורה ואיך נשתנה בחי' מצבם כ"כ, אמנם יתבאר עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, כי מתחלה כשבאו משה ואהרן אל זקני ישראל ודברו אליהם כל הדברים אשר דבר ד' פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו', השיגו ישראל שימהר השי"ת ויחיש גאולתם, כנרמז בפקידה כפולה כנזכר לעיל בשם ק"ז זלה"ה , ופי' פקד שיש פקידה מכבר לסוף ד' מאות שנה, אך פקדתי אתכם דייקא שאין אתם יכולים להתמהמה, והיו ישראל מייחלים ומצפים שיתקיים אצלם גם הסימן של אנכי ויפרשו מע"ז ויקבלו עליהם עול התורה ועי"ז יזכו לבחי ' אחישנה , וז"ש ויאמן העם וישמעו כי פקד ה' את בנ"י וגו' ויקדו וישתחוו ושמחו לקראת הבשורה, אמנם עכשיו ראו שתי סתירות בדבר שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולקבל עליהם עול התורה. מעתה חששו שאינם ראויים לגאולת אחישנה דתליא בזכו , גם ראו שניתוסף להם צרה על צרתם והכבידו מצרים שעבודם ולחצם עליהם, ע"כ אף שהאמינו בבשורת הגאולה וידעו שיש התעוררת מן השמים להחיש גאולתם, אבל כאשר ראו שנתגברו הצרות חששו שהפקידה נהפכה מששון לאבל כנ"ל, וזה שנתן הכתוב טעם ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ועפ"י דרשתם ז"ל שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, ומה"ט לא שמעו אל משה בבשורת הגאולה, שא"א שיזכו לבחי ' אחישנה כל זמן שלא פירשו מע"ז, ועפ"י פשוטו מעבודה קשה שהכבידו המצרים עול שעבודם עליהם ולזה נתייראו שנדחה ונתבטל הפקידה.
translation:
And this will clarify for us how to resolve the wonder of the commentators, may their memory be blessed (as mentioned above), that initially, when Moses and Aaron came to announce to Israel the tidings of redemption, it is written, "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, and they bowed their heads and worshipped." How did their level change so quickly that they did not listen to Moses? The reason given in the text is that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work. The sages expounded that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. It seems, however, that the question still stands, for even before and earlier they were immersed in idolatry and worked hard, and nevertheless, they rejoiced at the tidings. How then did their situation change so drastically? 

However, it can be explained according to our earlier approach, that initially, when Moses and Aaron came to the elders of Israel and spoke to them all the words that the Lord had spoken, "I have surely visited you," etc., the Israelites understood that the Holy One, blessed be He, would hasten and expedite their redemption, as hinted at in the double mention of "visitation" as mentioned above in the name of K.Z. Z.L.H. The meaning of "visited" indicates that there has been a visitation for the end of four hundred years, but "I have surely visited you" specifically means that you cannot delay. The Israelites were hoping and expecting that the sign of "I am the Lord your God" would also be fulfilled for them, that they would separate from idolatry and accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah, and through this, they would merit the aspect of "I will hasten it." 

And this is what is meant by "And the people believed, and they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel," etc., and they bowed their heads and worshipped and rejoiced at the tidings. However, now they saw two contradictions in the matter: that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry and to accept upon themselves the yoke of the Torah. From now on, they feared that they were not worthy of the redemption of "I will hasten it," which is dependent on merit. They also saw that their troubles had increased, as the Egyptians intensified their labor and pressed upon them. Therefore, even though they believed in the tidings of redemption and knew that there was a stirring from above to hasten their redemption, when they saw that the troubles had intensified, they feared that the visitation had turned from joy to mourning, as mentioned above. 

And this is why the text gives the reason that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, and according to their interpretation, that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. For this reason, they did not listen to Moses regarding the tidings of redemption, for it is impossible for them to merit the aspect of "I will hasten it" as long as they had not separated from idolatry. And according to the simple meaning, it was because of the hard work that the Egyptians intensified their burden of servitude upon them, and for this reason, they feared that the visitation would be delayed and nullified.
summary: The passage discusses the initial faith of the Israelites in Moses and Aaron's announcement of redemption, highlighting their joy and willingness to embrace the message of liberation. However, their situation quickly deteriorates as they face increased oppression from the Egyptians, leading to doubts about their worthiness for immediate redemption (אחישנה). The text emphasizes that their struggle to abandon idolatry and the burden of their labor contributed to their inability to fully accept the promise of salvation, illustrating the complex interplay between faith, suffering, and divine timing in the context of redemption. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between hope for liberation and the harsh realities that challenge that hope.

passage_content: גם אפ"ל דהפשט והדרש על קוטב א' יסובבו, והא בהא תליין, דלפי שהכבידו המצריים עולם עליהם בעבודה קשה, הי' לבם בל עמם מלהתבונן על מצבם הרוחני ולחפש דרך תשובה, כאשר מבשרינו נחזה בעוה"ר בגלות המר הזה, שכ"א טרוד בעבודה ובמו"מ כל היום וכל הלילה, ולא נשאר עת פנוי ודעת צלולה לדבר שבקדושה ולתורה ולתפלה כדבעי, וזה יסובב שפלות הרוחני שאנו נתונים בו, ופירשו המפרשים הפסוק (שמואל א' ב') מדוע לא בא בן ישי גם תמול גם היום, כלומר מדוע נתארך הגלות כ"כ, ועדיין לא בא בן ישי גם תמול גם היום, וע"ז בא הכתוב כמשיב אל הלחם, שכל איש ישראל עיניו ולבו נשואות רק אל הלחם, ומחשבותיו ורעיוניו טרודים על המחי' ועל הכלכלה, ואין משימין על הלב להתפלל על ישועת ישראל ועל הגאולה, וע"כ נתארך הגלות ועדיין בן דוד לא בא, ועד"ז במצרים ע"י שהיו טרודים בעבודה קשה הי' רוחם ודעתם קצרה מלהתבונן בעניני הנפש, ומה"ט הי' קשה בעיניהם להתגבר על יצרא דע"ז ולפרוש ממנה.
translation: It may also be that the simple meaning and the interpretation regarding one pole will revolve, and this is dependent on that, for since the Egyptians burdened them with hard labor, their hearts were not inclined to contemplate their spiritual state and to seek a path of repentance, as we see from our forefathers in this bitter exile, where everyone is preoccupied with work and business all day and all night, and there is no time left for a clear mind to engage in matters of holiness, Torah, and prayer as is proper. This will lead to the spiritual lowliness in which we find ourselves. The commentators explain the verse (1 Samuel 2) "Why has the son of Jesse not come, neither yesterday nor today?" meaning why has the exile been prolonged so much, and still the son of Jesse has not come, neither yesterday nor today. To this, the scripture responds as if answering to the bread, for every Jew's eyes and heart are directed only towards bread, and their thoughts and ideas are preoccupied with sustenance and livelihood, and they do not set their hearts to pray for the salvation of Israel and for the redemption. Therefore, the exile has been prolonged, and still the Messiah has not come. Similarly, in Egypt, because they were preoccupied with hard labor, their spirit and understanding were too short to contemplate matters of the soul, and for this reason, it was difficult for them to overcome the evil inclination towards idolatry and to separate from it.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual challenges faced by the Jewish people during their enslavement in Egypt, highlighting how their burdensome labor prevented them from contemplating their spiritual state and seeking repentance. It draws a parallel to the current exile, where individuals are preoccupied with daily survival and material concerns, leading to a neglect of prayer and spiritual connection. This distraction is seen as a reason for the prolonged exile and the delay in the coming of the Messiah, as people's focus remains on physical sustenance rather than on divine redemption. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the need for spiritual awareness and the dangers of being consumed by worldly matters.

passage_content: ויובן בזה הק"ו שאמר משרע"ה הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, וקושית המפרשים ידוע דהרי ק"ו פריכא הוא, דבנ"י לא שמעו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, וטעם זה לא שייך אצל פרעה, ולדרכנו טעם א' לשניהם, דגם פרעה טען טענה זו שלא נשלם עדיין זמן גלותם של ת' שנה, וא"א שתהי' גאולתם מיד ולא האמין לשלוחי ד', וז"ש הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי, אף שהם מאמינים בני מאמינים, והאמינו לקראת הבשורה של פקד פקדתי, מ"מ חוששים שנדחה הגאולה של אחישנה כנ"ל, ואיך ישמע אלי פרעה שהוא עומד ומצפה על זה שידחה גאולתם, ובודאי יסמוך על סימנים הנ"ל להחזיק בטענתו שאין זה גאולה, וא"ש כח הק"ו , ולזה בא תשובתו ית ' אליהם בפסוק של אחריו, ויצום אל בנ"י וגו' להוציא את בני ישראל מארץ מצרים, שעשאו ית ' שליח לקרב את ישראל לעבודתו ית ' ולהחזירם בתשובה, ועי"ז יזכו לגאולת אחישנה , להוציא את בנ"י מיד, ובזה הרגיעה רוחו, שבכח שליחותו ית ' יהי' בידו להפרישם מע"ז וינצחו התגברות הנורא של כוחות הסט"א אשר רצו למנוע גאולתם עי"ז , וכן הי' שפירשו ישראל מע"ז לפני גאולתם וקבלו עליהם עול התורה ובזכות זה נגאלו.
translation: And this is understood from the a fortiori argument that Moshe said: "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me, and how will Pharaoh listen to me?" The difficulty of the commentators is well known, for this is indeed a problematic a fortiori argument. The children of Israel did not listen due to shortness of spirit and hard work, and this reason does not apply to Pharaoh. According to our approach, there is one reason for both, for Pharaoh also claimed this argument, that the time of their exile of four hundred years has not yet been completed, and it is impossible for their redemption to be immediate, and he did not believe the messengers of G-d. Therefore, it is said: "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me," even though they are believers, the children of believers, and they believed in the announcement of "I have surely remembered you." Nevertheless, they are concerned that the redemption of "I will hasten it" may be delayed, as mentioned. And how will Pharaoh listen to me, when he stands and expects that their redemption will be delayed? Certainly, he will rely on the aforementioned signs to support his claim that this is not redemption. And this explains the strength of the a fortiori argument. To this, G-d's response came to them in the following verse: "And He commanded the children of Israel, etc., to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt," that G-d made him a messenger to bring Israel closer to His service and to return them in repentance. Through this, they will merit the redemption of "I will hasten it," to bring out the children of Israel immediately. And in this, his spirit was calmed, for through his mission, it would be in his power to separate them from idolatry, and they would overcome the terrible onslaught of the forces of the Other Side that sought to prevent their redemption through this. And so it was that Israel distanced themselves from idolatry before their redemption and accepted upon themselves the yoke of the Torah, and by virtue of this, they were redeemed.
summary: The passage discusses the challenge faced by Moses when the Israelites, burdened by their suffering, doubt the possibility of redemption, questioning how Pharaoh would listen to him. It highlights that both the Israelites and Pharaoh are concerned about the timing of their redemption, with Pharaoh believing that the prophesied period of exile has not yet concluded. The text emphasizes that God appointed Moses as a messenger to inspire the Israelites to return to Him and embrace the Torah, which would enable them to achieve an immediate redemption. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of faith and repentance as a means to overcome spiritual obstacles and attain divine salvation.

passage_content: ואיתא בירושלמי (ר"ה פ"ג ה"ה) אמר ר"ש בר"י ויצום אל בני ישראל על מה ציום על פרשת שלוח עבדים וכו' עיי"ש. וצ"ב מדוע דוקא במצוה זו נצטוו ישראל סמוך לגאולתם, ומה ענין תשובה זו על דברי משרע"ה הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי וגו' ויתבאר לדרכנו עפימ"ש בס' נחלת יעקב (הובא בישמח משה פ' משפטים) עמ"ש בגמ' ב"מ (י' ע"א) פועל יכול לחזור בו אף בחצי יום וכו' מ"ט כי לי בני ישראל עבדים ולא עבדים לעבדים, והקשו התוס ' א"כ יהי' אסור להשכיר עצמו בפועל, ותירצו כיון דיכול לחזור בו אימת שירצה לאו עבדות היא כלל ע"כ, והנה קשה על צדקתו ית"ש שמתנהג בדרך התורה האיך מכר אותנו לעבדים, והא אמר ולא עבדים לעבדים, אך התירוץ הוא כיון שבכל יום ויום זמן גאולה הוא א"כ לאו עבדות הוא כלל עיי"ש לדרכו, נמצא כי במצות שילוח עבדים שנתן הכתוב טעם כי עבדי הם וגו' לא ימכרו ממכרת עבד, נרמז בו סוד הגאולה של אחישנה , ובכל יומא ויומא זמני', דאל"ה לא יצוייר כלל עבדות וגלות, דהבוי"ת שומר משמרתה של תורה, ולז"א בירושלמי ויצום אל בנ"י ציום על פרשת שילוח עבדים, שבזכות שיקבלו עליהם מצוה זו יזכו לגאולה בבחי ' אחישנה , ועפ"י אמרם ז"ל ה' צלך שהבוי"ת מתנהג עם האדם כצל, כדרך שהצל עושה מה שהאדם עושה, כך הבוי"ת במידה שמתנהג האדם מודד לו.
translation: And it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Rosh Hashanah, Chapter 3, Halacha 5) that Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai said: "And He commanded the Children of Israel," on what did He command them? On the matter of the sending away of servants, etc. See there. And it is to be questioned why specifically in this commandment were the Israelites commanded close to their redemption, and what is the connection of this response to the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, "They did not listen to me," etc. It will be explained according to our path as mentioned in the book Nachalat Yaakov (brought in Yismach Moshe, Parashat Mishpatim), as it is stated in the Gemara (Baba Metzia 10a) that a worker can retract even halfway through the day, etc. Why? Because the Children of Israel are My servants and not servants to servants. The Tosafot questioned: If so, it should be forbidden for one to hire himself out as a worker. They answered that since he can retract whenever he wishes, it is not considered servitude at all. Therefore, it is difficult to understand the righteousness of the Holy One, Blessed be He, who conducts Himself according to the way of the Torah; how could He sell us into servitude, when it is said, "and not servants to servants"? However, the answer is that since every day is a time of redemption, it is not considered servitude at all, see there according to his path. It follows that in the commandment of sending away servants, the Torah gave a reason: "For they are My servants," etc., "they shall not be sold as a sale of a servant," hinting at the secret of redemption of "I will hasten it," and every day is a time for it. For otherwise, servitude and exile could not be conceived at all, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, guards the watch of the Torah. And thus it is said in the Jerusalem Talmud, "And He commanded the Children of Israel," a commandment regarding the sending away of servants, that in the merit of their accepting this commandment, they will merit redemption in the aspect of "I will hasten it." And according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said: "The Holy One, Blessed be He, behaves with man like a shadow; just as the shadow does what the person does, so the Holy One, Blessed be He, measures to him according to the way the person conducts himself."
summary: The passage discusses the commandment of releasing slaves, emphasizing its significance as a prelude to redemption for the Jewish people. It highlights the idea that true servitude belongs to God alone, and that the concept of slavery is not absolute, as individuals can return to freedom at any time. The text connects the observance of this commandment to the potential for immediate redemption, suggesting that adherence to divine commandments aligns with God's nature and leads to liberation. Ultimately, it illustrates the reciprocal relationship between human actions and divine response, akin to the way a shadow reflects its source.

passage_content: וראיתי בספה"ק לפרש אמרם ז"ל (יומא פ"ו ע"א) עבר על מ"ע ושב אינו זז משם עד שמוחלין לו, ובעבר על מצות ל"ת תליא כפרתו בזמן, דאף שעשה תשובה תשובה תולה ויוכ"פ מכפר וכן באידך חלוקי כפרה עיי"ש, וטעם הדבר עפ"י הנודע כי שורש מצות ל"ת הוא משם אלקים , ומ"ע שרשו משם הוי' ב"ה, והנה כל השמות הק ' המה תוארים ע"ש פעולותיו ית ' כמ"ש רז"ל במד"ר (פ' שמות), וא"כ המה תארים מחודשים בבריאה ונופלים תחת הזמן משא"כ שם הוי' שמורה על מהותו הי' הו' ויהי' הוא למעלה מן הזמן ועבר והו ' ועתיד יחד, (עיין ישמח משה ר"פ וארא ד"ה והנ"ל) ובזה נבין שבגאולת מצרים על כי הי' תליא בתשובה שאם יזכו ישראל יקדים הקב"ה גאולתם בבחי ' אחישנה , לזה בישרו הקב"ה למשרע"ה לכן אמור לבני ישראל אני ד' והוצאתי אתכם וגו', שהיציאה יהי' בכח שם הוי' ב"ה למעלה מן הזמן ותליא רק בתשובה, ועד"ז יתבאר קישור המסורה לכן אמר הנני נותן לו את בריתי שלו', עפי"ד התרגום יוב"ע שקאי על אלי' שיבשר את הגאולה בסוף יומיא , וגאולה העתידה תהי' ג"כ בבחי ' זו דתליא בתשובה ולא בזמן. שאם יזכו ישראל לעשות תשובה תהי' הגאולה בבחי ' אחישנה , ובכל יומא ויומא זמני'.
translation: And I saw in the holy books to explain their words, may their memory be blessed (Yoma 86a), that if one transgresses a positive commandment and repents, he does not move from there until he is forgiven. However, if he transgresses a negative commandment, his atonement is dependent on time, for even though he has repented, the repentance is suspended, and Yom Kippur atones, and so too with other distinctions of atonement, as mentioned there. The reason for this is according to the known principle that the root of the negative commandments is from the name of God, while the root of the positive commandments is from the name of Havayah, blessed be He. Behold, all the holy names are attributes based on His actions, as our sages have said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Shemot). Therefore, they are attributes newly created in the world and fall under time, whereas the name Havayah signifies His essence, which was, is, and will be, transcending time, past, present, and future together (see Yismach Moshe, Parashat Va'era, beginning of the discourse). With this, we understand that in the redemption from Egypt, it was dependent on repentance, for if Israel merits, the Holy One, blessed be He, will hasten their redemption in the aspect of "I will hasten it." For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, announced to Moshe, saying, "I am the Lord, and I have taken you out," etc., that the exodus will be through the power of the name Havayah, blessed be He, which is above time and depends only on repentance. Similarly, the connection of the tradition will be explained; therefore, it says, "Here I give him My covenant," according to the translation of Onkelos, which refers to Eliyahu, who will announce the redemption at the end of days. And the future redemption will also be in this aspect, which is dependent on repentance and not on time. For if Israel merits to repent, the redemption will be in the aspect of "I will hasten it," and every day and every day will have its times.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between positive commandments (Mitzvot Aseh) and prohibitive commandments (Mitzvot Lo Ta'aseh) in relation to repentance and atonement. It emphasizes that the root of prohibitive commandments is associated with the name of God (Elokim), which is tied to time, while positive commandments are linked to the name of the Lord (Havayah), which transcends time. The text highlights that the redemption from Egypt and future redemption are contingent upon the people's repentance, suggesting that if the Israelites merit it, their redemption will occur swiftly (Achishena) through the divine name that exists beyond temporal limitations.

passage_content: וידבר משה כן אל בנ"י ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה וכו' וידבר משה לפני ה' לאמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה ואני ערל שפתים, וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה וכו' להוציא את בנ"י מארץ מצרים, יל"ד טובא במקראי קודש אלו, דלכאורה הדעת נותן להיפך דלפי שהי' רוחם קצרה מעבודה קשה, הי' להם להטות אוזן קשבת ולהמלא שמחה וגיל להבשורה טובה אשר יגאלם ה' ולא יוסיפו לדאבה עוד, ולא שעבודה הקשה תהא סיבה לבל יאבו לשמוע לקול מבשר טוב, גם יל"ד במאמה"כ ולא שמעו "אל משה" כי תיבות אל משה נראה כמיותר דהא בי' עסיק וקאי .
translation: And Moses spoke thus to the Children of Israel, but they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work, etc. And Moses spoke before the Lord, saying, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to me; how then shall Pharaoh listen to me, for I am of uncircumcised lips?" And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the Children of Israel and to Pharaoh, etc., to bring the Children of Israel out of the land of Egypt. There is much to be learned from these holy scriptures, for it seems that the opposite should be true: since their spirit was short from hard work, they should have inclined their ears to listen and be filled with joy and gladness at the good tidings that the Lord would redeem them and they would no longer suffer. It is not that hard work should be a reason for them not to want to hear the voice of good tidings. Also, it is noteworthy that it says "did not listen to 'Moses'," for the words "to Moses" seem superfluous, as he was already engaged and present.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the paradox of the Israelites' inability to listen to Moses despite the promise of redemption from their suffering in Egypt. The text highlights the Hasidic concept that, contrary to expectations, their difficult circumstances led to a lack of receptiveness to the good news, suggesting that hardship can dull one's spirit and hope. Additionally, the phrase "to Moses" is examined as seemingly superfluous, indicating a deeper exploration of the relationship between the messenger and the message, emphasizing the struggle to accept divine communication amidst despair.

translation: B) The commentators have questioned the verse "Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me," for it is indeed a strong a fortiori argument that regarding Israel, the reason for not listening to Him is due to shortness of spirit, etc. This does not apply to Pharaoh, and it is possible that he would listen to Him.
summary: The passage discusses the verse "Indeed, the children of Israel did not listen to me," highlighting the difference between the Israelites and Pharaoh. It suggests that the Israelites' inability to hear stems from their shortness of spirit and suffering, which does not apply to Pharaoh, who could potentially listen. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of spiritual readiness and openness to divine communication, emphasizing that one's state of being can affect their receptiveness to God's message.

translation: 3) It is questioned in the Ma'amarei HaKodesh, "And He commanded concerning the Children of Israel and concerning Pharaoh, etc., to bring out the Children of Israel, etc." It is not clear what He commanded concerning the Children of Israel, and one should examine the commentary of Rashi, may his memory be blessed. However, from the language of the verse, it seems that He commanded them to bring out the Children of Israel, and this is not in their hands to bring themselves out.
summary: The passage discusses the command given to Moses to instruct both the Israelites and Pharaoh regarding the liberation of the Israelites from Egypt. It highlights the idea that the Israelites cannot free themselves, emphasizing their dependence on divine intervention. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of reliance on God for salvation and the belief that true redemption comes from a higher power rather than human effort alone. The text underscores the importance of divine authority in the process of liberation.

passage_content: ד) ( בפ ' בא) בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שיתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, משמע דמ"ש כי אני הכבדתי הוא נתינת טעם לשליחותו לילך אל פרעה, ולכאו ' איפכא מסתברא דאם השי"ת הכביד את לבו מה יועיל הליכתו ובוודאי לא ישמע אליו, ורש"י ז"ל פי' שיתי שימי שאשית אני, צ"ב מה שדייק לומר אשית אני דייקא .
translation: (d) "And I have hardened his heart" (Exodus 10:1) - "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc., so that I may place these signs of Mine in his midst." It implies that the statement "for I have hardened" serves as a reason for the mission to go to Pharaoh. However, it seems counterintuitive, for if the Holy One, blessed be He, has hardened his heart, what benefit is there in going, and surely he will not listen to him? And Rashi, of blessed memory, explains "I have placed" as "I have set," which raises the question of why he specifically emphasizes "I have set."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine hardening of Pharaoh's heart as a rationale for Moses' mission to confront him. The text suggests that God's action in hardening Pharaoh's heart serves a purpose, allowing for the demonstration of God's signs and wonders. The commentary highlights the paradox of sending Moses to a ruler whose heart has been hardened, questioning the effectiveness of such a mission. The emphasis on God's sovereignty and the unfolding of divine plans reflects key Hasidic themes of faith and the interplay between divine will and human agency.

passage_content: וכל אלה יתבארו בהקדם דברינו ( בפ ' שמות) לפרש דברי המדרש למה משה ואהרן תפריעו את העם ממעשיו, אתם למה ודבריכם למה, גם צ"ב ענין טענתו של משרע"ה למה הרעותה לעם הזה למה זה שלחתני, איך יתכן טענה זו לגבי משרע"ה עבד נאמן להשי"ת לקבול על שליחותו ולהתרעם על מדותיו ית"ש , ב) גם צ"ב אומרו למה זה שלחתני משמע דכל עיקר הקפידא על שהוא הי' השליח, וכי בלתי זאת לא יחשוש להרעה אשר ימצא את ישראל, ג) רש"י ז"ל פי' וא"ת מה איכפת לך קובל אני על אשר שלחתני, והוא תמוה לכאורה דאיך יעלה על הדעת לומר מה איכפת לך, הלא זה משה האיש ידענו מה הי' לו שהי' מיצר בצערן של ישראל ובכל צרתם לו צר. ד) תשובת השי"ת עתה תראה וגו' צ"ב עיין פירש"י ז"ל.
translation: And all these will be explained in advance of our words (in Parashat Shemot) to interpret the words of the Midrash regarding why Moshe and Aharon disturbed the people from their actions, and why you and your words, and also the matter of Moshe Rabbeinu's claim of why have You done evil to this people, why have You sent me. How can this claim be relevant to Moshe Rabbeinu, a faithful servant of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to complain about his mission and to be upset about His attributes, 2) Also, the question arises regarding his statement "why have You sent me," which implies that the entire essence of the complaint is that he was the messenger, and if not for that, he would not be concerned about the evil that would befall Israel. 3) Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains: "And you might ask, what do you care? I complain about the fact that You sent me," and this seems puzzling at first glance, for how could it enter one's mind to say "what do you care?" After all, this is Moshe, the man we know who was pained by the suffering of Israel, and in all their affliction, he was afflicted. 4) The response of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is "Now you will see," etc. There is a question; refer to Rashi, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the complexities of Moses' complaints to God regarding his mission to lead the Israelites, questioning why he should be held accountable for their suffering. It highlights the paradox of Moses, a faithful servant, expressing dissatisfaction with his role as a messenger, suggesting a deeper theological inquiry into the nature of divine responsibility and human agency. The text also references Rashi's commentary, emphasizing the emotional connection Moses has with the plight of the Israelites, which raises questions about the relationship between divine will and human experience. Ultimately, God's response to Moses serves as a pivotal moment in understanding the dynamics of leadership and divine purpose.

passage_content: וביארתי עפי"מ שהקשו רז"ל קושיא לאלקינו שהבטיח וגם את הגוי אשר יעבודו דן "אנכי" וכתיב "ואנכי" אעלך גם עלה, ומדוע נעשה כ"ז ע"י שליח משרע"ה , ותירצו דהבטחת דן אנכי לא היתה רק אחרי שישלמו ימי השעבוד ארבע מאות שנקצבו בגזירת ברית בין הבתרים, ובאמת לא עברו רק רד"ו שנים, ע"כ היתה הגאולה ע"י משה עכת"ד. והנה בישוב הקושיא דאיך יצאו ישראל קודם זמנם תירצו המפורשים דקושי השעבוד השלים, ולכאורה לפי"ז נסתר מחמתו תירוץ הנ"ל על קושית הבטחת דן אנכי ואנכי אעלך, דמפני שיצאו קודם זמנם ע"כ הי' ע"י שליח, דהרי כבר נשלם זמנם ע"י קושי השעבוד וא"כ הי' ראוי להיות הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בכבודו ובעצמו, ויתכן לומר דזה היתה טענת פרעה אתם למה, הלא הגאולה צריך להיות ע"י השי"ת בעצמו לא על ידי שליח, וכעת אשר שלח אתכם מוכרח לומר כתירוץ הנזכר משום שהוא קודם זמנו, וא"כ דבריכם למה, כי טרם נשלם זמנם איננו מוכרח לשחררם, ואולי עד"ז הי' ג"כ טענת אדון הנביאים משרע"ה לפני השי"ת למה הרעותה לעם הזה בקושי השעבוד, ואת"ל שעי"ז נשלם זמן שעבודם לסוף רד"ו שנה, א"כ למה זה שלחתני ומדוע לא גאלתם בכבודך ובעצמך, ובזה יתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל וא"ת מה איכפת לך ר"ל בקושי השעבוד, שה"ה באמת לטובתן של ישראל שעי"ז יושלם זמן שעבודם ויצאו מהר, ע"ז אמר קובל אני על מה ששלחתני, דאם נשלם זמנם הי' לך להוציאם בכבודך ובעצמך.
translation: And I explained according to the principle that our sages posed a question to our God who promised, "And also the nation that they will serve, I will judge," and it is written, "And I will also elevate you," and why was all this done through the messenger Moshe Rabbeinu. They answered that the promise of "I will judge" was only after the days of servitude, four hundred years, which were decreed in the covenant between the parts, and in truth, only one hundred and thirty years had passed. Therefore, the redemption was through Moshe, as stated. Now, in addressing the question of how the Israelites left before their time, the commentators explained that the difficulty of the servitude was completed. And seemingly, according to this, the explanation of the above regarding the question of the promise "I will judge" and "I will elevate you" is contradicted, for since they left before their time, it should have been through the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, and it could be said that this was Pharaoh's argument: "Why are you leaving? The redemption should be through the Holy One Himself, not through a messenger." And now that He sent you, it must be said as the aforementioned explanation, because it is before their time, and therefore your words, "Why?" because their time has not yet been completed, He is not obligated to free them. And perhaps this was also the argument of the master of the prophets, Moshe Rabbeinu, before the Holy One, blessed be He: "Why have You made this people suffer under the difficulty of servitude?" And even if through this their servitude time was completed at the end of one hundred and thirty years, then why did You send me, and why did You not redeem them in Your glory and essence? And with this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: "What does it matter to You," meaning, regarding the difficulty of the servitude, that it is indeed for the benefit of Israel, for through this their servitude time will be completed and they will leave quickly. To this, he said, "I complain about what You sent me," for if their time had been completed, it would have been fitting for You to take them out in Your glory and essence.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between God's promise of redemption and the timing of the Israelites' liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their suffering was meant to fulfill the prophesied duration of their enslavement. It raises the question of why God chose to send Moses as a messenger rather than redeeming them directly, suggesting that the premature nature of their release led to this delegation. The text reflects on the suffering endured by the Israelites, positing that it ultimately served a purpose in completing their time of servitude, yet Moses expresses a grievance about being sent to lead them out instead of God acting in His own glory. This highlights the complexity of divine intervention and the role of human agency in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ועתה נבאר תשובת השי"ת אליו במאמר עתה תראה וגו', דהנה אפ"ל עוד בישוב קושיא הנ"ל עה"פ ואנכי אעלך גם עלה, דבאמת עיקר הגאולה הי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, ומפורש בכתוב כחצות הלילה אני יוצא בתוך מצרים, והכיתי כל בכור וגו', וכהנה פסוקים רבים, ודרשו רז"ל אני ולא מלאך אני ולא שרף ולא השליח, אמנם שליחות משרע"ה הי' רק לעשות פועל דמיוני ואתערותא דלתתא , ולעורר לב בנ"י שיאמינו ויצפו לגאולתם ופדות נפשם, אשר ע"י אמונתם יוכלו לעשות אתערותא דלעילא להמשיך כח הגאולה, וכמה פסוקים יתנו עידיהם ע"ז, וכמ"ש להלן אתה תדבר את כל אשר אצוך וגו' ואני אקשה את לב פרעה וגו' ולא ישמע אליכם פרעה ונתתי את ידי במצרים ופי' רש"י יד ממש וכו ', והוצאתי את צבאותי וגו' וכדי לחזק הענין כפל דבריו ואמר וידעו מצרים כי אני ה' בנטותי את ידי דייקא , שעיקר הגאולה תהי' ע"י הבוית"ש כביכול בכבודו ובעצמו: ושליחות משה הוא רק בבחי ' הכנה לעצם הגאולה.
translation: And now we will explain the response of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to him in the statement "Now you will see, etc." Behold, it can also be said in resolving the above question regarding the verse "And I will also bring you up," that in truth, the essence of the redemption was through the Holy One Himself, as it is explicitly stated in the verse "At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt, and I will strike every firstborn, etc.," and many such verses. The sages have interpreted, "I [will do it] and not an angel, I [will do it] and not a seraph, and not a messenger." However, the mission of Moses was only to create a figurative action and an awakening from below, to stir the hearts of the Children of Israel to believe and anticipate their redemption and the salvation of their souls, which through their faith they could create an awakening from above to draw down the power of redemption. And how many verses testify to this, as it is said later, "You shall speak all that I command you, etc., and I will harden Pharaoh's heart, etc., and Pharaoh will not listen to you, and I will stretch out My hand over Egypt," and Rashi explains "My hand" literally, etc., "and I will bring out My hosts, etc." And to strengthen the matter, He repeated His words and said, "And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord when I stretch out My hand," specifically, that the essence of the redemption will be through the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it were, in His glory and essence: and the mission of Moses is only in the aspect of preparation for the essence of the redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of redemption, emphasizing that the primary act of salvation comes directly from God, as indicated in the biblical text where He declares, "I will go out into Egypt." It highlights that while Moses' role was significant, it was primarily to inspire the Israelites to believe in and anticipate their redemption, thereby facilitating a divine awakening. The text underscores that the ultimate redemption is a direct manifestation of God's presence, with Moses serving as a preparatory figure rather than the source of salvation itself.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו לנכון הפסוקים הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם הוציאו את בנ"י מארץ מצרים על צבאותם , דלכאו ' תיבת על צבאותם צ"ב (עיין פי' רש"י ז"ל), גם צ"ב שהכפיל הכתוב עוד הפעם הם המדברים אל פרעה וכו' הוא משה ואהרן, ולפימ"ש בא הכתוב להורות ולשלול שלא נטעה לחשוב דעצם הגאולה היתה ע"י משה, ע"כ אמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם הוציאו את בנ"י מארץ מצרים על צבאותם דייקא , היינו לעורר צבאות ופעולת ישראל, וע"י שיחזקו בטחונם בדבר יציאתם, דין גרמא לעורר אתערותא דלעילא , וכדי לחזק הענין כפל הכתוב לומר הם המדברים אל פרעה דייקא , וזה יסובב אתערותא דלעילא להוציא את ישראל ע"י הקב"ה ממצרים, הוא משה ואהרן רק זאת היתה פעולת משה ואהרן, אבל עצם הגאולה הי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, אמנם משרע"ה חשב בנפשו כי רצון השי"ת שתהי' גם עצם הגאולה בשליחותו, ע"כ סירב ומיאן בהשליחות ונשמט מלילך, ובא בקובלנא לפני הקב"ה בטענת למה הרעותה כנזכר.
translation: And this will clarify the verses: "It is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them, 'Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their hosts.'" The term "according to their hosts" is a question (see Rashi's commentary). It is also a question why the text repeats that they are the ones speaking to Pharaoh, etc., meaning Moses and Aaron. According to the explanation, the text comes to teach and to negate the thought that the essence of the redemption was through Moses. Therefore, it says, "It is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them, 'Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their hosts'" specifically, meaning to awaken the hosts and the actions of Israel, and by strengthening their trust in the matter of their departure, it causes a reaction to awaken from above. And to strengthen the matter, the text repeats to say that they are the ones speaking to Pharaoh specifically. This will cause an awakening from above to bring out Israel through the Holy One, Blessed be He, from Egypt. It is Moses and Aaron, but this was only the action of Moses and Aaron; the essence of the redemption was through the Blessed One Himself. However, Moses thought in his heart that the will of the Blessed One was that the essence of the redemption should also be through his agency. Therefore, he refused and was reluctant to go, and he came with a complaint before the Holy One, Blessed be He, with the argument of why He had caused him harm, as mentioned.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the redemption of the Israelites from Egypt was ultimately orchestrated by God Himself, despite the roles played by Moses and Aaron as His messengers. It highlights the importance of the Israelites' faith and trust in God, which serves as a catalyst for divine intervention. The repetition of their names in the text underscores their role in facilitating this awakening, while also clarifying that the essence of the redemption was not due to their actions but rather God's will. Moses' initial reluctance to accept his mission reflects his deep understanding of the divine plan and his desire for the redemption to be fully attributed to God.

passage_content: וע"ז בא תשובת השי"ת אליו לא כמו שאתה סובר שעצם הגאולה יהי' על ידך, כי באמת יושלם הזמן ע"י קושי השעבוד ואקיים הבטחת ואנכי אעלך, והשליחות שלך הוא רק בבחי ' הכנה לעשות אתערותא דלעילא , וזהו אומרו עתה תראה אשר אעשה לפרעה, ר"ל אחר שכבר התחלת לעשות איזה פעולה במקצת, למען יתעורר הענין באתערותא דלתתא , מעתה תראה את אשר אעשה דייקא בכבודי ובעצמי כי ביד חזקה ישלחם וכו' כוונתו על מכת בכורות, דאז ישלחם ביד חזקה כמ"ש ותחזק מצרים על העם, ובמכה זאת התרה לו ראשונה כפי' רש"י בפסוק הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, וזאת המכה אעשה בעצמי, ומכות האחרות הם רק למען יתעורר לב בנ"י שלא יתייאשו עצמם מן הגאולה ח"ו ע"י שהיו משוקעים בכור הברזל במ"ט שערי טומאה.
translation: And to this, the response of the Holy One, Blessed be He, came to him, not as you assume that the essence of the redemption will be through you, for in truth, the time will be completed through the severity of the servitude, and I will fulfill the promise, and I will elevate you. Your mission is only in the aspect of preparation to bring about an awakening from below. This is what He means when He says, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh," meaning after you have already begun to take some action, in order that the matter may be awakened through an awakening from below. From now on, you will see what I will do specifically in My honor and by My own hand, for with a strong hand I will send them out, etc. His intention is regarding the plague of the firstborn, for then He will send them out with a strong hand, as it is said, "And Egypt was strengthened against the people." And in this plague, He warned him first, as Rashi explains in the verse, "Behold, I am killing your firstborn." And this plague I will do Myself, while the other plagues are only so that the hearts of the Children of Israel will be stirred, that they should not despair of the redemption, Heaven forbid, due to being immersed in the iron furnace in the forty-nine gates of impurity.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author emphasizes that the ultimate redemption will not be achieved solely through human efforts, but rather through divine intervention, particularly in response to the suffering of the Israelites. The concept of "it'aaruta d'le'ela" (higher awakening) is highlighted, indicating that human actions can initiate a spiritual awakening that allows for divine action. The text also points out that while the plagues serve to awaken the Israelites' faith and hope for redemption, the final act of liberation, specifically the death of the firstborn, will be carried out directly by God. This underscores the belief in God's sovereignty and the necessity of divine assistance in the process of redemption.
