passage_content: ויתכן דזאת היתה הסיבה אשר בנ"י לא שמעו אל משה, דלפי שראו את קושי השעבוד שהוא להשלים הזמן, אותה נפשם שיקיים השי"ת הבטחת ואנכי אעלך ויוציאם בעצמו לא ע"י משה, וזהו אומרו ולא שמעו אל משה דייקא , שהוא יהי' השליח, והטעם מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, דלולא קושי השעבוד היו תולים דמחמת שלא נשלם הזמן עדיין מוכרח להיות הגאולה ע"י משרע"ה וכתירוץ הנ"ל, אמנם כיון שקצרה רוחם מכובד השעבוד שהוא כדי להשלים הזמן, ע"כ לא שמעו אל משה דייקא , ומשרע"ה פירש שיחתו לפני השי"ת ואמר הן בנ"י לא שמעו "אלי" דייקא מחמת קושית ממנ"פ הנ"ל, ואיך ישמעני פרעה להוציאם קודם זמנם, כי פרעה כבר טען טענה זו, דאם הגאולה ע"י שליח בשר ודם הרי זה מורה שעדיין לא נשלם זמנם לצאת כנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible that this was the reason why the Children of Israel did not listen to Moses, for since they saw the difficulty of the servitude, which was to complete the time, their soul was to fulfill the promise of the Holy One, blessed be He, "And I will bring you up" and He will take them out Himself, not through Moses. And this is what it means when it says, "and they did not listen to Moses specifically," that he would be the messenger. The reason was because of shortness of spirit and hard work, for were it not for the difficulty of the servitude, they would have thought that because the time had not yet been completed, it was necessary for the redemption to be through Moses, as explained above. However, since their spirit was short due to the heaviness of the servitude, which was to complete the time, therefore they did not listen to Moses specifically. And Moses explained his case before the Holy One, blessed be He, and said, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to 'Me' specifically because of the difficulty mentioned above, and how will Pharaoh listen to me to take them out before their time?" For Pharaoh had already raised this argument, that if the redemption is through a mortal messenger, it indicates that their time to leave has not yet been completed, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the reasons why the Israelites did not listen to Moses, emphasizing their deep yearning for direct divine intervention rather than reliance on a human messenger. Their suffering under harsh bondage led them to believe that the fulfillment of God's promise of redemption should come directly from Him, not through Moses, as they felt their time for liberation had not yet arrived. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the struggle between faith in divine timing and the harsh realities of human experience, illustrating the tension between hope for immediate redemption and the patience required in the face of suffering. Moses, recognizing their despair, questions how Pharaoh would allow their early release if it were to come through a human intermediary, highlighting the complexities of divine and human roles in the process of redemption.

passage_content: וע"ז בא תשובת השי"ת להודיע למשה אשר יגלה אוזן ישראל, כי באמת עיקר הגאולה תהי' ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, ושליחות משה הוא רק לעשות אתערותא דלתתא שיעוררו את לבבם ויתנו אומן בישועת השי"ת, וזאת ימשוך אתערותא דלעילא שיגמור השי"ת בעצמו את הגאולה, וזהו אומרו וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בנ"י אין צו אלא לשון זירוז כוונתו ששליחות משה הוא רק לזרזם כדי שיהי' אתערותא דלתתא , וכח זה יהי' סיבה להוציא את בנ"י מאמ"צ , היינו שעי"ז יוציא השי"ת כביכול בכבודו ובעצמו את בני ישראל מארץ מצרים ותיבת להוציא קאי על השי"ת.
translation: And in this, the response of the Holy One, Blessed be He, came to inform Moses that he will reveal to the ears of Israel, for indeed the essence of the redemption will be through the Holy One Himself, and the mission of Moses is only to create an awakening from below to stir their hearts and to place their trust in the salvation of the Holy One. This will draw down an awakening from above, so that the Holy One Himself will complete the redemption. And this is what is meant by, "And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron and commanded them to the children of Israel," for the term "command" is only a language of encouragement, indicating that the mission of Moses is only to encourage them so that there will be an awakening from below. This power will be the cause to bring the children of Israel out of Egypt, meaning that through this, the Holy One, as it were, will bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt with His honor and glory, and the term "to bring out" refers to the Holy One.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is emphasized that the ultimate redemption of the Jewish people will be accomplished by God Himself, while Moses' role is to inspire the people to awaken their hearts and trust in God's salvation. This awakening, referred to as "at'arat d'letata," serves as a catalyst for divine intervention, leading to the fulfillment of redemption. The text highlights that Moses' mission is to encourage the Israelites, as God's command to him is a call to prompt their spiritual readiness, which in turn will invoke God's own action in liberating them from Egypt. Thus, the act of redemption is portrayed as a partnership between human initiative and divine will.

passage_content: היוצא מדברינו שכל עיקר שמיאן משרע"ה בשליחותו והקביל לפני השי"ת על שנתן המשרה הזאת על שכמו, הי' לאשר נכספה וגם כלתה נפשו שיהי' הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בעצמו, אמנם כאשר ראה כי הולך אל פרעה פעם אחר פעם ואולי הכיר בפרעה כי מעט נתרכך לבבו, עלה מורא על ראשו אולי בין כך יתרצה פרעה לשלחם ע"י שליחותו, ולא יהי' הגאולה ע"י הבוית"ש בעצמו, ע"כ הי' בדעתו להשמיט עצמו מן השליחות, ולזה בא מאמר השי"ת אליו בא אל פרעה והתרה בו, ואין לך לחוש אולי יאבה ויסכים פרעה לשלחם, כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וכו' ובוודאי לא ישלח אותם, ושלא תאמר א"כ השליחות למה, ע"ז אמר למען שיתי וכו' כי עיקר השליחות הוא למען לעשות פועל דמיוני ואתערותא דלתתא שיזכו עי"ז שאשים "אני" את אותותי אלה בקרבו, כוונתו למכות בכורות ויהי' הגאולה ע"י השי"ת בכבודו ובעצמו, וזהו שפי' רש"י למען שיתי שימי שאשית "אני" דייקא בכבודי ובעצמי, וכימי צאתנו מארץ מצרים יראנו נפלאות.
translation: The conclusion of our words is that the main aspect of the heavens is through Moshe Rabbeinu in his mission, and he pleaded before the Holy One, Blessed be He, for having placed this burden upon him. He yearned and his soul longed for the redemption to be through the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself. However, when he saw that he was going to Pharaoh time and again, and perhaps he recognized that Pharaoh's heart had softened a little, fear arose in his mind that perhaps Pharaoh would agree to send them away through his mission, and the redemption would not be through the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself. Therefore, he intended to exempt himself from the mission. To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, spoke to him, saying, "Go to Pharaoh and warn him," and you need not worry that perhaps Pharaoh will agree and consent to send them, for I have hardened his heart, etc., and he will certainly not send them. And so that you do not say, "What is the purpose of the mission?" to this He said, "In order that I may set..." because the essence of the mission is to create a figurative action and an awakening from below, so that they may merit through this that I will place "I" My signs within him, referring to the plagues of the firstborn, and the redemption will be through the Holy One, Blessed be He, in His glory and essence. This is what Rashi explains, "In order that I may set My days," that I will place "I" specifically in My glory and essence, and as on the day of our exodus from the land of Egypt, He will show us wonders.
summary: The passage discusses the role of Moses as a messenger of God, emphasizing his deep desire for the redemption to come directly from God rather than through intermediaries. It highlights the tension between Moses' apprehension about Pharaoh's heart and God's assurance that He has hardened Pharaoh's heart to ensure that the redemption will be a direct act of divine intervention. The text underscores the importance of Moses' mission as a means to evoke a spiritual awakening among the people, ultimately leading to a miraculous redemption that showcases God's glory. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the necessity of divine involvement in the process of redemption and the transformative power of faith.

passage_content: ועפ"י פשוטו אפ"ל במאמה"כ ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, שהתוה"ק מלמדת זכות על ישראל, דלכאורה יקשה קושית המדרש וכי יש לך אדם שמתבשר בשורה טובה ואינו שמח, ומה שתירצו במדרש ומ"ט לומר לא שמעו אל משה, אלא שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז, לכאורה גם זה אינו מושג, הלא באמת הוא הבל הבלים, וכבר הי' מושרש בישראל דרך האמיתי בעבודת השי"ת מהאבוה"ק , והיו ביניהם שבט לוי כולם צדיקים עובדי ה', ומשה ואהרן הוכיחו אותם לפרוש מדרכי הע"ז , ומה גם שידעו שבזה תליא גאולתם כאמרז"ל , ומדוע הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז שאין בו ממש ומועיל, אמנם התירוץ על זה מבואר בפשוטו של מקרא באמרו מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, ועפימ"ד בילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ד בשם מדרש אבכיר ) והמים להם חומה חמה כתיב, שירד ס"מ ואמר רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסים וכו ', מיד השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם וכי לדעתם עבדוה, והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, עיין בדברנו (לעיל בפ ' שמות) שפירשנו דבחי ' האונס הי' ע"י כוחות הטומאה שהתגברו על ישראל בדרך כפי' עד שכאונס נחשבו עיי"ש, ועפ"י פשוטו מבואר האונס בכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה, שע"י כובד השעבוד קצרה רוחם ודעתם ולא יכלו להתבונן בשפלות מצבם ולעשות תשובה ראוי', ולטעם זה לא שמעו אל משה, ובזה יאות כח הק"ו שדן משרע"ה הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי ואיך ישמעני פרעה, וכבר הקשו דק"ו פריכא הוא. דהרי אצל פרעה לא יצדק טעם הכתוב מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה אמנם מה שהי' לגבי ישראל באונס, הי' לגבי פרעה ברצון, שברצון נפשו התנגד לדברי ה' וא"ש כח הק"ו .
translation: And according to its simple meaning, it can be said that they did not listen to Moses due to shortness of spirit and hard work, as the Holy Torah teaches merit for Israel. At first glance, the question of the Midrash is difficult: is there a person who receives good news and is not happy? And what the Midrash answers, that they did not listen to Moses, is that it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. This, too, seems incomprehensible; for it is indeed vanity of vanities, and the true path of serving the Holy One, Blessed be He, was already rooted in Israel from the forefathers, and among them was the tribe of Levi, all righteous servants of God. And Moses and Aaron rebuked them to separate from the ways of idolatry, especially since they knew that their redemption depended on this, as our sages have said. Why then was it difficult for them to separate from idolatry, which has no substance and is not beneficial? However, the answer to this is explained in the simple meaning of the verse, which states, "due to shortness of spirit and hard work." And according to the Midrash in Yalkut Parashat Beshalach (Remez 244 in the name of Midrash Abkir), it is written, "And the waters were a wall for them," that Satan descended and said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Did Israel not serve idolatry in Egypt, and You are performing miracles for them?" Immediately, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world! Do they think they served it? They did not serve it except out of servitude and madness, and you judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were willful," etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. See our discussion (above in Parashat Shemot) where we explained that the coercion was by the forces of impurity that overpowered Israel in such a way that they were considered coerced. According to its simple meaning, the coercion is explained in the verse "due to shortness of spirit and hard work," that due to the heaviness of the servitude, their spirit and understanding were shortened, and they could not contemplate the lowliness of their situation and make a proper repentance. For this reason, they did not listen to Moses, and thus the strength of the a fortiori argument is fitting, as Moses said, "The children of Israel did not listen to me; how then will Pharaoh listen to me?" And it has already been asked that the a fortiori argument is weak, for regarding Pharaoh, the reason of the verse "due to shortness of spirit and hard work" does not apply. However, what was for Israel as coercion was for Pharaoh as willful, for he willingly opposed the words of God, and the strength of the a fortiori argument is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the difficulty the Israelites had in listening to Moses due to their oppression and suffering in Egypt, which caused them to be spiritually and emotionally constrained. It emphasizes that their inability to respond positively to the message of redemption was not due to a lack of faith, but rather a result of their harsh conditions, which clouded their judgment and understanding. The text also contrasts the Israelites' situation with Pharaoh's willful defiance, highlighting that while the Israelites were coerced by external forces, Pharaoh acted out of his own volition. This distinction underscores the concept of divine judgment, where the circumstances of one's actions—whether coerced or voluntary—are taken into account.

passage_content: וידבר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה מלך מצרים, ופירש"י ז"ל צוה עליהם להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום עליו לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם, וקשה דציווי זה הי' צ"ל כשהלכו בפעם הראשונה בשליחותם אל ישראל ואל פרעה, אז הי' ראוי לצוות להם על ככה להנהיגם בנחת ולחלוק כבוד לפרעה, ומדוע נצטוו ע"ז דייקא בעת ההוא, ובספר חנוכת התורה מהגאון הר"ר העשיל זצ"ל מקראקא הקשה על מה שכתב רש"י ז"ל צום לחלוק לו כבוד בדבריהם, ממה דאיתא בגמרא (זבחים ק"ב ע"א) כל חרון אף שבתורה נאמר בו רושם וכו' ופריך והכתיב ויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אף ולא א"ל ולא מידי, ומשני אמר ר"ל סטרו ויצא, ופריך ומי אמר ר"ל הכי והכתיב ונצבת לקראתו וגו', אמר ר"ל מלך הוא והסביר לו פנים, ור"י אמר רשע הוא והעיז פניך בו, ומשני איפוך דר"י לר"ל , והנה רש"י ז"ל פי' לעיל ( בפ ' שמות) עה"פ ויחר אף ה' וגו' דכל חרון אף שבתורה עושה רושם שניטלה הכהונה וכו ', א"כ קשה כקושית הגמרא מהא דכתיב ויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אף מאי רושם הי' שם, ועכצ"ל כר"ל דסטרו ויצא, וגם הא דכתיב ונצבת לקראתו צריך לפרש העיז פניך כנגדו כנ"ל, והרי כאן פירש"י צום לחלוק כבוד למלכות א"כ דברי רש"י ז"ל סותרין אהדדי ע"כ קושיתו , ולכאורה קושיא זו הי' יכול להקשות מפסוק זה ויצא מעם פרעה בחרי אף דבאותו הפסוק כתיב וירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי, ופירש"י חלק כבוד למלכות שהרי בסוף ירד פרעה בעצמו אליו בלילה וכו ', ולפי"ד רש"י ז"ל יש סתירה בפסוק גופי' מרישי' לסיפי' ומדוע הוצרך להביא ממרחק לחמו.
translation: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and commanded them to speak to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt. And Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained that He commanded them to lead the people gently and to bear with them, and to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to show him honor in their words. It is difficult, for this command should have been given when they first went on their mission to Israel and to Pharaoh; then it would have been appropriate to command them to lead gently and to show honor to Pharaoh. Why were they specifically commanded about this at that time? In the book "Hanukat HaTorah" by the Gaon Rabbi R' Ashil, may his memory be blessed, from Krakow, he questioned what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote about showing honor in their words. From what is stated in the Gemara (Zevachim 102a), that every anger mentioned in the Torah leaves a mark, etc., and it asks, but it is written, "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," and he did not say anything to him. And it answers that R' Levi said he struck him and went out. And it asks, who said R' Levi said this? For it is written, "And you shall stand to meet him," etc. R' Levi said he is a king and he showed him a favorable face, and R' Yochanan said he is wicked and he brazened his face against him. And it answers that we reverse R' Yochanan and R' Levi. And behold, Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained above (in Parashat Shemot) on the verse "And the Lord's anger burned," that every anger in the Torah leaves a mark that the priesthood is taken away, etc. Therefore, it is difficult according to the question of the Gemara from the verse "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," what mark was there? And it must be according to R' Levi that he struck him and went out. Also, the fact that it is written "And you shall stand to meet him" needs to be explained as brazening your face against him, as mentioned. And here Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained to show honor to the monarchy; therefore, Rashi's words contradict each other, hence his question. And seemingly, this question could have been raised from this verse "And he went out from Pharaoh in anger," for in that verse it is written, "And all your servants will come down to me," and Rashi explained that he showed honor to the monarchy, since in the end Pharaoh himself came down to him at night, etc. According to Rashi's explanation, there is a contradiction in the verse itself from the beginning to the end, and why was it necessary to bring from afar his bread.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine command given to Moses and Aaron regarding their approach to the Israelites and Pharaoh, emphasizing the importance of leading with gentleness and showing respect to Pharaoh. The text raises questions about the timing and necessity of this command, particularly since it seems more appropriate for their initial encounter. The commentary highlights the tension between the need for respect towards authority and the inherent conflict in Pharaoh's character, illustrating the complexity of leadership and divine instruction in the context of the Exodus narrative. Ultimately, it reflects on the balance between reverence for authority and the moral imperatives of justice and truth.

passage_content: והנ"ל ליישב דהנה בגמרא שם איתא א"ר ינאי לעולם תהא אימת מלכות עליך דכתיב וירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי, ואילו לדידי' לא קאמר לי', ר' יוחנן אמר מהכא (מלכים א' י"ח) ויד ה' היתה אל אלי' וישנס מתניו וירץ לפני אחאב, וכתב הרלב"ג (מלכים א' כ"ב) וז"ל: ואמנם חלק לו כבוד עתה לא קודם זה, כי ידמה שגם הוא סר מאחרי הבעלים והאמין בהשי"ת ולזה הסכים לאלי' בהריגת נביאי הבעל, אך קודם זה שהי' בתכלית הרוע לא חלק לו כבוד, וכן לא חלק לו כבוד כשחטא בדבר נבות עכ"ל, ומבואר להדיא כדבריו בילקוט פ' משפטים עה"פ ונשיא בעמך לא תאור ועי' ויואל משה ח"א סי' קל"ג שהארכנו בזה) אמנם כל זה רק במלכי ישראל שהם משועבדים למצות התורה, גם יש אצלם מצות מיוחדות כמבואר בפסוק, ע"כ כל מלך הפונה מדרך התורה אינו בכלל מלך שצריך לחלוק לו כבוד, משא"כ במלכי אוה"ע מחוייבים אנו לחלוק להם כבוד בכל אופן, שהרי הם עובדי ע"ז בלא"ה ואעפי"כ צותה התוה"ק לחלוק להם כבוד כ"ז שגזירת השי"ת עלינו להיות בגלות בין האומות, ורק כשנתמלא סאתם והגיע זמן איבודם אז אין מחוייבים עוד לחלוק להם כבוד. ודבר זה א"א לשקול בדעת בנ"א אם הגיע קיצם ונתמלא סאתם, ושיקול זה רק בדעתו של א"ל דיעות ה', כי באמת תלוי זה גם במעשה ישראל ובזכותם, וכמו שפי' האוה"ח הק ' (פ' לך) עה"כ ודור רביעי ישובו הנה כי לא שלם עון האמורי עד הנה, וזל"ק מכאן מוכח שעון האמורי מעכב הכניסה, ובמעשה אשר סידר ה' בתורתו הנעימה יגיד, כי עון המרגלים הוא אשר סבב עכבת דור היוצא ממצרים וכו ', וזולת המרגלים שהרשיעו היו נכנסים הדור היוצא וכו' והלא לא שלם עון האמורי עדיין, אכן כוונת הכ ' הוא ע"ד אומרם ז"ל במס' (ברכות דף ז' ע"ב) בפסוק כבלע רשע צדיק ממנו, צדיק ממנו בולע צדיק גמור אינו בולע ע"כ, פי' כי אם יהי' הרשע עדיין יש בידו קצת זכות, ויבוא צדיק שרובו זכיות להתגרות בו, אין כח בצדיק לאבדו, כי עדיין יש לרשע להשתלם זכות הנשאר לו בעוה"ז, והרשע יתנקם מהצדיק להיות שיש ביד הצדיק מהתיעוב שאינו צדיק גמור, אבל כשיהי ' צדיק גמור הגם שישאר לרשע חלק מהטוב יפקע כלילתו, וכן אם יהי' הרשע מוחלט ונגמר דינו למות, בכל עושה ה' שליחותו לאבדו וכל הקודם בו זכה ואפילו אינו צדיק גמור יוכלו לאבדו מן העולם וכו' עיי"ש באריכות, מבואר מזה שהשגת קיצם של הרשעים ליאבד מן העולם תלוי גם במעשה וזכותם של ישראל, ואין בדעתינו לשקול ולהכריע בזה רק הקב"ה א"ל דעות ה' לו נתכנו עלילות, וכל עוד שלא נתברר שכבר הגיע קצם ליאבד מן העולם מחוייבים לחלוק כבוד למלכי עכו"ם.
translation: And the above is to clarify that in the Gemara there it is stated: Rabbi Yanai said, "The fear of the kingdom should always be upon you," as it is written, "And all your servants shall come down to me." And if it were for me, it would not be said. Rabbi Yochanan said from here (Kings I 18), "And the hand of the Lord was upon Eliyahu, and he girded up his loins and ran before Achav." And the Ralbag wrote (Kings I 22) as follows: "And indeed, he was honored now, not before this, for it seems that he also turned away from the Baalim and believed in the Holy One, Blessed be He, and for this reason he agreed with Eliyahu in the killing of the prophets of Baal. However, before this, when he was in the utmost wickedness, he was not honored, and he was not honored when he sinned regarding the matter of Navot." Thus, it is clearly explained according to his words in the Yalkut, Parashat Mishpatim, on the verse "And a prince among your people you shall not curse," and see Vayolech Moshe, Part I, Siman 133, where we elaborated on this. However, all this is only regarding the kings of Israel, who are subservient to the commandments of the Torah. They also have special commandments, as explained in the verse. Therefore, any king who turns away from the path of the Torah is not included in the category of a king to whom honor should be given. In contrast, regarding the kings of the nations of the world, we are obligated to give them honor in any case, for they are idol worshippers regardless, and yet the Holy Torah commanded to give them honor as long as the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is upon us to be in exile among the nations. Only when their measure is full and the time of their destruction arrives, then we are no longer obligated to give them honor. And this matter cannot be weighed in the minds of men whether their time has come and their measure is full; this consideration is only in the mind of the Holy One, Blessed be He, whose thoughts are His own, for in truth, this also depends on the actions and merits of Israel. As the Ohr HaChaim explained (Parashat Lech Lecha) on the verse "And the fourth generation shall return here, for the iniquity of the Amorite is not yet complete," it is implied from here that the iniquity of the Amorite delays the entry. And in the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, arranged in His pleasant Torah, it is indicated that the sin of the spies is what caused the delay of the generation that went out of Egypt, etc. And without the spies who sinned, the generation that went out would have entered, etc., and behold, the iniquity of the Amorite is still not complete. However, the intention of the verse is in accordance with what they said in the tractate (Berakhot 7b) on the verse "As the wicked one swallows the righteous," "The righteous one swallows the righteous one completely does not swallow." It means that if the wicked one still has some merit, and a righteous one whose majority is merits comes to provoke him, the righteous one does not have the power to destroy him, for the wicked one still has the merit that remains to him in this world. And the wicked one will take revenge on the righteous one because the righteous one has some deficiency that he is not a completely righteous one. But when there is a completely righteous one, even if there remains to the wicked one a portion of good, it will be nullified entirely. And likewise, if the wicked one is absolute and his judgment is completed for death, in all that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does His mission to destroy him, and whoever is first in it is worthy, and even if he is not a completely righteous one, he can destroy him from the world, etc. It is explained from this that the reaching of the end of the wicked to be destroyed from the world also depends on the actions and merits of Israel, and we do not have the mind to weigh and decide on this; only the Holy One, Blessed be He, knows the thoughts of the Lord, for His plots are established. And as long as it is not clarified that their end has already come to be destroyed from the world, we are obligated to give honor to the kings of the nations of the world.
summary: The passage discusses the obligation to show respect to non-Jewish rulers, emphasizing that this duty persists as long as the Jewish people are in exile, regardless of the rulers' idolatrous practices. It highlights that the status of kings in Israel is different; they must adhere to the Torah, and those who stray from it do not deserve honor. The text also suggests that the fate of the wicked is intertwined with the merits of the righteous, indicating that the timing of divine judgment is determined by God's will and the actions of the Jewish people. Ultimately, respect for non-Jewish authorities is mandated until it is clear that their time has come to an end.

passage_content: והנה כשהי' מרע"ה אצל פרעה בפעם האחרון כשאמר לו פרעה לך מעלי השמר לך אל תוסף ראות פני וגו', השיג מרע"ה שכבר הגיע פרעה לתכלית הרשעות וכבר הוחלט ונגמר דינו למיתה, ומעתה לא הי' צריך עוד לחלוק לו כבוד וע"כ סטרו על פניו ויצא כדרשת ר"ל, ומה שאמר לו וירדו כל עבדיך אלה אלי וחלק כבוד למלכות, סובב על אותו הזמן שבא פרעה אל מרע"ה והכניע עצמו לפניו ואמר לו קומו צאו מתוך עמו וגו' וברכתם גם אותי, שעשה קצת תשובה לפי ערכו ולא הי' כ"כ מוחלט ברע באותה שעה ע"כ חלק לו כבוד בדבריו, ולא קשה קושית הגאון ז"ל דהחיוב לחלוק כבוד למלכות תליא באיכות בחינתו שהוא עומד באותה שעה.
translation: And behold, when Moshe Rabbeinu was with Pharaoh for the last time, when Pharaoh said to him, "Get away from me; take heed to yourself; do not see my face again," Moshe Rabbeinu realized that Pharaoh had reached the ultimate level of wickedness and that his judgment had already been decided and sealed for death. From that point on, there was no need to show him honor, and therefore he struck him on the face and left, as the interpretation of R. Levi states. And what Pharaoh said, "And all your servants will come down to me," and he showed honor to the monarchy, refers to the time when Pharaoh came to Moshe Rabbeinu and humbled himself before him, saying, "Get up, go out from among my people," and "Bless me also," for he had done a bit of repentance according to his level and was not so completely wicked at that moment; therefore, he showed him honor in his words. And the question of the Gaon, may his memory be blessed, is not difficult, for the obligation to show honor to the monarchy depends on the quality of his standing at that moment.
summary: The passage discusses the moment when Moses confronts Pharaoh for the last time, recognizing that Pharaoh has reached the ultimate level of wickedness, leading to his predetermined fate of death. At this point, Moses no longer needs to show him respect, symbolized by striking him. The text reflects on the earlier moment when Pharaoh humbled himself before Moses, indicating a temporary acknowledgment of wrongdoing, which warranted a degree of honor at that time. This highlights the Hasidic concept that respect for authority is contingent upon the moral and spiritual state of the individual in that moment.

passage_content: ואיתא במד"ר פ' בא ( פט"ז סי' ג') משכו וקחו לכם צאן הה"ד (תהלים צ"ז) יבושו כל עובדי פסל. בשעה שאמר הקב"ה למשה לשחוט הפסח א"ל משה רבון העולם הדבר הזה האיך אני יכול לעשות, אי אתה יודע שהצאן אלהיהן של מצרים הן וכו' א"ל הקב"ה חייך אין ישראל יוצאין מכאן עד שישחטו אלהי מצרים לעיניהן שאודיע להן שאין אלהי העכו"ם כלום, גם איתא במד"ר פ' זו (פ' ו' סי' ה') ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח ומעבודה קשה שהי' קשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז, וזה שטען מרע"ה אל השי"ת הלא הגאולה א"א שתהי' כ"א שתקדים הכנעת ע"ז ע"י ישראל כמבואר במדרש הנ"ל, ובנ"י עדיין דבוקים בע"ז ולא ירצו לשחוט אלהי מצרים, וז"ש הן בנ"י לא שמעו אלי מפני שקשה בעיניהם לפרוש מע"ז וא"כ לא ירצו לבטל הע"ז , ואיך ישמעני פרעה לשלוח את ישראל כיון שמוכרח להיות ביטול ע"ז תחלה, ואמר לו הקב"ה ויצום אל בנ"י להנהיגם בנחת ולסבול אותם, היינו שמעט מעט בנחת יראה להחזירם בתשובה ולהפריש אותם מע"ז, ואל פרעה מלך מצרים צום לחלוק לו כבוד, דכל זמן שלא הופרשו ישראל מע"ז לא הגיע עדיין זמן איבודו של פרעה וצריכין לחלוק לו כבוד כמ"ש האוה"ח הק ' כי לא שלם עון האמורי עדיין לצד שאין ישראל בשלימות המעלה, ולזה שפיר שייך כאן הציווי לחלוק לו כבוד, דחלוקת כבוד לפרעה תליא במעשיהם וזכותן של ישראל כנ"ל.
translation: And it is stated in the Midrash on Parashat Bo (Chapter 17, Section 3) "Draw and take for yourselves sheep," as it is said (Psalms 97) "Let all the worshippers of idols be ashamed." At the time that the Holy One, Blessed be He, told Moses to slaughter the Passover, Moses said to Him, "Master of the Universe, how can I do this? Do You not know that the sheep are the gods of Egypt?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "I swear, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes, so that I will make known to them that the idols of the nations are nothing." It is also stated in the Midrash on this Parashah (Parashat Va'eira, Section 5) "And they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit and hard work," for it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry. This is what Moses argued before the Holy One, Blessed be He, that redemption cannot happen unless the subjugation of idolatry is first accomplished by Israel, as explained in the aforementioned Midrash. And the Children of Israel were still attached to idolatry and did not want to slaughter the gods of Egypt. Therefore, it is said, "Behold, the Children of Israel did not listen to Me because it was difficult in their eyes to separate from idolatry," and thus they would not want to nullify the idolatry. How then will Pharaoh listen to me to send out Israel, since it is necessary for the nullification of idolatry to happen first? And the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Command the Children of Israel to lead them gently and to bear with them," meaning that little by little, gently, he should see to return them in repentance and separate them from idolatry. And to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, a fast to honor him, for as long as Israel has not been separated from idolatry, the time for Pharaoh's downfall has not yet arrived, and they must honor him, as the Ohr HaChaim HaKadosh writes, "For the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete," because Israel is not yet in the fullness of their elevation. Therefore, it is appropriate here to command to honor him, for the honoring of Pharaoh depends on their actions and the merit of Israel, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the divine command to Moses to sacrifice the Egyptian gods, emphasizing that the Israelites must first renounce idolatry before their redemption can occur. It highlights the struggle of the Israelites to detach from their attachment to foreign deities, which complicates their liberation. God instructs Moses to lead the people gently, allowing them to gradually return to repentance, while also acknowledging that the timing of Pharaoh's downfall is linked to the Israelites' spiritual state. The text underscores the interconnectedness of Israel's spiritual journey and their eventual freedom from oppression.

passage_content: ( משה ואהרן כאשר צוה ד' אותם כן עשו, וצריך להבין מה דכפל הכתוב לומר כן עשו שהוא מיותר לכאורה, ובפ ' בא אחר פרשת קרבן פסח כתיב ג"כ כן עשו ושם ביאר רש"י ז"ל הכוונה וכאן לא פי' מאומה, ואפשר לומר דלעיל כתיב הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ה' להם וגו' הם המדברים אל פרעה וגו' הוא משה ואהרן דלכאורה כל הפסוק השני מיותר, דבמה שאמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ד' להם הוציאו וגו', כבר ידעינן הכל , ומה חידש לנו באמרו הם המדברים בפרט מה שסיים עוד הפעם הוא משה ואהרן אין לו הבנה, וברש"י ז"ל פי' הם המדברים הם שנצטוו הם שקיימו הוא משה ואהרן הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף, וגם זה צ"ב מה הוצרך לומר דהם שנצטוו הם קיימו וכי ס"ד דאחרים קיימו הלא מפורש בפרשה דהם קיימו אחר שנצטוו ולא הוצרך בכאן אלא לייחסם דהם הנולדים מיוכבד לעמרם ולא יותר, גם מה שאמר הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף צ"ב מה"ת לומר שנפלו ח"ו ממדריגת צדקתם עד שהוצרך לומר כי היו בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף.
translation: Moses and Aaron, as the Lord commanded them, so they did. And it is necessary to understand why the text repeats to say "so they did," which seems superfluous at first glance. In Parashat Bo, after the section of the Passover offering, it is also written "so they did," and there Rashi explains the intention, while here he did not explain anything. It can be said that above it is written, "It is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them," and they are the ones speaking to Pharaoh, etc. It is Moses and Aaron, and seemingly the entire second verse is superfluous, for in what was said, "It is Aaron and Moses whom the Lord said to them, 'Take out...'" we already know everything. What new information does it bring us by saying "they are the ones speaking," especially since it concludes again with "it is Moses and Aaron"? This does not have understanding. And Rashi explains that "they are the ones speaking" means they were commanded, they fulfilled it; it is Moses and Aaron who are acting on their behalf and in their righteousness from beginning to end. Yet, this also requires explanation: why is it necessary to say that they were commanded and they fulfilled it? Is it possible to think that others fulfilled it? It is explicitly stated in the section that they fulfilled it after they were commanded, and it was not necessary here except to attribute to them that they are the offspring of Yocheved and Amram and nothing more. Also, regarding what was said, "they are acting on their behalf and in their righteousness from beginning to end," it requires explanation: why say that they did not fall, Heaven forbid, from their level of righteousness to the point that it was necessary to say they were in their righteousness from beginning to end?
summary: The passage discusses the repetition in the Torah regarding Moses and Aaron's obedience to God's command, questioning the necessity of emphasizing that they were the ones who were commanded and who fulfilled the command. It highlights the idea that their actions were not only a result of divine instruction but also a reflection of their inherent righteousness and integrity throughout the process. The text suggests a deeper understanding of their role as leaders, emphasizing their unwavering commitment to their mission and the importance of their lineage and character in fulfilling God's will.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עפ"י מה שפי' ק"ז זצוקלה"ה בפתיחת ספרו ישמח משה עה"ת דברי המדרש ( ויק"ר פ"ח) ר"י אומר חביב קרבנם של נשיאים לפני הקב"ה כשירה שאמרו ישראל בים, ורבנן אמרו חביב קרבנו של אהרן לפני הקב"ה כקרבנם של נשיאים, דהנה אין חסידות כחסידות בתחלתו ואין לך אדם בישראל שאין לו שעה שחושק לעשות רצון קונו. רק אחר עבור שעה נתקרר וחוזר לקדמותו, אבל הבני עלי' כל שעה ושעה כשעה הראשונה, שבכל עת נדמה לו שעתה מתחיל לעבוד השי"ת ואין אצלו אמצע וסוף רק תמיד התחלה, וזהו דברי המדרש דהשירה שבים הי' חביב מאוד לפי שהי' בתחלת כניסתן לקדושה והי' בהתלהבות גדול וכו ', וכן נתינת הלוחות שזה התחלת קבלת התורה הי' בחשקות גדול עד שהזהירה התורה בכל יום יהיו בעיניך כחדשים, וכן קרבן נשיאים שהוא לחנוכת המזבח שהי' חנוכה הראשונה הי' בהתלהבות גדול והי' חביב מאוד בערך הדביקות והתלהבות שלהם, ובאו רבנן ואמרו שקרבן אהרן אף שהי' בכל יום פעמיים חביב לפני הקב"ה כקרבן נשיאים, שכן דרך בני עלי' שכל שעה ושעה אצלם כשעה ראשונה יעיי"ש שהאריך בזה, וא"א מו"ר הגה"ק זלה"ה פי' בזה דברי רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' בהעלותך) להגיד שבחו של אהרן שלא שינה, דר"ל שכמו שהתחיל לעשות עבודתו אחר שנצטוה מהשי"ת כן לא בא לידו שינוי וגרעון לעולם, ולא נתקרר כלל כי בכל שעה ושעה הי' אצלו התחלה מחדש.
translation: And it is possible to say according to what Rabbi K. Z. Z. U. L. H. explained in the introduction to his book "Yismach Moshe" on the Torah, the words of the Midrash (Vayikra Rabbah 8): Rabbi Yochanan says that the offering of the leaders is beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the song that Israel sang at the sea, and the Rabbis said that the offering of Aaron is beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the offering of the leaders. Behold, there is no piety like the piety at its beginning, and there is no person in Israel who does not have a moment when he yearns to do the will of his Creator. However, after that moment passes, he cools off and returns to his previous state. But the sons of elevation are every moment like the first moment, for at all times it seems to them that they are just beginning to serve the Holy One, Blessed be He, and there is no middle or end for them, only always a beginning. And this is the meaning of the Midrash that the song at the sea was very beloved because it was at the beginning of their entry into holiness and was with great enthusiasm, etc. Likewise, the giving of the tablets, which was the beginning of the receiving of the Torah, was with great desire, to the extent that the Torah warns that every day they should be in your eyes like new. And so too the offering of the leaders, which was for the inauguration of the altar, that the first inauguration was with great enthusiasm and was very beloved in terms of their attachment and fervor. And the Rabbis came and said that the offering of Aaron, even though it was every day twice, was beloved before the Holy One, Blessed be He, like the offering of the leaders, for this is the way of the sons of elevation that every moment for them is like the first moment, as you can see there that he elaborated on this. And our teacher, the holy and revered one, may his memory be blessed, explained the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Beha'alotecha), to indicate the praise of Aaron that he did not change, meaning that just as he began to perform his service after being commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, so he never experienced any change or diminishment at all, and he was never cooled off, for at every moment it was for him a new beginning.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the initial fervor in serving God, as highlighted by the Midrash comparing the offerings of the leaders of Israel and Aaron. It emphasizes that true Hasidic devotion is characterized by a continuous renewal of enthusiasm, akin to the initial excitement experienced during pivotal moments such as the crossing of the Red Sea and the giving of the Torah. The text illustrates that while most individuals may experience fluctuations in their spiritual fervor, the true "Bnei Aliyah" (those who ascend spiritually) maintain a constant state of devotion, perceiving each moment as a new beginning in their service to God. Aaron's unwavering commitment is praised, as he exemplifies this ideal by never allowing his dedication to wane.

passage_content: וזה אפשר לכוין בדברי רש"י ז"ל דבוודאי בעת שנצטוו משה ואהרן מפי הקב"ה לעשות שליחותם הי' אצלם התלהבות גדול והשתוקקות רב לקיים רצון קונם, ועד שבאו לידי עשי' הי' אפשר לומר שנתקררו קצת כדרך כל אדם אשר אין חסידות כבתחלתו ואחר עבור שעה אינו זה האיש שהי' בתחלתו , ע"כ אמר הוא אהרן ומשה אשר אמר ד' להם וגו' הם המדברים וגו' דהם שנצטוו הם שקיימו ממש בלי שום שינוי דכמו שהיו בהתלהבות גדול בעת שנצטוו, כן היו ממש בעת שקיימו דגם בעת שקיימו הי' אצלם התחלת הענין כמו בעת שנצטוו כדרך הבני עלי' אשר בכל שעה ושעה הוא בעיניהם כחדשים, ואח"כ הוסיף עוד לומר הוא אהרן ומשה כפירש"י ז"ל הם בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף דאל תאמר דאך טרם שעשו איזה דבר לא נתקררו מהתלהבות שלהם אבל אחר שעשו איזה דבר משליחותו של הקב"ה נתקרר דעתם בזה ונשקע אש ההתלהבות מקרבם קצת כדרך שאר בני אדם, ע"כ אמר הם בצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף שגם בסוף עשייתם אש תוקד בקרבם כאילו לא עשו עדיין מאומה, והתחילו אז לעשות מחדש ולא נגרע מצדקתם ועבודתם מאומה, וז"ש ויעש משה ואהרן כאשר צוה ד' אותם שקיימו המצוה כמאמרה כאשר נצטוו מפי השי"ת בחשק רב ובהתלהבות עצום, וכדי שלא תאמר שהן אמת שהי' הדבר בחסידות רב בתחלתו סמוך לציווי של הקב"ה, אבל אחר עשייתם קצת נתקררו ולא עשו כן כמו בתחלה לכן סיים כן עשו שבכל פעם ופעם עשו ממש כן כמו שהי' בתחלה .
translation: And this can be understood in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, that certainly at the time when Moses and Aaron were commanded by the Holy One, blessed be He, to fulfill their mission, they had a great enthusiasm and a strong desire to fulfill the will of their Creator. And until they came to the act, it could be said that they cooled down a bit, like all people, for there is no piety like at the beginning, and after an hour, he is not the same person he was at the beginning. Therefore, it says, "It is Aaron and Moses" whom the Lord spoke to them, etc., they are the ones speaking, etc., for they were commanded, and they fulfilled it exactly without any change, just as they were in great enthusiasm at the time they were commanded, so they were indeed at the time they fulfilled it, for even at the time of their fulfillment, the beginning of the matter was with them just as at the time they were commanded, like the sons of the righteous who at every moment see it as new. And then he added to say, "It is Aaron and Moses," as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained, they are in their righteousness from beginning to end. Do not say that only before they did anything did they not cool down from their enthusiasm, but after they did something of the Holy One's mission, their minds cooled down regarding this, and the fire of enthusiasm somewhat extinguished within them, like other people. Therefore, he said, "They are in their righteousness from beginning to end," that even at the end of their action, the fire burned within them as if they had not yet done anything, and they began then to do anew, and their righteousness and service were not diminished at all. And this is what is meant by "And Moses and Aaron did as the Lord commanded them," that they fulfilled the commandment as it was said, with great desire and immense enthusiasm. And so that you should not say that indeed the matter was with great piety at the beginning, close to the command of the Holy One, but after their action, they somewhat cooled down and did not do so as at the beginning, therefore it concludes, "So they did," that at every time they did indeed do just as they did at the beginning.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unwavering enthusiasm and dedication of Moses and Aaron in fulfilling God's commandments, suggesting that their fervor remained constant from the moment of their divine commissioning through the execution of their tasks. It highlights a key Hasidic concept that true righteousness and spiritual fervor do not diminish over time, as they maintained their initial zeal and commitment throughout their service. The text asserts that their actions were performed with the same intensity and passion as at the beginning, illustrating the ideal of continuous devotion in one's spiritual practice. Ultimately, it conveys that their righteousness and dedication were consistent and unchanging, embodying a model of steadfastness in faith and service.

passage_content: עוי"ל דהנה נודע בספה"ק אשר שני בחינות בעושי מצוה, דיש מי שעושה מצוה שמכריח את יצרו לעשות אבל לבו בל עמו ולא הגיע למדרגה זו שיהי' נכסוף ומשתוקק להמצוה באמת ויהי' צמאה נפשו לאלוקים בהרגש עריבות נעימות מתיקות המצוה , והן אמת כי גם זה חשוב לפני השי"ת אם מכריח את יצרו עכ"פ לעשות באיזה אופן שיהי', אבל זה אין בידו כ"א בשעה שעושה המצוה שאז מכריח את איבריו להעשי ', אבל אחר גמר עשותו כיון שהדבר הי' עליו לעול ויגיעה רבה, ממילא בשעה שהולך מהמצוה הוא כההולך ונפטר מעול ושיעבוד גדול ואין לו שייכות עוד עם המצוה , וכן קודם עשייתו בעת שלא הכריח עדיין את איבריו להמעשה אין בידו מאומה, אבל הבני עלי' וקדושי ה' הנכספים ומשתוקקים באמת, אשר מרוב התשוקה לא נחשב בעיניהם לעמל ויגיעה, וכמו שפי' זקיני הגה"ק זלה"ה בישמח משה (כי תשא ) דאצל החסידים ובני עלי' הפי' של וחי בהם ולא שימות בהם הוא בהיפך, ואין להם לבטל שום מצוה מחשש סכנה דכל חיותם הוא רק בהמצוה ואם לאו יפסק חיותם ח"ו מרוב השתוקקות להמצוה עיי"ש, ולפי"ז המה מקושרים ודבוקים במצות הבוית"ש גם לפני עשייתה ואף לאחרי' מרוב השתוקקותם לעשותה ולקיים רצון הבוית"ש .
translation:
It is known in the holy books that there are two aspects among those who perform a mitzvah. There are those who perform a mitzvah by forcing their yetzer (evil inclination) to act, but their heart is not with them, and they have not reached the level of truly yearning and desiring the mitzvah. Their soul does not thirst for God with the feeling of the sweetness and pleasantness of the mitzvah. And it is true that this is also important before the Holy One, blessed be He, if they at least force their yetzer to do so in some way. However, this is only in their control at the moment they are performing the mitzvah, when they force their limbs to act. But after they have completed the mitzvah, since the act was a burden and a great toil for them, it follows that at the moment they walk away from the mitzvah, they are like one who is walking away and freed from a great burden and servitude, and they no longer have any connection to the mitzvah. Likewise, before performing it, when they have not yet forced their limbs to act, they have no control whatsoever. 

But the elevated and holy ones, who truly yearn and desire, for whom the great longing makes the toil and effort insignificant in their eyes, as explained by my revered grandfather, the holy Gaon, in "Yismach Moshe" (Ki Tisa), that for the righteous and the elevated, the interpretation of "and they shall live by them" is the opposite, and they do not cancel any mitzvah for fear of danger, for all their life is only in the mitzvah, and if not, their life would cease, God forbid, from their great yearning for the mitzvah. According to this, they are connected and attached to the mitzvah of the Holy One, blessed be He, even before performing it, and even after, due to their great longing to fulfill it and to carry out the will of the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses two types of individuals who perform commandments: those who do so out of obligation, feeling burdened and disconnected from the spiritual essence of the mitzvah, and those who are truly passionate and yearn for the commandments, viewing them as a source of life and joy. The latter group, referred to as the "holy ones," experiences a deep connection to God through their fervent desire to fulfill His will, making the act of performing a mitzvah a vital part of their existence. This profound longing transforms their relationship with the commandments, allowing them to remain spiritually connected both before and after the act, as their lives are intertwined with the divine will.

passage_content: ובבחינה זו אמרתי לפרש מה שאמר דהע"ה שש אנכי על אמרתך כמוצא שלל רב דקשה לכאורה הלא כתיב טוב לי תורת פיך מאלפי זהב וכסף וכל חפציך לא ישוו בה, ומה דמיון וערוך להתוה"ק עם מציאת שלל רב והול"ל יותר ממוצא שלל רב, ועפ"י הנ"ל אפשר לומר דלא בא לדמות התוה"ק למציאת שלל רב בענין יקרת הערך, ואך בא להבינינו בזה האיך הי' שש ושמח בהתוה"ק אף שהוא באמת עבודה קשה ויגיעה רבה ואין התורה מתקיימת אלא במי שממית עצמו עלי' ולשמחה מה זו עושה, אמנם הדבר יובן לסתם בני אדם בעת שמוצא שלל רב ויוכל למלאות את ביתו בכסף וזהב ואבנים טובים ומרגליות, הנה אף שהוא עבודה קשה לילך כל היום וכל הלילה לישא משא הכסף והזהב על כתיפו אל תוך ביתו, עכ"ז תקטן בעיניו כל היגיעה ולא ירגיש שום צער בעמלו וליאותו , לרוב הרצון והחשק למלא את ביתו בכל טוב, ואדרבה כבד הוא בעיניו להניח רגע אחת מלישא משא ההוא שעי"ז יחסר לו מהטובה שיוכל להביא לביתו בזמן ההוא, ובזה מובן שהצדיקים הגדולים אשר כל טוב שבעוה"ז אפי' שבעוה"ב לא נחשב אצלם נגד תענוג קיום התורה והמצות, וכמו שפי' ביערות דבש דברי חז"ל יפה שעה אחת בתשובה ומע"ט מכל חיי העוה"ב, דמדקאמר יפה שעה אחת וכו' ש"מ דהוא גם יפה בתענוגים ומתוק יותר מכל חיי העוה"ב עכ"ד, א"כ לא נחשב אצלם שום צער ויגיעה לרוב המתיקות ואדרבה קשה בעיניהם לעזוב רגע, אף כי רחוקים אנחנו ממדה זו אבל כן העידו רבותינו זלה"ה בספה"ק על הצדיקים האמיתים , וז"ש שש אנכי על אמרתיך וכ"ת לרוב הצער והיגיעה לשמחה מה זו עושה ע"ז אמר לראי' כמוצא שלל רב שאין נחשב ליגיעה בדבר שיש בו רצון אמיתי.
translation: In this regard, I said to explain what the holy author said, that "I am joyful over Your word, like one who finds great spoil." It seems difficult, for it is written, "Your Torah is better to me than thousands of gold and silver," and all Your desires cannot be compared to it. What similarity and comparison is there between the holy Torah and finding great spoil? It should have been stated more than "like one who finds great spoil." According to the above, one can say that he did not come to compare the holy Torah to finding great spoil in terms of its precious value, but rather to help us understand how he was joyful and happy with the holy Torah, even though it is indeed hard work and great toil, and the Torah is only sustained by one who gives his life for it. And what joy does this bring? However, this can be understood by ordinary people when they find great spoil and can fill their house with silver and gold and precious stones and jewels. Even though it is hard work to walk all day and all night carrying the burden of silver and gold on their shoulders into their home, nevertheless, all the toil seems small in their eyes, and they do not feel any pain from their labor and fatigue, due to the great desire and eagerness to fill their house with all good things. On the contrary, it is heavy in their eyes to stop for even a moment from carrying that burden, for thereby they would miss out on the good they could bring home at that time. In this, it is understood that the great righteous ones, for whom all the good of this world, even of the World to Come, is not considered against the pleasure of fulfilling the Torah and the commandments, as explained in Yaarot Dvash, that the words of our sages are "One hour of repentance and good deeds is better than all the life of the World to Come," for since it says "better one hour," it implies that it is also better in pleasures and sweeter than all the life of the World to Come. Therefore, no pain or toil is considered by them due to the great sweetness, and on the contrary, it is hard for them to leave it for even a moment. Although we are far from this measure, our sages, may their memory be blessed, have testified in the holy books about the true righteous ones. And this is what is meant by "I am joyful over Your word," for in light of the great pain and toil, what joy does this bring? To this, he said, "like one who finds great spoil," for toil is not considered in a matter that has true desire.
summary: In this passage, the author explores the joy derived from the study of Torah, comparing it to the exhilaration of discovering great treasure. He emphasizes that, despite the hard work and effort required to engage with Torah, the profound pleasure and fulfillment it brings far outweighs any toil involved. The text highlights that for true tzaddikim (righteous individuals), the spiritual rewards of Torah and mitzvot are so significant that they perceive no burden in their efforts, akin to a treasure hunter who disregards fatigue for the sake of acquiring wealth. Ultimately, the joy of engaging with divine teachings transcends worldly gains, illustrating a deep connection between spiritual fulfillment and the experience of true happiness.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי קודש רש"י ז"ל הוא משה ואהרן, הם בשליחותם ובצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף דלגודל תשוקתם לעשות רצון קונם היו שווים בשליחותם וצדקתם מתחלה ועד סוף ואף לפני העשי' ואף לאחר שהשלימו שליחותם לא יעפו ולא יגעו ונכספה וכלתה נפשם לקראת המצוה ונחשב להם כל שעה כאלו עשוהו, וז"ש ויעש משה ואהרן כאשר צוה ד' אותם כן עשו, שנחשב להם עשי' זו בהוה כאלו כן עשו תמידי לרוב הרצון והחפץ בה, והבן.
translation: And in this, the holy words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: he (Moses) and Aaron, in their mission and righteousness from beginning to end, due to their great desire to fulfill the will of their Creator, were equal in their mission and righteousness from beginning to end. Even before the action and even after they completed their mission, they did not falter or stray, and their souls longed and yearned for the commandment, and every hour was considered as if they had performed it. Therefore, it is said, "And Moses and Aaron did as the Lord commanded them; so they did," which is considered for them as if they had always done it, due to their great will and desire for it. Understand this.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unwavering dedication of Moses and Aaron in fulfilling God's commandments, highlighting their equal commitment and righteousness from beginning to end. Their intense desire to perform God's will is so profound that every moment of their service is considered as if they are continuously engaged in the act. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the eternal significance of intention and devotion in spiritual practice, suggesting that their longing for the mitzvah elevates their actions to a perpetual state of fulfillment.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה ואל אהרן לאמר כי ידבר אליכם פרעה לאמר תנו לכם מופת ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך והשלך לפני פרעה יהי לתנין וגו' ויקרא גם פרעה לחכמים ולמכשפים ויעשו גם הם וגו' ויבלע מטה אהרן את מטותם , במד"ר (פר' ט' סי' ז') הה"ד (משלי כ"ט) כל רוחו יוציא כסיל וחכם באחור ישבחנה , כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה שהי' מלעיג על הקב"ה, שהי' סבור שמעשה כשפים הן מה שעשו משה ואהרן, וקרא לכל בני ביתו לעשות כמותם, הוי כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה, וחכם באחור ישבחנה זה הקב"ה שנאמר חכם לבב ואמיץ כח וכו ', אר"י ב"ר חנינא נס גדול נעשה במטה שאע"פ שבלע כל אותן המטות שהשליכו, שהיו רבים לעשות מהן עשרה עומרין ולא הועבה, וכל מי שרואה אותה אומר זה מטה אהרן, מכאן שהי' מטה אהרן סימן טוב לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות לדורות וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין הלא לא עביד קוב"ה ניסא למגנא , ומה הי' צורך לנס זה שלא הועבה המטה ממה שהי' ואיך הוא סימן טוב לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות לדורות.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, saying, "When Pharaoh speaks to you, saying, 'Give yourselves a sign,' you shall say to Aaron, 'Take your staff and throw it before Pharaoh; it shall become a serpent,' etc. And Pharaoh also called for the wise men and the sorcerers, and they did the same, etc. And Aaron's staff swallowed their staffs." In the Midrash (Parashat 9, Section 7), it is stated (Proverbs 29), "The fool utters all his mind, but a wise man keeps it in until afterwards." The fool who utters all his mind refers to Pharaoh, who mocked the Holy One, Blessed be He, thinking that the acts of sorcery performed by Moses and Aaron were mere magic. He called all his household to do likewise. Thus, "The fool utters all his mind" refers to Pharaoh, and "A wise man keeps it in until afterwards" refers to the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "A wise heart and strong in power," etc. Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Chanina, a great miracle was performed with the staff, for although it swallowed all those staffs that were thrown down, which were many enough to make ten measures, it was not thickened. And anyone who sees it says, "This is Aaron's staff." From here, it is evident that Aaron's staff was a good sign for performing miracles and wonders for generations, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not perform miracles for mere protection, and what was the need for this miracle that the staff was not thickened from what it was, and how is it a good sign for performing miracles and wonders for generations?
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between God, Moses, and Aaron highlights Pharaoh's arrogance and disbelief in God's power, as he equates the miracles performed by Moses and Aaron with mere sorcery. The Midrash emphasizes that despite the many staffs thrown down by the magicians, Aaron's staff swallowed them without losing its original form, symbolizing God's supremacy and the enduring nature of His miracles. This incident serves as a sign of divine favor, indicating that Aaron's staff would be a vessel for performing wonders throughout generations. The text invites reflection on the necessity of such miracles and their role in affirming God's authority in the face of human skepticism.

passage_content: ב) ילקוט (רמז קפ"א) כי ידבר אליכם פרעה לאמר תנו לכם מופת, א"ל למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים ואני נותן להם את התורה שנאמר בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא וגו' ונתן אליך אות או מופת, וצ"ב איך שייכא מצות הנביא שעתידה להינתן במ"ת אל מה שיאמר פרעה תנו לכם מופת.
translation: B) Yalkut (Remez 151) "When Pharaoh speaks to you saying, 'Give yourselves a sign,' he said to them, 'Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt and I will give them the Torah,' as it is stated, 'For a prophet will arise among you...' and he will give you a sign or a wonder." And it is to be pondered how the commandment of the prophet that is destined to be given at the Giving of the Torah is related to what Pharaoh says, "Give yourselves a sign."
summary: The passage discusses the connection between Pharaoh's demand for a sign and the future giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai. It highlights the significance of prophetic authority, suggesting that the miracles performed by Moses serve as a precursor to the divine revelation of the Torah. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the signs and wonders are not merely for validation but are integral to the unfolding of spiritual truths and the establishment of a covenantal relationship between God and the Israelites. The inquiry into the relationship between Pharaoh's request and the future commandments emphasizes the continuity of divine communication through signs and the role of prophecy in guiding the people.

passage_content: ונראה ביאור הענין דהנה איתא במדרש ילקוט (שם) כיון שהלכו משה ואהרן אצל פרעה אמר להם תנו לכם מופת מיד וישלך אהרן את מטהו, באותה שעה שחק פרעה אליהם, א"ל למה אתם סבורים שבאתם לשחק עלי, איני מתיירא מן הדברים האלו וכו ', שקרא לאשתו וא"ל ראו האיך באו היהודים לשחק בי וכו ', ולכאורה הוא פליאה עצומה למה עשה ה' ככה לצוות את משה ואהרן לעשות מופת זה לפני פרעה, הלא קמי שמיא גליא שפרעה יתלוצץ ממופת זה, ובפרט שמשה ואהרן באו לעורר את ישראל על התשובה לפרוש מדרכי ע"ז ושיאמינו בהקב"ה ובנפלאותיו, וכאן ראו שאותם האותות שעשו משה ואהרן בשליחות הקב"ה עשו גם פרעה והחרטומים, הגם שאח"כ נתברר במה שבלע מטה אהרן את מטותם שמעשה אהרן לא הי' ח"ו מעשה כשפים. אבל עד שנתברר הדבר היו יכולים ישראל לבוא ח"ו לידי ספיקות באמונת השי"ת, והי' העדר כבוד שמים באותו שעה שהתלוצץ פרעה עליהם והכל גלוי לפניו ית ' ומדוע ציום ית ' לעשות מופת זה
translation: And it seems to clarify the matter, for it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (there) that when Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, he said to them, "Give yourselves a sign immediately," and Aaron threw down his staff. At that moment, Pharaoh laughed at them, saying, "Why do you think you have come to mock me? I am not afraid of these things," etc. He called to his wife and said, "Look how the Jews have come to mock me," etc. And at first glance, it is a tremendous wonder why the Holy One, blessed be He, did this, commanding Moses and Aaron to perform this sign before Pharaoh, for it is clear before Heaven that Pharaoh would scoff at this sign. Especially since Moses and Aaron came to awaken Israel to repentance, to turn away from the ways of idolatry and to believe in the Holy One, blessed be He, and His wonders. And here they saw that the same signs that Moses and Aaron performed at the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, were also performed by Pharaoh and the magicians, even though it was later clarified when Aaron's staff swallowed their staffs that Aaron's act was not, Heaven forbid, an act of sorcery. But until the matter was clarified, the Israelites could, Heaven forbid, have come to doubts about their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, and there would have been a lack of the honor of Heaven at that moment when Pharaoh mocked them, and everything is revealed before Him, blessed be He. And why did He command them to perform this sign?
summary: The passage discusses the perplexity of God's command to Moses and Aaron to perform a miracle before Pharaoh, knowing that Pharaoh would mock them. It highlights the concern that this mockery could lead the Israelites to doubt their faith in God, especially since Pharaoh's magicians could replicate the signs. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the importance of faith and the divine plan, as Aaron's staff ultimately devours the magicians' staffs, reaffirming God's supremacy and the authenticity of His miracles.

passage_content: אמנם עניינו הוא שהי' גלוי וידוע לפני מי שאמר והי' העולם שיהי' זמן שיבואו ישראל לידי נסיון כזה כמ"ש כי יקום בקרבך נביא או חולם חלום ונתן אליך אות או מופת וגו', ויעמדו נביאי שקר בישראל ויבררו ע"י אותות ומופתים שמצות ה' לעבוד ע"ז או להתחבר לעובדי ע"ז ח"ו, וניתן מן השמים כח לשטן לעשות אותות ומופתים, וכמו שמצינו בחטא העגל שהשטן הי' מראה לפניהם שמשה רבינו מת ומוטל במטה, ובזה הטעה את ישראל לע"ז, וכדומה מנסיונות אחרים שמביא השטן ע"י אותות ומופתים, והנה איתא במדרש (פ' אחרי) אחרי מות שני בני אהרן, מלה"ד לרופא שנכנס אצל החולה א"ל אל תשתה צונן ואל תשכב בטחב, בא אחר וא"ל אל תשתה צונן ואל תשכב בטחב שמא תמות כדרך שמת פלוני, זה זרזו יותר מן הראשון וכו' לכך נאמר אחרי מות שני בני אהרן עכ"ד המדרש, וענין המשל הזה דטבע בני האדם כן שאם מזהירים בו ומראים לו דוגמא שכבר הי' כמוהו נתפעל יותר ונחקק האזהרה בלבו יותר להשמר ממנו וכמו"כ לעניננו שהתוה"ק מזהיר אותנו שלא נתפעל מאותות ומופתים שהם לעבור על התוה"ק באיזה אופן שיהיו א"כ יקשו קושיא גדולה מדוע לא הסיר ה' הכח מנביא השקר לעשות האות והמופת לבל יטעו ישראל מאחרי ה', ולמה ניתן כח ויכולת לכוחות הטומאה שיעשו אות זה, אמנם נתן הכתוב טעם כי מנסה ה' אלקיכם אתכם וגו' ולזה הראה לנו התוה"ק דוגמא שכבר נהי' כמוהו שפרעה וכת דילי' עשו אותן המופתים ממש מה שעשו משה ואהרן בשליחות הקב"ה, ונתגלה אח"כ שהמופתים שלהם אין בהם ממש, וכן הוא בכל המופתים שבאים מכוחות הטומאה, יתברר לאחר זמן שאין בהם ממש ויתבטלו כחרס הנשבר.
translation:
Indeed, the matter is that it was revealed and known before He who said and the world was, that there would be a time when Israel would come to such a trial, as it is written, "If a prophet arises among you or a dreamer of dreams and gives you a sign or a wonder," etc. False prophets will stand in Israel and will prove through signs and wonders that it is a command of the Lord to serve idols or to join with idol worshippers, Heaven forbid. And power is given from Heaven to the Satan to perform signs and wonders, as we find in the sin of the Golden Calf, where the Satan showed them that Moses our teacher had died and was lying in the grave, and by this he misled Israel to idol worship. Similarly, there are other trials that the Satan brings through signs and wonders. 

And it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Acharei) after the death of the two sons of Aaron, a parable of a doctor who entered to see a sick person and said to him, "Do not drink cold water and do not lie on damp ground." Another came and said to him, "Do not drink cold water and do not lie on damp ground, lest you die as so-and-so died." This second warning had a greater effect than the first, etc. Therefore, it is said, "After the death of the two sons of Aaron," thus concludes the Midrash. 

And the matter of this parable is that it is human nature that if one is warned and shown an example of something that has already happened, he is more affected and the warning is more deeply engraved in his heart to guard against it. Likewise, in our matter, the Holy Torah warns us not to be swayed by signs and wonders that lead to transgressing the Holy Torah in any way. Therefore, a great question arises: why did the Lord not remove the power from the false prophet to perform the sign and wonder so that Israel would not be misled from following the Lord? And why was power and ability given to the forces of impurity to perform this sign? 

However, the scripture provides a reason: "For the Lord your God is testing you," etc. And for this, the Holy Torah showed us an example that has already occurred, that Pharaoh and his faction performed the very same wonders that Moses and Aaron did by the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and it was later revealed that their wonders were without substance. And so it is with all the wonders that come from the forces of impurity; it will be clarified after a time that they are without substance and will be nullified like a broken shard.
summary: The passage discusses the divine allowance for false prophets and the power of evil forces to perform signs and wonders, which can lead the Jewish people astray from the commandments of the Torah. It emphasizes that such trials are a test from God, as illustrated by past events like the sin of the Golden Calf. The text reassures that, ultimately, the false signs will be proven meaningless and will fail, similar to the magicians of Pharaoh who could not match the true miracles of Moses and Aaron. This serves as a warning to remain steadfast in faith and not be swayed by deceptive miracles.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש כי ידבר אליכם פרעה לאמר תנו לכם מופת ואמרת אל אהרן קח את מטך וגו'. דקשה ע"ז קושיא גדולה למה צוה ה' לעשות מופת זה, וקמי שמיא גליא שיתלוצץ פרעה עליו, ע"ז מתרץ המדרש א"ל למחר אני מוציאם ממצרים ואני נותן להם את התורה שנאמר בה כי יקום בקרבך נביא וגו' ונתן אליך אות או מופת ולטעם זה צוה ה' לעשות אות זה, כדי ללמוד לישראל שלא יתפעלו מאותות ומופתים, והראה להם דוגמתו שפרעה הרשע עשה זה המופת עצמו שעשה משה ואהרן ונתברר זיופו לבסוף.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash, for Pharaoh will speak to you saying, "Give yourselves a sign," and you shall say to Aaron, "Take your staff," etc. There is a great difficulty regarding this: why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, command to perform this sign? And it is clear from Heaven that Pharaoh would mock him. To this, the Midrash answers: He said to them, "Tomorrow I will take them out of Egypt and I will give them the Torah, as it is said, 'If a prophet arises among you'... and gives you a sign or a wonder." And for this reason, the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded to perform this sign, to teach Israel not to be swayed by signs and wonders, and He showed them an example that the wicked Pharaoh performed the very same sign that Moses and Aaron did, and in the end, its falseness was revealed.
summary: The passage discusses the command from God to perform a miracle as a response to Pharaoh's demand for a sign. It raises the question of why God would instruct this, given that it would allow Pharaoh to mock the miracle. The Midrash explains that this was intended to teach the Israelites not to be swayed by signs and wonders, as Pharaoh, despite performing similar miracles, ultimately revealed their falsehood. This emphasizes the importance of faith and discernment over mere reliance on miraculous signs.

passage_content: והנה מדרך הסט"א לטשטש הגבולין ולהראות על אותות ומופתים של שקר שהוא אמת, ולהיפוך על מופת אמיתי מהקב"ה מסית לומר שמעשה כשפים הוא וכדרך שאמרו המצריים, ובזה יובן למה הוצרך לנס זה שלא הועבה המטה, דאמרז"ל שמטה אהרן הוא המטה שעתיד מלך המשיח לעשות בו נסים ונפלאות, ולזה אלמלי הועבה אחר שבלע מעות החרטומים: הי' להרשעים מקום לומר, שנכנס בו מכח מטותם , ובכח הזה נעשו בו נסים ונפלאות ואינם מצד הקדושה ח"ו, ע"כ עשה הקב"ה נס שלא הועבה מטה אהרן כלל למען יתברר שאין לצד הסט"א שום אחיזה בו, ומטה הזה שהוא כולו מצד הקדושה יהי' ביד מלך המשיח, ובו יעשה נסים ונפלאות, גם במה שבלע מטה אהרן מטותם ולא הועבה, נתברר שאין קיום להניסים והמופתים שנעשו ע"י כוחות הטומאה וסופם שיתבטלו מן העולם, וז"פ דברי המדרש כל רוחו יוציא כסיל זה פרעה שהוא מרכבה לסט"א הנקרא זקן וכסיל, והתגבר בכל כוחותיו להטעות את ישראל ע"י אותות ומופתים המדומים, אבל חכם באחור ישבחנה זה הקב"ה שנאמר חכם לבב ואמיץ כח . ולבסוף נתגדל עי"ז כבוד שמים ונתברר שאין באותותם ממש, והמאמין בהקב"ה צריך להמתין על ישועת השי"ת הבא באחרונה ולא להתפתות מנסים המדומים של כוחות הסט"א שסופם כלה ונאבד כעפרא דארעא, ורק ישועה הבא מצד הקדושה בדרך התוה"ק הוא ישועה אמיתית ונצחי, הבוכ"ע יעזור שנזכה להיות דבוק בהקב"ה ובתורתו הק ' ולראות בישועה שלימה ולא נהי' מן הנדחים ח"ו, וכאשר ראינו כל הצרות והשפלות כך נזכה לראות בשמחתן של ישראל כשיתרומם קרן התורה וישראל, השי"ת יעזור שנוושע במהרה בישועה שלימה ולראות בישועת ישראל ושמחתן ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And behold, it is the way of the Sitra Achra to blur the boundaries and to show false signs and wonders as if they are true, and to turn a true miracle from the Holy One, Blessed be He, into a claim that it is sorcery, as the Egyptians said. And this explains why this miracle was needed, that the staff was not thickened, for our Sages have said that the staff of Aaron is the staff with which the King Messiah will perform miracles and wonders. Therefore, had it been thickened after it swallowed the rods of the magicians, the wicked would have had a reason to say that it was empowered by their rods, and that through this power, miracles and wonders were performed, and they are not from holiness, Heaven forbid. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed a miracle that the staff of Aaron was not thickened at all, so that it would be clear that the Sitra Achra has no hold on it. This staff, which is entirely from holiness, will be in the hand of the King Messiah, and with it, he will perform miracles and wonders. Also, in that the staff of Aaron swallowed their rods and was not thickened, it was made clear that there is no permanence to the miracles and signs that were performed by the forces of impurity, and their end will be that they will be nullified from the world. And this is the meaning of the words of the Midrash: "Every spirit will expel this fool, Pharaoh, who is a chariot of the Sitra Achra, called old and foolish," and he strengthened himself with all his powers to deceive Israel through the false signs and wonders. But a wise person will praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "A wise heart and strong in power." And in the end, through this, the honor of Heaven will be magnified, and it will be made clear that their signs have no substance. The believer in the Holy One, Blessed be He, must wait for the salvation of the Blessed One that will come in the end and not be tempted by the false signs of the forces of the Sitra Achra, whose end is to perish and be lost like dust of the earth. Only the salvation that comes from holiness, through the path of the Holy Torah, is true and eternal salvation. May the Blessed One help us to merit being attached to the Holy One, Blessed be He, and to His holy Torah, and to see complete salvation and not to be among the castaways, Heaven forbid. And as we have seen all the troubles and humiliations, so may we merit to see the joy of Israel when the horn of the Torah and Israel is uplifted. May the Blessed One help us to be saved quickly with complete salvation and to see the salvation of Israel and their joy, and the revelation of the honor of Heaven upon us speedily in our days. Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the struggle between divine truth and the deceptive powers of the "Sitra Achra" (the Other Side), which seeks to blur the boundaries of reality by presenting false miracles as truth. It highlights that Aaron's staff, which is rooted in holiness, was not transformed by the sorcerers' powers, thereby demonstrating that true miracles come solely from God. The text encourages believers to remain steadfast in their faith and await genuine salvation from God, rather than being swayed by the illusions of false powers, ultimately affirming that true redemption will arise from holiness and the teachings of the Torah. The passage concludes with a hopeful prayer for the ultimate redemption and the revelation of God's glory.

passage_content: ויחפרו כל מצרים סביבות היאור מים לשתות וגו' כתב האבן עזרא ז"ל רבים אומרים כי המים היו ביד המצרי אדומים כדם ונתלבנו ביד הישראלי, א"כ למה לא נכתב אות זה בתורה, ומכח קושיא זו הכריח לומר כי מכת הדם והצפרדעים והכניס היתה כוללת המצריים והעבריים, וכן בשאר מכות חוץ מג' שמפורש בכתוב שהובדלו מהם ישראל, והם ערוב דכתיב והפלתי וגו', ובמכת דבר כתיב והפלה ה' בין מקנה מצרים וגו', ובברד כתיב רק בארץ גושן אשר שם בנ"י לא הי' ברד עכת"ד, וכתב האבי עזרי על דברי הראב"ע הנ"ל, אנו אין לנו אלא דברי רז"ל כי ממכת דם נתעשרו ישראל, ואפי' נכרי וישראל שותין בספל א', הי' חציו דם וחציו מים, ולפי דעתי תלמיד טועה ועני בדעת כתב הדברים האלה וכו '. וכן דעת כל המפרשים ז"ל, אמנם לדבריהם יקשה קושית הראב"ע ז"ל מדוע העלים הכתוב נס נפלא כזה שהי' במכת דם, שהובדלו ישראל כ"כ, עד שאפי' מצרי וישראל שותין בספל א' הי' חציו מים וחציו דם, ולא מצינו דוגמתו בכל המכות, וטעמא בעי שהעלימו הכתוב.
translation: And all of Egypt dug around the Nile for water to drink, etc. The Aben Ezra, may his memory be blessed, wrote that many say the water was in the hands of the Egyptians red as blood and became clear in the hands of the Israelites. If so, why is this not written in the Torah? And because of this difficulty, one is compelled to say that the plagues of blood, frogs, and lice included both Egyptians and Hebrews, as well as in the other plagues, except for the three that are explicitly stated in the text to have separated Israel from them, which are the mixture, as it is written, "And I will make a distinction," etc., and in the plague of livestock, it is written, "And the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Egypt," etc., and in the hail, it is written, "Only in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel were, there was no hail," thus it is said. And the Aben Ezra wrote on the words of the Aben Ezra mentioned above, we have only the words of our Sages, for from the plague of blood, the Israelites became wealthy, and even if a foreigner and an Israelite drink from one cup, it was half blood and half water. In my opinion, a student who is mistaken and poor in understanding wrote these words, etc. And so is the opinion of all the commentators, may their memory be blessed. However, according to their words, the difficulty of the Aben Ezra, may his memory be blessed, is why the text concealed such a wondrous miracle that occurred in the plague of blood, that Israel was so separated that even if an Egyptian and an Israelite drank from one cup, it was half water and half blood, and we do not find a similar case in all the plagues, and a reason is needed for why the text concealed it.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the plagues in Egypt, particularly the plague of blood, suggesting that both Egyptians and Israelites experienced the plague, albeit in different ways. It highlights a debate among commentators regarding the miraculous distinction made for the Israelites, who were said to have benefited from the plague, even sharing a cup with Egyptians that contained both blood and water. The text emphasizes the theological significance of divine intervention, where the Israelites were set apart during the plagues, showcasing God's protection and favor towards them. Ultimately, it raises questions about why such a profound miracle was not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, inviting deeper reflection on the nature of divine signs and their implications for faith.

passage_content: והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב במכת ערוב עה"פ והפלתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו', בעבור היות המכות הראשונות עומדות, איננו פלא שיהיו בארץ מצרים ולא בארץ גושן, אבל זו מכה משולחת וכאשר יעלו החיות מהררי נמרים וכו' ראוי הי' בטבעם שיבואו גם בארץ גושן אשר היא מכלל ארץ מצרים, לכך הוצרך והפלתי את ארץ גושן שתנצל כולה וכו' וכמו"כ נתן הרמב"ן ז"ל טעם במכת דבר וברד שהוצרך הכתוב לפרש שלא שלטו בישראל לצד הפלא שבהם עיי"ש, משא"כ בשאר המכות לא הי' פלא שהובדלו ישראל מהם, ע"כ לא הוצרך הכתוב לפרש את"ד ז"ל, הנה גם לדבריו יקשה ממכת דם, שהי' נס ההבדלה בו מופלג יותר מבערוב ודבר וברד, ומ"ט לא הודיע הכתוב נס ההבדלה בו כדרך שנתפרש בהם.
translation: And the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote regarding the plague of frogs on the verse "And I will set apart that day the land of Goshen," that since the first plagues were standing, it is not surprising that they were in the land of Egypt and not in the land of Goshen. However, this plague is unleashed, and when the beasts rise from the mountains of leopards, it would be natural for them to also come into the land of Goshen, which is part of the land of Egypt. Therefore, it was necessary to set apart the land of Goshen so that it would be entirely saved. Similarly, the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, gave a reason for the plagues of pestilence and hail, that the scripture needed to explain that they did not prevail over Israel due to the wonder in them, as mentioned there. In contrast, regarding the other plagues, it was not surprising that Israel was separated from them; therefore, the scripture did not need to explain this. However, according to his words, it is difficult regarding the plague of blood, where the miracle of separation was even more pronounced than in the plagues of frogs, pestilence, and hail. Why then did the scripture not inform us of the miracle of separation in the same way it was explained regarding them?
summary: The passage discusses the Ramban's interpretation of the plagues in Egypt, particularly focusing on the distinction between the plagues that affected the Egyptians and those that spared the Israelites in Goshen. It emphasizes that while the first plagues were naturally confined to Egypt, the later plagues, such as the swarms of animals, required divine intervention to ensure that Goshen remained untouched. The Ramban highlights the miraculous nature of the plagues, noting that the separation of the Israelites from the Egyptians was a significant wonder, especially in the case of the plague of blood, which was not explicitly detailed in the same way as the other plagues. This reflects a deeper theological insight into God's active role in protecting His people amidst judgment.
