passage_content: ואפ"ל בדרך פשטות עפי"מ שנתנו חז"ל ( במד"ר פר' ט' סי' ט') טעם למכת דם, מפני שמצרים עבדו לנילוס לפיכך הלקה את יראתם ואח"כ הלקה אותם ולהראות ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו ממש את"ד ז"ל, והנה היו רבים מבנ"י שנתפסו גם לע"ז במצרים כמבואר בדרז"ל , ואפשר דלאותן שעבדו ע"ז לא נעשה להם נס ההבדלה, ואף המים שבידם הי' לדם, להראות להם ביטולה של ע"ז שאין בו ממש, ומ"ש רז"ל שהיו המים נעשו לדם ביד המצרי ונתהפכו למים ביד הישראל, זה הי' רק בבנ"י הכשרים שהובדלו מכל בחי' ע"ז. ע"כ לא הי' צורך אצלם להראות ביטולה של ע"ז ע"י שיתהפכו לדם, דמיד שבא לידם נתבטל כל בחי' ע"ז שבו, וארז"ל בגמ' (ע"ז נ"ג ע"א) בעכו"ם שמכר או משכן ע"ז לצורף ישראל ד"ה ביטל, דמידע ידע דהאי תבר לה, וכתבו התוס ' לאו דוקא צורף, דכל ישראל לגבי ע"ז כצורפין עיי"ש, ולפי"ז אפשר שלא הובדלו כל ישראל ממכת הדם, כי אלו שהיו מודים בע"ז גם בידם נעשו המים לדם, לפי שהיו המים מבחי ' ע"ז, ואולי דמ"ש הראב"ע ששלטה מכת הדם גם בישראל, הכוונה ששלטה במקצתן , ואינו סתירה למ"ש רז"ל שהי' ביד מצרי דם וביד ישראל מים, כי זה הי' רק בבנ"י הכשרים שכפרו בע"ז, ואולי לטעם זה לא פי' הכתוב נס ההבדלה במכת דם, מפני שלא הי' בכל ישראל שוה , ולעשות הפרש בין ישראל לא רצתה התוה"ק לדבר בגנותן של ישראל, ע"כ לא גילה הכתוב נס ההבדלה בו כלל, ואולי עד"ז בשאר המכות שלא פירש הכתוב נס ההבדלה בהם, היו שולטים גם בבנ"י במקצתם באותן שלא פירשו מע"ז, רק בערוב דבר וברד ביאר הכתוב שלא שלטו בבנ"י כלל ולפי"ז יתיישבו דברי הראב"ע ז"ל להסיר ממנו הסתירה מדרז"ל .
translation: And even though, in a simple manner, according to what our Sages have given (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'era, Section 9), the reason for the plague of blood was because the Egyptians worshipped the Nile, therefore it struck their fear, and afterwards it struck them, to demonstrate the nullification of idolatry, which has no substance, as our Sages said. And behold, there were many from the children of Israel who were also caught up in idolatry in Egypt, as explained in the teachings of our Sages. It is possible that for those who served idolatry, a miracle of separation was not performed for them, and even the water in their hands turned to blood, to show them the nullification of idolatry, which has no substance. And what our Sages said that the water turned to blood in the hands of the Egyptian and was transformed back to water in the hands of the Israelite, this was only for the righteous among the children of Israel who were separated from all aspects of idolatry. Therefore, there was no need for them to demonstrate the nullification of idolatry by turning to blood, for as soon as it came into their hands, all aspects of idolatry within it were nullified. And our Sages said in the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 53a) regarding a non-Jew who sold or mortgaged an idol to a Jewish silversmith, it is nullified, for he knows that this is a loss for him. And the Tosafot wrote that this is not specifically about a silversmith, for all Jews regarding idolatry are like silversmiths, as stated there. According to this, it is possible that not all of Israel were separated from the plague of blood, for those who acknowledged idolatry also had the water in their hands turn to blood, since the water was from the aspect of idolatry. And perhaps what the Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra wrote, that the plague of blood also ruled over Israel, means that it ruled over some of them, and this does not contradict what our Sages said that there was blood in the hands of the Egyptian and water in the hands of the Israelite, for this was only among the righteous children of Israel who denied idolatry. And perhaps for this reason the scripture did not explain the miracle of separation in the plague of blood, because it was not the same for all of Israel, and the Holy Torah did not want to speak negatively about Israel to make a distinction between them. Therefore, the scripture did not reveal the miracle of separation in it at all, and perhaps similarly in the other plagues where the scripture did not explain the miracle of separation in them, they also ruled over some of the children of Israel among those who did not separate from idolatry. Only in the case of the mixed multitude and the hail did the scripture clarify that they did not rule over the children of Israel at all, and according to this, the words of Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra can be reconciled to remove the contradiction from the teachings of our Sages.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the plagues in Egypt, particularly the plague of blood, emphasizing the distinction between the Israelites who rejected idolatry and those who did not. It suggests that those Israelites who were still attached to idolatry experienced the plague as well, as their water turned to blood, reflecting the lack of true substance in idolatry. The text highlights that the miraculous separation between the Egyptians and the Israelites was not universally applicable, as it depended on the spiritual state of the individuals. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that the plagues served to demonstrate the futility of idolatry and the importance of faithfulness to God among the Israelites.

passage_content: ואפ"ל לאידך גיסא עפימ"ש האוהחה"ק עה"פ ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים וגו', לפי דבריהם ז"ל שהיו כל מימי מצרים לדם, א"כ מנין מצאו מים להפכו לדם וכו ', ותירץ עפימ"ש רז"ל כי ישראל נתעשרו ממכת היאור שהיו מוכרים מים למצרים וכו ', כפי זה עשו החרטומים מהנמכר להם עכ"ד ז"ל, והנה כח הזה שניתן להחרטומים לעשות מופת הדם בכשפים, הי' בכח הסט"א וע"צ הנסיון וע"ד שביארנו בנס המטה עיי"ש, ואפשר דאלו שהיו שותין בספל א' עם המצרי היו קרובים לדעתם ושיטתם, ומכרו להם מים לכוונה זו להראות מופת הדם בכשפים ולהטעות את ישראל אחריהם ולהחליש בהם האמונה בנסי משה ואהרן דע"י שיראו שגם החרטומים עושים כן בכשפים, יחשבו גם בניסיהם שהוא מעשה כשפים ח"ו, ומן הראוי הי' שלא יזמין ד' להם הנס ההוא שיהי' חלקם מים, אך נעשה להם הנס ג"כ ע"ד הנסיון וע"כ העלימה הכתוב ולא גילהו, וע"ד שפירשנו באמירת הנחש אל חוה, שלא סיפר הכתוב בנס של פתיחת פי הנחש, כמ"ש בנס פתיחת פי האתון, דשם אמרז"ל מלאך של רחמים הי' ובא למנעו מלחטוא , נמצא הי' בחי' הנס מסיטרא דקדושה ע"כ גילהו הכתוב, אמנם בנס דנחש שהי' ע"ד הסתה ומצד הסט"א ע"כ העלימו הכתוב ( עיי"ד בעה"ג סי' כ'), וכמו"כ בנס זה של מים לאלו ששתו בספל א' עם המצרים הי' כולו ע"צ הנסיון לכך העלימו הכתוב.
translation: And even if on the other hand, according to what is said in the holy teachings on the verse "And the magicians of Egypt did so," according to their words, may their memory be blessed, that all the waters of Egypt were turned to blood, then from where did they find water to turn it into blood, etc.? And it was explained according to what our sages, may their memory be blessed, said that the Israelites became wealthy from the plague of the Nile, as they were selling water to the Egyptians, etc. Based on this, the magicians did what was sold to them. Thus far their words, may their memory be blessed. Now, this power that was given to the magicians to perform the miracle of blood through sorcery was through the power of the other side and as a test, and as we explained regarding the miracle of the staff, see there. And it is possible that those who were drinking from one cup with the Egyptian were close to their opinion and method, and sold them water for this purpose, to show the miracle of blood through sorcery and to deceive Israel after them, weakening their faith in the miracles of Moses and Aaron, for by seeing that the magicians also do so through sorcery, they might think that also in their miracles it is an act of sorcery, Heaven forbid. It would have been fitting that the Holy One, blessed be He, would not have prepared for them that miracle that their portion would be water, but the miracle was also done for them as a test, and therefore the scripture concealed it and did not reveal it. And as we explained regarding the serpent's speech to Eve, that the scripture did not recount the miracle of the opening of the serpent's mouth, as it is said regarding the miracle of the opening of the donkey's mouth, where it is stated that a ministering angel of mercy was sent to prevent him from sinning, thus the miracle was from the side of holiness, and therefore the scripture revealed it. However, in the miracle of the serpent, which was in the nature of temptation and from the side of the other side, therefore the scripture concealed it (see there in the holy book, section 20). Likewise, in this miracle of water for those who drank from one cup with the Egyptians, it was all for the purpose of the test, and for that reason the scripture concealed it.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous transformation of water into blood by the Egyptian magicians, emphasizing that this power stemmed from the forces of the "Sitra Achra" (the Other Side) and was intended to challenge the faith of the Israelites. It suggests that the magicians' ability to replicate this miracle was a deliberate attempt to undermine belief in the divine miracles performed by Moses and Aaron. The text highlights the idea that certain miracles, particularly those associated with temptation or deception, are concealed in scripture to protect the faithful from confusion and doubt. Ultimately, it reflects on the nature of divine intervention and the trials of faith faced by the Israelites in the context of their liberation.

passage_content: ויאמר משה לפרעה התפאר עלי למתי אעתיר לך וגו' להכרית הצפרדעים וגו' ויאמר למחר, ותמהו המפורשים כי מנהג כל אדם לבקש להסר רעתו מיד, ומדוע ביקש פרעה שיסורו רק למחר ויתמהמה בצרתו שלא לצורך.
translation: And Moses said to Pharaoh, "Glorify yourself over me; when shall I entreat for you..." to eradicate the frogs, etc. And he said, "Tomorrow." And the commentators were astonished, for it is the custom of every person to seek to remove their affliction immediately, so why did Pharaoh request that it be removed only tomorrow and delay his suffering without necessity?
summary: Moses asks Pharaoh when he would like the frogs to be removed, and Pharaoh responds "tomorrow," which perplexes commentators since it is natural for one to seek immediate relief from suffering. This delay reflects a deeper spiritual struggle, illustrating Pharaoh's hardened heart and his unwillingness to fully submit to God's will. The request for a delay signifies a lack of true repentance and an attachment to the material world, emphasizing the Hasidic teaching that genuine faith requires immediate action and a desire for divine connection. Ultimately, this moment highlights the tension between human free will and divine intervention in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ב) כדבריך למען תדע כי אין כד' אלקינו , ראוי להבין איך יתברר לו ידיעה זו מהסרת הצפרדעים יותר מהסרת שאר המכות, ולא מצינו שא"ל משרע"ה כן במכות אחרות כ"א במכת הצפרדעים בלבד וטעמא בעי.
translation: As your words indicate, in order to know that there is none like our God, it is fitting to understand how this knowledge is clarified to him through the removal of the frogs more than through the removal of the other plagues, and we do not find that he said this to Moshe Rabbeinu regarding the other plagues, except for the plague of frogs alone, and the reason is sought.
summary: The passage discusses the unique significance of the plague of frogs in demonstrating God's unparalleled nature. It questions why this specific plague serves as a clearer revelation of God's knowledge compared to the other plagues, noting that such an inquiry is not raised regarding the other afflictions. This highlights a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine knowledge and the manifestations of God's power in the world. The text invites reflection on the distinct lessons that can be drawn from each of the plagues, particularly in understanding God's sovereignty.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי הגמ ' (פסחים נ"ג ע"ב) מה ראו חנני' מישאל ועזרי' שמסרו עצמן על קדושת השם לתוך כבשן האש נשאו ק"ו בעצמם מצפרדעים, ומה צפרדעים שאין מצווים על קדה"ש כתיב בהו ועלו ובאו בביתך וגו' ובתנוריך וכו' אנו שמצווין על קדה"ש עאכו"כ, וכתבו התוס ' ור"י מפרש מה ראו שלא ברחו, שהרי קודם המעשה היו יכולים לברוח עכ"ל, והקשו המפרשים דלפי"ד ר"י אין כאן ק"ו, דשאני צפרדעים שנגזר עליהם בגזירת השם שיבואו באש, משא"כ חנני' מישאל ועזרי' לא נצטוו על זה כיון שהי' אפשר להם לברוח, (עיין בדברנו לעיל ביאור הענין באריכות) ועוד לאלקי מילין .
translation: And we will explain in advance the words of the Gemara (Pesachim 53b): What did Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah see that they gave themselves over for the sanctification of the Name into the fiery furnace? They reasoned a fortiori from the frogs. And just as the frogs, which are not commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name, it is written about them, "And they went and came into your house," etc., and "into your ovens," etc., how much more so we, who are commanded regarding the sanctification of the Name! And the Tosafot wrote, and R. Yitzchak explains what did they see that they did not flee, for before the act they could have escaped. Thus far the quote. And the commentators questioned that according to R. Yitzchak's explanation, there is no a fortiori reasoning here, for the frogs were decreed by the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to come into the fire, whereas Chananiah, Mishael, and Azariah were not commanded regarding this since it was possible for them to flee (see our earlier discussion for an elaborate explanation of the matter) and further, to the God of matters.
summary: The passage discusses the bravery of Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who willingly faced the fiery furnace to sanctify God's name, drawing a comparison to the frogs that were compelled by divine decree to enter the fire. It highlights the theological concept of voluntary sacrifice for holiness, emphasizing that while the frogs had no choice, the three men chose to confront danger despite having the option to escape. This act of faith underscores the significance of divine commandments and the moral obligation to uphold sanctity, even in the face of peril. The text also reflects on the interpretations of the sages regarding the nature of their commitment and the implications of their actions.

passage_content: ואפ"ל דהנה תכלית ותועלת כל המכות היו להכניע ערפו הקשה ולבבו הערל עד שיאבה לשלח את ישראל, אלא שלא נשלמה פעולה זו בשלימות עד שעברו עליו כל המכות, כי נמדד עליו כאו"א כפי מדת רעתו והי' ראוי שיעברו עליו כולם, ועכ"פ בכל א' מהמכות נשלמה פעולה זו במקצת וחלק ממנה, וא"כ לפי"ז כיון שאמר פרעה העתירו אל ד' וגו' ואשלחה את העם ויזבחו לד', כבר נשלמה תכליתה של מכה זו והגיע עת הסרתה מיד, ולז"א משרע"ה למתי אעתיר לך וגו' כי יתכן שיסורו מיד אם תרצה, אמנם פרעה התחכם ברשעתו וחשב שבלא"ה יסורו מיד, אחרי שאמר ואשלחה את העם וכנ"ל ולזה ביקש ממשרע"ה שיתפלל שיסורו רק למחר, ולא יתקיימו דבריו כן, כי באמת כבר הגיע עת הסרתם היום, ועי"ז יעשה דברי משרע"ה פלסתר ח"ו, אמנם הצפרדעים אף שלא היו מצווים עוד שכבר הגיע עת הסרתם כנ"ל, מ"מ הוסיפו עוד יום א' לקדש ש"ש , וא"ש הק"ו שלמדו חמ"ו מהצפרדעים, שלא היו מצווים עוד בגזירת השם ליכנס בתנורים. אעפ"כ מסרו עצמם לקדש ש"ש , אנו על אחת כמה וכמה, ודבר זה לא עלה בדעתו של פרעה שהצפרדעים יתעכבו עד למחר כדי לקדש ש"ש , וע"כ ביקש על למחר וכשיסורו היום יתמעט כבוד שמים ח"ו, והשיב לו משרע"ה כדבריך שיסורו רק למחר למען תדע כי אין כד' אלקינו שיתקדש ש"ש על ידם.
translation: And even though the ultimate purpose and benefit of all the plagues was to subdue his stiff neck and his uncircumcised heart until he would be willing to send Israel away, this action was not completed in full until all the plagues had passed over him, for each one was measured according to the degree of his wickedness, and it was fitting that all of them should pass over him. Nevertheless, in each of the plagues, this action was completed to some extent and part of it. Therefore, since Pharaoh said, "Entreat the Lord for me... and I will send the people and they will sacrifice to the Lord," the purpose of this plague was already fulfilled, and the time for its removal had arrived. Thus, Moshe said to him, "When shall I entreat for you...?" because it is possible that it could be removed immediately if you wish. However, Pharaoh, in his wickedness, thought that it would be removed anyway immediately after he said, "I will send the people," as mentioned above. For this reason, he asked Moshe to pray that it be removed only tomorrow, and his words would not be fulfilled, for in truth, the time for their removal was today. By this, the words of Moshe would be rendered false, Heaven forbid. However, the frogs, even though they were no longer commanded since the time for their removal had arrived, nevertheless added another day to sanctify the Sabbath. And it is a fortiori from what the frogs did, who were no longer commanded by the decree of the Holy One to enter the ovens. Nevertheless, they dedicated themselves to sanctify the Sabbath. We, all the more so, and this thought did not enter Pharaoh's mind that the frogs would delay until tomorrow to sanctify the Sabbath. Therefore, he asked for tomorrow, for if they were to be removed today, the honor of Heaven would be diminished, Heaven forbid. Moshe responded to him as you said, that they would be removed only tomorrow, so that you should know that there is none like our God who would have the Sabbath sanctified by them.
summary: The passage discusses the purpose of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that they were meant to soften Pharaoh's hardened heart so he would release the Israelites. Each plague contributed to this goal, but Pharaoh's cunning led him to request that the relief come the next day, believing it would diminish God's glory. However, the frogs, despite not being commanded to delay, chose to prolong their presence to sanctify the Sabbath, illustrating the idea that even creatures can elevate God's honor. Moses' response to Pharaoh highlights the unique power of God, affirming that true sanctification comes from divine will, not human manipulation.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד מדוע ביקש פרעה שיסורו רק למחר עפימ"ד במד"ר (פר' י' ס"ה) ויאמר למחר מכאן אתה למד שאותו היום הי' לו להשלים ז' ימים לכך א"ל משה למתי אעתיר לך למחר אעתיר לך ולא לאותו יום, ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר (פר' ע' סי' י"ב) עה"פ וימלא שבעת ימים אחרי הכות ה' את היאור, ר' יהודה ור' נחמי', אחד מהם אומר כ"ד ימים הי' מתרה בהם עד שלא בא המכה, וז' ימים המכה משמשת בהם, וא' מהם אומר ז' ימים מתרה בהם וכ"ד ימים היתה המכה משמשת בהם, והנה כלל גדול בכל פלוגתת חז"ל דאלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים כאמרם ז"ל (עירובין י"ג ע"א) וכתב הריטב"א שם וז"ל שאלו רבני צרפת ז"ל האיך אפשר שיהי' שניהם דא"ח וזה אוסר וזה מתיר, ותירצו כי כשעלה משה למרום לקבל תורה, הראו לו על כל דבר ודבר מ"ט פנים לאיסור ומ"ט פנים להיתר ושאל להקב"ה ע"ז, ואמר שיהא זה מסור לחכמי ישראל שבכל דור ודור ויהי' ההכרעה כמותן עכ"ל, מבואר שכל או"א מדיעות החולקים יש לה שורש בגבהי מרומים וכח ההכרעה נמסרה לחכמי הדור, והנה בענין המכות על המצריים פליגי חז"ל כמה ימים שימשה כל מכה, ח"א ז' ימים וח"א כ"ד יום, ובאותו הדור נמסרה ההכרעה למרע"ה , וע"כ אמר לפרעה שיכול לברור א' משניהם או שיכרתו למחר שהוא יום הז ' להתחלת המכה כמבואר במדרש, או שתשמש המכה עד כ"ד יום, וכפי רצונו של פרעה יכריע מרע"ה , והשיב לו פרעה למחר כדרך בנ"א שאין רוצים לסבול צרתם כל שיש אפשרות להסירה, ולפי שנתן לו משרע"ה הבחירה לברור על יום מחר או לסוף כ"ד יום, בחר בזמן המוקדם ואמר למחר.
translation: And even if it is asked why Pharaoh requested that they only go tomorrow, as it is explained in the Midrash (Parashat Y, section 65), he said "tomorrow." From here you learn that on that day he was to complete seven days. Therefore, Moses said to him, "When shall I pray for you?" "Tomorrow I will pray for you, but not for that day." And we will also bring another teaching from the Midrash (Parashat A, section 12) regarding the verse "And it filled seven days after the Lord struck the river." Rabbi Judah and Rabbi Nehemiah, one of them says that there were twenty-four days of warning before the plague came, and seven days the plague was active among them. And one of them says there were seven days of warning and twenty-four days the plague was active among them. And behold, there is a great principle in all the disputes of the Sages that both these and those are the words of the living God, as they said (Eruvin 13a). And the Ritva wrote there, that the Rabbis of France asked how it is possible that both can be true, one permitting and the other prohibiting. They answered that when Moses ascended to the heavens to receive the Torah, he was shown each matter with forty-nine facets for prohibition and forty-nine facets for permission, and he asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, about this. And He said that this should be entrusted to the sages of Israel in every generation, and the decision would be according to them. It is clear that each of the opinions of those who disagree has its root in the heights above, and the power of the decision was given to the sages of the generation. And behold, concerning the plagues upon the Egyptians, the Sages disagree on how many days each plague lasted; one says seven days and one says twenty-four days. And in that generation, the decision was given to Moses our Teacher. Therefore, he said to Pharaoh that he could choose one of the two: either they would be struck tomorrow, which is the seventh day for the beginning of the plague, as explained in the Midrash, or the plague would last for twenty-four days. According to Pharaoh's desire, Moses would decide. And Pharaoh replied, "Tomorrow," in the way of human beings who do not wish to endure their suffering as long as there is a possibility to remove it. And since Moses gave him the choice to select either for tomorrow or after twenty-four days, he chose the earlier time and said, "Tomorrow."
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's request to delay the plagues until the next day, highlighting the theological concept of free will and divine judgment. It references a debate among the sages regarding the duration of the plagues, illustrating that both opinions have roots in higher spiritual truths. The text emphasizes that the authority to decide on such matters was given to Moses, who allowed Pharaoh the choice of timing, reflecting the human tendency to avoid suffering when possible. Ultimately, Pharaoh's choice to delay signifies a rejection of immediate divine intervention.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בזה בהעיר עוד בשינוי הלשון מדברי פרעה לדברי מרע"ה , דכתיב ויקרא פרעה למשה ולאהרן ויאמר העתירו אל ה' ויסר הצפרדעים ממני ומעמי וגו' ולא ביקש על עבדיו, ובדברי מרע"ה כתיב למתי אעתיר לך ולעבדיך ולעמך להכרית הצפרדעים וגו' וכן להלן וסרו הצפרדעים ממך ומבתיך ומעבדיך ומעמך וגו', ובודאי נרמז איזה ענין בשינוי הזה ואין לומר שבדברי פרעה נכללו העבדים בתיבת עמו, דא"כ למה הוצרך משה רבינו להזכירם בפ"ע, ואין תיבה ואות מיותר בתוה"ק, עוד יש שינוי אחד במכת הצפרדעים מה שאינו כן בשאר המכות, והוא מ"ש משרע"ה בהתראתו לפרעה למען תדע כי אין כה' אלקינו , ובמכת ערוב כתיב למען תדע כי אני ה' בקרב הארץ, ובמכת ברד למען תדע כי לה' הארץ ולא אמר כי אין כה' אלקינו . ובאמת חילוק גדול יש בין הני תרי לישני, דאין כה' אלקנו מורה על היחוד האמיתי שהוא ית"ש אחד יחיד ומיוחד ואין עוד מלבדו, משא"כ במאמר אני ה' בקרב הארץ אינו מבורר יחודו ואחדותו ית"ש , והי' פרעה יכול לטעות במאמר הזה כי אני ה' בקרב הארץ, שהאמנם שיש מציאות הבורא אבל ח"ו ב' רשויות הן, משא"כ במאמר אין כה' אלקינו אין בו מקום לטעות, וא"כ צריך להבין מדוע במכת הצפרדעים בלבד אמר מרע"ה לשון זה: ואיך נתברר לפרעה ידיעה זו מהסרת הצפרדעים יותר מבשאר המכות.
translation:
Furthermore, one can say in this regard, by changing the language from the words of Pharaoh to the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, as it is written: "And Pharaoh called for Moshe and Aharon and said, 'Entreat the Lord for me, and let the frogs be removed from me and my people,' etc., and he did not ask for his servants. In contrast, in the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, it is written: 'When shall I entreat for you and for your servants and for your people to exterminate the frogs,' etc., and similarly later, 'And the frogs shall depart from you and from your houses and from your servants and from your people,' etc. Certainly, some matter is hinted at in this change, and one cannot say that in Pharaoh's words his servants were included in the term 'my people,' for if so, why did Moshe Rabbeinu need to mention them separately? There is no superfluous word or letter in the Holy Torah. 

Moreover, there is another difference in the plague of frogs that is not the same as in the other plagues, which is what Moshe Rabbeinu said in his warning to Pharaoh: 'In order that you shall know that there is none like the Lord our God,' and in the plague of wild beasts, it is written: 'In order that you shall know that I am the Lord in the midst of the land,' and in the plague of hail, it is written: 'In order that you shall know that the land belongs to the Lord,' but it does not say 'that there is none like the Lord our God.' 

In truth, there is a great distinction between these two phrases. 'There is none like the Lord our God' indicates the true uniqueness of the Blessed One, who is One, Unique, and Singular, and there is none besides Him. In contrast, the statement 'I am the Lord in the midst of the land' does not clarify His uniqueness and oneness. Pharaoh could have erred in this statement, 'I am the Lord in the midst of the land,' for indeed there is the existence of the Creator, but God forbid, there are two authorities. However, in the statement 'There is none like the Lord our God,' there is no room for error. Therefore, one must understand why only in the plague of frogs did Moshe Rabbeinu use this language: and how did this knowledge become clear to Pharaoh regarding the removal of the frogs more than in the other plagues?
summary: The passage discusses the differences in the language used by Pharaoh and Moses regarding the plagues, particularly the frogs. It highlights that Pharaoh's request does not include his servants, while Moses explicitly mentions them, indicating a deeper theological significance. The text emphasizes the unique declaration of God's oneness in Moses' words, "there is none like our God," which asserts the absolute unity of God, contrasting with Pharaoh's more ambiguous acknowledgment of God's presence. This distinction raises questions about why this specific understanding of God's uniqueness was emphasized in the context of the frogs compared to other plagues.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה במכה זו כתיב ויעשו כן החרטומים בלהטיהם ויעלו את הצפרדעים על ארץ מצרים אמנם במכת כנים לא יכלו להוציא את הכנים ופרש"י הטעם שאין השד שולט על ברי' פחותה מכשעורה ובעכ"ח הודו שאצבע אלקים הוא, ומאז גם בשאר המכות שאח"כ לא מצינו שניסו החרטומים לעשות כמעשה משה ואהרן, אף שאין שייך בהם טעם זה שאין השד שולט וכו ', עכ"ז כיון שבעכ"ח הודו במעשה משה ואהרן שאצבע אלקים המה לא ניסו עוד לעשות כמעשיהם, והנה במכת הצפרדעים הוסיפו גם החרטומים על המכה והעלו צפרדעים ע"י כישוף נוסף על הצפרדעים שהעלו משה ואהרן, ולא מצינו שהחרטומים הסירו אלו הצפרדעים שהביאו בכח כשפיהם להכרית אותם, דזה לא הי' בכוחם לעשות וכ"כ הראב"ע ז"ל עיי"ש, נמצא שהוצרך פרעה לסבול גם מהצפרדעים שהוסיפו חרטומיו ולא יכלו להכריתם, וע"כ כעס פרעה על חרטומיו שיודעים רק להרע ולהטיב לא ידעו, ולזה אמר למרע"ה העתירו אל ה' ויסר הצפרדעים ממני ומעמי דייקא , ולא ביקש על עבדיו שהם החרטומים, כי רצה שיסבלו המכה אשר הביאו בעצמם כיון שאין בהם כח להכריתם ורק להוסיף ידעו, אבל מרע"ה השיב לו אני אבקש מהשי"ת יותר משאלתך וגם מעבדיך יסיר המכה, ע"ז ענה לו פרעה שעכ"פ לא יסיר מהם עד למחר, וממני ומעמי תסירם מיד, ומן החרטומים לא תסירם עד למחר, שעכ"פ יסבלו יום א' יותר, ויאמר לו משה רבינו כדבריך. ר"ל אעשה כדבריך שלא יסורו עד למחר, אך עי"ז יהי' הכרח שתשאר המכה בכל ארץ מצרים עד למחר למען תדע כי אין כה' אלקינו .
translation: And it appears that in this plague it is written, "And the magicians did so with their enchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt." However, in the plague of lice, they could not bring forth the lice, and Rashi explains the reason is that the demon does not have power over a creature smaller than a barley grain, and they acknowledged that it was the finger of God. Since then, in the other plagues that followed, we do not find that the magicians tried to do as Moses and Aaron did, even though the reason does not apply to them, that the demon does not have power, etc. Nevertheless, since they acknowledged in the act of Moses and Aaron that it is the finger of God, they did not try to do as they did anymore. Now, in the plague of frogs, the magicians also added to the plague and brought up frogs through additional sorcery beyond the frogs that Moses and Aaron brought. And we do not find that the magicians removed the frogs that they brought by the power of their sorcery to destroy them, for this was not within their power to do, and so said the Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed. It turns out that Pharaoh had to endure also the frogs that his magicians added, and they could not destroy them. Therefore, Pharaoh was angry with his magicians, saying that they only know how to do evil and do not know how to do good. For this reason, he said to Moses and Aaron, "Entreat the Lord that He may take away the frogs from me and from my people," specifically, and he did not ask for his servants, who are the magicians, because he wanted them to suffer the plague which they brought upon themselves, since they had no power to destroy them, only to add. But Moses replied to him, "I will ask from the Holy One, Blessed be He, more than your request, and also from your servants He will remove the plague." To this, Pharaoh answered him that at least He will not remove it from them until tomorrow, and from me and my people, remove them immediately, and from the magicians, He will not remove them until tomorrow, so that at least they will suffer one more day. And Moses our teacher said to him, "As you say." That is to say, I will do as you say, that they will not be removed until tomorrow, but through this it will be necessary that the plague remains throughout the land of Egypt until tomorrow, so that you may know that there is none like our God.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the limitations of the Egyptian magicians during the plagues, particularly highlighting their inability to remove the plague of lice, which they acknowledged as the "finger of God." Despite their initial attempts to replicate Moses and Aaron's miracles, the magicians ultimately recognized the divine power at work. Pharaoh's frustration with the magicians stems from their failure to alleviate the suffering they contributed to, leading him to request Moses to pray for relief. Moses agrees to Pharaoh's request but emphasizes that the plague will remain in Egypt until the next day, demonstrating God's supremacy and the futility of the magicians' powers.

passage_content: וביאור הענין עפי"מ דאיתא בגמרא (סנהדרין ס"ז ע"ב) א"ר יוחנן למה נקרא שמן כשפים שמכחישין פמליא של מעלה, אין עוד מלבדו א"ר חנינא אפילו לדבר כשפים, ( פירש"י אין בהם כח לפני גזירתו שאין כח מלבדו) ההיא איתתא דהות קא מהדרא למשקל עפרא מתותי כרעי' דר' חנינא , אמר לה אי מסתייעת זיל עביד אין עוד מלבדו כתיב עכ"ד הגמ ', והנה אם הי' מרע"ה עושה כדברי פרעה להכרית הצפרדעים מכל ארץ מצרים היום ורק אצל החרטומים ישארו עד למחר, מסתמא היו נשארו אותן הצפרדעים שהוסיפו החרטומים ע"י כישוף, דכל דבר נמשך אחרי שורשו ואותן הצפרדעים שהביאו היו נשארים ליסרם ע"ד תיסרך רעתך, אמנם כי כן יהי' להם להמכשפים פתחון פה לומר שכח הכישוף חזק הוא ח"ו יותר מכח השמים, והראי' שמשה לא הי' יכול להכרית הצפרדעים שהעלו בכח הכישוף, ונמצא היו מכחישין אמונת אין עוד מלבדו ואפי' כשפים, לזה הי' הכרח שישארו כל הצפרדעים עד למחר ולא יהי' להם פתחון פה, ויתברר להם שאין עוד מלבדו אפילו לדבר כשפים, וזה שאמר מרע"ה לפרעה אחר שביקש מאתו להשאיר הצפרדעים על החרטומים עד למחר, א"ל כדבריך פי' שלפי דבריך מוכרח שישארו כל הצפרדעים עד למחר למען תדע כי אין כה' אלקינו ולא יוכלו החרטומים לעשות דבר להקדים הסרתם או למנוע ובעל כרחם יודו שאין כה' אלקינו אפילו לדבר כשפים.
translation: And the explanation of the matter is according to what is stated in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 67b): Rabbi Yochanan said, "Why is it called the 'oil of sorcery'? Because it denies the heavenly entourage, 'There is none besides Him.' Rabbi Chanina said, 'Even to speak of sorcery' (Rashi explains that they have no power before His decree, for there is no power besides Him). There was a woman who was going to take dust from under the feet of Rabbi Chanina. He said to her, 'If you are able, go and do it; it is written, 'There is none besides Him.' Thus said the Gemara. Now, if Moshe Rabbeinu had acted according to Pharaoh's words to eradicate the frogs from all the land of Egypt today and only leave them with the magicians until tomorrow, surely those frogs that the magicians had added through sorcery would have remained, for everything is drawn after its root, and those frogs that they brought would remain to punish them according to 'as you have afflicted, so shall you be afflicted.' However, this would give the sorcerers a reason to claim that the power of sorcery is, Heaven forbid, stronger than the power of Heaven, and the proof would be that Moshe could not eradicate the frogs that were brought by the power of sorcery. Thus, they would deny the belief in 'There is none besides Him,' even regarding sorcery. Therefore, it was necessary that all the frogs remain until tomorrow, so that they would have no excuse, and it would be made clear to them that there is none besides Him, even to speak of sorcery. This is what Moshe Rabbeinu said to Pharaoh after he requested that the frogs be left with the magicians until tomorrow. He said to him, 'According to your words, it is necessary that all the frogs remain until tomorrow, so that you may know that there is none like our God, and the magicians will not be able to do anything to hasten their removal or prevent it, and against their will, they will admit that there is none like our God, even to speak of sorcery.'
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine sovereignty and the limitations of sorcery, emphasizing that true power belongs solely to God. It illustrates this through the example of Moses and Pharaoh, where Moses' refusal to eliminate the frogs until the next day serves to demonstrate that even the magicians' powers are ultimately subordinate to God's will. The text asserts that the existence of sorcery does not contradict the belief in God's singular authority, as any apparent power of the magicians is merely an illusion. Thus, the narrative reinforces the theological principle that there is "none besides Him," affirming God's supremacy over all forces, including those of magic.

passage_content: ויאמר ד' אל משה השכם בבקר וגו' כי אם אינך משלח את עמי הנני משליח בך ובעבדיך ובעמך ובבתיך את הערוב וגו', והפליתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו' ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך למחר יהי' האות הזה, פרש"י ז"ל והפליתי והפרשתי וכו ', ושמתי פדות שיבדיל בין עמי ובין עמך עכ"ל, ולפי פירושו שניהם מלשון הבדלה והפרשה, וראוי להבין מה צורך לכפול הלשון במלות שונות, גם צ"ב מדוע הוצרך הכתוב לפרט במכות הערוב דייקא , שהפריש הקב"ה את ישראל ולא שלטה בהם המכה, וכמו"כ הופרשו ונצולו בני ישראל מכל המכות שלא שלטו בהן, ובאבן עזרא כתב( בפ ' דם) דכל המכות היו כוללת המצריים והעבריים חוץ מערוב דבר וברד, שפירש בהם הכתוב שהיו ישראל מופרשים ממנה, וכתב עליו האבי עזרי אנו אין לנו אלא דברי רז"ל, כי ממכת דם נתעשרו ישראל, ואפי' נכרי וישראל שותין בספל א' הי' חציו דם וחציו מים, ולפי דעתי תלמיד טועה ועני בדעת כתב הדברים האלה עכ"ל, ולפי דברי רז"ל צריך ליתן טעם מדוע הוצרך הכתוב לפרט במכת הערוב שהופרשו ישראל ממנה, וכן הי' בכל המכות, ולא עוד אלא שכפלו הכתוב והפליתי וגו' ושמתי פדות וצ"ב .
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Rise early in the morning..." For if you do not send out My people, behold, I will send upon you and your servants and your people and your houses the swarms of flies..." And I will make a distinction on that day in the land of Goshen..." and I will set a distinction between My people and your people; tomorrow this sign will be." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "I will make a distinction" and "I will set a distinction" etc., and "I will set a distinction" means to separate between My people and your people. Thus far his words. According to his interpretation, both terms are from the language of separation and distinction, and it is fitting to understand why the language is doubled with different words. It is also necessary to clarify why the text needed to specify regarding the plague of the swarms of flies specifically, that the Holy One, blessed be He, separated Israel and the plague did not prevail over them. Likewise, the children of Israel were separated and saved from all the plagues that did not prevail over them. And Ibn Ezra wrote (in the plague of blood) that all the plagues included the Egyptians and the Hebrews, except for the swarms of flies, the plague of livestock, and hail, where the text specifies that Israel was separated from them. And the Aben Ezra wrote, "We have only the words of our Sages," for from the plague of blood, Israel became wealthy, and even a non-Jew and a Jew drinking from one cup, half of it was blood and half of it was water. In my opinion, a mistaken and poor student wrote these words. Thus far his words. According to the words of our Sages, it is necessary to provide a reason why the text needed to specify regarding the plague of the swarms of flies that Israel was separated from it, and so it was with all the plagues, and not only that, but the text doubled the language "I will make a distinction" and "I will set a distinction," and it is necessary to clarify.
summary: The passage discusses God's promise to distinguish between the Israelites and the Egyptians during the plagues, particularly emphasizing the plague of the swarms (ערוב). It highlights the concept of divine separation and protection, where the Israelites are spared from the afflictions that befall the Egyptians. The repetition of terms related to separation suggests a profound theological significance in God's safeguarding of His people. The text also raises questions about the necessity of specifying the distinction in certain plagues, inviting deeper reflection on the nature of divine intervention and the relationship between God and His chosen people.

passage_content: ב) אונקלס פי' פדות מלשון פדיון, ואשוי פורקן לעמי ועל עמך איתי מחא, וכן דרשו רז"ל במד"ר (י"א ב') ושמתי פדות בין עמי, מלמד שהיו ישראל ראויין ללקות בזו המכה, ונתן הקב"ה פדיונם המצרים, ואף לע"ל הקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוך גהינם תחת ישראל שנא' כי אני ד' אלקיך וגו' נתתי כפרך מצרים כוש וסבא תחתיך עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין מה נשתנה מכת הערוב שהיו ישראל ראויים ללקות בזו יותר משאר המכות, גם אם ישראל ראויים ללקות איך יהיו המצרים והאומה"ע פדיונם, ולא עביד קוב"ה דינא בלא דינא , גם צ"ב בלשון המדרש שלע"ל הקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוך גהינם תחת ישראל, ומדוע עכו"ם הקדמונים דייקא , והאחרונים ג"כ רשעים וראויים לזה.
translation: B) Onkelos interprets "p'dut" as coming from the word "pidyon" (redemption), and "ashui porkan" (I have made a release) for My people, and "on your people" (for your people) I have fought, and thus our sages expounded in Midrash Rabbah (11:2) "And I will place redemption between My people," teaching that the Israelites were deserving of punishment from this plague, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them their redemption from the Egyptians. Furthermore, in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the ancient nations and cast them into Gehenna in place of Israel, as it is said, "For I am the Lord your God... I have given your ransom, Egypt, Cush, and Seba in your stead," thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand what distinguishes the plague of the swarms, that the Israelites were more deserving of punishment from this than from the other plagues. Also, if the Israelites are deserving of punishment, how can the Egyptians and the nations of the world be their redemption? For the Holy One, blessed be He, does not act without justice. Additionally, it is puzzling in the language of the Midrash that in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the ancient nations and cast them into Gehenna in place of Israel, and why specifically the ancient nations, as the later ones are also wicked and deserving of this.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption (פדיון) in relation to the plagues of Egypt, emphasizing that the Israelites were deserving of punishment but were spared by God's intervention, which instead fell upon the Egyptians. It raises questions about why the plague of swarms (ערוב) was particularly significant and why the ancient nations are specifically mentioned as being punished in the future. The text highlights the idea that God's justice operates with a deeper wisdom, suggesting that the fate of the nations is intertwined with the spiritual status of Israel. Ultimately, it reflects on the themes of divine mercy, justice, and the unique relationship between God and the Jewish people.

passage_content: ג) פדות וגו' למחר יהי' האות הזה, צ"ב דא"א לומר מחר ממש, דזמן התראת המכה הי' יותר מיום א' לד"ה, למר ז' ימים ולמר כ"א יום, ואם הכוונה על מחר שהוא לאחר זמן. צ"ב מדוע הזכירו הכתוב ואיננו מוגבל ומבורר הזמן בלא"ה , גם לא נמצא כן בשאר המכות ומדוע במכת ערוב דייקא אמר כן.
translation: 3) Redemption, etc. "Tomorrow this sign will be," it is difficult to say "tomorrow" literally, as the time of warning for the plague was more than one day according to the opinions, for one opinion is seven days and for another opinion is twenty-one days. If the intention is for "tomorrow" to mean a later time, it is puzzling why the verse mentioned it and is not limited and clarified in time otherwise. This is also not found in the other plagues, and why specifically in the plague of swarms did it say so.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption and the timing of divine signs, specifically in relation to the plague of swarms (ערוב). It questions the literal interpretation of "tomorrow" as it pertains to the warning of the plague, noting that the duration of the warning was longer than a single day. The text emphasizes the unique nature of this plague, suggesting that the mention of "tomorrow" serves a deeper theological purpose, highlighting the significance of divine timing and the unfolding of redemption in a broader context.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה כל המכות באו על המצריים מידה כנגד מידה כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, ובמכת ערוב נתנו רז"ל טעם במד"ר ( פי"ב ס"ג) אמר רשב"ל אמר להם הקב"ה אתם עשיתם המונים על עמי, אף אני אעשה עליכם עוף השמים וחית הארץ המונים המונים , שנאמר הנני משליח בך את הערוב חיות ועופות מעורבבין , ופי' ביפ"ת שקבוץ החיות זו עם זו וכן העופות זו עם זו אע"פ שהם מינים שונים אינו כ"כ חידוש, לכן צ"ל כי החידוש כאן הי' קיבוץ החיות עם העופות דלא דבקין דנא עם דנא עכ"ל, והנה אין לך דבר בעולם מזיק לנפש מהתערבות והתדמות לגוים, כמשה"כ ויתערבו בגוים וילמדו מעשיהם, וזה גרם הירידה הנוראה לישראל במצרים, כמ"ש רז"ל במדרש ילקוט ובפסיקתא עה"פ וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וגו' ותמלא הארץ אותם, א"ר יוחנן שמלאו את מצרים, דבר אחר שנתמלאו בתי טרטיאות ובתי קרקסיאות מהם, וע"י התערובת והתבוללות התחילו לדמות למעשה ארץ מצרים ואמרז"ל במד"ר ללמדך כשמת יוסף הפרו ברית מילה אמרו נהי' כמצרים ואפשר דע"כ הי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל שגם המה ראויים ללקות במכת ערוב מידה כנגד מידה עבור חטא ההתערבות טהור בטמא דלא דבקין דנא עם דנא, ועוד יש מבחי ' התערובת בישראל מה שאינו נוהג באומה"ע כלל, היינו שאם מכניסים במעשה עבודת המצות והתוה"ק מחשבה זרה לשם פני' או מחשבה פסולה ר"ל, עי"ז מערבים קודש בחול וטומאה בטהרה, ולא יתכן בחי' תערובת זו באוה"ע שהם משורש הטומאה לגמרי ומשוקעים בה, ולזה הי' קטרוג על ישראל שגם הם ראויים ללקות במכה זו מידה כנגד מידה, אמנם ריחם הקב"ה עליהם ונתן פדיונם המצריים, כי הם היו הגורמים להחטיא את ישראל ועל ידם באו ישראל לירידה זו, וע"כ מגיע מדת העונש עליהם, וע"ד שפי' ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה דברי המדרש ילקוט פ' בשלח (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה חמה כתיב שנתמלא עליהם הים חמה להטביען וכו ', מיד אותה חמה שנתמלא על ישראל החזירו על מצרים, והטעם על כי הם היו הגורמים להחטיאם, ע"כ גם מדת עונשם של ישראל יחולו על ראשיהם (עיין בדברנו לעיל).
translation: And it is understood that all the plagues came upon the Egyptians measure for measure, as explained in the words of our Sages. And regarding the plague of swarms, our Sages provided a reason in the Midrash (Perek 12, Siman 63). Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said to them, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: You have made multitudes upon My people; I too will make upon you the multitudes of the birds of the heavens and the beasts of the earth, as it is said, "Behold, I am sending upon you the swarms, beasts and birds mixed together." And the explanation in Yefeh Toar is that the gathering of the beasts with one another and the birds with one another, even though they are different species, is not such a novelty. Therefore, it must be that the novelty here was the gathering of the beasts with the birds, that they do not stick together with one another. Thus, there is nothing in the world more harmful to the soul than the mixing and resembling of the nations, as it is written, "And they mixed with the nations and learned their deeds." And this caused the terrible decline of Israel in Egypt, as our Sages said in the Midrash Yalkut and in the Pesikta on the verse, "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, etc., and the land was filled with them." Rabbi Yochanan said that they filled Egypt, another explanation is that the houses of theaters and circuses were filled with them. And through the mixing and assimilation, they began to resemble the deeds of the land of Egypt. And our Sages said in the Midrash to teach you that when Joseph died, they nullified the covenant of circumcision, saying, "Let us be like the Egyptians." And it is possible that therefore there was a great accusation against Israel, that they too were worthy of being struck by the plague of swarms measure for measure for the sin of mixing the pure with the impure, that they do not stick together with one another. Moreover, there is a type of mixing among Israel that does not occur among the nations of the world at all, namely, that if they introduce a foreign thought into the performance of the commandments and the Torah, for the sake of Heaven, or a disqualified thought, Heaven forbid, through this they mix holiness with the mundane and impurity with purity. And this type of mixing cannot occur among the nations of the world, who are completely rooted in impurity and immersed in it. And for this reason, there was an accusation against Israel that they too were worthy of being struck by this plague measure for measure. However, the Holy One, Blessed be He, had mercy on them and gave them their redemption from the Egyptians, for they were the ones who caused Israel to sin, and through them Israel came to this decline. Therefore, the measure of punishment comes upon them. And as explained in the Midrash Yalkut, Parashat Beshalach (Remez 234), "And the waters were a wall for them," it is written that the sea was filled with heat to drown them, etc. Immediately that heat that was filled upon Israel was returned upon the Egyptians, and the reason is that they were the ones who caused them to sin. Therefore, the measure of their punishment will also fall upon their heads (see our words above).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine retribution, emphasizing that the plagues inflicted upon the Egyptians were a measure-for-measure response to their actions against the Israelites. It highlights the dangers of assimilation and the negative influence of the Egyptians on the Israelites, particularly after the death of Joseph, which led to a decline in their spiritual integrity. The text also notes that while the Israelites were deserving of punishment for their mingling with the Egyptians, God's mercy allowed for their redemption through the Egyptians' own downfall, as they were the catalysts for Israel's spiritual decline. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the intricate relationship between sin, punishment, and divine mercy within the framework of Hasidic thought.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בהקדם דברי הכלי יקר עה"פ הנה אנכי מכה במטך וגו' שנתן טעם על כל המכות עפ"י דרכו עיי"ש, ובמכת הערוב פי' ערוב באו עליהם לפי שנשתעבדו בישראל שנמשלו לחיות כמו שפירש"י על פסוק כי חיות הנה עכ"ד לעניננו , ואפשר להמתיק טעם זה בתוס ' נופך על דבה"ק , בהקדם שפירשנו לעיל בפ ' שמות עה"פ כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה, דהנה האומה"ע נמשלו לחיות טורפות על בחי' הרע שבהם, כמ"ש בזוה"ק (ר"פ שמות) ממעונות אריות אלין בני שעיר וכו' מהררי נמרים אלו בני ישמעאל עכ"ד, אבל ישראל נמשלו לחיות ע"צ הטובה, כאמרז"ל הוי עז כנמר וגבור כארי וכו' לעשות רצון אביך שבשמים, ואמרז"ל במד"ר פ' בשלח (כ"א ס"ה) אמר הקב"ה לישראל וכו ', אצלי הם כיונה פותה, כל מה שאני גוזר עליהם עושים ושומעים לי, אבל אצל עכו"ם הם קשים כחיות שנא' גור ארי' יהודה בנימן זאב יטרף וכו ', וז"פ כי לא כנשים המצריות העבריות כי חיות הנה ע"צ הקדושה, ולא כנשים המצריות שנמשלו למדות הגרועים שבחיות, ואדרבה לזה הם משולים לחיות שיתגברו בעזותן אפי' כנגד גזירת המלך ולא יתדמו לנשים המצריות לעולם, ולא תוכל להם להחטיאם בעריות עייש"ד באריכות.
translation: And I would like to further preface the words of the Kli Yakar on the verse "Behold, I am striking with my staff," which provides an explanation for all the plagues according to his way, as mentioned there. And regarding the plague of the mixture, he explains that the mixture came upon them because they were subjugated to Israel, who are compared to animals, as Rashi explains on the verse "for they are animals." This is relevant to our discussion. It is possible to sweeten this explanation with an additional nuance, as we have previously explained in Parashat Shemot on the verse "for they are not like the Egyptian women, the Hebrew women, for they are animals," for the nations of the world are compared to predatory animals regarding the evil within them, as it is written in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot) "from the dwellings of lions, these are the sons of Seir," etc., "from the mountains of leopards, these are the sons of Ishmael." However, Israel is compared to animals in terms of goodness, as our sages said, "Be strong like a leopard and brave like a lion," etc., to do the will of your Father in heaven. And our sages said in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Beshalach (21:65), "The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, 'With Me, they are like a gentle dove; whatever I decree upon them, they do and listen to Me,' but with the idolaters, they are as fierce as animals, as it is said, 'The lion's cub is Judah, Benjamin is a wolf that tears.'" Thus, it is explained that they are not like the Egyptian women, the Hebrew women, for they are animals in terms of holiness, and not like the Egyptian women who are compared to the worst traits of animals. On the contrary, they are compared to animals that strengthen themselves in their boldness even against the king's decree and will not resemble the Egyptian women at all, and they cannot be led astray by immorality, as explained there at length.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the spiritual states of the Jewish people and the Egyptians, using the metaphor of animals to illustrate their respective qualities. It emphasizes that while the Egyptians are likened to predatory beasts, representing their negative traits, the Jewish people are compared to noble animals, symbolizing their inherent holiness and strength in fulfilling God's will. This contrast highlights the idea that the Jewish people possess a unique spiritual resilience and connection to the divine, enabling them to withstand challenges and remain faithful, unlike the Egyptians who embody base instincts. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of spiritual identity and the divine favor bestowed upon the Jewish people.

passage_content: ועפ"י דרכנו מצינו טעם למכת הערוב שהי' מדה כנגד מידה, על שהשתמשו המצרים במידת חיות טורפות עם ישראל באכזריות נורא בלי חמלה, ע"כ מידה כ"מ הביא הקב"ה עליהם חיות טורפות, והנה בהתחלת ימי השעבוד עדיין היו ישראל בבחי ' הקדושה להיותן משולים לחיות ע"צ הטובה, לעזותו של נמר וגבורתו של ארי להתגבר נגד כוחות הטומאה והמסיתים, אמנם אחר זמן ועידנים ירדו ממדריגתם והשקעו בכובד הגלות והנסיונות עד שהגיעו למ"ט שערי טומאה כאמרז"ל , ונדבק בהם ממדות הרעות של מצרים עד שנמשלו לעזותן של חיות ע"צ הרעה, כאמרז"ל ג' עזין הן ישראל באומות וכו ', ואלמלא ניתנה תורה לישראל לא הי' כל ברי' יכולה לעמוד בפניהם מפני עזותן , ולז"א במדרש שהיו ישראל ראויין ללקות במכה זו לפי שהשתמשו ג"כ במידות חיות הטורפות וקיטרגה מידת הדין עליהם שגם הם ראויים ללקות, אלא שריחם הקב"ה עליהם ונתן פדיונם המצריים, שהם היו הגורמים והביאו אותם לזה, ע"כ נלקו המצריים תחתיהם.
translation: According to our way, we find a reason for the plague of wild beasts, which was measure for measure, because the Egyptians used the trait of ferocious animals against the Jewish people with terrible cruelty and without compassion. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brought upon them ferocious beasts. And behold, at the beginning of the days of servitude, the Israelites were still in a state of holiness, being compared to the animals of the good, to the audacity of the leopard and the strength of the lion to overcome the forces of impurity and the seducers. However, after a time and ages, they descended from their level and became immersed in the heaviness of exile and trials until they reached the forty-nine gates of impurity, as our sages have said. They became attached to the evil traits of Egypt until they were likened to the audacity of the animals of evil, as our sages have said, "There are three audacious ones: Israel among the nations," etc. And were it not for the Torah being given to Israel, no creature would be able to stand before them because of their audacity. And this is why it is said in the Midrash that the Israelites were worthy of being struck by this plague because they also used the traits of ferocious animals, and the attribute of judgment accused them that they too were deserving of punishment. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them and gave them the redemption of the Egyptians, who were the cause and brought them to this, therefore the Egyptians were struck beneath them.
summary: The passage discusses the plague of wild animals (ערוב) as a measure-for-measure punishment for the Egyptians, who cruelly oppressed the Israelites. Initially, the Israelites were aligned with holiness and strength, symbolized by the qualities of powerful animals, but over time, they succumbed to the impurities of exile and adopted negative traits from the Egyptians. Despite their shortcomings, God showed mercy and allowed the Egyptians to suffer instead, as they were the ones who led the Israelites to this state. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine justice tempered by compassion, emphasizing the relationship between human actions and divine response.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר סיום דברי המדרש ואף לע"ל הקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לתוך גהינם תחת ישראל, דהנה בעוה"ר בדרא בתראה הע"ר נעשו למושלים בישראל, ואחת מטרתם לעשות כל תועבות אשר שנא ד', וחוקקים חקי זימה אשר לא נשמע אף בגרועים שבאומות, וכבר פירשתי במאמה"כ איעצך אשר יעשה העם לעמך באחרית הימים. שהתנבא בלעם הרשע דעצה זו של זימה יעשה העם הזה לעמך באחרית הימים, ע"י שימשלו בם רשעים ואומה"ע ילמדו מהם דרכי הזימה, ולזה יהי' פתחון פה לאומה"ע לע"ל , מדוע מגיע להם עונש גיהנם יותר מישראל, וע"כ הקב"ה מביא עכו"ם הקדמונים ומשליכן לגיהנם תחת ישראל, כי בימיהם היו ישראל מתנהגים בגדרי הקדושה והצניעות, והם אשר גרמו להחטיאם וכמו שהתגברו המצריים ובלעם הרשע לעשותם רעים וחטאים, וע"כ גם מדת עונשם של ישראל יחולו על ראשם.
translation: And according to our path, the conclusion of the words of the Midrash will be clarified, and even in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will bring the ancient idolaters and cast them into Gehenna beneath Israel. For behold, in our current times, in the latter generation, the wicked have become rulers over Israel, and one of their goals is to commit all the abominations that the Holy One hates, and to enact laws of immorality that have not been heard even among the most degraded of nations. And I have already explained in my commentary that I advise you what this people will do to Your people in the end of days. That the wicked Bilaam prophesied that this counsel of immorality will be done by this people to Your people in the end of days, through the fact that the wicked will rule over them, and the nations will learn from them the ways of immorality. And thus, there will be a justification for the nations in the future, as to why they deserve the punishment of Gehenna more than Israel. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brings the ancient idolaters and casts them into Gehenna beneath Israel, for in their days, Israel conducted themselves within the bounds of holiness and modesty, and they are the ones who caused them to sin, just as the Egyptians and the wicked Bilaam prevailed to make them evil and sinful. Therefore, the measure of punishment of Israel will also fall upon their heads.
summary: The passage discusses the future judgment of the nations, emphasizing that in the end of days, God will bring the ancient nations and cast them into hell beneath Israel. It highlights the current state of the world, where wicked rulers lead Israel astray into immorality, fulfilling the prophecy of Balaam regarding the sins of the people. The text asserts that the ancient nations, who once caused Israel to stray from holiness, will bear the consequences of their actions, as their influence led to Israel's transgressions. Ultimately, this reflects a divine justice where the sins of the nations are met with punishment, while Israel's suffering is linked to the corrupting influence of these nations.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר המסורה ושמתי פדות בין עמי וגו' שהיו ישראל ראויין ללקות בזו המכה ונתן הקב"ה פדיונם המצריים, ואף לע"ל יהי' כן, וזהו פדות שלח לעמו צוה לעולם בריתו שיהי' פדות הזאת בחי' נצחית נוהג לעולם, והטעם כי עם ד' החסד והרבה עמו פדות, כי הבוי"ת יודע כל תעלומות חוקר כליות ולב, והוא יודע ועד כי לא בבחירתם עשו ישראל את כל הרעה, אלא העכו"ם היו הגורמים להחטיא אותם, וע"כ והרבה עמו פדות ליתן האומה"ע פדיונם של ישראל.
translation: And this will clarify the tradition, "And I have set redemption between My people," etc. that the Israelites were worthy of being struck by this plague, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them their redemption from the Egyptians. Even in the future, it will be so. This is the redemption that He sent to His people; He commanded forever His covenant that this redemption should be an eternal aspect that will be in effect forever. The reason is that with the Holy One, blessed be He, is kindness, and much with Him is redemption, for the Blessed One knows all secrets, searches the kidneys and the heart, and He knows and bears witness that it was not by their choice that the Israelites did all the evil, but the idolaters were the ones who caused them to sin. Therefore, "and much with Him is redemption" to give the nations of the world the redemption of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption (p'dut) in relation to the Jewish people, emphasizing that despite their deserving punishment, God provided their redemption through the Egyptians. This act of redemption is portrayed as an eternal covenant, reflecting God's nature as a source of kindness and mercy. It highlights that the sins of Israel were not solely due to their own choices, but rather influenced by external forces, thus reinforcing the idea that God's compassion leads to the ongoing redemption of His people.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ד בתנחומא ויצום אל בנ"י ואל פרעה מלך מצרים, אמר להם הקב"ה היו נוהגין בו כבוד וחלקו כבוד למלך שאני צריך לו לעשות בו את הדין וצ"ב , ובמד"ר (פר' ז' ס"ג) אל פרעה מלך מצרים א"ר לוי משל למלך שהי' לו פרדס ונטע בו אילני סרק ואילני מאכל, אמרו לו עבדיו מה הנאה יש לך באילני סרק הללו, אמר להם כשם שאני צריך לאילני מאכל כך אני צריך לאילני סרק שאילולא אילני סרק מהיכן הייתי עושה לי מרחצאות וכבשונות, לכך נאמר אל בני ישראל ואל פרעה שכשם שקילוסו של הקב"ה עולה מג"ע מפי הצדיקים, כך עולה מגיהנם מפי הרשעים וכו ', מה הם אומרים, אמר ר"י יפה אמרת יפה דנת וצ"ב כוונת המשל ולכאורה אינו דומה לגמרי אל הנמשל, דמאילני סרק יש הנאה למלך שעושה על ידן כבשונות, אבל הרשעים מה צורך להן ולקילוסן, אמנם יתבאר לדרכנו שיש צורך ברשעים לעשות בהם כבשונות כהמשל של אילני סרק, שעתיד הקב"ה להשליכן לגיהנם תחת ישראל לפי שהם היו הגורמים להחטיא את ישראל, והם מצדיקים עליהם הדין ואומרים יפה דנת, ואף פרעה הי' צורך בו לעשות בו את הדין אף בשביל ישראל.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Midrash Tanchuma: "And He commanded concerning the children of Israel and concerning Pharaoh, king of Egypt." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "You should treat him with honor and give respect to the king, for I need to execute judgment upon him." And it is questioned, and in the Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'eira 7:63) it says regarding Pharaoh, king of Egypt, Rabbi Levi said: "It is like a king who had an orchard and planted in it trees that bear no fruit and fruit-bearing trees. His servants said to him, 'What benefit do you have from these fruitless trees?' He said to them, 'Just as I need the fruit-bearing trees, so too I need the fruitless trees, for if it were not for the fruitless trees, from where would I make my baths and kilns?'" Therefore, it is said to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh that just as the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, rises from the Garden of Eden from the mouths of the righteous, so it rises from Gehenna from the mouths of the wicked, etc. What do they say? Rabbi Yochanan said: "You have spoken well, you have judged well," and the intention of the parable is questioned, for it does not seem entirely similar to the interpretation. For from the fruitless trees, there is benefit to the king who makes kilns through them, but what need do the wicked have for their praise? However, it can be explained in our way that there is a need for the wicked to make kilns from them, like the parable of the fruitless trees, for the Holy One, blessed be He, will cast them into Gehenna under Israel because they were the ones who caused Israel to sin, and they justify the judgment against them and say, "You have judged well." And even Pharaoh was needed to execute judgment upon him, even for the sake of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of both the righteous and the wicked in God's divine plan, using the metaphor of fruit-bearing and non-fruit-bearing trees. Just as the king needs both types of trees for different purposes, God requires the wicked to fulfill justice and to serve as a means for the righteous to attain their spiritual elevation. The wicked, despite their negative role, ultimately contribute to the glorification of God by justifying divine judgment. This highlights the interconnectedness of all beings in the divine scheme, where even the unrighteous have a purpose in the broader context of creation and redemption.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך יש לך לידע שנא' טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו, טובה אחריתן של ישראל מראשית שנתתי להם במצרים, דע"י קישוי השעבוד שסבלו ישראל, ניצולו אח"כ מן החימה , על כי אנוסים היו בידיהם נמצא הם הגורמים לכל מעשיהם, ואף לעתיד ינתנו העכו"ם פדיונם בטענה זו, ויצמח הצלה לישראל מראשית שסבלו בימי גלותם, וזהו טוב אחרית דבר מראשיתו והבן.
translation: In this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, you should know that it is said, 'Good is the end of a matter from its beginning.' The goodness of the end of Israel began from the moment I gave it to them in Egypt. Know that through the hardship of the servitude that Israel endured, they were later saved from the wrath, for they were forced in their hands, thus they are the cause of all their actions. Even in the future, the nations will be redeemed with this claim, and salvation will sprout for Israel from the beginning of their suffering during their exile. This is what is meant by 'Good is the end of a matter from its beginning.' Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that the suffering endured by the Israelites in Egypt ultimately leads to their redemption and salvation. It emphasizes that their hardships were not in vain, as they serve as a foundation for future deliverance, illustrating the concept of "the good end of a matter from its beginning." This reflects a Hasidic belief in the transformative power of suffering and the divine plan that ensures that even the most difficult experiences can lead to ultimate goodness and redemption for the Jewish people.

passage_content: ולבאר יתר הדקדוקים אפ"ל כשראו ישראל המצרים לוקים במכת ערוב והצילם הקב"ה ממנה, התבוננו שגם המה ראויים ללקות במכה זו מידה כנגד מידה כנ"ל, ע"כ עשו הבדלה והפרשה גמורה מדרכי הגוים וקבלו עליהם לילך בדרכי השי"ת בלי שום תערובות, וע"ד שאמר הנביא (צפני' ג' ו') הכרתי גוים נשמו פנותם החרבתי חוצותם וגו' אמרתי אך תראו אותי תקחו מוסר וגו', שאם ישראל זוכין לוקחים מוסר מעונש הבא על אומה"ע ועושים תשובה, ובזה מקדמים פני הרעה שלא יגיע אליהם ומעתה אפ"ל ששני הפירושים במאמה"כ ושמתי פדות, לפרש"י לשון הבדלה והפרשה ולפי' הת"א והמדרשים הוא מלשון פדיון והצלה, שניהם הא בהא תליין, שהביא הקב"ה על המצרים מכת ערוב ופדה והציל את ישראל, ועי"ז עשו הבדלה והפרשה גמורה מדרכי המצריים, וא"ש מה שחזר ושנה הכתוב לומר ושמתי פדות וגו', וכבר הזכיר שנצולו ישראל מערוב שנא' והפליתי ביום ההוא את ארץ גושן וגו', אמנם כאן הודיע לנו הכתוב דבר חדש שע"י הצלה זו עשו ישראל הבדלה והפרשה מדרכי המצריים, וז"א ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך ונכלל בו ג"כ לשון הצלה ופדיון דשניהם אחד הם, אולם אף שקבלו עליהם במכת ערוב לעשות הבדלה והפרשה מדרכי המצריים, לא זכו למעשה זו בשלימות עד אחר שיצאו ממצרים ואחר קבלת התורה, שאז השיגו בחי' הפרשה זו בשלימותה ואולי זה ירמוז הכתוב ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך למחר יהי' האות הזה יש מחר שהוא לאחר זמן, דהיינו ביצ"מ ואחר קבלת התורה ישתלם אצלם בחי' הזאת, אלא שמיד קבלו עליהם לעשות הבדלה והפרשה וזה נחשב להם כמעשה.
translation: To explain the additional nuances of the grammar, it can be said that when the Israelites saw the Egyptians suffering from the plague of swarms and that the Holy One, blessed be He, saved them from it, they realized that they too were deserving of suffering from this plague, measure for measure, as mentioned above. Therefore, they made a complete separation and distinction from the ways of the nations and accepted upon themselves to walk in the ways of the Blessed One without any mixture. This is in accordance with what the prophet said (Zephaniah 3:6), "I have cut off nations; their towers are desolate," etc. "I said, 'Only you should fear Me, take correction,'" etc. For if Israel merits, they take correction from the punishment that comes upon the nations of the world and repent, and through this, they avert the evil from reaching them. From now on, it can be said that both interpretations of the verse "And I will set redemption" are valid: according to Rashi, it refers to the language of separation and distinction, and according to the Targum and the Midrashim, it is from the language of redemption and salvation. Both are interconnected, as the Holy One, blessed be He, brought the plague of swarms upon the Egyptians and redeemed and saved Israel. Through this, they made a complete separation and distinction from the ways of the Egyptians. It is clear why the verse repeats, "And I will set redemption," etc. It has already mentioned that Israel was saved from the swarms, as it is said, "And I will make a distinction on that day in the land of Goshen," etc. However, here the verse informs us of a new matter: that through this salvation, Israel made a distinction and separation from the ways of the Egyptians. This means, "And I will set redemption between My people and your people," and it also includes the language of salvation and redemption, as both are one. However, even though they accepted upon themselves during the plague of swarms to make a distinction and separation from the ways of the Egyptians, they did not merit to complete this act until after they left Egypt and after receiving the Torah. At that time, they achieved this level of separation in its completeness, and perhaps this is hinted at in the verse "And I will set redemption between My people and your people," for tomorrow this sign will be, meaning after a time, that is, at the Exodus from Egypt and after receiving the Torah, this quality will be completed among them. Nevertheless, immediately they accepted upon themselves to make a distinction and separation, and this was considered an act for them.
summary: The passage discusses how the Israelites, witnessing the plagues upon the Egyptians, recognized their own potential for punishment and chose to separate themselves from the ways of the nations, committing to follow God's path. This act of distinction is seen as a form of repentance that protects them from impending harm. The text emphasizes that while they initially made this commitment during the plague of swarms, true and complete separation was only achieved after their exodus from Egypt and the receiving of the Torah. Ultimately, the concepts of redemption and separation are intertwined, highlighting the importance of spiritual distinction in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בדרך רמז מוסר עפ"י המבואר בספה"ק דעיקר עבודת בני ישראל בגלות, לברר ולקבץ הניצה"ק חלקי הנפש ולהעלותם מעומק הקליפות, וזהו ענין קיבוץ נידחים וגאולת הנפשות, ובזה תליא גם גאולת הגופים, דכשישלם בירור כל הניצה"ק להעלותם מעמקי הקליפות אז יגאלו ישראל גאולת עולם בגאולת הנפשות והגופים יחדיו, נמצא כי יסוד הגאולה וסודו תליא בשמירת הברית, דאם ח"ו פוגמים בקדושת הברית ר"ל, מפזרים ניצה"ק בשבי' אל כוחות הסט"א זוגו של הס"מ שמשם מקורו של חטא זה וכמ"ש בספה"ק רמז מהפסוק וקרבה אשת האחד והחזיקה במבושיו זהו זוגו של הס"מ וכת דילה המחטיאים לבנ"א בפגם הברית ר"ל, וזהו בחי' הגלות, שחלקי הנפש היינו הניצה"ק נשבים ביד הקליפות, וא"א להיגאל גאולת הגוף מבין הגוים זולתי אם תקדים אלי' גאולת הנפש כנ"ל.
translation: And even further, in a hint of moral teaching according to what is explained in the holy books, the main work of the Children of Israel in exile is to clarify and gather the sparks of the soul and elevate them from the depths of the klipot. This is the matter of gathering the exiles and the redemption of the souls, and in this, the redemption of the bodies is also dependent. When the clarification of all the sparks is completed and they are elevated from the depths of the klipot, then Israel will be redeemed with an eternal redemption, both of souls and bodies together. It is found that the foundation and secret of redemption is dependent on the preservation of the covenant. For if, Heaven forbid, they blemish the sanctity of the covenant, they scatter the sparks into captivity to the forces of the Other Side, the counterpart of the Sitra Achra, from where the source of this sin comes, as it is written in the holy books, hinted at by the verse, "And the wife of one approached and held onto his garments," this is the counterpart of the Sitra Achra and its faction that causes people to sin through the blemish of the covenant, Heaven forbid. This is the aspect of exile, where the parts of the soul, namely the sparks, are captured by the klipot, and it is impossible to achieve the redemption of the body from among the nations unless the redemption of the soul precedes it, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the primary task of the Jewish people in exile is to refine and gather the sparks of the soul, elevating them from the depths of the klipot (impurities). This process of redeeming the sparks is linked to the ultimate redemption of both souls and bodies. The text highlights that the foundation of redemption is rooted in the sanctity of the covenant, warning that any transgression can lead to the scattering of these sparks into the forces of evil. Thus, true redemption can only occur when the redemption of the soul precedes the redemption of the body.

passage_content: ואפשר לרמוז זה במאמה"כ פדות שלח לעמו צוה לעולם בריתו, עפי"ד הגמ ' (נדרים ל"ב ע"ב) גדולה מילה שאלמלא מילה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ שנאמר (ירמי' ל"ג) אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה חקות שמים וארץ לא שמתי, ופליגא דרב אלעזר דא"ר אלעזר גדולה תורה שאלמלא תורה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ שנא' אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה וגו' עכ"ד הגמ ' וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל דר"א משמע לי' דהאי ברית היינו תורה, דהיינו ברית של יומם ולילה דכתיב ובתורתו יהגה יומם ולילה עכ"ל, אמנם צ"ב לאידך מ"ד דמוקי להאי קרא אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה במצות מילה, ומילה אינה נוהגת אלא ביום ולא בלילה, דנפק"ל בגמ' מביום השמיני ימול וגו' ביום ולא בלילה, אולם כבר ביארנו במקו"א דשלימות מצוה זו של מילה נשלם רק ע"י שמירת הברית, והרמב"ם ז"ל כתב בטעם מצוה זו שהוא להחליש כח התאוה , ואמרז"ל בגמ' דהפוגם בריתו נמשכה ערלתו ונראה כאינו מהול, עד שאאע"ה אינו מכיר לי' אם מהול ואינו מוציאו מגיהנם עיי"ש נמצא שרק ע"י שמירת הברית נתקיים המצוה בשלימותה, ודבר זה נוהגת ביום ובלילה שצריך שמירה בכל רגע בלי הפסק, ורז"ל אמרו שלא יהרהר אדם ביום ויבוא לידי טומאה בלילה ר"ל, ותלוי בזה קיום כל העולם וגאולתן של ישראל, גם מקושר עם ברית של תורה, שאם יזכה האדם להתדבק בתוה"ק דביקות אמיתי ולא יתפרד מחשבתו הימנה, אז ינצל בודאי מהרהורים רעים ופגם הברית, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל דאין ההרהור מצוי אלא בלב פנוי מן החכמה היינו חכמת התוה"ק , וז"ש רז"ל אלמלא מילה ואלמלא תורה לא נתקיימו שמים וארץ. שנא' אם לא בריתי יומם ולילה חקות שמים וארץ לא שמתי, דקיום כל העולמות תלויים בהם, וז"פ הפסוק פדות שלח לעמו צוה לעולם בריתו, שהבוי"ת הכין כח הפדות והגאולה לישראל, ע"י שצוה לעולם בריתו, היינו ברית המילה וברית התורה הנוהגים לעולם יומם ולילה, ואם ישמרו בריתות אלו יזכו להחיש ולמהר גאולתם בב"א.
translation:
And it is possible to hint at this in the verse, "He sent redemption to His people; He commanded His covenant forever." According to the Gemara (Nedarim 32b), "Great is the commandment of circumcision, for were it not for circumcision, the heavens and the earth would not have been established," as it is said (Jeremiah 33), "If My covenant for day and night had not been established, I would not have set the laws of heaven and earth." This is in disagreement with Rabbi Elazar, who said, "Great is the Torah, for were it not for the Torah, the heavens and the earth would not have been established," as it is said, "If My covenant for day and night..." Thus says the Gemara. And the Maharsha wrote that Rabbi Elazar understands that this covenant refers to the Torah, which is the covenant of day and night, as it is written, "And in His Torah he shall meditate day and night." However, it is difficult to understand the other opinion that establishes this verse, "If My covenant for day and night" in the context of the commandment of circumcision, since circumcision is only practiced during the day and not at night, as the Gemara derives, "On the eighth day he shall be circumcised... during the day and not at night." 

However, we have already explained elsewhere that the completeness of this commandment of circumcision is only fulfilled through the observance of the covenant. And the Rambam wrote that the reason for this commandment is to weaken the power of desire. And our Sages said in the Gemara that one who damages his covenant has his foreskin prolonged and appears as if he is uncircumcised, to the extent that, Heaven forbid, he is not recognized if he is circumcised, and he is not taken out of Gehenna, as stated there. Thus, it is found that only through the observance of the covenant is the commandment fulfilled in its entirety, and this matter is applicable both day and night, as there must be vigilance at every moment without interruption. And our Sages said that a person should not contemplate during the day and come to impurity at night, Heaven forbid. The existence of the entire world and the redemption of Israel depend on this, and it is also connected with the covenant of the Torah, for if a person merits to cling to the Holy Torah with true attachment and does not separate his thoughts from it, then he will certainly be saved from evil thoughts and the blemish of the covenant, as the Rambam wrote that contemplation is only found in a heart free from wisdom, meaning the wisdom of the Holy Torah. This is what our Sages said, "Were it not for circumcision and were it not for the Torah, the heavens and the earth would not have been established," as it is said, "If My covenant for day and night had not been established, I would not have set the laws of heaven and earth," for the existence of all worlds depends on them. 

Thus, the verse "He sent redemption to His people; He commanded His covenant forever" indicates that the Blessed One prepared the power of redemption and salvation for Israel by commanding His covenant forever, which is the covenant of circumcision and the covenant of the Torah that are practiced forever, day and night. If they keep these covenants, they will merit to hasten and expedite their redemption, may it be soon.
summary: The passage emphasizes the essential connection between the covenant of circumcision (Brit Milah) and the study of Torah, asserting that both are crucial for the existence of the heavens and the earth. It highlights that the fulfillment of the commandment of circumcision is achieved through the ongoing commitment to the covenant, which must be maintained at all times, day and night. The text also suggests that true attachment to the Torah protects individuals from negative thoughts and the degradation of the covenant, ultimately linking the observance of these covenants to the redemption of Israel. The overarching message is that adherence to these divine covenants is vital for the sustenance and redemption of the world.

passage_content: ויתבאר בזה דברי המסורה ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך, היינו הבדלה והפרשה מן העכו"ם לברר חלקי הנפש הניצה"ק השבויים אצלם, גם יתפרש פדות מלשון פדיון וגאולה כפי' המדרש כי בזה תליא גאולתם של ישראל, וזהו פדות שלח לעמו צוה לעולם בריתו ע"י הברית של תורה וברית של מילה יגאלו ישראל, אמנם בעוה"ר הנסיונות והתגברות כוחות הטומאה גדולים וחזקים עלינו מאוד. ואם כבר נכשל האדם ר"ל בפגם הברית, נבראו ממעשיו מזיקים ומלאכים רעים הגורמים לו לחטוא עוד ולהביאו לידי הרהורים רעים, ואין בכח האדם להתגבר נגדם כ"א בסייעתא דשמיא, ולז"א כי עם ד' החסד והרבה עמו פדות שהבוי"ת רב החסד ומרבה להטיב יסייע בידנו להשלים נפשותינו ולהרבות בחי' הפדות ע"י שמירת שני הבריתות שבהם תליא גאולתם של ישראל.
translation: And the words of the Masorah will be clarified here, and I have placed redemption between My people and your people, meaning the distinction and separation from the idolaters to clarify the parts of the soul that are captured among them. Additionally, redemption will be explained from the language of redemption and salvation, as the Midrash interprets, for in this their redemption of Israel is dependent. And this is the redemption that He sent to His people; He commanded forever His covenant through the covenant of the Torah and the covenant of circumcision, by which Israel will be redeemed. However, in our current situation, the trials and the strengthening of the forces of impurity are very great and strong against us. And if a person has already stumbled, God forbid, in the breach of the covenant, harmful spirits and evil angels are created from his actions, causing him to sin further and leading him to evil thoughts. And a person does not have the strength to overcome them except with heavenly assistance. Therefore, it is said that with God, who is kindness, and much with Him is redemption, for the Master of kindness and the One who increases goodness will assist us to complete our souls and to increase the life of redemption through the observance of the two covenants, in which their redemption of Israel is dependent.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption (p'dut) in relation to the Jewish people, emphasizing the importance of separating from non-Jewish influences to reclaim the divine sparks of the soul that are trapped among them. It highlights that the redemption of Israel is linked to the observance of the Torah and the covenant of circumcision, which serve as means of spiritual liberation. The text acknowledges the challenges posed by negative forces and the difficulty individuals face in overcoming them, stressing the necessity of divine assistance. Ultimately, it conveys that through the practice of these covenants, one can achieve spiritual elevation and redemption.
