passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המסורה, שירמזו הפסוקים על ג' זמני גאולה שהי' בחינתם שונה זה מזה, ושמתי פדות בין עמו ובין עמך ירמוז על גאולת מצרים שנגאלו ישראל מהם לעולם ונפטרו משעבודם לגמרי וז"א ושמתי פדות בין עמי ובין עמך שיהי' הבדלה והפרשה גמורה כמ"ש כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם, אמנם בגאולת בבל לא הי' רק בחי' פקידה ועדיין היו ישראל משועבדים תחת יד פרס והרומיים, ולא זכו לבחי ' הפרשה זו שהי' בגאולת מצרים שנאמר לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, אלא שהי' צורך בו להקים עולה של תורה שבע"פ, שנתייסדה בזמן בית שני ע"י אנשי כנה"ג וחכמי המשנה כמו שביארנו במקו"א , וזהו ירמוז פדות שלח לעמו, שהי' גאולה ע"י שליח ולא גאולה נצחית רק בחי' פקידה, למען הקים יסוד תושבע"פ, וז"ש פדות שלח לעמו צוה לעולם בריתו לקיים ברית התורה, שלא כרת ד' ברית כ"א על תושבע"פ כאמרז"ל ולא אמר בין עמי ובין עמך שלא הי' הפרשה גמורה ועדיין היו משועבדים למלכי פרס כנ"ל ובגלות האחרון הזה שאין לנו כח התורה וכח שמירת הברית ואיך נזכה להיגאל, אמנם כבר הבטיחנו הנבואה ( ישעי ' ס"ג) שיאמר הקב"ה ואביט כי אין עוזר ואשתומם כי אין סומך ותושע לי זרועי וגו', ואמר למעני למעני אעשה והגאולה העתידה יהי' למען שמו ית ', וזהו ירמוז כי עם ד' החסד והרבה "עמו" פדות, כביכול הבוי"ת נגאל עמנו כמ"ש רז"ל (מגילה כ"ט ע"א) ושב ד' אלקיך את שבותך והשיב לא נאמר אלא ושב מלמד שהקב"ה שב עמהן מבין הגליות ואז יהי' גאולת עולם וז"ש והרבה עמו פדות שבחי' הגאולה יהי' יתירה וגדולה על כל הגאולות שקדמו אלי', הבוי"ת יזכנו לזה בב"א.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the Masorah, that the verses hint at three times of redemption that were of different natures from one another. "And I will put redemption between My people and your people" hints at the redemption from Egypt, from which Israel was redeemed forever and completely freed from their servitude. This is to say, "And I will put redemption between My people and your people," that there will be a complete distinction and separation, as it is said, "For as you have seen Egypt today, you shall see them no more forever." However, in the redemption from Babylon, it was only a matter of visitation, and Israel was still subjugated under the hand of Persia and the Romans, and they did not merit this kind of separation that was in the redemption from Egypt, which is said to take a nation from the midst of a nation. Rather, there was a need to establish the foundation of the Oral Torah, which was established during the Second Temple by the Men of the Great Assembly and the sages of the Mishnah, as we have explained in other places. This hints at "redemption He sent to His people," which was a redemption through a messenger and not an eternal redemption, only a matter of visitation, in order to establish the foundation of the Oral Torah. This is what is meant by "redemption He sent to His people," He commanded forever His covenant to uphold the covenant of the Torah, which the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not make a covenant except regarding the Oral Torah, as our sages have said. And He did not say "between My people and your people," for there was not a complete separation, and they were still subjugated to the kings of Persia, as mentioned above. And in this last exile, we do not have the strength of the Torah and the strength of keeping the covenant, and how will we merit to be redeemed? However, the prophecy has already assured us (Isaiah 63) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will say, "And I looked, and there was no helper; and I wondered that there was no supporter; therefore My own arm brought salvation to Me," and He said, "For My sake, for My sake I will act," and the future redemption will be for the sake of His name, Blessed be He. This hints that with the Holy One, Blessed be He, of kindness and much "with His people" redemption, as it were, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will redeem with us, as our sages have said (Megillah 29a), "And the Lord your God will restore your captivity," and it does not say "and He will return," but "and He will return" teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, returns with them from among the exiles, and then there will be an eternal redemption. This is what is meant by "and much with His people" redemption, that the nature of the redemption will be greater and more significant than all the redemptions that have preceded it. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, grant us this speedily in our days.
summary: The passage discusses three distinct phases of redemption in Jewish history, emphasizing the complete separation of the Israelites from their oppressors during the Exodus from Egypt, contrasted with the partial redemption during the Babylonian exile. It highlights the importance of the Oral Torah established during the Second Temple period, which served as a means of spiritual sustenance despite ongoing subjugation. The text reassures that in the final redemption, God will act for His own sake, ensuring a profound and ultimate liberation that surpasses all previous redemptions, with a promise of divine presence and support for His people.

passage_content: כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך וגו' פרש"י ז"ל למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות עכ"ל, הקשה הרא"ם ז"ל מכת בכורות מאן דכר שמי', ולמה לא יתפרש על מכת ברד שמדבר בה הכתוב, ותירץ בשם ר"ת מאורליינוש שהגירסא צ"ל ביכורות, והוא הברד שנלקה בו האביב הממהר להתבכר וכו ', שהוא שקולה נגד כל המכות, אמנם הקשה עליו הגו"א זלה"ה ממ"ש רש"י ( בפ ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, שמכת בכורות קשה מכולם, ואם נפרש כאן דברי רש"י על מכת ברד, א"כ יהיו דבריו סותרות זא"ז .
translation: For this time, I am sending all My plagues upon your heart, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, teaches us that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. Thus far the text. The Ra'ah, of blessed memory, questioned why the plague of the firstborn is mentioned, and why it should not be interpreted as referring to the plague of hail, which is discussed in the verse. He answered in the name of R. Tzvi of Orlianush that the correct reading should be "the firstborn," which refers to the hail that struck during the spring, hastening to ripen, etc., and that it is equivalent to all the plagues. However, the G'ra, of blessed memory, challenged him based on what Rashi writes (in Parashat Shemot) regarding the verse "Behold, I am killing your firstborn son," that the plague of the firstborn is more severe than all. If we interpret Rashi's words here as referring to the plague of hail, then his statements would contradict one another.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of the firstborn, which is considered equivalent to all the other plagues. It raises a question about the interpretation of this plague in relation to the plague of hail, suggesting that the term "firstborn" may refer to the hail that affects the early spring. However, it also highlights a contradiction with Rashi's commentary, which states that the plague of the firstborn is the most severe of all, emphasizing the unique theological weight and severity attributed to this particular plague in the context of divine judgment.

passage_content: ב) ממ"ש רז"ל עה"פ והנה לא שמעת עד כה, עד שתשמע ממני מכת בכורות שאפתח בכה, שנא' כה אמר ד' בחצות לילה וגו' ואם נימא שמכת ברד שקולה נגד כל המכות, איך יתכן שסבל מכת ברד הקשה שבכולם ולא יכנע לבבו, ואח"כ נכנע ע"י מכת בכורות שאינו קשה כמוהו.
translation: B) As our Sages have said regarding the verse "And behold, you have not heard until now," until you hear from me about the plague of the firstborn that I will open with, as it is said, "Thus says the Lord, at midnight..." And if we say that the plague of hail is equivalent to all the plagues, how is it possible that he endured the severe plague of hail, which is the hardest of them all, and did not humble his heart, and afterwards he was humbled by the plague of the firstborn, which is not as severe as it?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine judgment and the nature of suffering, highlighting that despite the severity of the plague of hail, it did not lead to true repentance in the heart of Pharaoh. In contrast, the plague of the firstborn, though seemingly less severe, ultimately broke Pharaoh's resistance. This illustrates the idea that spiritual awakening and humility can arise from unexpected sources, emphasizing the transformative power of divine intervention in the face of human obstinacy. The text reflects a deeper understanding of how different forms of suffering can lead to repentance and change.

passage_content: ג) את העיר אפרוש את כפי אל ד' וגו' פרש"י (בשם מד"ר) אבל בתוך העיר לא התפלל לפי שהיתה מלאה גלולים והקשו המפרשים דלטעם זה הי' צריך להיות כן בכל המכות, ולא מצינו שהזכיר כן אלא במכת ברד בלבד, ובמכת הצפרדעים כתיב ויצא משה ואהרן מעם פרעה ויצעק משה אל ד' וגו', וכן במכת ערוב הנה אנכי יוצא מעמך והעתרתי אל ד', ובמכת הארבה ויצא מעם פרעה ויעתר לד' ואינו מבואר שיצא מן העיר כ"א במכת ברד בלבד וטעמא בעי. והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב על דרך הפשט יתכן לומר שהי' משה מתפלל בביתו, רק בפעם הזאת ראה להיות כפיו פרושות השמים ויחדלו הקולות והמטר מיד, ולא יתכן לעשות כן בעיר ע"כ אמר כצאתי את העיר עכ"ל ואינו מבואר כוונתו מדוע הי' צורך במכה זו דייקא פרישת כפים, ומ"ט לא יתכן לעשות כן בעיר.
translation: 3) "I will stretch out my hand over the city to the Lord," etc. Rashi explains (in the name of Midrash Rabbah) that he did not pray within the city because it was filled with idols. The commentators question that for this reason it should have been the case for all the plagues, yet we find this mentioned only regarding the plague of hail. And regarding the plague of frogs, it is written, "And Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord," and similarly in the plague of wild beasts, "Behold, I am going out from you, and I will entreat the Lord," and in the plague of locusts, "He went out from Pharaoh and entreated the Lord," and it is not clarified that he went out of the city except in the plague of hail alone, and the reason is needed. And Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the straightforward interpretation that it is possible to say that Moses was praying in his house, but this time he saw fit to have his hands stretched out to the heavens, and the sounds and the rain ceased immediately, and it is not appropriate to do so in the city; therefore, he said, "As I go out of the city." And his intention is not clarified as to why there was a need for this plague specifically to stretch out hands, and why it is not appropriate to do so in the city.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion centers on why Moses specifically prayed outside the city during the plague of hail, as the city was filled with idols. The text raises questions about why this practice was not consistently applied in other plagues. The Ramban suggests that Moses needed to raise his hands to the heavens in a way that was not possible within the idolatrous city, highlighting the importance of purity and intention in prayer. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of the necessity for spiritual elevation and the rejection of idolatry in seeking divine intervention.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"ד הרבינו בחיי זלה"ה שכתב ע"ד הקבלה, שהוצרך משרע"ה במכה זו להתפלל בנשיאת כפים משא"כ בכל השאר, מטעם שהיו בנ"א מתים בה לפחד הקולות ולמכת הברד שהיתה בהסכמת הוא ובית דינו וכו ', ולכך הוצרך בביטולם לישא את כפיו כדי שיתקדשו כל העשר וכו ', וז"ש משה אפרוש כפי אל ד' כלומר אפרוש כפי כנגד העשר ויתקדשו ואכוין בהם אל ד' ומיד הקולות יחדלון עכ"ל, ואולי גם הרמב"ן ז"ל הלביש בדבריו בחי' הסוד הזה כדרכו בכ"מ , וז"ש כי רק בפעם הזאת ראה להיות כפיו פרושות השמים וכו' והתכוין לבחי ' נשיאות כפים והנה לזה צריך טהרה גדולה כמ"ש המט"א דלטעם זה אין נוהגין לישא כפים בכל יום מפני שאין לנו כח הטהרה הצורך לנ"כ עייש"ד , ואולי לטעם זה יצא משרע"ה מן העיר לצד שהיתה מלאה גילולים ולא יתכן לעשות עבודה חשובה זו במקום טומאה, אבל בשאר המכות אולי הי' מתפלל בביתו כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, כי מצד הדין סגי בהרחקה זו, ולא נאסר כל העיר בשביל הע"ז אשר בו, אלא לפי שהוצרך לנשיאת כפים יצא מן העיר ונרמז סוד זה בלשונו הק ' של הרמב"ן ז"ל.
translation: And although according to the words of our teacher Rabbi Bachye, may his memory be blessed, who wrote regarding the Kabbalah, that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to pray with raised hands for this plague, unlike all the others, because there were people dying from fear of the sounds and the hail that was agreed upon by him and his court, therefore he needed to raise his hands so that all ten would be sanctified, etc. This is what is meant by Moshe saying, "I will stretch out my hands to God," meaning I will stretch out my hands against the ten and they will be sanctified, and I will direct them towards God, and immediately the sounds will cease, etc. Perhaps also the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, clothed his words with this aspect of the secret as he does everywhere. This is what is meant by saying that only at this time did he see fit to have his hands stretched out to the heavens, etc., and he intended the aspect of the raising of hands, and behold, for this one needs great purity, as mentioned by the MTA, and for this reason we do not practice raising hands every day because we do not have the purity necessary for the priestly blessing, as is known. And perhaps for this reason Moshe Rabbeinu went out of the city because it was full of idols, and it is not fitting to perform this important service in a place of impurity. But regarding the other plagues, perhaps he prayed in his house, as mentioned by the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, because according to the law, this separation is sufficient, and the entire city was not forbidden because of the idolatry within it, but since he needed to raise his hands, he went out of the city, and this secret is hinted at in the holy language of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the unique necessity for Moses to pray with raised hands during the plague of hail, as opposed to other plagues, due to the fear and death among the people caused by the sounds and the severity of the plague. It emphasizes the importance of spiritual purity and the need for a sacred environment for such a significant act of prayer, suggesting that Moses left the city filled with idolatry to maintain this purity. The text also hints at deeper mystical insights, indicating that the act of raising hands is connected to divine intention and the sanctification of the ten plagues. Overall, it reflects on the interplay between ritual, purity, and divine intervention in the context of the plagues in Egypt.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בהקדם לבאר דברי רש"י ז"ל למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות, ולכאורה לפי משמעות הפסוק מכת ברד שקולה נגד כולן דכתיב כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי וגו' וכתב רבינו בחיי ז"ל שבמכת ברד נכללו בו מגיפות הרבה וזהו כל מגפתי עיי"ש גם הי' בו שינוי מנהגו של עולם שנא' ויהי ברד ואש מתלקחת בתוך הברד, ואמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' י"ב סי' ד') שהי' נס בתוך נס האש והברד מעורבין והברד מים הוא ולעשות רצון קונם עשו שלו' ביניהם, וע"כ נתרכך לב פרעה ולא הכביד את לבו כבראשונים, ואמר חטאתי הפעם ד' הצדיק ואני ועמי הרשעים, אלא שהחזיק ד' את לבבו כמ"ש ויחזק לב פרעה ולא שלח את בנ"י , כי עדיין לא הגיע זמן גאולתם של ישראל, ובסודן של דברים הי' צורך עוד להביא עליו עוד מכת ארבה חושך מכת בכורות, ע"כ נתן לו השי"ת אבירת הלב ואחר שחדל הברד הכביד לבו הוא ועבדיו.
translation: And although it is also appropriate to explain the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, we learned that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. And seemingly, according to the meaning of the verse, the plague of hail is equivalent to all of them, as it is written, "For this time I will send all My plagues..." And Rabbi Bechaye, may his memory be blessed, wrote that in the plague of hail many afflictions were included, and this is "all My plagues." Furthermore, there was a change in the order of the world, as it is said, "And there was hail, and fire mingled with the hail." And our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat 12, section 4) that there was a miracle within a miracle; the fire and the hail were mixed, and the hail is water, and to do the will of their Creator, they made peace between them. Therefore, Pharaoh's heart softened, and he did not harden his heart as he had before. And he said, "I have sinned this time; the Lord is righteous, and I and my people are wicked." However, the Holy One, blessed be He, hardened his heart, as it is written, "And the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart," and he did not send the Children of Israel, for the time of their redemption had not yet arrived. And in the secret of the matter, there was still a need to bring upon him another plague of locusts, darkness, and the plague of the firstborn. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him a strong heart, and after the hail ceased, he hardened his heart, he and his servants.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plagues in Egypt, particularly highlighting that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the other plagues combined. It notes that the plague of hail contained multiple afflictions and was marked by a miraculous intertwining of fire and hail, symbolizing divine intervention. The text emphasizes that Pharaoh's heart was softened temporarily, leading him to acknowledge his wrongdoing, yet God ultimately hardened his heart to fulfill the necessary timeline for Israel's redemption. This reflects the Hasidic understanding of divine timing and the interplay between human free will and divine orchestration in the process of redemption.

passage_content: וז"פ הפסוק כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי, אל לבך שיהי' לפי מדת לבך וינתן לך אומץ הלב שתוכל לסבלו, אף שהוא שקולה כנגד כל המכות כאומרו את כל מגפתי, אמנם במכת בכורות הי' רצון הבוי"ת שישלח את ישראל מיד, כמ"ש עוד נגע א' אביא על פרעה ועל מצרים אח"כ ישלח אתכם, וע"כ לא חיזק ד' את לבבו במכה זו, ולא הי' בכוחו לסבול עוד והוכרח לשלחם, ולפי"ז אפשר דמצד האיכות היתה מכת הברד קשה מכולן, אבל לפי שנתן לו הקב"ה אבירת הלב הי' יכול לסבלו ופג צערו מיד אחר שחדל הברד, וזהו כלל גדול דאם יש לאדם אבירת לב יכול לסבול הרבה יותר מכוחו, ואם אין לו אומץ הלב אינו יכול לעמוד אפי' ברכות ולצד זה הי' מכת בכורות קשה מכולן לפי שניטל ממנו חוזק הלב.
translation: And the meaning of the verse is that this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart, so that it will be according to the measure of your heart, and you will be given courage of heart to be able to endure it, even though it is equivalent to all the plagues, as it says, all My plagues. However, in the plague of the firstborn, it was the will of the Blessed One that He would send Israel out immediately, as it is written, "I will bring one more plague upon Pharaoh and upon Egypt; afterwards, he will send you out." Therefore, God did not strengthen his heart in this plague, and he was no longer able to endure and was compelled to send them out. According to this, it is possible that in terms of quality, the plague of hail was the hardest of all, but since the Holy One, blessed be He, gave him courage of heart, he was able to endure it, and his pain ceased immediately after the hail stopped. This is a great principle: if a person has courage of heart, he can endure much more than his natural strength; but if he lacks courage of heart, he cannot withstand even blessings. And for this reason, the plague of the firstborn was the hardest of all, as the strength of the heart was taken from him.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence and the strength of the heart in facing challenges. It emphasizes that God sends afflictions tailored to an individual's capacity to endure, granting them the courage needed to withstand suffering. The text contrasts the plagues, noting that while the plague of the firstborn was the most severe due to the removal of Pharaoh's heart's strength, the hail plague was bearable for him because God provided him with the fortitude to endure it. Ultimately, the ability to withstand trials is linked to the inner strength bestowed by God.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי רש"י ז"ל דממ"ש הכתוב בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך , שינתן לך אומץ לב לסבול מכה זו השקולה כנגד כולם, למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות לצד שניטל ממנו חוזק הלב, וע"כ לפי בחי' מצבו היתה זו קשה מכולן, ובאיכות היתה ברד קשה מכולן ומעתה אין עוד סתירה וכל דרז"ל שרירים וקיימים, ואולי לטעם זה יצא משרע"ה מן העיר להתפלל במכה זו דייקא , לפי שכבר נתרכך לב פרעה ואמר ד' הצדיק, והודיעו השי"ת למשרע"ה כי אין רצונו שיעשה פרעה תשובה כמ"ש את כל מגפתי אל לבך , ע"כ לא התפלל משרע"ה בתוך העיר, כי נודע דתפלת הצדיק עושה רושם להכניס בחי' יראה ואהבה בלבות בנ"א, ולא ימלט שלא הי' נאחז קצת בחי' קדושה בלב פרעה מתפלת משרע"ה ע"כ התרחק כפי האפשרות ויצא מן העיר, משא"כ בשאר המכות לא הוצרך לזה כי הי' פרעה רחוק מבחי ' זו לעשות תשובה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, regarding what the verse states, "In this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," that you should be given courage of heart to endure this plague, which is equivalent to all of them. We have learned that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues, in that the strength of the heart was taken from him. Therefore, according to the state of his being, this was the hardest of all. In quality, the hail was the hardest of all. From now on, there is no contradiction, and all the teachings of our Sages are firm and enduring. Perhaps for this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu went out of the city to pray specifically for this plague, since Pharaoh's heart had already softened, and he said, "The Lord is the righteous one." And the Holy One, blessed be He, informed Moshe Rabbeinu that He did not want Pharaoh to repent, as it is said, "All My plagues upon your heart." Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu did not pray within the city, for it is known that the prayer of the righteous makes an impression to instill a measure of fear and love in the hearts of people. It cannot be avoided that there was not a little grasp of holiness in Pharaoh's heart from the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu. Therefore, he distanced himself as much as possible and went out of the city. In contrast, for the other plagues, he did not need to do this, as Pharaoh was far from this state to repent.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of the firstborn, which is considered the most severe due to its impact on Pharaoh's heart, contrasting it with other plagues. It emphasizes that this plague was unique because it stripped Pharaoh of his resolve, making it harder for him to repent. The text suggests that Moses refrained from praying within the city during this plague to avoid inadvertently instilling a sense of holiness in Pharaoh, as his prayers could evoke fear and love of God in others. In contrast, during the other plagues, Pharaoh was too distant from repentance for such considerations to be necessary.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד בחי' בזה עפימ"ש בתרגום יוב"ע עה"פ כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך , ארי בזמנא חדא אנא שלח מחתא לך מן שמיא, ותתיב ית כל מחתי וכו ', דמן קדמי הוון משתלחין ולא מן חרשיותא , ועד"ז פי' באוהחה"ק כי בכל המכות עד עתה, לא הי' מחליט פרעה בדעתו כי הם מאלקי היכולת והי' תולה במכשפות ומעשה שדים וכו' לזה אמר אליו ד' באמצעות המכה אשר אביא עליך, אני שולח את כל מגפתי שכבר הבאתי וכו' אל לבך , פי' שתדע כי לא מעשה כישוף ושדים המה אלא מעשה אלקים עכדה"ק , וכבר ביארנו בפנים שונים איך נתברר לו ממכה זו בירור גמור שמעשה אלקים הוא ולא בכשפים.
translation: And even though there is another aspect to this, as explained in the translation of the verse, "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," for at one time I sent a messenger to you from Heaven, and all My plagues were set before you, etc., for from the beginning they were sent and not from sorcery, and similarly it is explained in the holy teachings that in all the plagues until now, Pharaoh did not decisively understand that they were from the God of power, and he attributed it to sorcery and the deeds of demons, etc. Therefore, God said to him through the plague that I will bring upon you, "I am sending all My plagues that I have already brought," etc., to mean that you should know that they are not the works of sorcery and demons, but rather the works of God, blessed be He. And we have already explained in various ways how it became clear to him from this plague that it is a complete clarification that it is the work of God and not through sorcery.
summary: The passage discusses the divine nature of the plagues sent to Pharaoh, emphasizing that they are not the result of sorcery or witchcraft, but rather direct acts of God. It highlights that previous plagues did not convince Pharaoh of God's power, as he attributed them to magical forces. However, through the current plague, God aims to instill a clear understanding in Pharaoh's heart that these events are unequivocally divine interventions. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of recognizing God's omnipotence in the world and the importance of faith in divine providence.

passage_content: והנ"ל לעניננו עפימ"ד במד"ר ( פי"ב ז') ובתנחומא ( וארא סי' ט"ז) ומטר לא נתך ארצה תלאן ברפיון, ואימתי ירד בימי יהושע על האמורים שנאמר (יהושע י') וד' השליך עליהם אבנים גדולות וגו', והשאר עתידין לירד על גוג ומגוג לימות המשיח עכ"ד המדרש, ובזוה"ק (פ' בשלח דף נ"ג ע"א) ר' יהודה אמר אינון אבני ברדא דהוו נחתין אתעכבו על ידוי דמשה , לבתר עבדו נוקמין ביומי דיהושע , ולזמנא דאתי זמינין לאחתא אינון דאשתארן על אדום ובנותי ' עכ"ל, נמצא שמכת הברד שירד בימי פרעה, חלק ממנה תלוי' באויר ומוכנת לימות המשיח, ופרעה הי' חכם בכשפים וידע מקצת העתידות באצטגנינות ע"כ נתברר לו מזה שאינו מעשה כשפים, דאז יתבטל כל ענין הכשפים והאלילים כרות יכרתון, ולפי שחלק ממנה נגנז לימות המשיח החלק יעיד על כולו שאינו מעשה כשפים.
translation: And the above is relevant to our discussion according to the Midrash (Parashat Beshalach, Chapter 2, Verse 7) and in Tanchuma (Va'era, Section 16), and the rain did not fall to the ground, it was suspended in the air. And when did it fall? In the days of Joshua upon the Amorites, as it is said (Joshua 10), "And the Lord cast down great stones upon them," etc. The remainder is destined to fall upon Gog and Magog in the days of the Messiah, thus concludes the Midrash. And in the Zohar (Parashat Beshalach, Page 53, Side A), Rabbi Yehuda said, "Those are the hailstones that were held back at the hands of Moses; afterwards, they will take revenge in the days of Joshua, and for the time that is coming, they are prepared to strike those that remain upon Edom and its daughters." Thus, it is found that the plague of hail that fell in the days of Pharaoh, part of it is suspended in the air and prepared for the days of the Messiah. And Pharaoh was wise in sorcery and knew some of the future through astrology; therefore, it was clarified to him that this is not an act of sorcery, for then all matters of sorcery and idols would be nullified, they will be cut off. And because part of it is hidden for the days of the Messiah, that part will testify for the whole that it is not an act of sorcery.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the hail that fell during the plagues in Egypt, suggesting that a portion of it is preserved for the Messianic era. It highlights that this hail, which was a divine act rather than a result of sorcery, serves as a testament to the ultimate nullification of magic and idolatry in the future. The text emphasizes the connection between historical events and their eschatological implications, illustrating the belief that remnants of divine interventions are retained for future redemption. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the continuity of divine presence and action throughout history, culminating in the Messianic age.

passage_content: והנה זה נעשה ע"י תפלת משרע"ה כמ"ש ויפרוש כפיו אל ד' ויחדלו הקולות והברד ומטר לא נתך ארצה, ודרשו רז"ל שתלאן ברפיון, ואולי לטעם זה יצא משרע"ה מן העיר ולא התפלל בעיר על הסרת הברד לטעם שהיתה מלאה גילולים ולא מצינו שעשה כן בשאר המכות, אמנם בכל המכות הי' בחי' תפלתו רק על הזמן ההוא להסירם, אבל במכת הברד הרי פעל בתפלתו לימות המשיח ועל מלחמת אדום, ואז יתקיים כל הרשעה כעשן תכלה והאלילים כרות יכרתון, וע"כ בענין הנוגע לגאולה העתידה א"א שיהי' במקום גילולים, ולטעם זה יצא משרע"ה מן העיר בתפלה זו לעשות הרחקה יתירה מכל תערובת כוחות הטומאה משא"כ בשאר תפלה סגי מדינא בהרחקה לבית אחר שאין בו ע"ז, וכמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דיתכן לומר שהי' מתפלל משרע"ה בביתו עיי"ש.
translation: And behold, this was accomplished through the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu, as it is written, "And he spread out his hands to the Lord," and the voices ceased, and the hail and rain did not fall to the ground. The sages explained that he suspended them in a state of slackness, and perhaps for this reason Moshe Rabbeinu left the city and did not pray in the city for the removal of the hail, because it was filled with idols, and we do not find that he did so for the other plagues. However, in all the other plagues, his prayer was only for that time to remove them, but regarding the plague of hail, he indeed acted in his prayer for the days of the Messiah and for the war against Edom. Then all wickedness will be consumed like smoke, and the idols will be cut off. Therefore, concerning the matter related to the future redemption, it is impossible for it to be in a place of idols, and for this reason Moshe Rabbeinu left the city in this prayer to create a greater separation from any mixture of the forces of impurity, unlike in other prayers where it suffices according to the law to distance oneself to another house that has no idolatry, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote that it is possible to say that Moshe Rabbeinu was praying in his house, as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses how Moses' prayer for the cessation of the hail was distinct due to the idolatry present in the city, leading him to pray outside of it. This act symbolizes a deeper spiritual separation from impurity, as the prayer not only sought immediate relief but also invoked a future redemption associated with the Messianic era. The text emphasizes that true redemption cannot occur in a place filled with idolatry, highlighting the necessity of spiritual purity in the process of divine intervention. Thus, Moses' actions reflect a profound understanding of the interplay between prayer, holiness, and the ultimate redemption.

passage_content: וז"ש כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את "כל מגפתי" אל לבך , שיהי' כולל כל המכות ושקולה נגד כולן, ואח"כ יהי' סוף לכל המכות שתתקיים לנער רשעים מן הארץ, ורמז באמרו אל לבך , שבחי' זו עדיין לא ניתנה להתגלות בדבור כ"א בבחי ' המחשבה, כנודע שכל עניני הגאולה הם בבחי ' ליבא לפומא לא גליא , והרבה פירושים נאמרו בכוונת המאמר הזה, ועפ"י פשוטו שלא ניתן להתגלות בדבור כ"א בבחי ' המחשבה שבלב, וע"כ נשמע מכאן דמכת בכורות קשה מכולן, דמ"ש הכתוב את כל מגפתי, שמכת הברד כוללת כל המכות ושקולה נגד כולן, זה בבחי ' אל לבך ויתקיים רק לימות המשיח, אבל בזמן ההוא הי' מכת בכורות קשה מכולן.
translation: And this is what is meant by saying that this time I am sending "all My plagues" to your heart, which will encompass all the plagues and be equal to all of them. And afterwards, there will be an end to all the plagues that will befall the wicked from the land. And it hints by saying to your heart, that this aspect has not yet been revealed in speech, but only in the aspect of thought, as is known that all matters of redemption are in the aspect of "the heart to the mouth is not revealed." Many interpretations have been said regarding the intention of this statement, and according to its simple meaning, it cannot be revealed in speech, but only in the aspect of the thought that is in the heart. Therefore, it is heard from here that the plague of the firstborn is the hardest of all, as the verse states "all My plagues," which means that the plague of hail includes all the plagues and is equal to all of them. This is in the aspect of "to your heart" and will only be fulfilled in the days of the Messiah, but at that time, the plague of the firstborn was the hardest of all.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine punishment and redemption, emphasizing that the plagues are a manifestation of God's will directed at the heart, symbolizing inner contemplation rather than outward expression. It highlights that the final plague, the death of the firstborn, is the most severe and serves as a precursor to the ultimate redemption, which will be fully realized in the Messianic era. The text suggests that the understanding of these events is often concealed in thought rather than articulated, reflecting a deeper spiritual truth about the nature of suffering and salvation.

passage_content: ואיתא במדרש (שה"ש רבה פ"ג סי"ב ) א"ר יוחנן כתיב (איוב כ"ה) עושה שלו' במרומיו, הרקיע של מים והכוכבים של אש ואינן מזיקין זל"ז וכו ', אף במכות פרעה עשה הקב"ה שלום שנא' ויהי ברד ואש מתלקחת בתוך הברד עכ"ד המדרש, ואולי רמזו רז"ל בזה שמכת הברד מוכנת על אדום בזמן ביאת המשיח. ויתקיים שלו' ואמת יהי' בימיו ויבוא אלי' לעשות שלו' בעולם, גם עפ"י פשוטו מקושר הברד עם מדת השלו' כמ"ש ז"ל דהברד מים והי' מתערבת עם האש ועשו שלו' ביניהם לעשות רצון קונם ית ', נוסף לזה יצמח מזה שלו' נצחי ע"י מפלת אדום בגאולה העתידה בב"א.
translation: And it is stated in the Midrash (Song of Songs Rabbah, Chapter 3, Section 12) that Rabbi Yochanan said: It is written (Job 25) "He makes peace in His heights," the firmament of water and the stars of fire, and they do not harm one another, etc. Likewise, in the plagues of Pharaoh, the Holy One, Blessed be He, made peace, as it is stated, "And there was hail, and fire flashing in the midst of the hail." Thus said the Midrash. Perhaps our Sages hinted here that the plague of hail is prepared for Edom at the time of the coming of the Messiah. And peace and truth will be established in his days, and Eliyahu will come to make peace in the world. Also, according to its simple meaning, the hail is connected with the attribute of peace, as our Sages said, that the hail is water and it was mixed with fire, and they made peace between them to fulfill the will of their Creator, Blessed be He. In addition to this, from this will grow eternal peace through the downfall of Edom in the future redemption, may it be soon.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of peace as exemplified in the Midrash, where Rabbi Yochanan highlights the harmony between fire and water in the context of the plagues of Egypt, specifically the plague of hail. This duality symbolizes the ultimate peace that will be established during the Messianic era, particularly through the downfall of Edom. The text suggests that the mingling of fire and water in the hail represents a divine orchestration of peace, reflecting God's will and the promise of eternal tranquility in the future redemption. Ultimately, it emphasizes the connection between divine justice and the restoration of peace in the world.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל לתרץ קושית הראשונים הנ"ל, מדוע במכת ברד דייקא אמר משרע"ה כצאתי את העיר אפרוש כפי, ולא התפלל בתוך העיר לפי שמלאה גלולים, ולא עשה כן בראשונות, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א מכות (דף י' ע"ב) דממחשבת עבירה נברא מלאך רע וממחשבת מצוה נברא מלאך קדוש, ופי' בזה דברי הגמ ' שם בדרך שאדם רוצה לילך מוליכין אותו, דאותן המלאכים שנבראו מרצונו ומחשבתו, מוליכין אותו לגמור מעשהו כפי דעתו ומחשבתו, וכתב האוהחה"ק ( בפ ' תשא עה"פ ולא יהי' בהם נגף) דמלאך רע הנברא מהעבירה הוא מן העון ממש כמעשהו, בסוד עבירה גוררת עבירה עייש"ד , ומבואר בספה"ק שאם זוכה האדם לעשות תשובה מחסר ומחליש כח המשחית מלאך הרע הנברא על ידו, ואף ע"י תנועה קלה של תשובה נפגם צורתו ונחסר משלימותו.
translation: It can also be explained to answer the question of the earlier authorities mentioned, why specifically in the plague of hail did Moshe say, "As I go out of the city, I will spread out my hands," and did not pray within the city because it was filled with idols, whereas he did not do so in the earlier plagues. This will be clarified by first explaining the words of the Maharsha, of blessed memory, in the first chapter of Makkot (page 10b) that from the thought of a transgression, an evil angel is created, and from the thought of a commandment, a holy angel is created. The Gemara explains there that "in the way that a person wants to go, they lead him," meaning that those angels created from his will and thought lead him to complete his actions according to his opinion and thought. The Holy Ohr HaChaim (in Parashat Terumah on the verse "and there shall not be a plague among them") writes that the evil angel created from the transgression is from the sin itself, like his action, in the secret that "a transgression brings another transgression," as explained there. It is clarified in the holy books that if a person merits to repent, it weakens and diminishes the power of the destroying angel created by him, and even through a slight movement of repentance, its form is damaged and it is diminished from its completeness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses' actions during the plague of hail, emphasizing his decision to pray outside the city filled with idols, contrasting it with his previous behavior. It references the teachings of the Maharsha, explaining that thoughts of sin create evil angels, while thoughts of mitzvot (commandments) generate holy angels. The text highlights the idea that a person's intentions guide their spiritual journey, and that through sincere repentance, one can weaken the negative forces created by their sins, thereby restoring their spiritual integrity.

passage_content: והנה במכות הראשונות בעת שביקש פרעה ממשה ואהרן שיתפללו אל ד' להסיר המכה והבטיח לשלח את ישראל, אף שלא היתה תשובתו שלימה, מ"מ מיראת העונש ומאימת המות התחרט לפי שעה על רשעתו וכפירתו בהשי"ת , אלא שאחר שסר המכה ממנו התחזק וחזר לרשעתו , ועכ"פ באותה שעה שאמר העתירו אל ה' הי' לו קצת בחי' אמונה באלקי היכולת ונפגם מלאך המשחית שנברא מרשעתו , והוי כמו ע"ז שביטלו ונפחת צורתו, אף שלא נתבטל ביטול גמור, אבל ביטול קצת הוי ולא הי' עוד בתוקפו כבראשונה, ואולי לטעם זה לא הי' הכרח למשרע"ה לצאת מן העיר להתפלל, כי נתבטל כח הע"ז במקצת ע"י פרעה ריש חורשיא מרכבה להס"מ אבל ממכה השישית ואילך חיזק ה' את לבבו ונמנע ממנו כח התשובה כאמרז"ל , ע"כ מאז נתגבר אצלם כח הסט"א והע"ז , והנה ברד ה' הראשון שהתפלל משרע"ה עליו אחר שחיזק ה' לב פרעה, וע"כ במכה זו בהכרח יצא להתפלל חוץ לעיר, לטעם התגברות כח הע"ז .
translation: And behold, in the first plagues, when Pharaoh asked Moshe and Aharon to pray to Hashem to remove the plague and promised to send Israel away, even though his response was not complete, nevertheless, out of fear of punishment and the terror of death, he momentarily regretted his wickedness and denial of the Holy One, Blessed be He. However, after the plague was removed from him, he strengthened himself and returned to his wickedness. Yet, at that moment when he said, "Entreat Hashem," he had a slight semblance of faith in the Almighty, and the destroying angel that was created from his wickedness was diminished, and it was as if the idolatry was nullified and its form was diminished, even though it was not completely nullified, but a partial nullification does exist, and it was no longer in its full strength as it was before. Perhaps for this reason, it was not necessary for Moshe to go out of the city to pray, because the power of the idolatry was somewhat nullified by Pharaoh, the head of the chariot of the Sitra Achra. But from the sixth plague onward, Hashem strengthened his heart and prevented him from the power of repentance, as our Sages have said. Therefore, from then on, the power of the Sitra Achra and idolatry became stronger against them. And behold, in the first hail, Moshe prayed for him after Hashem had strengthened Pharaoh's heart, and therefore, in this plague, it was necessary for him to go out to pray outside the city, due to the strengthening of the power of idolatry.
summary: In the initial plagues, Pharaoh temporarily repented and showed a semblance of faith in God due to fear of punishment, which weakened the power of the destructive angel created from his wickedness. However, once the plague was lifted, he returned to his evil ways, and from the sixth plague onward, God hardened his heart, preventing true repentance. This shift allowed the forces of evil to gain strength, necessitating Moses to pray outside the city during the hail plague, as the power of idolatry had intensified.

passage_content: באופן אחר נל"פ דברי רש"י ז"ל, עפי"ד הגמ ' (תענית ח' ע"ב) בימי רשב"נ הוה כפנא ומותנא וכו ', א"ל ר' שמואל בר נחמני ניבעי רחמי אכפנא , דכי יהיב רחמנא שובעא לחיי הוא דיהיב דכתיב פותח את ידך ומשביע לכל חי רצון עכ"ד הגמ ', ובזה יל"פ הכתוב ותן זרע ונחי' ולא נמות, דצ"ב הכפל, ואפ"ל הכוונה דע"י שיפסק הרעב יהיו ניצולים מעונש מיתה שאינו בגרמת הרעב, דכי יהיב רחמנא שובעא לחיי הוא דיהיב , והנה ע"י ברכת יעקב אבינו נפסק מהם הרעב, ובתרגום יוב"ע (פ' ויגש ) פי' עה"פ ויברך יעקב את פרעה, ואמר יהי רעוא דיתמלון מוי דנילוס ויעדי כפנא מן עלמא ביומך, והנה כתב רש"י ז"ל ( בפ ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכרך, הוא מכה אחרונה ובה התרהו תחלה מפני שהוא קשה וכו ', ואפשר שלא נכנס הפחד בלבו , מפני שהי' בוטח בברכת יעאע"ה שלא יהי' רעב בימיו, וכי יהיב רחמנא שובעא לחיי הוא דיהיב , וא"כ גם מכת המיתה לא ישלוט עליהם, אבל עכשיו בהתראת הברד שישחית כל תבואתם, חשש שיוסר מהם הברכה ויבוא עליהם הרעב וא"כ אינו בטוח מהצלת המיתה ג"כ, ונכנס עכשיו בלבו הפחד על מכת בכורות, וז"ש כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי "אל לבך " ר"ל שע"י הברד יכנס בלבך גם הפחד על מכת בכורות שהוא שקולה נגד כל מגפתי, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל למדנו מכאן שמכת בכורות קשה מכולן, וע"כ התרהו במכת ברד כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך , שיכנס בלבו הפחד על המכה ששקולה נגד כולן, היינו מכת בכורות.
translation: In another way, we can interpret the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, according to the Gemara (Taanit 8b) which states that in the days of Rabbi Shimon ben Nanas there was famine and hunger, etc. Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said to him, "Let us pray for mercy for the hunger, for when the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives abundance to life, it is indeed given, as it is written, 'You open Your hand and satisfy the desire of every living thing.'" Thus, we can interpret the verse "And give seed and we shall live, and we shall not die," questioning the repetition. It may be understood that by stopping the famine, they would be saved from the punishment of death that is not caused by the famine, for when the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives abundance to life, it is indeed given. And behold, through the blessing of our forefather Jacob, the famine ceased for them. In the Targum Yonoson (Parshat Vayigash), it explains regarding the verse "And Jacob blessed Pharaoh," and said, "May it be Your will that the waters of the Nile be filled and that hunger be removed from the world in your days." And Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Parshat Shemot) regarding the verse "Behold, I am killing your son in the city," that it is the final blow, and with it, he was first warned because it is severe, etc. It is possible that fear did not enter his heart because he was confident in the blessing of our father Abraham that there would be no famine in his days, for when the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives abundance to life, it is indeed given. Therefore, even the plague of death would not rule over them. But now, with the warning of the hail that will destroy all their produce, he feared that the blessing would be removed from them and that famine would come upon them, and thus he was not certain about the salvation from death as well. Now fear entered his heart regarding the plague of the firstborn, and this is what is meant by "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," meaning that through the hail, fear will also enter your heart regarding the plague of the firstborn, which is equivalent to all My plagues. This is what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, teaches us here, that the plague of the firstborn is more severe than all of them. Therefore, he warned him with the plague of hail, for "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," so that fear will enter his heart regarding the plague that is equivalent to all of them, namely, the plague of the firstborn.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine mercy and sustenance, emphasizing that when God provides abundance, it is a sign of life and protection from death. It highlights the connection between the cessation of famine and the blessings bestowed by Jacob, suggesting that such blessings shield individuals from the punishment of death. The text also reflects on the fear of impending plagues, particularly the plague of the firstborn, indicating that the fear arises when the assurance of divine protection is perceived to be at risk due to other calamities. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that God's mercy is crucial for survival and the avoidance of divine retribution.
